DOC.HEAD: North Korea Will Hand Over Soldiers' Remains To Visiting Congressmen
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lede and 4th graf: ``Montgomery, chairman,'' to CORRECT that delegation going to Panmunjom, not North Korea
DOC.TEXT: A congressional delegation will travel to Korea later this month to accept the remains of five U.S. soldiers killed in the Korean War, the lawmakers said Monday. The action by the communist government will mark the first time North Korea has repatriated remains from the war since 1954. ``We hope this will be a breakthrough that we can work with the North Koreans to get other remains back from that country as we have done in Vietnam,'' Rep. G.V. ``Sonny'' Montgomery, D-Miss., told reporters. Montgomery, chairman of the House Veterans Affairs Committee, will lead the six-member delegation to Panmunjom, the village in the Demilitarized Zone between North and South Korea where the Military Armistice Commission meets.
DOC.HEAD: The Defense, 5th graf
Study Says Second Generation Teen Motherhood Not Highly Likely
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf, `Of the...,' to CORRECT name of journal.
DOC.TEXT: Only about a third of the daughters of poor teen-age mothers in a 20-year study became teen-age mothers themselves, indicating the cycle of teen childbearing is less prevalent than thought, researchers said Monday. However, the new generation of teen-ager mothers appeared more vulnerable to poverty than even their own young mothers were, meaning the problem remains a serious factor in urban poverty, the report said. ``There isn't a kind of inevitability of the cycle of poverty being repeated from generation to generation,'' said Frank Furstenberg Jr., a University of Pennsylvania sociologist. ``That's an important finding.'' But, he said in an interview, ``There are also some sobering results that indicate that the minority who do go on to follow in their mothers' footsteps could have less room for maneuvering their way out of poverty.'' The study consisted of interviews of 404 pregnant teen-agers in Baltimore from 1966-1968, then follow-up interviews with the mothers and their children one, three, five, 17 and 20 years later. Of the 118 female children who remained in the sample after 20 years, only 42 _ or 36 percent _ had become teen-age mothers themselves, said the study, led by Furstenberg and published in the journal ``Family Planning Perspectives.'' That finding ``challenges the popular belief that the offspring of teen-age mothers are themselves destined to become adolescent parents,'' the report said. It defined teen mothers as those under 19. The 404 original mothers, mostly poor urban blacks, were not selected randomly, meaning the results cannot be projected to a broader population. However, when the researchers examined data gathered from 1979-1986 in the ongoing National Longitudinal Survey of Youth, which is based on a random sample, they reached the same finding: Only about a third of the daughters of black teen-age mothers became teen-age mothers themselves. The study apparently marked the first time the national survey results were examined this way, Furstenberg said. He said his group checked for the confirmatory data because it was startled by its Baltimore finding. While the percentage of second-generation teen-age mothers was lower than expected, it was much higher than the teen pregnancy rate among daughters of adult mothers. Among urban blacks in that group, surveys indicate that only about a fifth become teen mothers, Furstenberg said. The current study did not focus on why the children of teen mothers are more likely to become teen mothers. He speculated that the rate is lower than expected because researchers have underestimated the strength of urban black teen-agers' feelings against having children. The most troubling finding, Furstenberg said, was that second-generation teen mothers in the Baltimore survey were more likely than their mothers to remain unmarried, collect welfare and fail a grade in school. ``This trend could portend the growth of an urban underclass, even though only a minority of the offspring of urban teen-age mothers go on to become adolescent parents,'' the report said. It addition to Furstenberg, it was written by research assistant Judith Levine of the University of Pennsylvania and senior research scientist Jeanne Brooks-Gunn of the Educational Testing Service in Princeton, N.J.

DOC.HEAD: Courthouse Latest Target in County's Tradition of Arson
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Dozens of folks from this mountain hamlet jammed into a tiny church last week to find out why the Grundy County Courthouse had burned down. When District Attorney General Bill Pope Jr. announced it was arson, the crowd of men in baseball caps and women carrying babies heaved a long, sad sigh. Their worst fears had been confirmed. The destruction of the 105-year-old courthouse added one more chapter to the county's embarrassing history of arson. ``It's just another happening that puts Grundy County in the news media, something bad happening,'' said Sheriff Aubrey Harper. A pair of brothers fresh from a brush with the law were charged in the May 3 courthouse blaze. The case seems part of a history of suspicious fires and explosions stretching nearly from the turn of the century in this old mining county on the Cumberland Plateau northwest of Chattanooga. An arson blaze on April 27, 1935, leveled 10 buildings in Tracy City, causing more than $100,000 in damage and nearly wiping out the business district. On Aug. 24, 1971, when the 100-year-old L&N Depot in Tracy City burned down, then-Sheriff Henry Morrison said it was the county's 22nd fire of the year. Most were blamed on arson. In May 1976, two men were charged with torching the town's James K. Shook School, a massive 86-year-old building that boasted a turret and a clock tower. Newspaper offices have been a favorite target. The Grundy County Times office was set afire in September 1915, and the Grundy County Herald was destroyed by arson in 1978, 11 years after an explosion damaged that paper's old office. Sometimes revenge seems to be the motive. Other times it's just plain vandalism. Law enforcement authorities hesitate to label Grundy County a hotbed of suspicious fires. ``I'm not going to say that Grundy County is any different than any other rural county,'' said Bill Thompson, special agent in charge of the Tennessee Bureau of Investigation's eastern district. ``There are a ton of good people there.'' Still, the rugged county of 14,500 people has a certain notoriety. Beyond arson, vandals seem especially fond of dynamite, probably because of the area's coalfield history. In 1965, '67 and '70, dynamite blasts destroyed or damaged water tanks in various parts of the county. Also in 1967, about 800 people lost water service after somebody blew up the Tracy City pumping station. A Tracy City lumber yard was dynamited in 1969, and the next year a similar blast leveled a doctor's clinic there. Fires and bombings were so common at abandoned county schools in the '70s that officials had a hard time getting insurance. Said then-Superintendent Glenn Bonner: ``Just as soon as a building becomes vacant _ boom!'' In recent years, the county has become notorious as a hub for chop shops, places where stolen cars are stripped for parts that are resold. Folks are still rankled by a 1988 newspaper story in which a Davidson County police officer said, ``If you don't cut wood or steal trucks in Grundy County, you're in bad shape.'' The chop shops sprang up in the 1960s after the coal mines closed, and they flourished despite major police raids in 1965, 1971 and 1979 that sent dozens of people to jail. Harper contends stepped-up enforcement has put the business in decline. In 1987, he said, deputies recovered about 400 stolen cars; last year, the number had shrunk to under 50. But Grundy County's rough-and-tumble image lingers. ``In many respects, I think it is unfair,'' said Harper. ``But at the same time, I know that many things have happened here over the years that are still in people's minds.'' The brothers charged in the courthouse fire, Brian Ellege, 23, and Steve Ellege, 21, had been released on bond on burglary charges the day before the fire. They were arrested May 8 and charged with arson and felony vandalism. The brothers deny setting the fire. Authorities allege the two burned the building either out of revenge or in an effort to destroy their criminal records. As much as anything, say some observers, that kind of attitude may explain why many buildings in Grundy County come to an incendiary end. ``Is there an attempt by wronged persons to administer justice more so in a rural county than in an urban county? Possibly, yes,'' said Thompson. Said Harper: ``I think (rural) people probably take matters into their own hands a little faster.''

DOC.HEAD: Unlocking Mysteries is Slow Going
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: A team of six people is toiling in a small suite of offices, unlocking the secrets of three decades of governmental paranoia. The quasi-librarians have begun what promises to be months of scrutinizing the disorganized files of the Detroit Police Department's Red Squad, a product of the McCarthy-era hunts for suspected Communist sympathizers. The files containing about 1.5 million names were released after the city and a group of plaintiffs settled a 16-year-old lawsuit. The plaintiffs argued that they were subject to illegal police surveillance between the mid-1940s and the mid-70s. The surveillance stopped in 1974, when Mayor Coleman A. Young first took office and ordered it halted. The Red Squad Notification and Distribution Compliance Program was set up as part of a settlement approved last week by Wayne County Circuit Judge Lucile A. Watts. Since then, the program has received 300 to 500 requests for applications to receive files contained in boxes and file cabinets in the offices, said its director, Dorian Paster. ``The requests are coming relatively thickly,'' he said Monday. ``We are in the (file) room and getting acquainted.'' The task may take months, Paster said. The files will not be available to the general public, but people who were spied on may receive copies of their dossiers. Before releasing any information, Paster said, names of police officers, informants and any unsubstantiated information from a third party will be deleted. The workers are plunging into a haphazard filing system of reports, newspaper stories, photographs and other information assembled by the Red Squad. The lack of organization of many of the files has raised Paster's eyebrows. ``It was a very thorough operation,'' he said of the early days of the squad. ``I have a suspicion that that broke down in later years. It seems that some material was moved.'' But Paster won't know if that's the case until the files are sorted. ``It is, at best, a difficult task,'' he added. Some of the people helping Paster sift through the files were themselves onetime targets of the squad. ``By having people like that involved, it would go toward assuaging some of the fears of the people who are applying,'' he said. ``The applications will not be seen by the police.'' The primary focus of the squad was to gather information about people suspected of having ties to the Communist Party. The number of names in the squad poses a considerable problem. ``It's amazing how many small people are the subject (of a file),'' he said. ``One of things I ran across in a couple of cases now is address books or other books that were either lost or stolen. They started a file on every name in that book.'' Also hampering his team's work is the nature of the program itself. ``Part of the problem is that I can't name any names or organizations and bring that information to the public,'' Paster said. ``Anybody who has the least suspicion that they may be covered by this should make an application.''

DOC.HEAD: Jury Declares Town Bell a Nuisance
DOC.TEXT: In a case of symbol vs. slumber, a jury agreed with a couple that the hourly ringing of an 1,800-pound town bell next to their house is a nuisance at night. A judge won't rule until Friday whether the bell should be silenced from 9 p.m. to 6 a.m., but Richard and Pamela Carnall, newcomers to the pretty New England town of Hatfield, said they were happy with Monday's verdict. ``We understood it was a tradition and we never tried to take it away from them,'' Carnall said. The jury found that the bell was a nuisance at night and caused Mrs. Carnall injury by depriving her of sleep. But the panel found no evidence her husband was harmed by the ringing, and it awarded no damages to the couple. After the verdict, the Carnalls asked Superior Court Judge John F. Murphy to order the bell silenced at night. Hatfield Selectmen Chairman George Zgrodnick Jr. said he was unsure what the town's next step would be. Town hall was ``not a happy place'' after the verdict, he said. ``Everybody seems kind of downhearted and disgusted.'' The bell, regarded by old-timers as a comforting fixture, has called the 320-year-old farming community to work and rest for generations. Ninety-one years ago, the town clock was installed and the bell began its hourly chiming. Zgrodnick and other long-time residents had testified to their fond memories of the bell. ``How did the people of Hatfield, how did their values get so twisted, so distorted that they can put this symbol, this empty symbol ahead of people's feelings,'' the Carnalls' attorney, W. Michael Ryan, said in closing arguments. ``This is a historic old New England village of which the clock and bell tower are a very significant part,'' said William O'Neil, Hatfield town counsel. The bell belongs to the town but is housed in the white-steepled First Congregational Church, which many years ago doubled as the town hall. In 1988, the Carnalls moved next door to the town clock, which was broken. Six months later, the clock was fixed and the Carnalls began to complain they were being awakened at all hours. The Carnalls had asked that the ringing be declared a nuisance and that a jury award damages. Jurors deliberated for about two hours. ``I am comfortable that having convinced a jury, we'll also convince the judge,'' Ryan said.

Controversy Continues as Park Celebrates Centennial
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: It wasn't long after the first tourists appeared in the valley carved amid granite peaks that conservationists mourned the impact of humans here. Frederick Law Olmsted, a member of the first Yosemite Commission, wrote in 1865 of ``picturesque rocks stenciled over with advertisements of patent medicines.'' Naturalist John Muir complained the ``valley looked like a frowsy, backwoods pasture'' after a visit in 1889, the year before Yosemite became a national park. Yosemite National Park turns 100 this year. So do its problems. In Muir's day, no more than a couple of thousand hardy folk each year trekked through the wilderness to refresh themselves in the mists of Yosemite Falls and marvel at the park's granite monolith, El Capitan. Last year, 3.4 million people came through the valley, bringing with them some of the very problems they were trying to escape in the city. Park officials are struggling with the best way to deal with the crowding, pollution, development and traffic that threaten its natural beauty and serenity. ``Yosemite, for a number of reasons, really just ranks very highly in people's level of care,'' said Allan Bedwell, National Park Service spokesman. ``It goes back to Yosemite playing a major role in this country as a symbol of wilderness or nature or primeval heritage. ``I think a lot of it has to do with the fact that it's accessible to people. Those cliffs, those waterfalls, represent wilderness _ even though you have to view that wilderness in a fairly urban setting.'' Visitors can order anything from pizza to prime rib in Yosemite's snack bars and restaurants, or buy T-shirts, tennis balls and mugs in park gift shops, then get extra cash from an automatic teller machine. A beauty shop and video rental cater to park service and concession employees who live in the valley. Law enforcement officers booked 500 people into the jail last year. It was anticipated a decade ago that Yosemite's 100th birthday on Oct. 1, 1990, also would be a celebration of the ambitious 1980 general management plan that promised to balance convenience with conservation. But 10 years proved too short a time to meet such grandiose goals as eliminating cars from the valley and removing nonessential businesses, offices and personnel to locations outside the park boundaries. The park service has acknowledged the failure to fully implement the plan and is cataloging nearly 4,500 letters of comment from park enthusiasts as it decides how to plan realistically for Yosemite's next 100 years. ``The plan was formulated at a time when there was a different administration and different political climate,'' Park Superintendent Michael Finley said. Its implementation was hindered, in part, by a lack of money and, in some instances, by proposals that proved unrealistic, Finley said. For example, a landscape architect has found there is not enough suitable land to expand employee housing in the community of El Portal outside the park, as the plan proposes, Finley said. The park service did succeed in eliminating 650 parking spaces as planned, but a parking garage that was supposed to replace some of the lost spaces never materialized. Pressure to remove facilities from the park has remained constant from environmentalists, who complain many of the services interfere with the mandate to preserve Yosemite. ``We want to make it accessible to people. But do you need to be able to buy mugs and T-shirts and a badminton racquet in order to enjoy Yosemite National Park?'' asked Patricia Schifferle, regional director of the Wilderness Society. Superintendent Finley argues that visitors who soothe their muscles in a swimming pool after hiking to the top of Yosemite Falls or spend a night in a $180 room at the Ahwahnee Hotel also gain an appreciation of the park. ``If you look at it one way, you could be shocked and say, `In John Muir's holy temple there are swimming pools,''' Finley said. ``But if John Muir could keep 200,000 people from churning up the Merced River, would he do it by putting in three swimming pools?'' At the heart of the controversy over what services are appropriate for a national park is the Yosemite Park and Curry Co., a subsidiary of MCA, which provides guest services in the park. Critics argue that Curry wields too much influence over the park. Schifferle cites Curry's proposal to remove some existing employee housing and replace it with dormitories near Yosemite Lodge. Schifferle says the plan is contrary to the goal of removing unnecessary employee housing from the valley. ``A lot of what's been said critical of the Curry Company is flat erroneous. They've said we want to build more facilities here. Not true,'' said Curry spokesman John Poimiroo. He defended the dormitory plan, saying it would decrease traffic between El Portal, where it was proposed employees would be moved, and the valley floor. Critics also say the company profits from a 30-year contract that requires it to pay the government only .75 percent of its annual sales while not contributing to the goals of the general management plan. The National Park Service revealed that in 1989 Curry paid $635,000 to provide, without competition, most guest services. Poimiroo admits the fee is low. He points out, however, that Curry's financial commitment to the park does not end with the concessions fee. Curry also has invested $100 million in the park since 1973, when MCA bought the concessionaire, in maintenance and capital improvements, which included $8 million to repair and restore the Ahwahnee Hotel, Poimiroo said. But claims that the money represents an investment in the park are met with skepticism by environmentalists, who say Curry ultimately makes money on that type of spending. ``Are they spending money on the park, or are they spending money to do business in the park?'' Schifferle said. ``That's why I find the $100 million is probably more PR hype than reality as far as actual benefit to the park. It's probably benefiting Curry Company enormously.'' Attempts to renegotiate the concessions fee before the contract expires in 1993 have failed, but many expect the new contract to include clauses requiring Curry to invest some profits in specific programs. Finley points out that even successfully raising the fee would not necessarily mean more money for Yosemite itself. The concessions fee is deposited in the U.S. Treasury where it is re-appropriated by Congress, leaving the park service to compete with other interests, Finley said. The lively debate on how to protect Yosemite's natural beauty inevitably leads to the park service's conflicting missions: preserving the park while making it accessible to the public. ``Yosemite always has been on the political hot seat because, probably more than any other park, it mirrors that tension every day of every year,'' said Jim Snyder, park historian. ``The issues have become national because they symbolize what could happen to the national parks.''

DOC.HEAD: Conservatives Aim New Criticism at Liberal Justice Marshall
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: EDITORS NOTE: The Supreme Court's nine members are among the most private of public officials. They wield enormous power, but rarely hold news conferences or give interviews. Recent polls indicate only one in three Americans can name any of the nine. This, the eighth in an occasional series, offers an up-to-date look at one member of the nation's highest court.
DOC.TEXT: Thurgood Marshall's place in history was assured before he became a member of the Supreme Court in 1967. Now his conservative critics, long distressed by Marshall's liberal record, say it's time for the first black justice to step aside for a more youthful, energetic successor. Marshall, a civil rights pioneer who as a lawyer helped changed the nation, will be 82 in July. He shrugs off questions about retirement with customary curmudgeonly humor. ``I have a lifetime appointment and I intend to serve it,'' he has said numerous times. He once told The Washington Post, ``I expect to die at 110, shot by a jealous husband.'' For decades before President Johnson named him to the high court, Marshall had traveled the nation as the recognized legal champion of the poor and the powerless. Some say he ranks with the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. as a leader in the battle for racial equality. Over 23 years as legal director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People and then as the federal government's solicitor general, Marshall argued 32 cases before the Supreme Court. He won 29. His biggest NAACP victory came in the 1954 ruling that declared racially segregated public schools unconstitutional. ``He changed America,'' said Erwin Griswold, the onetime Harvard University Law School dean and himself a former solicitor general. ``When I think of great American lawyers, I think of Thurgood Marshall, Abe Lincoln and Daniel Webster,'' said Georgetown University Law School Dean Thomas G. Krattenmaker. Experts agree Marshall's legal accomplishments before joining the high court far surpass those of any fellow justice. It is his stature as a justice that has been questioned of late by conservative critics. They say he is losing interest in much of the court's day-to-day work and delegates too much responsibility to his young law clerks. Former clerks deny it. Marshall declined to be interviewed for this article. One of the harshest attacks on Marshall was penned by Terry Eastland, onetime aide to former Attorney General Edwin K. Meese III. Eastland last year wrote in the conservative National Review, ``One joke has it that if Marshall retired, at least he wouldn't be paid for watching television.'' The reference apparently was prompted by earlier reports that Marshall is a fan of ``The People's Court'' and watches the TV show in his court office. The justice has denied the reports, saying, ``That's an awful program.'' Criticism of Marshall's supposed work habits are often accompanied by questions of his health. Standing 6 feet 2 and overweight, Marshall shuns exercise. He had a heart attack in 1976, has suffered from bouts of pneumonia and bronchitis. He was hospitalized in 1987 with a potentially dangerous blood clot in his right foot. Marshall walks slowly and with apparent difficulty. Family members reportedly convinced him a few years ago to stop driving; he now gets to work in a chauffeur-driven limousine. Former clerks, however, insist his health is not deteriorating. Georgetown law professor Mark Tushnet, a Marshall clerk in 1972, said, ``He did not look in good health then. He doesn't look any different now.'' Tushnet, who is writing a biography of Marshall, also dismissed the idea that the increasing dominance of the court's conservatives has soured Marshall. ``He seemed grumpy when I worked with him and he seems grumpy now,'' Tushnet said. Legal scholars say a succession of conservative court appointments has denied the old civil rights fighter the chance that was briefly his to shape the law. Within two years of Marshall's appointment to a predominantly liberal court, Chief Justice Warren Burger replaced Earl Warren and the court's evolution toward conservatism had begun. ``But Marshall has been very important in providing visions of where the law should go,'' said Krattenmaker. ``He has written several (dissenting) opinions that may prove to be persuasive.'' Marshall and Justice William J. Brennan are the court's most consistent liberals and most frequent dissenters. They stand alone in opposing capital punishment in all circumstances, press for broader protection for criminal defendants and lead the way in supporting affirmative action for minorities and women. Marshall's former law clerks call him the court's conscience and say his role is one of making sure the other justices realize their decisions are affecting real, flesh-and-blood people. Marshall suffers from glaucoma. At times, it seems he has trouble reading summaries of his opinions from the bench. At a celebration of his 80th birthday, he insisted that television camera lights be turned off because the glare bothered his eyes. Rumors of declining alertness were fed by an incident last fall during an oral argument session before the court. Marshall posed several questions to a lawyer he seemingly believed was representing the government when, in fact, the lawyer was representing the other side. ``If I appear confused, I am,'' Marshall said at one point. When another justice noted whom the lawyer represented, Marshall recovered by telling the lawyer, ``Well ... there is no bar to you giving me some help.'' Marshall's public appearances away from the bench are rare. But, when he does appear, he doesn't mince words. In televised interviews in 1987, he said President Reagan's civil rights record ``ranks at the bottom,'' and accused Meese's Justice Department of trying ``to undermine the Supreme Court itself.'' In a speech to a conference of lawyers and judges that year, he said he was not about to quit fighting right-wingers. ``Don't worry, I'm going to outlive those bastards,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: For Nation's Next Weather Radar, the Future Is Now
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: For more than a decade Doppler radar has been the weather technology of the future. At the National Weather Service the future, finally, is now. The first Next Generation Weather Radar _ NEXRAD _ is being installed in Oklahoma City. A second will go to Melbourne, Fla., in late summer and the third near Washington after the first of next year. NEXRAD will bring substantial improvement to the forecasting of severe storms and floods, predicted Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher. That already has begun, says National Weather Service Director Elbert W. Friday Jr. During a 5{-month test in Oklahoma, NEXRAD was used in preparing warnings for 450 severe weather events, Friday said. ``It was a beautiful season to test a system, but it was a terrible season for the residents of Oklahoma,'' he said in a recent interview. ``This was one of the most active seasons they had had in a long time.'' During that period, weather offices accurately warned of storms about 59 percent of the time. The NEXRAD results were 91 percent, Friday said. And the false alarm rate was cut from about 60 percent to 21 percent at the Doppler radar site. Friday, pointing to the hazy sky outside his 18th floor office in Silver Spring, Md., said current radars would see nothing there. But NEXRAD, he said, would see air movement in that sky, telling forecasters wind speed and direction to help make predictions. Radars send out a short radio pulse and listen for it to bounce back. The time it takes tells the distance from whatever the signal bounced off. The direction can be seen from where the radar faces. The current WSR-57 and WSR-74 radars, some 30 years old, can detect things like rain, airplanes and buildings. NEXRAD can also see the invisible moisture and dust in apparently clear air. And it can sense movement, telling which way the wind is blowing at different levels by measuring the change in frequency of the signal bouncing back. Just as an ambulance siren has a higher pitch coming toward you than one going away, radar waves change depending on the movement and speed of the object reflecting them back. Being able to see where the direction of the wind changes abruptly can help a forecaster determine where a storm is likely to develop and can tell a pilot where his plane may encounter dangerous turbulence. This allowed meteorologists to give an hour and a half warning of a tornado developing in the Denver area last year, Friday said. ``By seeing those fine-scale details in the atmosphere you can identify ... factors that will be triggering the development of the storm,'' instead of waiting to spot the twister, Friday explained. In combination with satellites and other new systems, NEXRAD ``is going to generate much more of a detailed look at the atmosphere than we've ever had before,'' he said. This should help meteorologists understand ``what drives all of the very small-scale features that really do cause most of the problems for ... the flash floods and the heavy snows and the tornadoes and the thunderstorms.'' The radars and associated computerized work stations are being built by the Unisys Corp. In addition to the National Weather Service, the price tag of more than $400 million for the 175 radars is being shared by the departments of Defense and Transportation. An Air Force test analysis of the NEXRAD found some serious shortcomings, Friday acknowledged. But that was the idea, he said. Maintenance problems, with the machinery not operating for long periods, were the biggest troubles, according to the Air Force. Some operators rated the radars not acceptable. Many involved construction problems, and those have been taken care of, Friday said. Another problem cited by the Air Force technicians was ``range folding,'' which also occurs with current radars. Sometimes the bounce-back signal received by a radar is not from the most recent pulse, but an earlier one coming back from a more distant object. The computer can't tell the difference, assuming all signals are from the most recent pulse. That results in a distant storm showing up on radar as nearby. Computers now have been programmed to show purple on the screen when two signals come back from the same spot, an indication to the meteorologist that range folding is occurring. The radar operator then can change the frequency of the signals to separate them on the screen. Installation of the new radars is part of an overall reorganization of the National Weather Service. The agency will go from about 300 weather offices to 115.

DOC.HEAD: Prolonged Drought Leaves S. California Firefighters Facing Potential Crisis
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: A four-year drought and a mysterious fungus are killing the chaparral, the dense brush that blankets the hills of southern California, leaving it tinder-dry with a potential for fires with ``the energy of Hiroshima.'' Officials fear this summer could be the worst wildfire season in decades. Fire season was declared weeks early in Santa Barbara and San Luis Obispo counties, and will be declared Monday for the rest of southern California, said Doug Allen of the California Department of Forestry. Rainfall in the region so far this year measures about 38 percent of normal, which is about 15.5 inches. ``It is as bad as I have seen in my 33 years in the fire service,'' said Los Angeles Deputy Fire Chief Donald F. Anthony. He has ordered firefighters to stockpile plastic pipe so they can pump water from home swimming pools. Especially alarming is a fungus that preys on drought-weakened brush, killing as much as 60 percent of it in parts of the suburban Santa Monica and San Gabriel Mountains, said Philip J. Riggan, a U.S. Forest Service scientist. Mountain lilac, manzanita, sumac, California holly and even oak trees all have been afflicted, leaving gray blotches of dead wood on mountains and canyons. A pound of chaparral has about the same energy as a cup of gasoline, said Los Angeles County Fire Capt. Scott Franklin. In areas of dense growth, fire officials estimate the chaparral at more than 60 tons per acre, he said. ``We're talking about the energy of Hiroshima,'' he added. The fungus, botryosphaeria ribis, appears to act like an opportunistic disease on already-stressed brush. At some elevations, the dead bushes look like ``a bathtub ring around the Los Angeles basin,'' suggesting a link to air pollution, which is held to certain altitudes by warm desert air over cooler marine air, Riggan said. ``If people saw this kind of mortality in forests, they'd be quite upset,'' Riggan added. ``The area is just ripe for a huge fire.'' But then, the forests are dying, too. Drought-stressed trees are plagued by bark beetles, with most of the pines dead in some stands, Riggan said. A worst-case scenario that Anthony and other fire officials often use is the 1961 Bel-Air wildfire, which destroyed 484 homes and injured 185 firefighters. Damage was estimated at $30 million, but Anthony noted: ``Most of those homes were valued between $35,000 and $70,000 at that time. I seriously doubt that there are many homes there now valued at less than $850,000. That same fire today could certainly run into the billions of dollars.'' Conditions this year are worse, fire officials said, and many residential developments in southern California have tempted fate by pushing deep into scenic canyons and brushy hills. Every spring, homeowners are ordered to clear the brush surrounding their home for at least 100 feet, but that won't help much in the face of a major fire, officials said. On a recent trip through the San Gabriel Mountains above La Canada Flintridge, Franklin looked down from a fire road to multimillion-dollar homes snuggled amid the dense foliage of Winery Canyon. ``That's the threat, right there,'' he said. ``We've got whole communities that are at risk. We've got to start educating people that we've got a serious problem.'' ``It's just something that people are not very interested in,'' said Joan Feehan, a La Canada Flintridge City Council member who has a $1.5 million mountain home nestled at the city's border with the Angeles National Forest. ``Of course, you're aware of it when you pay your fire insurance,'' Feehan said. The premium for her 5,000-square-foot home is $3,200 a year. Controlled burning of chaparral is the only solution, Riggan and Franklin said, but most prescribed burning programs have been curtailed by state and federal budget cuts. ``If we're ever going to slow down these major fires, we've got to go in and remove the fuel,'' Riggan said. ``If we don't do this (prescribed burning), it's going to be business as usual, with one catastrophic fire after another.''

DOC.HEAD: Call Out For U.S. Regulation of Its Burgeoning Antarctica Tour Industry
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: U.S. tour operators are planning to send a record 4,000 or more travelers to Antarctica, prompting calls for strict government regulation to protect penguins, other wildlife and the very fate of the frozen continent. ``The number of tourists visiting Antarctica has more than tripled in the past five years,'' said Bruce Manheim, a Washington activist of the Environmental Defense Fund who calls existing controls inadequate. Antarctica has become a ``hot'' travel destination for the 1990s, beckoning older Americans seeking more adventure than Europe and hoping to see a fragile frontierland visited by only a privileged few in their youth. They are fueling fresh growth in the adventure travel industry, an estimated $1.3 billion-a-year phenomenon. About 800 American tourists traveled to Antarctica in 1988, 3,000 in 1989, and tour operators expect at least 4,000 in the December-February summer season. Manheim says it could reach 5,000. ``There's clearly a trend toward these type of expeditionary visits to remote places in the world,'' said Manheim. He filed an appeal Tuesday with the government urging more regulation. ``We are not trying to prohibit tourists from going to Antarctica, we just think tourism is something that has to be regulated carefully,'' he said. Concern began mounting after the January 1989 grounding of the Argentine naval ship Bahia Paraiso in which an estimated 175,000 gallons leaked into marine habitats, killing seals, penguins and other marine life. The vessel remains at the site off Palmer Station with some oil in its tanks. Particularly worrisome to critics are the plans of Ocean Cruise Lines of Fort Lauderdale to send the largest cruise ship in years to Antarctica, the 460-passenger Ocean Princess. Rates begin at $3,895 per person for a double-occupancy cabin on its three wine-and-caviar cruises, which are selling briskly. The first round trip from Buenos Aires, Argentina, begins Dec. 22. Manheim's appeal is urging the government to place strict controls on helicopter flights near wildlife sites, guidelines on tourist observation of penguins and seals, and coordination of cruise ship visits to breeding grounds. He said ships had made repeated tourist visits to the same wildlife sites, disrupting the breeding of seals, penguins and other birds. ``A year after Antarctica's most significant environmental disaster, we still don't have regulations to prevent similar catastrophes,'' said Manheim. The U.S. government responds that effective regulations are already in place. ``We have tried, and we believed we have dealt succesfully with the explosion of Antarctica tourism,'' said Jack Talmadge of the National Science Foundation, which regulates U.S. activities in Antarctica. Talmadge said the NSF has issued tourist regulations, established a mechanism for assessing fines for violations and taken steps to limit visits to U.S. research stations. He said the tour operators are also cooperating with the NSF to minimize the impact of tourism, including giving advance notice of ship visits. Although 16 nations fly flags in Antactica and seven claim slices of it, no nation holds title to the continent, which is larger than the United States and Mexico combined. Military flights and small ships carrying about 100 tourists have been frequent modes of travel to Antarctica since the first tourists visited in 1958. Now, the Chilean government has opened a spartan hotel at its Teniente Marsh Station on King George island, and LanChile airlines began commercial flights to that Antarctic stop last year. Australian entrepreneurs have proposed a five-story hotel, airstrip and hovercraft dock. The Canada-based Adventure Network currently flies tourists to one South Pole station. But the bulk of the tourists are Americans brought in by U.S.-based operators. Conservationists say the United States should therefore take the lead in adopting a model regulatory policy. ``Antarctica tourism originates almost exclusively in the United States, and therefore we have the responsibility to regulate our tourism if we are to push for regulation at an international level,'' said Manheim. Operators of the Ocean Cruise Lines said there is no cause for alarm. ``The tourist visiting Antarctica is a determined environmentalist, an avid lover of wildlife, and I can assure you that no tourist _ not one _ has hurt or killed a bird or animal,'' said Lars Eric Lindblad, an Antarctic travel pioneer who will lecture aboard the Ocean Princess. James Barnes, with Friends of the Earth in Washington, concludes that the travelers may leave their footprints, but they often return home more committed environmentalists _ ``Ambassadors of Antarctica.'' Nonetheless, he said, ``The scale of these activities is growing at such a pace that it does provide cause for concern.''

DOC.HEAD: Government's Economic Plan Shows Signs of Trouble
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Signs of renewed inflation and financial speculation have created fears in Brazil that a drastic economic austerity plan launched in mid-March is running into trouble. ``The full economic picture is not clear but one thing is: Things are getting worse,'' said Alexandre Barros, a political consultant. Economy Minister Zelia Cardoso de Mello met all weekend with key advisers, and rumors abounded that new austerity measures would soon be announced, including tightening credit and increasing interest rates to hold down the money supply. ``The government will have to take immediate action now, or the situation could spin out of control,'' said economist Jose Marcio Camargo of Rio's Pontifical Catholic University. ``We may soon be facing a recession with inflation _ the worst of both worlds.'' The main concern is inflation, which seemed under control after President Fernando Collor de Mello imposed his austerity plan on March 16, a day after he took office. The measures, which included an 18-month freeze on $115 billion in savings accounts and money market deposits, drastically reduced record annual inflation of almost 5,000 percent. The plan also led to a dramatic economic downturn, with unions estimating 300,000 people fired and businesses reporting drastically reduced sales. The government has said the slowdown is needed to put the economy in order. But after predicting just 10 days ago that inflation was ``dead and beaten,'' Cardoso de Mello said on Friday the cost of living rose more than 3 percent in April. Several private institutions say the government is seriously underestimating inflation, and that the real rate for April was between 10 percent and 20 percent. ``Whatever the true figure, the cost of living is creeping back up again,'' said Camargo. Also troubling observers was the return of financial speculation, which forced the government to sell gold last week to keep down the price of the metal. And the dollar has already recovered its early March value of 80 cruzeiros. The currency on the illegal but widely tolerated black market had fallen by more than 50 percent after Collor announced the austerity plan. Last week, federal police raided the offices of black market operators in Sao Paulo to try to slow the dollar's rise. ``Those sorts of actions are effective for only a few days. The government will have to find better ways to end speculation,'' said David Fleischer, a political science professor at the University of Brasilia. The new round of speculation seemed tied in part to the public's diminished faith in the economic program. A survey released last week by the Brazilian Association of Credit and Savings Companies said $4 million has been pulled from savings deposits. That would represent 36 percent of all money in accounts not blocked by the freeze. Another sign of the public's lack of confidence is a recent boom in sales of residential safes. Brazil's biggest safe manufacturer, the Bernardini company, said home safe sales were almost double levels prior to March. ``We've always had a credible financial sector. But people are skeptical now and would rather spend or buy dollars,'' Camargo said. A final problem is that many companies skirted the bank freeze. The prominent Rio daily O Globo reported last week that firms had managed to ``unfreeze'' almost $50 billion, mostly by paying off debts and taxes as rules allowed. Jean Daniel Peter, the president of the Brazilian subsidiary of Union Carbide, told the paper the company used all of its $18 million caught in the bank freeze. Others resorted to illegal methods. Blocked funds could be donated to charities, and some companies made deals whereby they made large contributions but received part of the money back. The money injected into the economy by such methods is believed in part responsible for the rise in inflation.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev's Sanctions on Lithuania Not Stopping Others
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: An AP Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev imposed tough sanctions on Lithuania in hopes of frightening other republics away from pressing for independence, but merely made them more cautious. An embargo on shipments of fuel, manufactured goods and raw materials to Lithuania prompted the other two Baltic states, Latvia and Estonia, to rephrase their demands for independence. They declared their firm intention to leave the Soviet Union, but provided for transition periods of unspecified length. On Saturday, the three republics announced they had forged a united front to negotiate with the Kremlin. In other republics, activists are following in the early steps of the Baltic republics on many issues, from opposing the military draft to rejecting the orders of Moscow ministries on the economy. ``I think in half a year we'll see that, not only the Baltic republics but some other republics _ first of all the Caucasus republics _ will say they want real independence,'' said sociologist Peteris Lakis, a leader of the Latvian People's Front political movement. On May 6, representatives of people's fronts from eight republics and several reform movements from Russia met in Kiev to organize a Union of Democratic Forces ``to help republics quit the U.S.S.R. ... and to ensure the empire disbands peacefully,'' said a statement from the Ukrainian people's front, called Rukh. Gorbachev has said he believes splitting up the Soviet Union would bring more violence than China's Cultural Revolution of 1966-76. He has pledged to prevent that, but indicated he wants to avoid using force. In Sverdlovsk two weeks ago, he told citizens: ``Some say, let this `empire' fall apart, while others say ... we need to restore order with an iron fist. Neither has any connection to serious policy.'' Regions across the less-than-unified Soviet Union are rejecting Kremlin authority. _Georgia's Parliament has demanded negotiations on independence. Pro-independence parties are campaigning for seats in the republic's Parliament in hopes of duplicating the Baltic activists' two-thirds majorities. _Neighboring Azerbaijan exploded into virtual armed revolt in January and remains under military control. _The Armenian Parliament has defied the Kremlin and ordered local draftees to remain in Armenia to work on rebuilding areas wrecked by the 1988 earthquake. _A pro-independence political party has formed in the Ukrainian agricultural and industrial heartland, where nationalism is most feared by Moscow. Activists in Lvov won control of the city council in a recent election and raised the yellow and sky-blue Ukrainian national flag over city hall. _In Moldavia, Mircha Snegur won the presidency from Communist Party chief Pyotr Luchinsky with the backing of those who favor greater autonomy or independence. He opposes Gorbachev's blockade of Lithuania. _On the opposite end of the country, Sakhalin Island is planning economic reforms, including selling land to farmers, according to Moscow News. _Even the Russian republic's legislature will consider a sovereignty resolution at the session beginning May 16. The extent of support for it is not clear, but the Baltic republics started their moves toward independence with constitutional amendments claiming sovereignty and the right to reject national laws in their territory. Gorbachev has not indicated willingness to abandon his demand that Lithuania withdraw its March 11 declaration of independence before any negotiations begin. He is calling for a new Soviet federation in which all republics would have greater autonomy. New legislation provides a mechanism for republics to secede, but only after a long waiting period. In several difficult periods of his five years in power, Gorbachev has taken unexpected steps that not only solved the immediate problem but carried him well beyond it. Until December, he rejected the idea of multiparty politics. He suddenly threw his support behind the idea in January and by mid-February had pushed the reform through. Baltic leaders and Western experts on Soviet nationalities say a new leap by Gorbachev could ease the mounting pressure on Moscow from the republics. Last month, he was said to have offered Estonia and Latvia ``special status'' in a ``confederative'' Soviet Union if they would drop their demands for independence. Exactly what he meant is not clear. Lakis, the Latvian activist, predicted Gorbachev would be forced to negotiate and accept transformation of the country into a confederation of independent nations. Asked whether that meant the end of the Soviet Union, he replied: ``I think that's a necessity of history.''
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Ann Imse has reported from the Soviet Union since September 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Young Men Talk of Holy War for Kashmir
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Snowy peaks of the Pir Panjal look down on dusty bazaars and winding alleys where young Moslems speak of a holy war for Kashmir. Voices muffled by brightly colored bandannas that cover their faces, they pledge themselves to a freedom-or-death struggle against a mighty Indian army in what they call their homeland. Their goal is independence for Jammu-Kashmir, the only predominantly Moslem state in the overwhelmingly Hindu nation of India. Leaders of the movement plan a government-in-exile as refugees fleeing across the mountains pitch tents on the Pakistan side of the border, the focus of periodic skirmishes and two wars. The plotters of Kashmir's jihad, or holy war, are short on weapons, money and guerrilla training, so they turn for help to their Moslem brethren on another battlefield, Afghanistan. ``There is no difference between the Afghan jihad and the Kashmir jihad,'' said Sheik Rashid, a right-wing opposition leader who has asked religious leaders in Islam's holiest cities to declare jihad in Kashmir. Such a declaration would oblige all Moslems to support a holy war. Both India and Pakistan have claimed the former princely state of Kashmir since independence from Britain in 1947. They fought wars over the region in 1948 and 1965, and fears of another have arisen. India accuses Pakistan of arming, training and harboring separatists in dozens of guerrilla camps along the border. Pakistan denies it and accuses India of using violent tactics against self-determination. Pakistani officials and militant leaders estimate up to 8,000 people have slipped across the border to what Pakistan calls Azad (Free) Kashmir since India cracked down on the Jammu-Kashmir separatist movement in January. The militants said they were inspired by Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto's emotional pledge, ``Your blood is our blood,'' and had expected to receive weapons, money and training in guerrilla warfare in Pakistan. All they got, the men said, was food, shelter and the right to speak their minds. ``The cause we are fighting for is self-determination,'' said Ghulam Mohammad Safi. ``Our cause is a just cause, a holy war, but Pakistan is doing nothing.'' Safi leads Hezb-ul-Mujahedeen, or Party of Islamic Holy Warriors, the most militarily organized of six Kashmiri groups based in Muzaffarabad, capital of Azad Kashmir. ``Pakistan supported the Afghan resistance; we expect something more,'' said Safi, a 40-year-old former schoolteacher who left Jammu-Kashmir in March. ``The Pakistan army didn't intervene in Afghanistan. We expect Pakistan to wage war against India.'' Ms. Bhutto's government says it does not want another war with India and has called for negotiations. The leader of the Jammu-Kashmir Liberation Front, leader of the independence movement, said any agreement reached without the consent of the Kashmiris would be doomed. ``We have our own agenda,'' said Raja Muzaffar Khan. ``We are determined to win our freedom any way possible, by any means possible.'' He showed invoices for the purchase of $70,000 worth of weapons and ammunition from tribal areas on the Pakistan-Afghanistan border. Included was $1,675 paid a smuggler to carry eight French-made machine guns to Srinagar, the Jammu-Kashmir summer capital and center of the separatist movement. Muzaffar Khan said the weapons were bought with money from Kashmiris living in the United States and Europe, and from Arab countries. ``We'll buy more as the need arises,'' he said. The militants have not been able to establish training camps, but Muzaffar Khan said men were being taken into the dense mountain forests for instruction in small arms. ``There are a lot of places where we can operate without the knowledge of either government,'' he said. Muzaffar Khan said his group was distributing instruction pamphlets on how to fire weapons and had made a demonstration videotape. Nearly 1,500 men have gone to Afghanistan for combat training with guerrillas who have spent 12 years trying to overthrow the Soviet-backed government in Kabul, militant leaders said. Abdul Qayyum, president of Azad Kashmir, said the leaders of Afghan guerrilla groups had offered help but the offers were declined. Young men who wait in makeshift camps, however, are looking for support from Gulbuddin Hekmatyar, the fundamentalist Afghan guerrilla leader. Despite his fervent anti-West rhetoric, Hekmatyar has received most of the U.S. and Saudi weapons channeled to the guerrillas. He said he had been in contact with all Kashmiri groups, but would not be specific. Many Pakistanis fear Muzaffarabad will become like Peshawar, the wild frontier town that serves as the staging area for Afghan guerrillas. Slogans demanding ``Give us freedom or we will take it'' are painted on nearly every wall, and posters of slain militant leaders are plastered on buildings throughout the provincial capital. Qayyum said his government planned to shut down the Jammu-Kashmir Liberation Front, which he called a ``nuisance'' engaged in terrorist acts, but said that would be difficult because the government had only half the security forces it needed. Leaders of the militants are trying to draft a constitution, form a common strategy and set up military, planning and recruiting committees, but appear as divided as the Afgha resistance. ``It's one thing to sit in air conditioned offices and make lofty plans,'' Qayyum said. ``They have no responsibility, no code for the lives of other people.'' ``You can teach an Afghan how to handle a gun in an hour,'' he said. ``Afghans are born militants. It's their nature, it's in their blood. Kashmiris have been pacificists over the centuries. We don't know how to fight.''

DOC.HEAD: Knights of Columbus to Give Bishops $3 Million to Oppose Abortion
DOC.TEXT: The Knights of Columbus has pledged $3 million to help underwrite an anti-abortion campaign by the nation's Roman Catholic bishops. The 1.5 million-member Roman Catholic fraternal group announced its backing of the public relations campaign on Sunday. ``This effort is needed to set out the facts about abortion as a violation of human rights and counter the barrage of `pro-choice' propaganda being generated by supporters of legalized abortion,'' said Supreme Knight Virgil C. Dechant. The bishops decided months ago to hire the public relations firm Hill & Knowlton and the Wirthlin Group, a polling concern, for help in presenting their stand against abortion. The program is estimated to cost $5 million. The bishops had said the program would be funded by outside sources. The Knights were the first group to announce they would cover part of the cost. The gift will allow the program to ``begin in earnest,'' said Archbishop Daniel C. Pilarczyk of Cincinnati, president of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops. The campaign will start with a public opinion poll, then proceed with a public information effort, said John Berard, a Hill & Knowlton spokesman. At their annual meeting in November, the first since a Supreme Court ruling in a Missouri case gave states greater leeway to restrict abortion, the bishops declared abortion was ``the fundamental human rights issue'' of the day. The public relations program was unanimously approved in March by the 50-member Administrative Committee of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops.

DOC.HEAD: Summary of Americans Killed During Communist Insurgency
With PM-Philippines, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a summary of attacks on Americans during a 21-year-old Marxist insurgency: April 13, 1974: Three Navy officers from a construction regiment were ambushed and killed by Communist guerrillas near the Subic Bay naval base, 50 miles west of Manila. The victims were inspecting a new highway project when ambushed by about 16 New People's Army rebels. Oct. 28, 1987: Two airmen, one retired Air Force sergeant and a Filipino civilian of U.S. descent were slain in a series of near simultaneous attacks near Clark Air Base. U.S. officials believe they were killed in reprisal for American military ambulances having evacuated Filipino troops wounded in a clash with the rebels near Clark. The rebels claimed responsibility. April 21, 1989: Army Col. James ``Nick'' Rowe was ambushed and killed as he rode to work at the Joint U.S. Military Assistance Group in suburban Quezon City. The following day, the commander of the New People's Army, Romulo Kintanar, claimed responsibility in retaliation for U.S. ``arrogant trampling'' upon Philippine independence. Sept. 26, 1989: Two American civilians employed by the Air Force at Camp O'Donnell, 10 miles north of Clark, were ambushed on the day Vice President Dan Quayle arrived in Manila for an official visit. Rebels fired M-16 rifles from a commandeered dump truck and a jeep. Although there was never a claim of responsibility, U.S. officials believe the rebels were responsible. Feb. 21, 1990: American civilian geologist John Robert Mitchell, 42, of Fairbanks, Alaska, was ambushed and slain along with his Filipino wife and father-in-law on Bohol island. Rebels later said they were trying to kill the father-in-law because he refused to pay ``revolutionary taxes'' and that Mitchell was caught in the cross-fire. March 6, 1990: Stewart Frank Raab, 76, a longtime Philippine resident, was killed by rebels on Masbate island after he refused to pay ``revolutionary taxes.'' Police identified two longtime rebel commanders as his killers, but no arrests have been made. May 4, 1990: Marine Gunnery Sgt. John Fredette, 34, was slain by several assailants near Subic. No claim of responsibility was made, but U.S. officials believe rebels were responsible. Two Filipino drug addicts were arrested for the killing, but U.S. officials doubt they were the killers. Civilian prosecutors have refused to prosecute the two unless police gather more evidence. May 13, 1990: Airman John H. Raven and Airman James C. Green were shot and killed by suspected Communist rebels near Clark. There was no immediate claim of responsibility.

DOC.HEAD: Colleges Help Seniors Learn Their Way Around `The Real World'
LaserPhoto BX3
DOC.TEXT: To paraphrase those harried parents in the 1960 musical ``Bye Bye Birdie'': What's the matter with college kids today? How about fear of fatal sex, soaring inflation, debt, anxiety and vague notions of the real world? And that's just the start, say college administrators who are trying to help by offering courses that ease graduating seniors into adulthood. One such program, ``The Last Six Weeks,'' is offered at Assumption College, a Catholic school of 2,000 students set amid rolling lawns and quiet woods. Until he signed on, senior Paul Irish stared into the abyss of life-after-graduation and worried. ``Money was a big thing _ how you make ends meet, getting a car, getting an apartment,'' said the 22-year-old from Auburn. He knew he wanted to be a history teacher. But he was sketchy on the details of adult survival. ``I thought willpower was everything,'' he said. Now he knows better. ``The Last Six Weeks'' is an optional, non-credit course of structured late-night chat and pizza that gets into the nitty-gritty of the necessities like shelter and transportation, such as how much they cost and how to avoid scams. Students learn about picking a career and shopping the job market, from writing a resume to dealing with sexual harassment and learning about corporate culture. The last class is about getting the most out of saying goodbye to college friends. Why college students these days need such help isn't clear. Members of the ``me generation'' may have become so self-absorbed they forgot to look around, suggested Brian McCoy, assistant director of residential life at Assumption. He helped design the program. ``Students don't explore as much as they used to,'' McCoy said. Schools also feel pressure to do better, said John N. Gardner, a vice chancellor at the University of South Carolina in Columbia. ``A number of corporate leaders are very unhappy about what we're producing,'' he said. ``This year we're spending $110 billion on higher education for 13.2 million people. That's about one-third of what we spend on national defense. ``There is a tremendous increased public pressure for accountability in colleges and universities.'' One result is that Gardner has focused his attention on the transitions into and out of college. In March, he organized a national conference in Atlanta called the ``Senior Year Experience'' to look at what schools are doing about it. Regis College in Weston offers a course in leadership for students planning management careers. Carroll College in Waukesha, Wis., sends its seniors to work as consultants to businesses to get them past ``job shock.'' Seniors at the University of Hartford can take a course called ``Pluralism Revisited'' to expose them to the diverse world they are about to enter. Unlike college kids in the days of ``Bye Bye Birdie,'' graduates these days have a harder world to take on, Gardner said. ``Sex can kill,'' he said. ``It costs more money to buy a home. There are far fewer barriers for women and minorities, but on the other hand there are more personal threats to your health and more violence. ``Students are graduating with staggering debt. You add that all up and college graduates are a lot more anxious and they count on a lot fewer certainties than their parents.'' Marianne Tavares works in human resources at Waters Chromatography in nearby of Milford and encounters naive college grads all the time. The ones who make her chuckle say they intend to be managers making $40,000 in 18 months. More troubling are those who, when asked how they would solve a conflict with a co-worker, say they would take it to the boss. ``That's where we see the negative side,'' Tavares said. They mistakenly believe ``the company is going to take care of them, you're going to be their parent.''

DOC.HEAD: Booming Orlando Feels the Pinch of Rapid Growth
DOC.TEXT: The booming metropolitan area is getting tired of late-night carousers, drunken boaters and people who stand in traffic, collecting donations for what they say is charity. Mayor Bill Frederick and the City Council have scheduled public hearings in the next two weeks to deal with some of the residents' gripes. City officials are particularly concerned about the growing number of people approaching drivers for money. Complaints have come from motorists, shopkeepers, police and homeowners. Some officials want to ban the practice, contending it is dangerous and looks bad to visitors to this tourist area where Disney World is situated. ``We've got no clue as to what some of these charities are,'' the mayor said at a council meeting last week. ``We don't know where the money goes.'' Some of the solicitors are hired out of unemployment lines. Others answer classified ads and make $4 to $6 an hour. Still others are volunteers. In nearby Apopka, Police Chief Tom Collins said he thinks some of the T-shirted solicitors are merely panhandling. ``They're standing in the middle of the road,'' he said. ``I think it's too dangerous. What would be the liability if one of these people got hit?'' Orlando and other communities in Orange, Seminole and Osceola counties issue hundreds of permits to nonprofit groups and charities, but only to a few that collect at intersections. In most of central Florida, police can stop collecting only if it poses a danger or impedes traffic. Some officials and collectors for charitable groups such as Easter Seals and drug-education foundations say a large portion of their money comes from such activities. Margaret Fowler, director of the Lighthouse Mission, a shelter for homeless men, said she opposes a ban. Also high on Orlando's list of gripes are people carousing downtown after 2 a.m. and those driving boats too fast on lakes. Frederick and several commissioners said they have heard complaints about reckless and drunken boating. The City Council wants to ban drinking on board boats and bar boaters from going faster than 35 mph during the day and 20 mph at night. Some lakes in Orlando have speed limits, but there is no citywide limit. Some patrons of downtown bars repeatedly break the law, especially early in the morning, police said. ``They come out and they drink. They buy dope. They urinate on cars. There is a massive problem,'' said City Attorney Bob Hamilton. A proposed ordinance would force bars to close down at 2 a.m., when they stop serving liquor, instead of one or two hours later. Police Chief Danny Wilson said the carousers do not ``project the kind of image we want to have for downtown.'' The Orlando metropolitan area, largely undeveloped a few decades ago, tripled in population from 1960 to nearly 1 million in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: A Look at U.S. Bases in the Philippines
With PM-Philippines, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are brief descriptions of the six U.S. military installations in the Philippines:

CLARK AIR BASE _ It is 50 miles north of Manila and has been used by American forces since 1901, originally as a cavalry post. Clark is headquarters for the 13th U.S. Air Force, tactical arm of the Air Force in the western Pacific and Indian Ocean. Pilots from the United States and allied nations train there, and the base is a major transit point for the U.S. military's transport command.

SUBIC BAY NAVAL STATION _ It is 50 miles west of Manila and the Navy's main supply and repair center in the western Pacific. Marines train in jungle tactics in Subic's forested hills, and surveillance planes from its Cubi Point naval air station monitor sea lanes.
WALLACE AIR STATION _ It is on the western coast of Luzon, about 150 miles north of Manila. Wallace provides air defense and radar monitoring for the Philippines.
SAN MIGUEL NAVAL COMMUNICATIONS STATION _ About 60 miles northwest of Manila, San Miguel is a major relay station for the U.S. Navy's Pacific communications system.

CAMP O'DONNELL _ About 10 miles north of Clark, the camp serves as an Air Force communications and electronic warfare station. In 1942, the Japanese used it to hold survivors of the Bataan Death March.
CAMP JOHN HAY _ It is in Baguio, a mountain resort 130 miles north of Manila, and serves as a rest and recreation center for U.S. forces in the Philippines.

DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court Hears Arguments on Flag Burning Law
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Arguments scheduled 10 a.m. EDT; pre-noon lead expected
DOC.TEXT: The politically charged issue of flag burning is again before the Supreme Court as the justices hold an extraordinary session to study a federal law intended to protect Old Glory's ``physical integrity.'' Today's oral arguments on the constitutionality of the Flag Protection Act of 1989 marked the first time in nine years the justices held such a session after April. They are reviewing rulings by federal judges in Washington and Seattle who said the law violates the freedom of expression protection granted by the First Amendment. The law was challenged by demonstrators who burned American flags in the two cities. The political stakes are high. The court is expected to rule before the end of its current term, probably in late June or early July. If the law is struck down, a proposed constitutional amendment to protect the flag almost certainly would become a leading issue in congressional and state legislative races this fall. While the Bush administration is defending the law, President Bush and Republican leaders have said they would prefer a constitutional amendment to ban flag burning, which would be unnecessary if the justices uphold the law. The Justice Department, in a written brief to the court, said, ``It is the physical assault and accompanying violation of the flag's physical integrity _ not robust and uninhibited debate _ that occasion the injury that our society should not be called upon to bear.'' Department lawyers said the court owes Congress special deference in this case because an equal branch of government has determined that flag burning can be outlawed without violating freedom of speech. Lawyers for the demonstrators challenging the law said their clients ``consider flag burning an essential element of their political expression because, for them, the flag represents not glory but oppression.'' They also said flag desecration is an American tradition. ``The United States flag was born of a desecration,'' the lawyers said. ``George Washington ... in 1776 ... defaced a British flag by ordering sewn upon it 13 red and white stripes.'' And, the attorneys added, the United States should make it clear the world's leading democracy stands with those who want more freedom. Last year when the people of Eastern Europe rose up to protest oppressive communist regimes, they carried national flags ``desecrated by excised centers,'' the lawyers said. Democratic congressional leaders, hoping to head off a battle over amending the Constitution, were the prime sponsors of the Flag Protection Act. The law was passed after the Supreme Court touched off a political firestorm in June 1989 by striking down a Texas statute that banned flag desecration. The 5-4 ruling said burning the flag as a form of political protest is protected by the Constitution's free speech guarantees. Supporters of the federal law say it differs from the Texas law because the federal act does not single out flag burning as a means of expression. The federal law forbids defiling or destruction of the flag for any purpose, except to destroy a soiled or tattered flag. The Texas law specifically banned flag burning that seriously offends others.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecution Must Prove the Victims were Indeed Victims
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors consider Dorothea Montalvo Puente a rare breed, a female serial killer, but they'll first have to show that the nine boarders the landlady allegedly poisoned were victims of foul play. A judge is deciding whether there is sufficient evidence to hold the 61-year-old woman for trial on charges of murdering seven tenants found buried in her boardinghouse yard and two others whose bodies turned up elsewhere. The preliminary hearing began in Municipal Court on April 27, a year and a half after her arrest. In eight of the cases, a cause of death was never determined. Whether the nine people were even homicides has not been established; the boarders, dead for weeks to years, were too decomposed for autopsies to tell what killed them. Assistant District Attorney George Williamson is trying to show that Puente, who has a record of administering stupefying drugs to people she intended to rob, poisoned the nine people over a six-year period for their Social Security and other benefit checks. She could face the death penalty if convicted. But her lawyers contend the tenants, ranging in age from 52 to 80 and most poor and alcoholic, could have died from a variety of medical problems. Among their ailments were a brain tumor, lung disease, heart disease and diabetes. ``Those people all died a natural death,'' defense attorney Peter Vlautin said recently. More than 100 witnesses are expected to testify by the time the hearing ends in three to four weeks. ``I have not killed anyone. The checks I cashed, yes,'' Puente said in a TV interview after her arrest. On Thursday, a jailhouse informant testified that Puente admitted she poisoned her tenants because she had gotten ``a little greedy.'' Michelle Crowl, whose cell was two doors from Puente's, said the landlady told her in late 1988 or early 1989 that she killed her tenants by giving them an overdose of prescription drugs mixed with alcohol. Defense attorneys accused Crowl of lying to buy her freedom. In exchange for her testimony, prosecutors agreed to release her from jail on probation and not seek a prison term for a parole violation on a drug conviction. Other testimony by an ex-convict and a doctor portrays Puente as a woman who had extensive knowledge about medications and used deception to obtain them. Former tenants described Puente alternately as a devoted, motherly caretaker and a hot-tempered woman who had a penchant for swearing and sought control of some boarders' money. In only one death was a cause ever listed. The 1982 death of a 61-year-old man from an apparent codeine overdose was considered accidental until investigators began digging up seven bodies from Puente's yard. A prescription tranquilizer flurazepam, sold under the trade name Dalmane, was detected in all seven bodies. Doctors have testified that it can be toxic if taken in large enough doses in combination with other drugs or alcohol. A total of nine other drugs were found in the boardinghouse bodies. Their doctors and fellow boarders have testified most of them were heavy drinkers and many took prescription drugs. One tenant, according to her doctor, was a prescription drug abuser who preferred Valium.

DOC.HEAD: Presidential Commission to Call for FAA Changes, Won't Lay Blame
DOC.TEXT: A presidential commission on terrorism is expected to call for changes in federal aviation security operations without laying blame for the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103. The seven-member commission headed by former Labor Secretary Ann McLaughlin is giving its report to President Bush on Tuesday, followed by a briefing at the White House for relatives of some of the 270 people killed in the Dec. 21, 1988, bombing over Lockerbie, Scotland. Bush appointed the panel after family members demanded a congressional investigation into government actions before and after the attack. The relatives withdrew the demand pending outcome of the nine-month presidential inquiry. Investigators in Britain say the Boeing 747 was downed by a plastic explosive concealed in a radio cassette player by still unidentified terrorists. The terrorism commission, which includes four members of Congress and three former government figures, steered away from criminal investigation of the Lockerbie bombing. It has tried to determine whether errors by any federal agency, the airline, or others might have allowed it to occur. Federal Aviation Administration officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said they expect the report to be critical of the agency which has worldwide responsibility for the security of U.S. airlines. Aides to the commission have said investigators found ``no smoking gun'' that would allow the report to lay blame for the bombing. But during hearings, commission members strongly criticized the FAA and Pan Am for security flaws and the State Department for poor handling of victims' relatives after the incident. Ms. McLaughlin met with Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner last week to brief him on the report, but a department spokesman said there was no in-depth discussion and that Skinner did not get a copy of the report. A congressional source said the panel recommends a revamp of the FAA's security office to give it higher visibility. ``It's pretty hard on the FAA and calls for some changes in FAA operations,'' said the source, who characterized the report in advance only on condition of anonymity. The FAA said Thursday it had removed Raymond Salazar as civil aviation security chief, putting the office under his superior, Monte Belger, associate administrator for aviation standards. Salazar, who will take over an FAA management training facility in Florida, was criticized by commission members for lapses in security before and after the Pan Am bombing. Victims' relatives, who had called for his resignation, applauded his removal, but FAA Administrator James Busey said Salazar's departure was not connected with the imminent release of the report. Commission members have raised concerns about the government's policy of not informing passengers of most terrorist threats. Victims' relatives claim government employees avoided the flight because of warnings posted at the U.S. Embassy in Moscow. But commission investigators said last month they found no evidence of cancellations by such passengers. Some family members have braced themselves for disappointment, based on early indications of the report's contents. One family member said there were rumors that the report would call for a halt to installation of sophisticated Thermal Neutron Analysis (TNA) bomb detection devices ordered by the Federal Aviation Administration. ``Halting the installation of TNA bomb-detection units in airports would send the right signal to terrorists and the wrong signal to the traveling public,'' said Ted Reina, whose daughter Jocelyn was a flight attendant on Flight 103. Chairwoman McLaughlin, at the commission's last hearing in April, criticized the FAA for ordering carriers to buy the $1 million machines which airlines say have not been sufficiently tested. But commission member Rep. James Oberstar, D-Minn., has welcomed installation of the detectors, although he says the government should pay for them. The panel held five public hearings in Washington and traveled to Europe for interviews with aviation and airline officials in France, Germany and Britain. Flight 103 originated in Frankfurt and switched to a different airliner in London before leaving for New York on a path over Lockerbie. Other commission members besides Ms. McLaughlin and Oberstar include Sens. Frank Lautenberg, D-N.J., and Alfonse D'Amato, R-N.Y.; Rep. John Paul Hammerschmidt, D-Ark.: retired Air Force Gen. Thomas C. Richards, and Edward Hidalgo, an attorney and former assistant Navy secretary. At least two other airliner bombings have occurred since the Lockerbie disaster, killing 171 people aboard a French UTA jetliner in September and 107 on a Colombian jet in November.

DOC.HEAD: Iran Begins Maneuvers in Gulf
