DOC.TEXT: Iran has begun military maneuvers in the Persian Gulf, including for the first time ``combat submarines,'' Iran's official Islamic Republic News Agency reported. The agency, monitored in Cyprus, said the weeklong maneuvers under the command of Rear Adm. Ali Shamkhani include naval and air units of the Revolutionary Guards Corps. Shamkhani was quoted as saying the exercises, which began Sunday, were being carried out in the Persian Gulf and Oman Sea, spread over an area of 10,000 square miles. The agency did not elaborate on the ``combat submarines.'' During its 8-year-old war with Iraq, Iran displayed a small domestically manufactured submarine, a few yards long, mounted with a single gun and apparently designed to be ridden externally by frogmen.

DOC.HEAD: Governor's Race Hinging on Fiscal Fallout After Dukakis Campaign
DOC.TEXT: The collapse of the ``Massachusetts miracle'' touted by Michael Dukakis in his failed 1988 presidential campaign is giving Republicans their best hope in years to take the governor's office. But Democrats are far from doomed, and a Democratic former attorney general who served with Dukakis now appears to be the favorite to succeed him. After three terms as governor, Dukakis is not seeking re-election. Republicans, who have been locked out of the governor's office for 16 years, are fighting to end what they call ``one-party rule'' in the state. The GOP's prospects rose as a slump in the state economy and a slowdown in tax collections led to burgeoning deficits. Dukakis and his fellow Democrats got the blame for mismanaging the state's finances. Dukakis and his presidential bid remain central issues in the governor's race. This was apparent last week as the state House debated and sent to the Senate a $1.2 billion tax bill designed to improve the state's shaky finances. ``In 1988, this Legislature was in the process of mortgaging the future of Massachusetts,'' said House Minority Leader Steven Pierce, the Republican Party's endorsed candidate for governor. Political observers say with Dukakis absent from the race, Republicans must campaign against his policies and link them to the Democratic Party as a whole. ``His name won't be on the ballot, but that's the name people will see when they look at these candidates,'' said Todd Domke, a Republican political consultant. ``The only way they can vote against Dukakis is to vote against the Democratic slate.'' The Democratic gubernatorial hopefuls, too, have distanced themselves from Dukakis as they prepare for next month's state convention, which will determine the candidates who will appear on September's primary ballot. Former Attorney General Francis X. Bellotti, who leads in public opinion polls, has been a frequent critic of current policies even though he was a past Dukakis supporter. Bellotti's main Democratic rival, Lt. Gov. Evelyn Murphy, has been a loyal deputy to Dukakis but also has pointed out disagreements. The other two Democratic candidates have not worried about tactful breaks. John Silber, on leave as Boston University president, is a sharp-tongued conservative whose support has grown recently, improving his chances to make the primary ballot. Political analysts say he might be drawing support away from Republicans. State Rep. John Flood, who is considered a long shot, warned about excessive state spending at the height of the ``miracle'' years. On the Republican side, Pierce will face former U.S. Attorney William Weld in September. Pierce won the party's endorsement at the state GOP convention in March. Some political observers say that as November approaches, an anti-Dukakis campaign will become less viable. ``Michael Dukakis is continuing to fade from public view, fade as a target,'' said Dan Payne, a Democratic consultant. ``He's not accommodating them.'' ``Pretty soon they will realize the Democratic candidates in the race now are the ones they have to take shots at,'' he said. Republicans, however, saw the debate over the tax increase as another opportunity to boost their chances and knock Democrats for the state's financial slide. ``I think this is going to be the dominant issue of the campaign,'' Pierce said of the tax package. Of the major Democratic gubernatorial contenders, however, only Murphy reacted favorably to the tax proposal. That didn't stop Republicans from seizing the chance to criticize Democratic policies. ``They have to show momentum now,'' Payne said.

DOC.HEAD: 11 Die From Drinking Methanol in Bootleg Liquor
DOC.TEXT: Bootleg liquor containing methanol was blamed for the deaths of 11 people, and 44 others were hospitalized in critical condition after drinking it, the official APS news agency reported. All the victims had consumed the local liquor, illegally produced and sold in plastic bottles near Sidi Bel-Abbes, about 250 miles west of Algiers, the agency reported Sunday. Police opened an investigation into the poisonings, the agency said, and the the 44 victims in regional hospitals were undergoing detoxification. Toxicologists analyzing the liquor said it contained at least 18.75 percent methanol, a compound that can cause blindness or death if consumed above a level of 15 percent, APS said. Most alcohol-based beverages contain ethanol, a less-dangerous alcohol compound.

DOC.HEAD: Medicine Shortage Leaves Thousands in Soviet Capital Afflicted with Lice
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of young Muscovites suffer from head lice, and a shortage of disinfectants leaves no remedy except combing their hair with vinegar and taking a shower, a newspaper reported. Last year in the Soviet capital, sanitation clinics reported that only 4,000 children sought treatment for lice, Moskovskaya Pravda, the city Communist Party newspaper, said Sunday. ``And how many more did not seek help?'' it asked, saying parents' embarrassment and ignorance about the pests make that number only ``the tip of the iceberg.'' Statistics on the problem were not published until 1986, leaving health authorities ``unarmed in the battle'' against lice, the newspaper said. Moscow does not have enough sanitary stations, medicinal baths, or public health instructors to battle the lice, said A. Frolova, a senior scientific worker of the All-Union Scientific Research Institute of Preventative Toxicology and Disinfection. The government recalled soaps containing the pesticide DDT, which is harmful to the environment and banned in the United States, and did not offer any adequate substitutes, she said. ``Civilized countries have all kinds of methods: shampoos, aerosols, lotions,'' she said, noting that Moscow pharmacies don't have the effective treatments that are available in the West or even in Hungary. ``Our pharmaceutical industry is in the Stone Age,'' said T. Borisenko, deputy chief of the supply and sales department of the ``Pharmatsia'' concern that distributes drugs to the city's pharmacies and clinics. One effective medication that is available in Hungary is being supplied for the first time to some city clinics and children's hospitals, he said. Two years ago, there was a demand for 8,000 bottles of the medication, and this year at least 50,000 bottles will be needed, Borisenko said. The problem becomes acute after children are sent off to summer camps and return to the city carrying the parasites. Until more medication is available, Moskovskaya Pravda advised its readers to use combs with cotton wads soaked in vinegar, then take a shower and put on a change of clothes. ``See how simple it is,'' the newspaper added sarcastically, noting general shortages of goods. ``If, of course, you can find combs, cotton vinegar and soap.''

DOC.HEAD: Law Aimed at Animal-Rights Activists Enacted in Kansas
DOC.TEXT: Kansas has enacted a law to punish animal-rights activists for entering and damaging farms and research laboratories. A Humane Society official, however, said the law will hamper investigations into abuses. Gov. Mike Hayden signed the measure over the weekend, calling it one of the first of its kind in the nation. ``It properly provides increased penalties for damage to research facilities and agriculture operations,'' he said. The law was prompted by militant actions around the nation, including vandalism and theft of animals. Under the law, entering farms, ranches or research operations and damaging property are punishable by up to 10 years in prison and a $10,000 fine. Wendell Maddox, regional director for the Humane Society of the United States, said an amendment barring individuals from entering an animal operation to take photos will make it difficult for his group to document abuses. ``It's more than obvious their intention is to keep us out of `puppy mills,''' he said. The so-called puppy mills, which raise puppies for sale, have been criticized by animal-rights groups for unhealthy conditions. Hayden said the law does not conflict with humane societies' authority to deal with abuse. The Republican signed a law two years ago aimed at stopping puppy mills and said he supports efforts to ``close down these disgraceful operations.'' But Maddox said the act will make organizations such as his more dependent on assistance from law enforcement agencies. ``Law enforcement historically doesn't consider animal abuse a priority,'' he said. ``Unless we gather evidence, nothing gets done.''

DOC.HEAD: Pieces of Clothing Found in Killer Crocodile's Teeth
DOC.TEXT: Rangers searching for a killer crocodile on the northeast coast of Australia harpooned the animal after noticing pieces of clothing in its teeth, authorities said today. They believe the 10-foot crocodile attacked and ate a 43-year-old man who had been walking along a beach Friday night or early Saturday morning. Police killed the reptile Sunday after finding remains of the man just off Groote Eylandt, an island 360 miles east of Darwin. The rangers searched for the missing man, Albert Juzelinunas, late Saturday and Sunday, and found the crocodile in the waters off Bartalumba Bay. They harpooned the crocodile and later shot it dead when they saw pieces of clothing in the animal's teeth, police said. Juzeliunas, who worked for the government communications company Telecom, had gone to the island Friday with three other employees to install a radio communications system.

DOC.HEAD: Recent Attacks May Indicate Open Season On U.S. Troops
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf `U.S. officials...' with 1 graf to UPDATE with U.S. officials identifying airmen. Pickup 4th graf `Nine days...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Philippines, Bjt
AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: The killing of three U.S. enlisted men within 10 days indicates Communist rebels may have abandoned the quest for ``quality targets'' and will strike at any American service member in this country. Police believe New People's Army guerrillas gunned down two Air Force servicemen late Sunday near Clark Air Base, 50 miles north of Manila. U.S. officials identified the dead servicemen as Airmen John H. Raven and James C. Green, on temporary assignment from Kunsan Air Base in South Korea. Nine days earlier, gunmen killed Marine Gunnery Sgt. John Fredette near Subic Bay naval base, 50 miles west of the capital. Fredette, 34, was on temporary duty from the Marine air station at El Toro, Calif. Although no one has claimed responsibility for the three killings, U.S. and many Filipino officials believe the rebels were responsible. All three killings were believed timed to today's start of talks on the future of U.S. military bases, which the guerrillas want closed. Although the rebels have repeatedly threatened to kill Americans, U.S. officials expected them to try to assassinate a senior diplomat or military officer. They cited the April 1989 assassination of U.S. Army Col. James ``Nick'' Rowe, a decorated Vietnam War veteran who was ambushed and slain by the rebels on his way to work at the Joint U.S. Military Assistance Group in suburban Quezon City. ``Rowe was a quality target,'' said one U.S. official, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``They don't get the same propaganda value from killing an enlisted man.'' In October 1987, rebels killed two enlisted U.S. airmen and a retired U.S. Air Force sergeant near Clark. That triggered a backlash among the Filipino population in the area after the U.S. military temporarily banned Americans from leaving post to shop in local stores. The quality target theory was also based on recent statements from the rebels indicating they would be selective in deciding whom to kill. In March, rebel commander Romulo Kintanar said the guerrillas would be ``highly selective in launching military operations in the cities.'' But all three recent victims were low-ranking enlisted men who were not even permanently assigned in the Philippines. It appeared they were selected at random simply because of nationality. After Fredette's slaying, U.S. officials suggested he may have been killed by mistake because the rebels thought he was an officer. Fredette's nickname was ``the colonel'' because of his maturity and bearing. It is unlikely Sunday's victims were mistaken for officers. The rebels have been fighting the Philippine government for more than 21 years. If they now are willing to kill any U.S. service member, the security implications are serious, both for American and Filipino authorities. The United States maintains about 40,000 troops, Defense Department civilians and military dependents at the six bases, some in rebel strongholds. Thousands more come temporarily for training at Clark or aboard American warships that call at Subic. In addition, the U.S. Embassy estimates 80,000 to 100,000 American civilians live in the Philippines. Protecting all of them is impossible. ``We can provide good security for senior diplomats, ranking officers, people like that,'' said one American official speaking on condition of anonymity. ``But how do you protect every private?'' Faced with security threats, the State Department is considering increasing hazardous duty pay for embassy personnel. Diplomatic sources say the proposal is opposed by the Defense Department because it would not automatically cover service personnel. The only way military personnel could receive extra compensation would be through awarding combat pay. But that would mean most dependents would have to return to the United States. A sizeable reduction in the American military community would undermine Filipino support for the bases at a time when a new agreement on the installations is in doubt. Many Filipinos who support the bases do so because of the estimated $1 billion they pump into the economy every year. Without large numbers of dependents, many of whom live and shop on the local economy, that figure would decline dramatically.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Robert Reid has been AP chief of bureau in Manila since September 1986.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Backing House Statehood For Puerto Rico Bill
DOC.TEXT: Is a 51-star flag in America's future? Puerto Rico could vote to become a state in two years under legislation pending in the House and backed by President Bush. The target date would be Columbus Day 1992, nearly 500 years since Christopher Columbus claimed the island for Spain and almost 100 years since the United States claimed it in the Spanish-American War. ``I want it to become the 51st state,'' Bush said last week in a letter to Rep. Robert Lagomarsino, ranking Republican member on the Interior subcommittee overseeing Puerto Rican affairs. Lagomarsino and subcommittee Chairman Ron de Lugo, the non-voting delegate from the Virgin Islands, introduced a bill Thursday that calls for Puerto Ricans to hold a referendum in 1991 to choose among statehood, independence or continued commonwealth status with added authority. Similar legislation is pending in the Senate. De Lugo says he will hold hearings in June in New York to determine whether Puerto Ricans living in the United States should be allowed to vote with the islanders in the referendum. If statehood wins, the 3.3 million Puerto Ricans would comprise the 26th most populous state and send six or seven House members to Congress in addition to two senators. In a poll published in February, 43 percent of Puerto Ricans favored statehood, 36 percent favored enhanced commonwealth status, 5 percent called for independence, and 9 percent said they did not know. A similar poll six months earlier had found 41 percent favored statehood. Both recent polls showed a switch from a year earlier, when enhanced commonwealth was the single most popular choice. Status has been an obsession on the island since Spain ruled. After more 400 years as a colony, Puerto Rico won autonomy and full representation in the Spanish parliament in 1897. The next year, it lost all self-governance when the United States took possession through the Treaty of Paris. The people were in political limbo until 1917 when they were made U.S. citizens. While that meant they could be drafted into the U.S. armed forces and send delegates to the political conventions, they never have voted in presidential elections and do not have voting representation in Congress. ``How can we applaud the exciting and momentous movements toward freedom in Eastern Europe, Latin America, and elsewhere while refusing to grant our own citizens the right to self-determination?'' Bush asked in his letter. Until last week, it looked as if Congress was trying to avoid the issue. The legislation was approved by the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee but had to go to the Senate Finance Committee as well, because of tax issues involved. Hearings have been held there but no vote has been scheduled. De Lugo said that under a previous arrangement he was waiting for the bill to clear the Senate before taking it up in the House. But with time running out on the congressional session, he said, the House decided to go forward with its own bill. The issue is complicated by financial considerations, including special federal tax exemptions for businesses on the island that would have to change with statehood. Some people believe the change would cause business to leave, hurting Puerto Ricans financially. The Senate bill states the steps that would be taken to make Puerto Rico a state, enhanced commonwealth or independent. ``Our bill would require the development of legislation to implement winning status next year,'' said de Lugo. Final federal action could not take effect without another vote by Puerto Rico, which would be in July 1992. ``The status development would then be effective in October 1992,'' de Lugo said.

DOC.HEAD: Agriculture Department Forecasts Bumper Winter Wheat Crop
DOC.TEXT: Last week's Agriculture Department forecast of a bumper 1990 winter wheat crop has a pretty good chance of being correct. Based on surveys just before May 1, the department's agricultural statistics board estimated production at slightly more than 2.09 billion bushels, a 44 percent increase from the weather-damaged 1989 harvest. And since winter wheat makes up about three-fourths of the U.S. all-wheat total, a fairly normal yield of spring-planted wheat should put the nation's relatively skimpy supply back into shape. The board, a part of the department's National Agricultural Statistics Service, takes pains to explain the crop surveys and their accuracy. Revised estimates are published each month during the growing season of specific crops. By August or so, it should be fairly clear what the total U.S. wheat output will be this year. ``The May 1 forecast has been below the final estimate seven times and above three times,'' last week's report said. ``This does not imply that the May 1 winter wheat forecast this year is likely to understate or overstate final production.'' A year ago, the May estimate of 1989 winter wheat production was slightly more than 1.43 billion bushels. The final 1989 figure included in last week's report was a bit more than 1.45 billion bushels. In a related supply-and-demand report issued by the department's world agricultural outlook board, analysts projected _ based on yield trends, an assumption of normal weather and other factors _ a total U.S. wheat harvest this year of more than 2.69 billion bushels. That would be the third-largest U.S. wheat crop on record, exceeded by the 1981 and 1982 harvests of 2.79 billion and 2.77 billion bushels, respectively. A year ago, the same outlook board, which represents the department's Economic Research Service and the Foreign Agricultural Service, projected a 1989 total wheat production of 2.05 billion bushels. The final was less than 2.04 billion. The USDA winter wheat estimate announced last Thursday afternoon was substantially higher than most private forecasters and commodity traders expected. Many of those believed the department's all-wheat projection would be in the range of 2.3 billion to 2.5 billion bushels. One maverick, however, was Sparks Commodities Inc. of Memphis, Tenn., which the week before forecast the 1990 wheat crop at 2.7 billion bushels _ almost exactly matching the USDA projection announced on May 10.

The 1988 drought did more than ravage crops, send commodity prices upward and put livestock on expensive diets. Drought also chewed into farm productivity, says the Agriculture Department. As the economists say, that happens when output drops faster than input. Overall, said the department's Economic Research Service, farm production _ output _ dropped 7.7 percent in 1988. The total quantity of labor, machinery and land used in 1988 _ inputs _ declined 1.6 percent. There are other inputs, too, but the three basic groups accounted for almost 69 percent of the total in 1988. Others include feed, seed, livestock, taxes and interest, and chemicals. When all the factors are compared and expressed as units in an index, the report showed that 1988 farm production per unit of input _ productivity _ dropped 6.2 percent. Expressed another way, U.S. farm productivity in 1988 averaged 120 percent of a 1977 base used for comparison. That was down from 128 percent in 1987. ``This decline reflected drought conditions, rather than technical deterioration,'' the report said. Regionally, the figures showed farm productivity in 1988 dropped 16.8 percent in the Corn Belt, 15.2 percent in the Northern Plains and Lake States, 2.8 percent in the Northeast, and 2.2 percent in the Mountain states. Productivity rose 13.6 percent in the Mississippi Delta, 10 percent in the Southeast, 7.1 percent in Appalachia, 1.8 percent in the Southern Plains, and 0.7 percent in the Pacific region.

The estimated wholesale value of cut flowers, potted plants and other floriculture crops rose 6 percent in 1989 to about $2.43 billion, according to an annual report by the Agriculture Department. ``All major groups except foliage plants had increased wholesale values,'' the report said. ``Cut flowers increased 2 percent in value to $469 million. Potted flowering plants, valued at $522 million, increased 3 percent.'' But foliage plants dropped 1 percent in 1989 to $476 million. The report said sales of bedding plants were estimated at a wholesale value of $867 million, up 9 percent from 1988. The value of cut cultivated greens rose 9 percent to $98.8 million.

DOC.HEAD: US-Chile Agreement a Major Step, State Department Negotiator Says
DOC.TEXT: One more step remains before US-Chilean relations can be normalized, now that Chile has agreed to pay compensation for the 1976 slaying in Washington of a Chilean opposition figure and his aide, a U.S. negotiator says. The ``agreement in principle'' was concluded last week following talks between Chilean and U.S. negotiators in Washington, State Department legal adviser Abraham D. Sofaer said Sunday. He said the second step toward normalizing relations is to see that the killers of Chilean exile leader Orlando Letelier and his aide, Ronni Moffitt, are brought to justice. Letelier and Moffitt died in a car bombing in Washington. ``Once we have both those things done, relations between both these two countries can be completely normalized,'' Sofaer said. ``So it is very significant. It has taken us years to get here.'' The agreement with the new government of Chilean President Patricio Aylwin marks a reversal of the stance taken by Aylwin's predecessor, right-wing Gen. Augusto Pinochet, who seized power in the 1973 overthrow. Aylwin, who defeated a Pinochet-backed candidate in elections to replace the military government, has promised full cooperation with U.S. officials in the case. Aylwin took power in March. Sofaer underscored that Chile would make payments without conceding any government liability for the death of Letelier, who served in the government of Salvador Allende, a Marxist president who died in a 1973 coup in Chile. ``We have agreed in principle to arbitration, in effect, to set an amount of compensation to be paid to those people damaged by the bombing,'' he said. The amount would be set by an international tribunal. At the time of the Sept. 21, 1976, bombing, Letelier and Ms. Moffitt were working for the Institute for Policy Studies. The survivors include Letelier's widow and Ms. Moffitt's husband. A federal judge in 1980 concluded that the Pinochet government and its agents were responsible for the deaths of Letelier and Moffitt and ordered the Chilean government to pay $2.9 million in compensation to the survivors. But the relatives have been unable to collect, and the United States is expected to ask the tribunal to award at least the $2.9 million and 10 years' interest, The New York Times reported Sunday. In Chile, the issue of reparations has been seen as key battle between Aylwin and Pinochet, who remains as army commander and has promised to block human rights investigations of the military. Letelier served as ambassador to Washington and was foreign minister during the Allende rule. In exile after the coup, he became a severe critic of Pinochet's rule. Sofaer said the issue of civil payments is wholly separate from criminal cases in the United States against former officials of the Chilean secret police indicted in the killings.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Composer Andrew Lloyd Webber says stale ideas, high costs and a fear of bad reviews have made Broadway ``a mess.'' ``They're still talking about the smashes of the '40s and '50s, which I hugely admire,'' Webber said Saturday. ``But not to the exclusion of what's going on elsewhere.'' The 42-year-old composer and creator of such hits as ``The Phantom of the Opera,'' ``Cats'' and ``Evita,'' received an honorary doctorate of fine arts during commencement exercises at the University of South Carolina. ``Broadway is a mess,'' he told reporters afterward. ``There is no question about it.''

John F. Kennedy Jr. may have a brighter future on stage than in a courtroom. The assistant prosecutor, who twice has flunked the bar exam, plays the guitar and sings in the movie ``A Matter of Degrees,'' which is scheduled to open in Europe but has no U.S. distributor, according to the May 21 issue of People. The son of the slain president, who must pass the bar exam on his third try in July or lose his $30,000-a-year job, made his professional acting debut opposite Christina Haag in ``Winners'' in an off-off-Broadway theater in 1988. ``He is the finest young actor I have seen in 12 years,'' said the theater's operator, Nye Heron. But Kennedy's mother, Jacqueline Onassis, may have vetoed a longer run in ``Winners,'' the magazine reported. ``The acting drove Jackie crazy,'' said Harrison Rainie, co-author of ``Growing Up Kennedy.''

Producer Fred Caruso wouldn't rewrite ``The Bonfire of the Vanities'' to get permission to shoot a scene in a New Jersey courthouse. New Jersey Chief Justice Robert N. Wilentz on Sunday offered to allow the filmmakers to shoot a scene in a courthouse stairwell if they cut out a part showing an actor slamming shut an iron gate to keep a ``mob of blacks'' at bay. ``I won't rewrite the script for the judge, or for anyone,'' Caruso said in a telephone interview. The movie version of Tom Wolfe's novel about a Wall Street bond salesman who gets enmeshed in the Bronx court system has been accused of unfairly portraying blacks and Hispanics as criminals. Caruso said the judge is ``misinformed'' about the racial overtones of the scene. He said he would meet with Essex County officials today to gain access to the courthouse. Wilentz said in a statement Sunday, ``I will not permit a New Jersey courthouse, courtroom or corridor to be used to portray blacks as having so little respect for law they would riot and threaten a judge's life.''

Comedian Jerry Seinfeld says he doesn't try to hide his shallowness. ``I take the most normal things in life and spend way too much time thinking about them,'' Seinfeld, 36, said in the May 21 issue of Time magazine. The creator, co-writer and star of ``Seinfeld,'' scheduled to debut on NBC this month, said the show will depict incidents that expose his most personal side. But he is not worried. Because ``when you're a shallow person, there's no danger in opening yourself up.''

DOC.HEAD: Mohawk Devotes His Life to Preserving Traditional Ways
DOC.TEXT: Tom Porter wears his hair in a ponytail, refuses to send his children to school and disdains running water, electricity and democracy. Porter, whose friends know him by his tribal name, Sakowkenonkwas, is a Mohawk chief. The 46-year-old carpenter has built a house on the reservation, and his family lives off produce from a large garden. They speak Iroquois. But modern practices have intruded. A 9-month-old dispute over casino gambling has torn apart the 9,000-member reservation, culminating in two slayings May 1. Porter, his Choctaw Indian wife and their six children were among more than 500 people driven from their homes to a refugee center in Cornwall, Ontario. ``I've never seen this in my life,'' Porter said. ``I never dreamed people would do this to other people. A true Mohawk doesn't carry a shotgun. He doesn't bring dissension. He tries to remove turmoil.'' Since the killings, Canadian and New York police have sealed off the reservation with roadblocks, keeping non-residents out and effectively closing the casinos, along with many other businesses on Mohawk land. Four Mohawks were arrested by Canadian police Sunday in an investigation of one of the slayings, but no charges were immediately filed. Supporters of gambling say the six casinos and bingo parlors on the American side of the reservation produce jobs and revenue. Busloads of visitors are lured to the gaming houses by slot machines, roulette and craps. But opponents such as Porter say gambling has brought drugs, guns and prostitution and is destroying an old and valued lifestyle. Porter was appointed by the tribe's elders to the Council of Traditional Chiefs, one of three fractious councils governing the reserve straddling the Canadian border. He wants the casinos closed. Elected tribal leaders have said they will hold a referendum on the gambling issue sometime in June. But Porter is disdainful of democracy, believing people should be led by those chosen for their ``character and goodness.'' ``I was raised with the old Mohawk values and I've always embraced those teachings in life,'' he said. His house lacks running water, electricity, a television or a telephone. Many Mohawks, in contrast, have factory jobs off the reservation, TV sets in their homes and satellite dishes in their yards. ``When I was a child I cherished serenity,'' Porter said. ``I don't want electricity and phones because I don't want to bring the trappings of the fast life into my life.'' Such modern comforts also have brought alcoholism, drug abuse and other social ills, Porter said.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Ambassador Describes a Rapidly Changing World
DOC.TEXT: As he gets ready to leave Washington for Paris, Soviet Ambassador Yuri Dubinin is telling American college graduates to get ready for a changing world. ``Perhaps a Soviet ambassador has more reason to say that, since in my country, a week _ and sometimes a day _ brings changes which otherwise would have taken years,'' Dubinin said Sunday at commencement ceremonies for George Washington University's Elliott School of International Affairs. He told the class of 1990 that it was entering ``a unique world, which is changing rapidly as never before.'' The speech was Dubinin's last scheduled formal public appearance in Washington before his departure to become the Soviet Union's ambassador to France. Dubinin, who has headed the Soviet embassy here since 1986, is being succeeded by Aleksandr A. Bessmertnhkh, currently the Soviet Union's first deputy foreign minister and a veteran expert on U.S. affairs. ``Perhaps for the first time, mankind now has a chance to rid itself of the ideological, political and military confrontation among states in order to address the problems which call for joint efforts,'' said Dubinin.
DOC.HEAD: Report: Make Schools More Productive, Not Richer
DOC.TEXT: An education researcher says the problem in American schools is waste, not a shortage of cash. ``American schools actually are shortchanging the nation by wasting some $100 billion a year through sprawling bureaucracy and outmoded technology,'' Lewis J. Perelman of the Hudson Institute said Sunday. In a rebuttal to those who claim increased education spending will improve student achievement, he said: ``More spending on more of the same education will waste resources, weaken the U.S. economy and undermine the nation's global competitiveness.'' In a report released Sunday, ``The `Acanemia' Deception,'' Perelman said the United States spent $3,310 to educate each student from preschool to grade 12 in 1985. The expenditure is second only to Switzerland, which spent $3,683. The figures are based on a special 1985 index of purchasing power of industrial nations. The statistics contradict a recent analysis by the Economic Policy Institute that said the United States trailed 13 other industrial nations in spending on elementary and secondary education. The EPI recommended adding at least $20 billion per year to the nation's kindergarten through 12th grade spending. Among Perelmen's recommendations were: _Every education and training institution, organization and program in the United States should set aside at least 1 percent of its gross revenues for investment in research and development. The funds could be pooled in a common fund administered by a new National Institute for Learning Technology. _The goal of the new investment in educational initiative should be to double the productivity of U.S. education. _Every student in America should have access to a ``distance learning'' network by the year 2001. He explained that teachers can instruct students across the state or country at the same time with the two-way video.
DOC.HEAD: Dubcek Says 1968 Uprising Foretold Today's Changes in Eastern Europe
DOC.TEXT: The Prague Spring reform movement of 1968, crushed by Red Army tanks, helped plant the seeds of the revolutionary changes now sweeping Eastern Europe, Alexander Dubcek told American University graduates. Dubcek, in his commencement address Sunday, also said Czechoslovakia began to fear a loss of identity after the Soviet invasion of 1968. ``An act of violence and malevolence relegated us to the role of a pawn in a great game of politics,'' Dubcek said. ``Once again, we were reminded that our country lies at the front line, at the frontier of the Cold War.'' But he said the country's push toward reform more than two decades ago influenced today's changes in Eastern Europe. Dubcek, who headed his country's Communist Party at the time of the 1968 Soviet invasion, said the transition to democracy should be ``smooth, gradual, cultured, civilized.'' Czechoslovakia's ``Velvet Revolution'' last fall brought Dubcek back to public life as chairman of the country's Federal Parliament. At Sunday's ceremony, American University also awarded Dubcek an honorary degree, calling him ``a symbol in the face of tyranny'' for launching the Prague Spring reforms and trying to create a new ``socialism with a human face.''

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Up
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 32,042.65, up 530.51 points, or 1.68 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange on Monday.

DOC.HEAD: North Korea Promises To Release Soldiers' Remains, U.S. To Improve Contacts
DOC.TEXT: North Korea today said it will release the remains of some U.S. soldiers killed in the Korean War, and a South Korean newspaper reported Washington plans to upgrade contacts with the Communist north. Chosun Ilbo, a leading newspaper, quoted anonymous sources as saying Washington wants to include diplomats up to the ambassadorial level and will carry on such contacts in new unspecified locations. North Korea's official Korean Central News Agency, monitored in Tokyo, said the Pyongyang government will return ``some unearthed remains of U.S. soldiers'' to the United States through U.S. congressmen at the border village of Panmunjom May 28. There was no immediate comment from Washington on the reports. North Korean officials meeting last month with U.S. diplomats in Beijing offered to return the remains of five U.S. soldiers killed in the Korean War, Japan's JiJi news agency reported Saturday. United States diplomats reportedly have met North Korean officials in Beijing eight times since early last year in efforts to persuade the North to open its doors and improve relations with capitalist South Korea. Washington and North Korean leaders have no diplomatic relations, and the United States maintains 43,000 troops in rival South Korea to deter an attack from the north. According to U.S. Defense Department figures, about 8,200 U.S. soldiers were unaccounted for at the end of the war, with 345 of those listed as possible prisoners of war. North Korea is one of the last hard-line communist states and one of the most isolated countries in the world. It has not instituted political and economic reforms such as those in Eastern Europe. Foreign Minister Choi Ho-joong has made a personal appeal that Washington ``be prudent in its contacts'' with North Korea, according to Yonhap, South Korea's the national news agency. Choi met last week with Richard Solomon, the U.S. assistant secretary of state for Asian and Pacific Affairs. Yonhap said the two discussed North Korea's return of the remains of U.S. soldiers killed in the 1950-53 Korean War. `Choi reaffirmed the government's stance that prudence should prevail in that such contacts would contribute to easing tension on the Korean peninsula,'' Yonhap said, quoting an anonymous government official. It said Solomon reaffirmed Washington would not positively respond to North Korea's call for improved ties unless ``it met a set of conditions.'' It said Solomon reaffirmed Washington would not positively respond to North Korea's call for improved ties unless ``it met a set of conditions.'' These conditions included agreement for more confidence building measures in the Demilitarized Zone dividing North and South Korea, abandonment of terrorism and adherence to the safeguards clause in the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty. The United States imposed sanctions against North Korea after the November 1987 bombing of a South Korean airliner off Burma, allegedly by North Korean agents. The sanctions, which included a ban on meetings between U.S. and North Korean officials, were lifted just before the 1988 Olympic Games in Seoul.

DOC.HEAD: Stock Prices Surge, Dollar Declines Against Yen
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 4 grafs to UPDATE with closing Nikkei, dollar, bonds. Pickup 5th graf `Exchange dealers...'
DOC.TEXT: Share prices surged on the Tokyo stock market Monday, and the dollar arrested an early fall against the Japanese yen to close moderately lower. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average rose 530.51 points, or 1.68 percent, to reach 32,042.65 points at the market close. Tokyo's main barometer rose 531.88 points Friday. The dollar closed the afternoon session at 153.35 yen, down 0.80 yen from its finish Friday at 154.15 yen. After starting at 152.45, the currency fluctuated between 152.45 yen and 153.90 yen. The price of the benchmark 10-year Japanese government bonds rose 87.69 points by 3:00 p.m. (2 a.m. EDT) Monday, up from its Friday close at 87.40 percent. Their yield dropped to 7.020 percent from 7.080 percent. Exchange dealers attributed the dollar's early retreat Monday to its downswing in New York Friday, due partly to U.S. government reports indicating the nation's economy remains slow and inflationary pressures had been curbed. A U.S. Labor Department report, released Friday, showed an unexpected 0.3 percent decline in April U.S. wholesale prices, coupled with a 0.6 percent decline in retail sales during the month. Both figures accelerated the dollar's decline. But in subsequent morning trading, buy orders for the dollar appeared and it rebounded into the 153 yen range, said Toru Kanai, exchange analyst for New Japan Securities Co. Despite the dollar's continuous fall at the end of last week, the demand for the U.S. currency remained unexpectedly high, Kanai commented. ``It is not so much that we are seeing a real decline in the dollar, but rather a long-term adjustment,'' he said. An analyst for Japan's largest securities company, Nomura Securities, said the decline in interest rates abroad, the rise in domestic bond prices and the rapid fall of the dollar led to the recent rises in stock prices. Stock prices were increasing all across the board Monday morning, though shares keyed to local demand attracted particular buyer interest, the analyst said, speaking on condition of anonymity. The main reason for the bullishess of the Tokyo market was that ``fears of inflation in the United States and Europe have faded into the distance,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``How can we applaud the exciting and momentous movements toward freedom in Eastern Europe, Latin America and elsewhere while refusing to grant our own citizens the right to self-determination?'' President Bush, in support of statehood for Puerto Rico.

``This brutal and clumsy attempt to drive a wedge between the United States and the Philippines will fail.'' _ Richard Armitage, chief U.S. negotiator in talks over military bases in the Philippines, on the fatal shootings of two American servicemen there by suspected Communist guerrillas.

``I never dreamed people would do this to other people. A true Mohawk doesn't carry a shotgun. He doesn't bring dissension. He tries to remove turmoil.'' _ Mohawk chief Tom Porter, on a dispute over casino gambling on the St. Regis Indian Reservation, where he lives.

DOC.HEAD: Pope Wraps Up 47th Foreign Trip, Marks Anniversary of Assassination Attempt
LaserPhoto XWIL2
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II marked the ninth anniversary of an attempt on his life and urged residents of this thriving Dutch Caribbean island to shun materialism, as he concluded the 47th foreign trip of his papacy. The pontiff stopped in Curacao, about 35 miles north of Venezuela, on Sunday on his way back to Rome after an eight-day, 10-city tour of Mexico. Celebrating Mass in a sports stadium, John Paul struck familiar themes, speaking out against divorce, cohabitation and abortion. He earlier made a brief reference to the 1981 assassination attempt that nearly ended his life in St. Peter's Square. He noted in a Mexico City airport address that the church was celebrating the Feast of the Virgin of Fatima on May 13. ``(It is) a very significant date for me because on a day like today nine years ago I felt in a particular way the maternal protection of Mary,'' the pope told hundreds of people seeing him off at the end of his second trip to Mexico. In Curacao, he urged residents to set a Christian example to the thousands of tourists who visit every year, and warned against materialism. ``The person, the family and the society will not be fully human if they limit their aspirations just to possessing, consuming and enjoying,'' the pontiff said. Curacao, a financial and tourism center, has one of the highest standards of living in the Caribbean. With a population of 147,000, it is the most populous of the five islands that make up the autonomous Netherlands Antilles chain. Several Latin American clerics, including Cardinal Miguel Obando y Bravo of Nicaragua, traveled to Curacao to celebrate Mass with the pope. The stadium, with a capacity of 20,000, was about half full. Behind the altar was a yellow backdrop representing the gabled colonial buildings of downtown Willemstad, the capital of the Netherland Antilles. The pope received a warm welcome at the airport in this overwhelmingly Catholic island. A group of schoolgirls in white blouses and blue skirts sang calypso music and shook pompons of yellow and white, the Vatican's colors. Scattered knots of people, some waving palm fronds, greeted the pope along his motorcade route. Billboards read ``Bon Bini,'' or ``Welcome'' in the local Papamiento language. John Paul's eight-hour stop in Curacao also included meetings with the prime minister of the Netherland Antilles, Maria Liberia-Peters, who is Catholic, non-Catholic leaders and priests and nuns, as well as the Mass. The pontiff wound up staying on the island about an hour longer than the scheduled seven hours, spending more time than allotted to mingle with crowds. His plane left for Rome at 11:12 p.m. EDT Sunday and was expected to arrive in the Italian capital this afternoon. John Paul, who turns 70 Friday, barely showed strain during his visit to Mexico. The Vatican's secretary of state, Cardinal Agostino Casaroli, remarked on the assassination anniversary as the pope's special Aeromexico jet left Mexico City on its way to Curacao. ``Nine years ago at this precise moment, there occurred one of the most incredible manifestations of hate against he who only preached love,'' he said over the airplane's intercom at 9:17 a.m. (11:17 a.m. EDT). ``But at the same time, there occurred a manifestation of the intervention of providence,'' Casaroli said. ``Providence not only saved the life of the pope, but, in a certain sense, reinvigorated him.'' The pope was shot as he circled in an open car through the crowd at his weekly general audience. A Turk, Mehmet Ali Agca, was convicted of the attempted assassination. Since he recovered, John Paul has traveled 400,000 miles in more than 80 countries.

DOC.HEAD: Police Uncover Intricate Male Prostitution Ring
DOC.TEXT: A Navy computer expert ran a vast, 39-state male prostitution ring that recruited ``well-built guys'' through an electronic network, authorities said. The ring, advertising in gay magazines, drew clients that included a priest and a policeman, authorities said Sunday. Police estimate at least 50 prostitutes and 300 patrons are involved, but no identities were disclosed and no arrests made. The ring was organized by James William Dayton, 44, a computer scientist at the Naval Avionics Center in Indianapolis who died of March 16 after suffering a heart attack at a Tiffin, Ohio, bed and breakfast, authorities said. He had been having sex with a man who wanted to join the network as a prostitute, police said. Diana Hogue, spokeswoman for the Naval Avionics Center, said there is no indication Dayton used computers at his job for the prostitution ring or that anyone else at the center was involved. The center acquires and produces advanced electronics systems for the Naval Air Systems command. Dayton did not have access to classified data, she said. Dayton's setup began to unravel after a sheriff's detective who investigated his death searched his car and found 140 pages of computer-generated job applications and photos of nude men, authorities said. Investigators found evidence of an intricate, computerized system for matching clients with prostitutes across the country, in two Canadian provinces, in Guam and in Korea. Don Smith, a computer expert at Indiana University-Purdue University at Indianapolis, helped police break the codes to gain access to that network. Smith determined that Dayton had used the computer sign-on Blue Boy and was the owner-operator of Muscles USA and Muscles Midwest. ``I've asked police to go after the most prolific prostitutes as targets now. We're going to start with the most active ones and we will ask the patrons to cooperate,'' said Marion County Prosecutor Stephen Goldsmith. He said authorities will try to arrange for AIDS testing of the patrons. The investigation began in 1985 but hit many dead-ends, said Andrew Stoner, a police spokesman. ``It had built-in barriers that prevented undercover officers from infiltrating the system,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Highway Dollars Caught in Deficit Fight
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report. ^An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Your highway dollars are at work in Washington, but they're not necessarily building roads and bridges. More people are complaining that the dollars coming from the 9.1-cent-a-gallon federal gasoline tax and other user fees are maintaining a rickety budget machine instead. On Capitol Hill, the Bush administration and congressional analysts are trying to explain why more available highway money isn't being spent for its intended purposes. ``Our roads and highways are victims of a highway mistrust fund,'' Sen. Harry Reid, D-Nev., charged at a hearing last week. Fellow Senate Nevadan, Democrat Richard H. Bryan, has introduced legislation that would require $3 billion extra in projects to be approved in each of the next three years. The highway account of the Federal Highway Trust fund takes in between $13 billion and $14 billion a year from the gasoline tax, a 15-cent-per-gallon diesel fuel tax and other user fees. Part of the fund is used for mass transit projects. Spending from the highway or similar funds, such as for aviation, counts in figuring the federal deficit. Likewise, revenues count against it. Rep. Bob McEwen, R-Ohio, has introduced a bill that would remove the highway fund from overall budget calculations. The fund began with the Federal-Aid Highway Act of 1956, which created the nation's interstate highways. The law specified that the 75 percent to 90 percent federal share of the state-run projects be financed by the so-called highway user fees. Congressional public works committees and the Department of Transportation authorizes projects. DOT's Federal Highway Administration apportions the so-called contract authority yearly under a formula. This authority has a dollar amount. But at the same time the spending committees grant obligation authority, which tells the states how much they can really commit themselves to spend. States pay the bills for projects then ask the federal government for reimbursement, so there is a lag between when a project is authorized and when the federal check comes in the mail. As a result of efforts to regulate outlays, the administration and then later Congress put ceilings on obligations. An unused cash balance of $11 billion built up and has remained at that level for years. Both the General Accounting Office and the Congressional Budget Office say about $7 billion to $8 billion of that balance could be committed this year, based on projected income to the account. GAO, the auditing arm of Congress, adds that $3.4 billion would be a more reasonable amount, with the remainder set aside for a rainy day. But a real problem is interest. The unspent balances earn about $1 billion a year in interest, the result of the Treasury borrowing against the account. The fund has accumulated $15.6 billion in interest since 1956. The Transportation Department says $4.7 billion of that interest has been spent. The remaining $11 billion equals the cash balance. ``If spending is increased to use more of the interest that is accruing, the Treasury will have to pay the resulting bills,'' Kate L. Moore, an assistant Transportation secretary, testified last week. The administration's 1991 budget proposal calls for spending $300 million of the $900 million in interest credited to the highway account. Future interest spending has yet to be proposed.
EDITOR'S NOTE: Robert Greene covers transportation issues in Congress for The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: Deadly Bomb Attack Angers Residents of Working Class Neighborhood
LaserPhoto NY10
DOC.TEXT: The rubble has been swept away from a working-class neighborhood after a car bomb killed 15 people. But the anger remains among residents who blame both drug traffickers and the United States for the carnage wracking their country. Stunned residents coul not understand why their neighborhood had suddenly become a target. ``It's an evil group of people who would attack poor people for no reason,'' said Luis Benavides, a glass worker whose small two-story house in the Quirigua neighborhood was severely damaged by the bomb. ``How can we try to understand such madness? Whoever they are, they are attacking our families and our children in the middle of the street,'' said Benavides, who shares the house with several of his 11 children and 12 grandchildren. Police blamed drug traffickers for the Quirigua car bomb attack and two others on Saturday that killed 27 people, including six children, and wounded some 200. The death toll was the highest this year for a single day of terrorist attacks, police said. Two of the attacks came in the capital of Bogota, in Quirigua and the upper-middle-class enclave of Niza, and the third in the southern city of Cali. Police said the cars were packed with dynamite, and the explosions triggered by remote control. On Sunday, scores of police officers stood guard in Quirigua against looters. Hundreds of curious onlookers stood behind ropes stretched across both ends of a commercial street by police to cordon off the bomb scene. Martha Lucia Sanchez, a 19-year-old student and neighbor of Benavides, said the car bomb exploded when the streets were full of people shopping for Mother's Day. ``The terrorists did not just want to cause damage to property.'' she said. ``They wanted to kill as many of the innocent as they could. They were very determined.'' Police said 15 people were killed in the Quirigua bomb attack. Two more people died in Niza and 10 were killed in Cali. Benavides' 26-year-old son, Jose Luis, said he was standing by a front window of his family's home when the bomb exploded. On Sunday, he stood by the empty frame of the same window, still dazed and wearing a blood-stained bandage around his head. Jose Luis said he didn't want to stay in a damaged house without windows, but had no choice. ``If we don't stay here we will be robbed,'' he said. His wife, Carmen Rosa, shuddered and cried as she told how the family was planning to celebrate its 18th anniversary of living in the house at the end of May. ``We have been humble persons all our lives,'' she said. ``The fight between politicians and criminals has nothing to do with us.'' But many Quirigua residents were more precise in singling out targets for their rage. ``This is the fault of the United States for forcing Colombia to fight its war against drug traffickers,'' said 34-year-old Miguel Angel Ayure. He angrily blasted President Virgilio Barco and other Colombian government officials as ``cowards for not resisting the pressure of the gringos to extradite drug suspects'' to the United States. ``I want the death penalty for the drug terrorists who did this,'' he said. ``But I want them to die in Colombia.'' Ernesto Aguacida, 34, said Colombia was not only at the mercy of drug traffickers, but also of foreign governments. He noted that drug traffickers are using weapons made in the United States and Israel. ``Those countries profit from this violence,'' he said. Aguacida and others predicted that regardless of who wins the May 27 presidential election and succeeds Barco, the violence will continue. In August, the government announced an offensive against the drug traffickers following the assassination of presidential candidate Sen. Luis Carlos Galan. The drug cartels responded with an offensive of their own. Police blame them for hundreds of bobings and other attacks that have left nearly 300 people dead.

DOC.HEAD: Bride and Groom Robbed at Gunpoint
DOC.TEXT: A couple who hours earlier had promised to love each other for richer or for poorer were robbed at gunpoint of $13,000 in wedding gifts. Four robbers in ski masks even took the bridal bouquet and the top of the wedding cake, police and family members said. The newlyweds, Diane and Anthony Rohr, left their wedding reception early Sunday and stopped for a light in Brooklyn when another car cut them off and two armed men got out and demanded money, said police Sgt. Diane Kubler. The bride, still in her gown, and the groom, in a tuxedo, were pulled from the car with the groom's brother and his wife, and the new Mrs. Rohr was thrown to the ground. ``Can you imagine, 10 minutes after your wedding, lying on the middle of the street with guns pointed everywhere?'' said Rosalie Williams, the mother of the bride. Four men took the wedding gifts, which included cash and checks, and the car. The shaken Rohrs went on their Caribbean honeymoon anyway. ``I made them go,'' said the groom's father, William. ``I told them, `The thieves got everything material. They may have gotten the car and the money, but you still have each other and that's what counts.'''

DOC.HEAD: Albanian Communist Leader Rejects Western-Style Democracy
DOC.TEXT: Albanian Communist leaders say their country will continue its cautious course of reform, but they still reject Western-style politics. ``I think it would be absurd to recommend the French or English model of democracy in another country,'' Albanian Communist Party leader Ramiz Alia said in comments made available Sunday. ``The English Parliament is hundreds of years old, ours not even 50,'' Albania's state ATA news agency quoted Alia as telling U.N. Secretary General Javier Perez De Cuellar. The visit by Perez De Cuellar, who arrived Friday, was the latest sign that Eastern Europe's last hard-line Communist nation is emerging from its decades-long policy of isolation. At last week's parliament session, Albanian officials eased restrictions on travel abroad _ difficult if not impossible for decades for ordinary Albanians _and abolished the death penalty for those caught trying to flee the country. They also said penalties would be lifted for spreading religious or anti-socialist propaganda. But these reforms fall far short of the sweeping changes being introduced elsewhere in Eastern Europe, where multiparty democracies are being established. The Albanian Communist Party continues to exert its control in a manner reminiscent of the repressive Stalinist era of the 1940s and 1950s in the Soviet bloc. Perez De Cuellar, who has attempted to emphasize the positive aspects of what remains a restrictive society, on Sunday praised the cautious changes being introduced in Albania. ``I am convinced that this process will be further promoted and it will lead the country towards a modern society,'' he said at a reception given in his honor by Alia. Albanian officials have suggested that the changes have been made possible by the relaxation off East-West tensions. Prime Minister Adil Carcani touched on that theme at a meeting Saturday with Perez de Cuellar, who is the first U.N. secretary-general to visit Albania. ``In the future too, the Albanian government will make other changes in accordance with the conditions of the country's development and with the international circumstances,'' ATA quoted Carcani as saying.

DOC.HEAD: Bell Workers Walk Out Over Health Coverage
DOC.TEXT: Managers handled operator-assistance calls and took over other duties after 3,000 union members went on strike against Cincinnati Bell. The union, representing operators, clerical workers and installers, walked out on Mother's Day, one of the busiest calling days of the year, after a 14-hour bargaining session broke down early Sunday. No new talks were scheduled. Company spokeswoman Cyndy Cantoni said direct calls are automated and weren't affected, and people making long distance calls on Mother's Day saw no difference because Cincinnati Bell is not a long distance carrier. Ms. Cantoni said 1,000 management workers were called in to fill in for the strikers, and some will put in 12-hour shifts for the duration of the strike. The company serves more than 500,000 customers in the Cincinnati area and portions of northern Kentucky and southeastern Indiana. ``I don't think customers will see a big difference in most services, but they can expect slower response time from repair and installation,'' she said. Union leaders said workers went on strike over health benefits and a plan that would require workers to pay part of their health premiums. Cincinnati Bell workers last struck in 1983. Managers replaced union workers during the two-week walkout.

DOC.HEAD: Crowds Mob Campaigning Premier Outside Bucharest
DOC.TEXT: Few Romanians knew who Petre Roman was before the December revolution. Now tens of thousands mob him like a rock star on his swings around the country campaigning for the May 20 elections. Thousands of people protest daily in Bucharest and some other cities, accusing the governing National Salvation Front of planning to install a new Communist government. The Front took over when dictator Nicolae Ceausescu was overthrown and executed. In the towns and countryside, the government and its leaders are much more popular. At Birlad, 160 miles northeast of Bucharest, the crowd of 20,000 pressed so close that Roman ordered his driver to speed away. His spokesman was spreadeagled on the back of the vehicle, desperately clutching the antenna. After the campaign tour last week, the 43-year-old premier predicted the Front would win Romania's first free elections in 50 years. He, interim President Ion Iliescu and many other Front members are former officials of the Ceausescu regime who fell out with the dictator. Roman said in an interview that critics were ``partly justified'' in suspecting them of being ``neo-Communists.'' ``We lived 50 years under dictatorship, so the suspicion for some of them may be sincere,'' the premier said in an interview aboart his campaign plane. Opposition claims that the Front seeks to restore Marxist-style government should not be taken seriously, he said. ``If you assume that the 4 million members of the party were really Communists, you are wrong,'' Roman said of Communist Party membership under Ceausescu. ``Many even at the middle level were in reality fighting to preserve human rights, at risk to themselves.'' International attention has focused on mass protest against the Front and Roman's government that began April 22 in downtown Bucharest, and on opposition accusations that the Front is using unfair tactics in the campaign. The United States recalled its ambassador for consultations May 10. At times, 10,000 people have been involved in the Bucharest protest. Similar demonstrations have been reported in Brasov, Romania's second-largest city, and Timisoara, where the uprising against Ceausescu began. Roman, a professor of hydraulic engineering before the revolution, said he expects the Front to win a majority in the new parliament and Iliescu to be chosen as president. Tens of thousands of people have attended campaign rallies for the two men outside Bucharest, chanting slogans for the Front. Whether to accept people with Communist backgrounds into the new governments being debated throughout the former Soviet bloc. The debate has all but paralyzed society in Romania, where many in the opposition feel the ideals of the revolution are being betrayed. The Front, a loose assocation of technocrats, intellectuals and Communists opposed to Ceausescu, seized power by proclamation just after the dictator tried to flee Dec. 22. He was executed three days later. Under pressure from opposition parties and street demonstrators, the Front agreed in January to share power in a provisional legislature, whose enactments included a new election law. Opponents accuse the Front of failing to dismiss former members of Ceausescu's dreaded Securitate secret police from key positions in ministerial bureaucracies. Roman said there were ``no more than 1,000 Communists in the country'' at the time of the revolution. ``Communism is dead in all of eastern Europe,'' he said. ``It brought no benefits _ not economic, not social, not even moral.'' The prime minister's father, Walter Roman, was among the few genuine Communists in Romania before World War II and fought in the Spanish civil war, where he met and married Petre's mother, Hortensia. Petre Roman's relative obscurity before becoming premier, his Communist background and reluctance to endorse free-market economics have contributed to suspicions about his plans. In the interview, Roman said choices are limited in Romania's shattered economy, which has little chance of providing better living standards soon. ``I am not for savage liberalism,'' he said. ``I favor a transition to a market ... with an important social protection program such as in France, Sweden, but within the limits of an economy that is profitable for a free- market point of view.''

DOC.HEAD: Female Midshipman Resigns After Being Handcuffed to Urinal
DOC.TEXT: A female midshipman was dragged from her dormitory room, handcuffed to a urinal and taunted by male midshipmen in what Naval Academy officials said was a ``good-natured exchange'' that got out of hand. Gwen Marie Dreyer resigned after the December incident, and the midshipmen involved were punished with demerits and a loss of leave time. ``We still don't believe that they understand that it was in fact an assault,'' said Carolyn A. Dreyer, her stepmother. ``An assault. And it would have been treated that way in any other school, in any other situation.'' But academy officials ruled that the incident began as a friendly encounter that got out of hand after a snowball fight and therefore couldn't be considered premeditated hazing, which can lead to dismissal. ``We take this kind of thing extremely seriously,'' said Academy Superintendent Virgil L. Hill Jr. ``Admittedly the incident grew out of a good-natured exchange between friends. None of that takes away from the fact that they overstepped bounds and her end feeling was humiliation. That's sexual harassment. We don't allow that.'' Dreyer, who was photographed while handcuffed to the urinal, was eventually freed by her roommates. In her letter of resignation last month, Dreyer said resentment expressed toward women at the academy crushes their spirits. ``I understand that steps are now being taken to correct some very serious human relations problems,'' she wrote. ``However, after what I've been through and have seen, not only because of what has happened to me personally, I have decided to leave.'' She plans to study engineering at California State Polytechnic Institute in San Luis Obispo. Two midshipmen were punished with demerits and loss of leave time. Six other midshipmen received written warnings for lesser roles in the incident. Hill said the incident was an isolated one, but Dreyer's father and another academy graduate said it shows the academy still has not resolved resentment of women at the academy, which first allowed women in 1976. About 10 percent of the 4,000 midshipmen at the academy are women. ``Something needs to be done to change the attitudes of the macho guys who just don't want women at that school,'' said Gregory Dreyer, a 1967 academy graduate. Hill said attitudes take a long time to change, but his administration has made strides toward complete assimilation of women. ``There are problems, I won't deny that,'' Hill said. ``But in the overall, the system works.'' Lt. Barbette Lowndes, a 1980 academy graduate polling women in the military, disagreed. ``There still are large cliques of men who want to make it a men's school again,'' she said. ``They ignore you, keep you isolated, just let you know that you're not wanted. It's more mental abuse.'' Gregory Dreyer said his daughter was intimidated by classmates who warned her not to testify at a disciplinary hearing. ``She was told her life would be made miserable,'' he said. A 1987 study found that about 35 percent of the women enrolled at Annapolis eventually left, compared with 22 percent for men. The gap was the widest of any at the three major military academies.

DOC.HEAD: School's First Integrated Prom at Gets High Marks
DOC.TEXT: Blacks and whites mingled at Peach County High School's first integrated prom, and many of the nearly 200 students said the change was long overdue. ``Somebody is going to come along every time and break some tradition that's really stupid, some tradition you don't really think about because you've always done it,'' said Hope Bickley, a white 17-year-old at the dance Saturday. ``I'm glad it was our class that broke it.'' Ato Crumbly, a black student, agreed. ``We go to school together, play football together, run track together, so why can't we socialize together?'' Crumbly said Saturday at the formal dance in the school gym. All school dances and parties were canceled by the school board in the early 1960s when a student apparently was injured during a prom. Board members also said planning the dances took time away from schoolwork. Nearly 20 years ago, the school was desegregated. But without a school-sponsored prom, parents began organizing their own _ one for blacks, one for whites. ``I go out of town a lot in the summer, to Las Vegas and California,'' Crumbly said. ``I'd tell about the prom and they'd say `What?' And they'd ask, `Do y'all still have to drink out of separate fountains?'' Three years ago, Peach County's parent-teacher group tried to change the board's policy. The board rejected the group's request for a school-sponsored prom. Last year, the board changed its position, and Saturday's integrated prom was held without incident. Susan Jordan, president of the parent-teacher group, said the students set an example for the community. ``A child shall lead them,'' she said. ``Well, in this case, a group of children shall perhaps lead the community, and won't that be great? And isn't it about time?''

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: Researchers at the University of Chicago have found many things over the years _ the speed of light, the controlled nuclear chain reaction and the treasures of ancient Persepolis. Over the weekend, about 1,300 young scholars sought ``finds'' of a different kind in the school's fourth annual Scavenger Hunt. The students came up with items ranging from ``1,000 points of light'' to human bologna sandwiches. The hunt determined ``how low people would go,'' said Steve Kornya, a senior from Huntsville, Ala. ``When it comes to crunch time and you need points, is somebody willing to smear himself with a couple quarts of condiments and lunch meat?'' At least eight students were willing. They wrapped themselves in five loaves of bread, 16 ounces of mayonnaise, an 8-ounce jar of mustard and a pound or so of bologna each. Students had 72 hours, from Thursday to Sunday, to assemble the objects, performances and answers to questions on the 303-item list. An item asking for ``your mother wearing combat boots (with ID)'' produced one mother, by plane, from Minnesota, said Michael Sherman, a junior from Albany, N.Y. Many fulfilled the 1,000 points of light requirement by puncturing holes in a piece of paper and shining a light bulb behind it. The $500 first prize was shared by a group of 40 dormitory students, one of whom had stripped and wore a skirt made of yellow Post-it notes stuck together.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Gains Against Euro Currencies but Not Yen; Gold Up
DOC.TEXT: The dollar gained against key Europen currencies today but continued to slip against the yen. Gold rose in thin trading. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 153.35 yen, down 0.80 yen from its finish Friday. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 153.25 yen. Dealers said the dollar's level was due partly to U.S. government reports indicating inflationary pressures had been curbed. Inflation tends to push up interest rates, making the dollar more attractive to investors. Buy orders for the dollar appeared in today's trading, but the upswing did not affect the dollar's overall downward trend, said Masato Nakamura, a currency dealer for Sumitomo Bank. Other dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Friday: _ 1.6434 West German marks, up from 1.6300 _ 1.4005 Swiss francs, up from 1.3955 _ 5.5390 French francs, up from 5.5096 _ 1.8478 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8330 _ 1,210.00 Italian lire, up from 1,200.40 _ 1.1770 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1783 The British pound traded at $1.6797, down from $1.6817 late Friday. Gold dealers in London fixed a recommended price of $368.30 an ounce today, from $369.05 bid late Friday. In Zurich, gold opened at a bid of $367.20, down from $368.80 bid late Friday. In Hong Kong, gold closed at $369.10 an ounce, down 97 cents from Saturday. Silver bullion was quoted in London at a bid price of $5.06 an ounce, unchanged from late Friday.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. and Iran Sign $105 Million Settlement Accord
DOC.TEXT: The United States and Iran have signed a $105 million settlement of some 3,000 financial claims, bringing the two countries one step closer to re-establishing economic relations, a U.S. official said today. The settlement deals primarily with so-called ``Small Claims'' for under $250,000 that stem from the 1979 Islamic revolution, said the official, speaking on condition of anonymity. It clears the way for the Iran-United States Claims Tribunal to deal with about $16 billion in major claims, whose resolution in turn could open the way to normalizing economic ties between the two nations, the official said. The settlement accord was signed late Sunday night or early this morning by Timothy Ramish, U.S. agent to the tribunal, and Iranian Agent Ali Nobari, according to the American official at the tribunal. The most recent settlement talks between U.S. and Iranian officials occurred shortly after the release of American hostages Frank Reed and Robert Polhill by pro-Iranian kidnappers in Lebanon. But U.S. and Iranian representatives to the tribunal have repeatedly stated the talks dealt only with financial arbitration and not with the six remaining Americans still in captivity in Lebanon. Last week a U.S. State Department official in Washington, who commented on condition of anonymity, said he could not predict whether resolving its financial disputes will result in the release of remaining hostages or was in any way related to the release of Polhill and Reed. The Small Claims package dealt primarily with Americans who left behind personal possessions or were owed salaries by Iranian companies when they fled Iran during the revolution. They were settled for a total of $50 million. The settlement also provided $55 million for repayment of a loan from the U.S. Agency for International Development. The tribunal was set up as part of the Algiers Accord of 1980, which resulted in freedom for the American hostages held by Iranian militants at the U.S. embassy in Tehran for 444 days. The tribunal has three Iranian, three American and three third-nation arbitrators. The biggest claim still before the tribunal, valued at up to $11 billion by Iran, is for military equipment which Iran ordered but did not receive as a result of the embargo imposed by the U.S. government. After the overthrow of Shah Mohammad Reza Pahlavi in 1979, Iran canceled contracts for $9 billion worth of weaponry, including four destroyers under construction that were later taken over by the U.S. Navy. Remaining major claims, totaling about $5 billion, were filed by American oil companies for property and operations expropiated by the Iranian government, as well as for broken contracts.

DOC.HEAD: Government Promises Jobs, Kashmiris Demand Freedom
DOC.TEXT: The government's top troubleshooter handling the Moslem secessionist movement came to Kashmir over the weekend offering jobs. But his audience demanded nothing less than freedom from Indian rule. The chasm between the people of Kashmir and the central government in New Delhi cannot be easily bridged today. Now, four decades of pent-up feelings among Kashmir's Moslem majority have finally exploded into a bloody separatist movement for an Islamic state. George Fernandes, minister for Kashmiri affairs in the 6-month-old government of Prime Minister V.P. Singh, spoke earnestly of the need to right economic wrongs to pacify a people whose sentiments he says have been hijacked by a few radical separatists. But the men and women who crowded around him Saturday in the city of Anantnag weren't interested in economics. Sometimes angrily, sometimes tearfully, they demanded the release of sons and husbands detained by Indian security forces on suspicion of belonging to militant groups that kill government employees, military men and suspected informers. The deployment of tens of thousands of security troops and the arrests of hundreds of people have galvanized the public as never before against what Kashmiri Moslems now routinely describe as ``Indian occupation.'' In Anantnag and Srinagar, summer capital of Jammu-Kashmir state and heart of the secessionist movement, men and women, without bidding, pull up sleeves and tunics to reveal deep bruises, gashes and sometimes bullet wounds they say were inflicted by Indian security forces. When Fernandes arrived in Anantnag, 34 miles southeast of Srinagar Saturday, about 100 men, women and children greeted him with a chant: ``What do we want? We want freedom.'' Fernandes, a silver-haired socialist and former labor leader, settled into a chair in front of the government guesthouse and began hearing grievances in an effort to persuade Kashmiris that the Indian government cares about them. A young woman, concealed by a black Islamic veil from the top of her head to the knees of her baggy pantaloons, said one of her brothers had been taken away by security troops and a second had gone into hiding for fear he, too, would be arrested. ``We will take up guns here,'' she cried. Stories tumbled over each other in a cacophony of complaints against the Indian army and the paramilitary Central Reserve Police Force which have been deployed in Kashmir since the government's latest _ and harshest _ crackdown started Jan. 20. At least 368 people have been killed so far. ``At midnight they came and my son was taken naked,'' said Raja Begum. ``His was the only earning hand in my family. I have had four operations and cannot even work in the fields.'' She said her son, Kurshid Ahmad, was detained 10 days ago and she still had no word of his whereabouts. It is impossible to say which accounts are accurate. Anantnag has long been a bulwark of support for the separatists and is the home of one of their top leaders, Shabir Shah, jailed since March. Fernandes, who has made a half-dozen trips to Kashmir in the past four months, said he believed that by offering jobs the government could regain the support of the majority of people in this scenic valley. Tourism has long been the economic mainstay of Kashmir, but the tourist trade has all but vanished due to the unrest. Asked about allegations of brutality, Fernandes said: ``I don't blame the security forces. In this sort of situation, many things can happen.'' The Kashmir conflict stems from the region's division along a still-disputed frontier between India and predominantly Moslem Pakistan after the two countries were partitioned along religious lines in gaining independence from Britain in 1947.
