Kashmir was mainly Moslem, but its Hindu ruler opted to join India instead of Pakistan. The two countries went to war over Kashmir in 1948 and 1965. Today, the Indian-governed part of Kashmir is incorporated into the state of Jammu-Kashmir, the only one in India with a Moslem majority. Sixty-four percent of Jammu-Kashmir's 6 million people are Moslems, but nationwide Moslems account for only 12 percent of India's 880 million population.

DOC.HEAD: Baby Sitter Suspect in Boy's Death and Sex Attacks of Three Girls
DOC.TEXT: A partially blind baby sitter stabbed himself in the stomach after killing an 11-year-old boy and sexually assaulting three girls, authorities said. Lenard Johnson, 37, was hospitalized under police guard Sunday in serious condition with an apparent self-inflicted knife wound to the stomach and cuts to his wrist and head, said Lt. David Andrews of the Montgomery County Sheriff's Department. Montgomery County State's Attorney Kathryn Dobrinic said she has not determined what charges to file against Johnson, but she is ``certain they will include a first-degree murder charge.'' She said in a telephone interview that prosecutors may seek the death penalty. The slain boy, Donald L. Buske, was stabbed twice in the neck in the attack early Saturday morning, said Montgomery County Coroner Rick Broaddus. Reports conflicted about whether the girls _ ages 7, 11 and 13 _ remained at St. Francis Hospital for observation or had been released. Nursing supervisor Vicki Holzhausen referred all calls to the state's attorney's office early today. The boy and the 7-year-old girl were siblings, and the two other girls had been visiting them for the night. Johnson lived two blocks from the house where the attacks occurred, said Dobrinic. The incident began Friday night after the Buske children's mother, Susan Emerson, and her husband, James, went out for the night, leaving the children with Johnson. When James Emerson later took Johnson back to his own home, Susan Emerson's 7-year-old daughter told her mother that she had been assaulted, authorities said. The Emersons took the girl to St. Francis Hospital, instructing the remaining children to lock the house and admit no one, according to police. After the parents left, Johnson sneaked back to the house, tore open a screen and lifed a front window to enter, authorities said. Once inside, Johnson allegedly killed the boy, then assaulted the two girls, isolating himself in the bathroom with them briefly after police arrived. When the standoff ended about 15 minutes later, police said they found Johnson suffering from stab wounds to the abdomen, neck and wrists.

DOC.HEAD: Gubernatorial Primary Focused on Abortion
DOC.TEXT: Anti-abortion Gov. Robert P. Casey faces a pro-choice lawyer Tuesday in a Democratic primary hinged largely on one issue _ abortion. Casey's Democratic primary opponent, Philip Berg, has spent $35,000 on radio advertising focused on the incumbent's opposition to abortion rights. ``I believe that this primary election will be decided by voters who will choose to reaffirm individual rights,'' Berg said. ``By spending money to help voters identify the one candidate who holds those rights sacred, I am affirming the right of all Americans to have the right to choose,'' he said. Casey, 58, and his running mate, incumbent Lt. Gov. Mark Singel, 36, prefer to dwell on his administration's efforts to battle drugs, boost economic development and clean up the environment. Casey was first elected in 1986 after three unsuccessful runs for governor and is seeking a second term. Berg, 45, a former Democratic Party chairman in Montgomery County, is running with Edward Mezvinsky, 53, a former state party chairman. State Auditor General Barbara Hafer and Marguerite Luksik are running for governor in the Republican primary. Hafer, 46, is running as a pro-choice Republican. She has aimed her campaign at Casey. Mrs. Luksik, 34, opposes abortion rights. Mrs. Luksik, a homemaker and executive director of Mom's House, a child care center with tutoring and counseling for single parents who return to school, has focused her campaign on abortion. Karen Chandler, a campaign spokeswoman for Casey, said the governor's accomplishments have not been outshined by the hammering on abortion. ``We've seen no indication throughout the campaign that the kind of single-issue hammering being done by Berg and Mezvinsky is having any kind of effect on people's impressions of what the governor has accomplished in the last three and a half years,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Talks On U.S. Bases Open, One Day After Slaying of Two U.S. Airmen
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with rally in Angeles City; Pickup 5th pvs, `U.S. and...'; INSERT 1 graf after 16th, `In Manila...' to ADD details of rally in city; EDITS to tighten. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MLA8
DOC.TEXT: Negotiators began talks today on the future of U.S. military bases in this country, a day after suspected Communist guerrillas shot and killed two American servicemen near one of the installations. Truncheon-wielding police fired tear gas at hundreds of anti-base protesters during running confrontations through the streets of the capital. At least 42 people were arrested and five hospitalized, witnesses and police said. Protesters, mostly students, retaliated by throwing small homemade bombs at police. Rallies were held throughout the day and security was tight for the talks, which opened at the Central Bank building with about 500 police on hand. Five truckloads of riot police were deployed before the gate at Clark Air Base as about 400 base opponents rallied in nearby Angeles City. U.S. and Philippine officials had expressed fears that the Communist New People's Army would try to kill Americans before the talks on extending the lease on Clark and Subic Bay naval base as well as four smaller facilities. The lease is set to expire Sept. 16, 1991. As the talks opened, the chief U.S. negotiator condemned the killings of two U.S. airmen near Clark on Sunday and assailed the ``banditry'' of Communist rebels, blamed by authorities for the attack. ``This brutal and clumsy attempt to drive a wedge between the United States and the Philippines will fail,'' said Richard Armitage, a former assistant secretary of defense. Police Capt. Gener Manguni said it appeared the rebels were responsible for the killings because of the style of the attack. Two or three Filipinos approached the Americans and shot them in the back of their heads with .45-caliber pistols, the rebels' favored weapon in street killings. The dead servicemen were identified by Air Force officials as Airman John H. Raven, 19, of Delta Junction, Alaska, and Airman James C. Green, 20, of Craig, Colo. A companion, Airman 1st Class Randall Moore, 23, managed to escape. They were among 280 airmen and support personnel assigned to the 8th Aircraft Generation Squadron on temporary duty from Kunsan Air Base, 110 miles south of Seoul, South Korea. Police rounded up more than 200 people for questioning in the attack but no charges were filed. The Navy banned off-post leave for the 40,000 troops, Defense Department civilians and military dependents at U.S. installations in the Philippines. Eight Americans have died in politically motivated slayings in the Phillipines since April 1989. The rebels made no claim of responsibility for Sunday's killings. But in a media statement the New People's Army denounced the bases talks. ``The NPA pledges that all its territorial and unit commands, all officers and men, will carry out their mission to the last man if necessary, of expelling U.S. imperialism out of our country,'' the statement said. In Manila, about 3,000 militant workers gathered in a city square as speakers denounced the bases. ``Americans must be driven away,'' Crispin Beltran, chairman of the May First Movement, a labor federation, told the crowd. ``And those who refuse must be buried here.'' Later, the group tried to march to the U.S. Embassy but was blocked by police. The protesters placed a plywood placard bearing a base ``eviction notice'' on a traffic island in front of the embassy. President Corazon Aquino told reporters the government was taking ``all necessary measures'' to protect Americans but ``we cannot guarantee a 100 percent, fail-safe protection. No government can.'' She has refused to say whether she will agree to extend the lease for the bases, among the largest outside the United States. Armitage said the bases help provide stability in the Far East but that the United States would leave if Filipinos wanted the installations closed. ``If you ask us to leave, leave we shall, as expeditiously as possible and with our pride fully intact,'' Armitage said. ``If we do not truly believe that there exists a compelling mutual interest between the Philippines and the United States, then we have precious little to discuss other than the terms of an amicable separation.'' Stanley Schrager, spokesman for the U.S. panel, said security for Americans would also be high on the agenda during the first round of talks. The Municipal Mayors League of the Philippines today presented Mrs. Aquino with a copy of a resolution approved last March endorsing retention of the bases. The league said the installations contributed to the nation's economy as well as regional security. But opposition to the bases has been increasing because a growing number of Filipinos believe they infringe on national sovereignty. Criticism intensified after Congress cut $96 million from the Bush administration's request for aid to Manila. In 1988, the Reagan administration pledged $962 million over two years to keep the bases through 1991. Philippine officials consider the congressional cutbacks a breach of that agreement. Foreign Secretary Raul Manglapus, chief Philippine delegate, cited the shortfall and urged Washington to provide more aid. The talks are considered exploratory. Afterward, the two sides will decide whether to enter formal negotiations. Any agreement must be ratified by two-thirds of the 23-member Philippine Senate, where opposition to the bases is strong.

DOC.HEAD: Flooding Continues in Louisiana, Cool Temperatures in East
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf after 4th graf, `Thunderstorms spawned...', to add tornado damage in Pennsylvania. Picks up 5th graf, `Snow was...'.
DOC.TEXT: Thunderstorms ushered in cool weather in the East and the north-central United States today after a round of tornadoes in the Plains and more flooding in the South. Rain fell early today in Minneapolis-St. Paul and in Anchorage, Alaska. Boston had drizzle. Louisiana braced for the worst flooding in 45 years and more flooding was expected in Texas and Arkansas. Heavy weekend rain worsened the flood threat in Louisiana as the Red River continued to rise from Shreveport to Alexandria. Thunderstorms spawned tornadoes Sunday in Nebraska, Wyoming, Kansas, Maryland, North Carolina and Pennsylvania. A tornado caused heavy damage to a shopping center and an apartment complex in Newberry Township in eastern Pennsylvania. The National Weather Service also said 12 houses were damaged about 10 miles south of Harrisburg. No injuries were reported. Snow was predicted today in the Cascade Mountains of Oregon, and high wind was expected in Arizona. Sunday's thunderstorms were scattered in Colorado, Wyoming and South Dakota and rain extended from Minnesota to Wyoming, where snow fell in higher elevations. The central Gulf Coast, Maryland and parts of Florida and North Carolina also were hit by thunderstorms Sunday. Temperatures early today were in the 40s in portions of the West and Midwest and in the 50s in parts of New England. The nation's high Sunday was 101 degrees in the Texas towns of Cotulla and Laredo. DOC.HEAD: Population Growth Makes Coasts Vulnerable to Hurricane Disaster
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 2 grafs background after 13th graf pvs, Strong storms ...; picks up 14th graf pvs, While Florida's...
DOC.TEXT: Millions more Americans are exposed to hurricanes as the population grows in the Southeast and Gulf states, and meteorologists worry that these new residents may underestimate the dangers they could face. The entire region from Texas to North Carolina has experienced sharp growth in recent years _ a period that has averaged relatively few hurricanes. That means many coastal residents have never experienced a major storm. Emergency management officials say they fear that when a major storm does threaten, people will underestimate the danger and delay evacuation or fail to leave at all. ``We are more vulnerable to hurricanes in the United States now than we have ever been in our history,'' said the American Meteorological Society in a special statement of concern adopted a couple of years ago. ``It is imperative that coastal residents and visitors alike take the threat seriously, acquaint themselves with hurricane safety rules, and evacuate immediately if advised to do so,'' said Robert Sheets, director of the National Hurricane Center in Coral Gables, Fla. As it is, the population in many regions _ such as the New Orleans area _ now exceeds the number that could be safely evacuated in the time available, officials said. ``Some evacuation times for high-density coastal populations are much larger than the amount of time that we can reasonably give a decent warning,'' said meteorologist Miles Lawrence of the Hurricane Center. Florida's Atlantic coast tops the region with 2,075 people per shoreline mile, up from 824 per mile in 1960, according to a new study from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. About one-third of the residents in the Southeast region _ from Texas to North Carolina _ are considered coastal in the NOAA study, including the entire population of Florida. June 1 marks the official start of hurricane season for the Southeast, and the danger period extends to autumn. ``Overall, there have been less hurricanes in the last 20 years than prior to that,'' noted Lawrence, adding that ``southeast Florida has not had a direct hit by a Category 3 or higher (storm) since 1965.'' Strong storms have struck in recent years in South Carolina and Texas, however, he said. Hurricanes are graded on a scale of 1 to 5, with 5 the strongest. Last year's Hurricane Hugo killed 29 people and did an estimated $5.9 billion in damage in South Carolina. The storm also inflicted serious damage on adjacent states as well as the Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico. Advance warning, however, allowed people to be evacuated from many coastal islands and low-lying regions. While Hugo is reportedly the most expensive hurricane in U.S. history, it is far from the deadliest. That occurred in 1900 when a storm arriving with little warning drove a wall of water over Galveston, Texas, killing an estimated 6,000 people. While Florida's East Coast is the most densely populated area where hurricanes post the greatest threat, all areas seem to be growing rapidly. Texas' coastal counties average 1,517 people per shore mile, up from 798 in 1960. Third is Florida's west coast, where the coastal population has risen from 433 per mile in 1960 to 1,064 currently, according to NOAA. Here is a rundown of the population in coastal states most threatened by hurricanes. It includes the percentage of the state's population considered coastal and the estimated number of people per shoreline mile in 1988 compared with 1960 and the projected population in the year 2010. _Florida (East Coast), 100 percent coastal; 2,075 people per shoreline mile, up from 824 in 1960, headed for 2,689 in 2010. _Florida (Gulf Coast), 100 percent coastal; 1,064 per mile; up from 433, headed for 1,411. _Texas, 31 percent coastal; 1,517 per shoreline mile, up from 798, headed for 1,956. _Mississippi, 13 percent coastal; 928 per mile, up from 527, headed for 1,102. _Alabama, 12 percent coastal; 800 per mile, up from 599, headed for 886. _Louisiana, 62 percent coastal; 352 per mile, up from 248, headed for 420. _South Carolina, 25 percent coastal, 303 per mile, up from 176, headed for 365. _North Carolina, 11 percent coastal, 202 per mile, up from 140, headed for 234. _Georgia, 6 percent coastal, 158 per mile, up from 114, headed for 179.

DOC.HEAD: Three Arrested in Alleged White Supremacist Bomb Plot
DOC.TEXT: Three men affiliated with an Idaho white-supremacist group were arrested hours before they had planned to stage a bombing attack on minorities or homosexuals, the FBI sasid. Two of the men were arrested in the Seattle area Saturday, FBI agent Steven Pomerantz said Sunday. The third man was arrested in Coeur d'Alene, Idaho. The men were held for investigation of conspiracy, illegal possession of firearms and possession of an explosive device. Pomerantz said the attack was to occur in Seattle ``directed against either members of a minority group or the homosexual community.'' Pomerantz refused to disclose details of the plot or its intended victims except to say it had been planned to take place within hours of the time the men were arrested. He said agents made the arrests before the men were able to assemble the bomb. John Winslow, 29, of LaClede, Idaho, and Stephen E. Nelson, 35, of Hayden Lake, Idaho, were arrested as they emerged from a van. They were to appear before a U.S. magistrate in Seattle today. The third man, James P. Baker, was to appear in court in Idaho. The three are associated with the white supremacist group Aryan Nations, based in Hayden Lake, Pomerantz said. The group, led by 72-year-old founder and pastor Richard Butler, has preached a goal of white supremacy and has vowed to establish a whites-only homeland in the Northwest. A search of the van turned up a 6-inch pipe, smokeless gunpowder, a coil of primer fuse, a propane cylinder, a 12-gauge shotgun, a .38-caliber revolver, a ``stun gun,'' knives, hate literature and other items, the FBI said.

DOC.HEAD: Suspect Captured In Slayings of Two Chicago Police Officers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with three grafs to UPDATE with charges filed and recovery of weapon used in killings. Picks up 4th graf, `Police said...'.
DOC.TEXT: A man suspected of killing two policemen sent to quell a family dispute was arrested early today during a search by more than 100 officers using dogs, authorities said. Roman Chavez, 23, was charged with two counts of murder and one count of armed robbery, said James Fruin at the Grand Central police district. Chavez is accused in the late Sunday slayings of 20-year officers Gregory A. Hauser, 43, and Raymond C. Kilroy, 47. Chavez was captured about 3 a.m. after a five-hour search in the northwest side neighborhood where the shootings took place. Police recovered the weapon believed used in the killings. Fruin said the revolver belonged to one of the slain officers. Police said the officers had answered a complaint of a dispute between Chavez and his grandmother. The policemen had called for backup officers and a squadrol, or paddy wagon, said police Superintendent LeRoy Martin. ``When the squadrol got there they found them dead,'' Martin said. ``It seems that they were hit and knocked off their feet, and then shot in the head.'' Kilroy died at Illinois Masonic Hospital of gunshot wounds to the chest and the back of his head, said a nursing supervisor who would not give her name. Hauser died at Lutheran General Hospital in suburban Park Ridge from four gunshot wounds, said spokeswoman Laurel Stevens. A woman identified as Chavez's grandmother was taken in for questioning. Her name was withheld.

DOC.HEAD: Court Refuses to Let Dtates Sue Asbestos Manufacturers in High Court
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today refused to let 30 states sue 26 manufacturers in the nation's highest court over removal of asbestos from public schools and other government buildings. The court, without comment, refused to hear arguments that the manufacturers should pay for such removal. Today's action does not preclude the 30 states from suing asbestos manufacturers in their respective state courts. But the states first went to the justices, hoping to head off a competition among themselves for monetary damages from the asbestos makers. In an unsual move, the states asked the court to invoke its ``original jurisdiction'' so this big-stakes dispute could be consolidated and resolved before any lower court considers it. The request was denied. Asbestos has been used for decades in the construction of buildings and ships. The inhalation of asbestos fibers has been linked to various diseases. Tens of thousands of personal-injury lawsuits have been filed against asbestos manufacturers by shipyard workers. Hundreds of asbestos-in-buildings suits also have been filed. The justices were told that eight states have sued asbestos makers in their state courts, seeking to have them pay the costs of removing the substance from public buildings. The eight states are Kentucky, Maryland, Minnesota, Mississippi, Pennsylvania, South Carolina, Virginia and West Virginia. In response to the request acted on today, lawyers for one asbestos maker, W.R. Grace & Co., said, ``There is no national or even interstate issue involved here. Plaintiffs may turn at any time to their own state courts as have their eight sister states.'' Lawyers for the company said the suggestion ``that only this court can equitably apportion defendants' assets and spare the states a race to judgment'' wrongly implies a preordained finding of liability. They quoted Environmental Protection Agency reports indicating that the presence of asbestos in a building does not mean the health of occupants is endangered if the asbestos-containing material remains in good condition and is unlikely to be disturbed. The states' request was prepared by Attorney General Kenneth Eikenberry of Washington state. The states were Washington, Alabama, Arizona, Arkansas, California, Connecticut, Delaware, Florida, Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Louisiana, Maine, Missouri, Montana, Nebraska, New Hampshire, New York, North Carolina, North Dakota, Ohio, Oklahoma, Rhode Island, South Dakota, Tennessee, Texas, Utah, Vermont and Wyoming. New Jersey subsequently asked the court to join the other states as a plaintiff. In addition to W.R. Grace, the named defendants were National Gypsum, U.S. Gypsum, USG Corp., American Biltrite, Armstrong World Industries, Azrock Industries, Basic Inc., Carey-Canada, Celotex, Certainteed Corp., Crown Cork & Seal, Eagle-Pitcher Industries, Fibreboard Corp., Flintkote, GAF, Georgia-Pacific, H.K. Porter Co., Keene Corp., Kentile Floors, Owens-Corning Fiberglass, Owens-Illinois, Pfizer, Raymark Industries, Sprayed Insulation Inc. and Turner & Newall. The case is Alabama vs. W.R. Grace, 116 Original.

DOC.HEAD: Demjanjuk Appeals Conviction For War Crimes
DOC.TEXT: The trial judges who convicted retired Ohio autoworker John Demjanjuk of killing Jews at a World War II death camp were biased, his attorney said today in court arguments appealing the war crimes conviction. In April 1988, a three-judge panel found that Demjanjuk was a brutal guard known as ``Ivan the terrible,'' who operated gas chambers at the Treblinka death camp in Poland from 1942 to 1943. More than 850,000 Jews died there. Demjanjuk, 70, was sentenced to death under a 1950 Israeli law allowing prosecution of Nazis and their collaborators. The Ukrainian-born Demjanjuk has maintained he is a victim of mistaken identity and that he was incarcerated in German POW camps during the period in question. Speaking before a five-justice Supreme Court panel, Demjanjuk's Israeli attorney, Yoram Sheftel, said he disputed the conviction on 10 points. The most significant, Sheftel said, was ``the bias of the court.'' ``It should lead to the clear conclusion that the conviction should be canceled and especially in a case where the sentence is capital punishment,'' he said. Sheftel argued at length about what he said was a hostile atmosphere created by news reports and the judges' treatment of the defense during the 17-month trial. He claimed the trial judges _ Dov Levine, Dalia Dorner and Shmuel Tal _subscribed to a clipping service that twice daily delivered reports from newspapers. He also asserted the judges briefed reporters on occasion. He said biased reporting ``clearly had a great deal of influence on the court. Sometimes I thought I wasn't sitting in a court but at Bloomfield,'' a football stadium near Tel Aviv, said Sheftel. He said there were frequent shouts and interruptions from the audience at the trial, which was held in a converted movie theater. ``Not only was an appearance of justice lacking but justice in fact was not done,'' said Sheftel. He said the judges repeatedly interrupted defense cross-examinations and intervened frequently in the proceedings. Throughout the proceedings, Demjanjuk, wearing a dark brown prison uniform, listened impassively from a witness stand, guarded by two policemen. He muttered ``good morning'' in Hebrew as he entered the courtroom wearing handcuffs and then embraced his son, John Jr. Demjanjuk's wife, Vera, also was present and refused to speak to reporters. Prosecutor Yonah Blattman interrupted Sheftel once in the first five hours of arguments. Blattman said Sheftel's bases for claiming bias ``are not legal or factual arguments and are not worthy of being brought before the court.' Chief Justice Meir Shamgar overruled the objection. Sheftel also challenged Israel's jurisdiction to try Demjanjuk as a war criminal. He noted Israel's extradition treaty with the United States, and that the warrant under which Demjanjuk was deported allowed for trying a suspect on murder charges but not genocide or mass murder. Demjanjuk was extradited from his home in Cleveland, Ohio, in February 1986 after an Ohio court stripped him of his citizenship for lying about his Nazi past on immigration forms. Sheftel said he will argue eight other points in the coming five weeks of court sessions.

DOC.HEAD: Court Won't Revive Suit Challenging Libya Raid
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today refused to revive a lawsuit accusing the Reagan administration of unlawfully bombing Libya in 1986 with help from Great Britain. The court, without comment, let stand a ruling that threw out the suit and also ordered the Libyans and their lawyers _ including former Attorney General Ramsey Clark _ to pay penalties and the British government's legal costs. The suit first was dismissed by U.S. District Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson, who said it had ``no hope whatsoever of success.'' But Jackson did not assess penalties or court costs because, he said, the suit was not frivolous ``so much as it is audacious.'' The government of British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher then asked that it be reimbursed for legal fees and court costs, and the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals here agreed. The appeals court last September said the Libyans' lawyers must have known the suit was hopeless but went through with it ``as a public statement of protest.'' The appeals court said since the case lacks legal merit, the Libyans and their attorneys must be penalized under court rules barring frivolous suits. The appeals court ordered them to pay $16,852 in legal fees and court costs, and sent the case back to Jackson to determine additional sanctions. Reagan administration officials, including former President Reagan, previously had dropped an appeal for such reimbursement and penalties. The Libyans' suit charged that the April 15, 1986, bombing raid violated principles of international law and numerous treaties and declarations. Mrs. Thatcher was sued for approving the use of U.S. military bases in Britain to launch the attacks. The suit said the Reagan administration's real purpose was to kill Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi and to ``terrorize Libyans by inflicting injury upon the civilian population ... to undermine support'' for Gadhafi. Reagan said the raid was in retaliation for anti-American attacks authorized by Gadhafi, including the bombing of a West Berlin discotheque frequented by U.S. servicemen that killed two and injured 150 others. Among the victims of the bombing raid was a 3-month-old girl who died when hit by shrapnel while asleep in her home in Benghazi. The child's 38-year-old father was also killed by shrapnel, according to the suit. Clark, attorney general under President Johnson, has been criticized in the past for dealing with nations hostile to the United States. In 1980 he attended a ``Crimes of America'' conference in Iran while American hostages were being held in Tehran. In 1972 he went to Hanoi to investigate the effects of U.S. bombing during the Vietnam War. The case is Saltany vs. Reagan, 89-1497.

DOC.HEAD: Thirteen in ``Pizza Connection'' Lose High Court Appeal
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today rejected appeals by 13 men convicted in the so-called pizza connection drug-trafficking conspiracy. The court, without comment, let stand a ruling that the men's rights were not violated in one of the longest and costliest trials in U.S. history. The 13 were convicted in New York City three years ago after a 17-month trial. They received sentences ranging from four to 45 years in prison. The government said the drug ring brought $1.6 billion worth of heroin and cocaine into the country from Turkey, Sicily and Brazil through a network of pizza parlors. The 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals upheld the convictions last October, although it expressed misgivings about the length and complexity of the trial. All told, there were 21 defendants in the case and numerous charges of conspiracy, racketeering, money laundering and other offenses on three continents dating back to the 1970s. Not all those convicted appealed to the 2nd Circuit court. The Supreme Court last February rejected a separate appeal by a 14th defendant, Filippo Casamento, who had been sentenced to 30 years. The main defendants included Gaetano Badalamenti, reputed former head of the Mafia in Sicily, and Salvatore Catalano, the mob's reputed New York boss. Each received a 45-year sentence. Also convicted were Giuseppe Lamberti, 30 years; Salvatore Greco, Salvatore Lamberti, Frank Castronovo and Salvatore Mazzurco, 20 years each; Giovanni Ligammari, 15 years; Giovanni Cangialosi and Emanuele Palazzolo, 12 years each; Salvatore Salamone and Giuseppe Vitale, five years each, and Lorenzo Devardo, four years. A 15th defendant, Francesco Polizzi, was sentenced to 20 years in prison but was not involved in the appeal acted on today. In their appeal, the 13 said their jury did not represent a fair cross-section of the community because it was drawn from people who were unemployed, retired or who held low-level jobs they could afford to leave for a long time. Moreover, the defendants' lawyers said, ``No jury, given this trial's length, complexity and subject matter, could have rendered a reliable verdict.'' The appeal also argued that the jurors were prejudiced by violent events outside the courtroom during the trial. One defendant was murdered during the proceedings; another was shot. One juror was excused after her daughter received a threatening telephone call. The case is Palazzolo vs. U.S., 89-1565.

DOC.HEAD: Business Inventories Unchanged in March
DOC.TEXT: Business inventories were unchanged in March after advancing during the two previous three months, the government reported today, while sales rose 0.6 percent for their third consecutive gain. The Commerce Department said inventories on shelves and backlots totaled a seasonally adjusted $794.0 billion after rising a revised 0.4 percent in February and 0.3 percent in January. Inventories in February originally were reported to have fallen 0.4 percent. Sales totaled a seasonally adjusted $539.1 billion following gains of 1.4 percent in February and 0.4 percent in January. The February increase first was reported to have been 1.3 percent. The March business activity produced a 1.47 ratio of inventories to sales, matching a 1.47 ratio in January 1989, which was the lowest since the current economic expansion began after the 1981-82 recession. The ratio means that it would take 1.47 months to exhaust inventories at the March pace. Rising sales and falling inventories is a sign of economic strength. If inventories were to rise excessively, it could mean cutbacks in production and a loss of jobs. For instance, the ratio peaked at 1.70 in October 1982 during the last recession. The inventory decline was centered in the manufacturing sector, where it fell 0.3 percent. Inventories edged up 0.3 percent at the retail level and 0.2 percent at the wholesale level. Sales, on the other hand, dropped 0.2 percent at the retail level. The Commerce Department reported last Friday that retail sales fell another 0.6 percent in April, the biggest plunge in six months. Manufacturing sales rose 1.1 percent and wholesale sales advanced 0.8 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Jordanian Forces Disperse March At Bridge Bordering Occupied West Bank
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to UPDATE with discrepancy in casualty toll; Pickup 3rd pvs, `Many of...'
DOC.TEXT: Police and troops backed by tanks hurled tear gas and fired in the air today to disperse thousands of demonstrators who tried to enter the Israeli-occupied West Bank during a pro-Palestinian march. Many teen-agers threw stones at the tanks and police, and hospital sources said at least 103 people were injured in the 90-minute clash. Later, however, Interior Minister Salem Masadeh said 52 were injured. There was no immediate explanation for the discrepancy. Many of the participants in the march collapsed on the ground as tear gas canisters exploded in the middle of the crowd, estimated at more than 20,000 people. The army and police had told the crowd to stop 700 yards from the bridge over the Jordan River that leads to the West Bank. But when the demonstrators arrived after a one-hour walk from Hajjaj City, three miles to the north, about 2,500 demonstrators tried to run toward the wooden bridge. Some protesters were only two yards away from the bridge when the policemen began firing their guns into the air and hurling tear gas. ``There was nothing else for us to do,'' said a riot policeman. ``We had to stop them by force. Otherwise, they would have penetrated into the Israeli side.'' Some of those injured appeared to have broken limbs, and a few were bleeding after being trampled in the stampede as hysterical crowds ran in all directions. Shuna Hospital sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said most of casualties were unconscious from inhaling tear gas, but they said there were no gunshot wounds. It was not clear if any of the estimated 700 policemen and 300 army soldiers was injured. Israel seized the West Bank from Jordan during the 1967 Middle East war, and a Palestinian uprising against the occupation has been simmering for 29 months. Palestinian flags, portraits of Palestinian figures and anti-American and anti-Israeli banners the demonstrators had waved during the march were left lying on the ground. The march was organized by 120 Arab unions and profession associations to mark the 42nd anniversary of the U.N. Partition Plan that sliced British-mandated Palestine into Jewish and Arab states. The participants included Jordanian citizens, Arab unionists, Jordanian Parliament members and scores of Palestinians who had been deported after Israel seized the West Bank. Roughly half of Jordan's 3.1 million population come from Palestinian families who fled or were driven out during the 1948 and 1967 Arab-Israeli wars. The demonstrators waved banners that said: ``America is the head of the snake.'' Other slogans read: ``American is the number one enemy of the Arabs as it is the strategic ally of the cancerous Zionist entity.'' The crowd chanted ``We want an independent Palestine state amd homes to shelter our childrens,'' as well as Palestinian songs. Many waved the four-color Palestinian flag and portraits of Khalil al-Wazir, deputy commander of the Palestine Liberation Organization who was killed by an Israeli commando unit in Tunis on April 16, 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Court Rules Price-Cutting Schemes Do Not Necessarily Violate Laws
DOC.TEXT: Price-cutting schemes that hurt a competitor's business do not necessarily violate federal antitrust laws, the Supreme Court ruled today. By a 7-2 vote, the justices killed a lawsuit against Atlantic Richfield Co. (ARCO) by independent gas stations in California and Washington state. The court said that only when a company's price-cutting can be proved to be ``predatory'' and harmful does it violate the Sherman Act, a major antitrust law. USA Petroleum Co., an independent oil dealer, accused ARCO of conspiring with ARCO gas station dealers to fix prices illegally to drive the smaller independents out of business. ARCO contended that its plan, lower gasoline prices to attract more customers and discontinuing credit card sales to save money, is legitimate. ARCO lawyers said the major company's share of the retail gas market in California and Washington was 10 to 12 percent in 1981 and increased to 14 to 16 percent in 1983 because of lower prices. A federal judge threw out the lawsuit, but the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals reinstated it in 1988. The appeals court said that even though there was no proof that ARCO engaged in predatory pricing, it still may have injured USA Petroleum in violation of federal antitrust law. Predatory pricing is defined as setting prices below the level necessary to sell a product at a profit or below an appropriate measure of the cost of producing the product. Writing for the high court today, Justice William J. Brennan said USA Petroleum had not suffered any ``antitrust injury.'' ``When a firm, or even a group of firms ... lowers prices but maintains them above predatory levels, the business lost by rivals cannot be viewed as an anticompetitive consequence,'' Brennan said. ``This is not an antitrust injury.'' Justices John Paul Stevens and Byron R. White dissented. The case is Atlantic Richfield vs. USA Petroleum, 88-1668.

DOC.HEAD: Calm Returns to Madagascar Capital After Failed Coup Attempt
DOC.TEXT: The capital of this Indian Ocean island nation was calm today after troops loyal to President Didier Ratsiraka crushed a coup attempt by armed rebels. The government said 13 dissidents were arrested Sunday after loyalist troops stormed the national radio station, which rebels had seized. Information Minister Jean-Claude Rahaga said in a statement late Sunday the dissidents ``were being interrogated and would appear in court.'' ``It is quite calm in the streets today. It seems it's all over,'' a U.S. Embassy official in Antananarivo said on condition of anonymity. Hospitals reported at least three people died and 15 were wounded by bullets and grenades in Sunday's fighting. Government officials had not confirmed the casualty figures. The rebels seized the station early Sunday and announced that Ratsiraka's government had been overthrown. Loyalist troops launched tear gas canisters into the station and exchanged gunfire with the dissidents, reportedly armed with automatic rifles, pistols and knives. Soldiers overpowered the rebels after a six-hour battle. The director of the radio network said eight employees taken hostage were freed by troops. No one died inside the station, he said. There were no reports of disturbances elsewhere on Sunday on the island nation of 10 million people. The rebels claimed to be members of a previously unknown group called the Republican Committee of Public Safety. Their political beliefs were unknown. It was the second time in a year that opponents of Ratsiraka had seized the state Radio Madagascar station. On July 14, 1989, six armed men took over the national radio and claimed the government had been toppled. However, government troops took back the station and there was no violence elsewhere. Ratsiraka has led Madagascar since he was installed by the military in June 1975. The country, which is off the east coast of Africa, gained independence from France in 1960. Ratsiraka was elected to seven-year presidential terms in 1975, 1982 and 1989. In last year's elections, the opposition charged fraud and demanded that Ratsiraka step down. In recent years, the president has modified his Marxist views and adopted free market economic policies. On Sunday the rebels broadcast an appeal urging people to rise against the government and demanding that retired Gen. Jean Rakotoharison, an opposition leader, be named president. The broadcast was cut off after about 45 minutes, and government forces surrounded the building. Witnesses said Rakotoharison joined a crowd of about 5,000 milling outside the radio station and declined the rebel offer. Gangs of youths roamed the streets later, setting two cars ablaze and hurling rocks through the windows of the Justice Ministry and the American Cultural Center, the U.S. Embassy official said. No Americans were injured, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Court Refuses to Consider Increasing Judgment Against Hare Krishnas
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today refused to consider increasing a $5 million judgment that the justices were told already threatens to destroy the Hare Krishna religion. The court, without comment, rejected an appeal in which a California woman sought to have restored millions of dollars in damages a jury awarded her. The award was reduced by appeals courts and now, with interest, totals about $5 million. The justices today took no definitive action on the religious sect's still-pending appeal of rulings that, if left standing, could force the sale of five Hare Krishna temples across the country and in Canada. Lawyers for the Krishnas argue, among other things, that the California court judgment violates the church's religious freedom. Various corporate entities of the International Society of Krishna Consciousness and two Krishna officials were sued successfully by a mother and daughter, Marcia and Robin George of Cypress, Calif. Their 1977 lawsuit alleged that Robin had been brainwashed by the Krishnas when she was 14 and that Krishna leaders conspired to keep her away from her parents. A California jury in 1983 awarded the Georges $32.5 million in damages against the Krishnas, but the award was reduced on appeal to $2.9 million. With interest, the judgment today is estimated to be in excess of $5 million. A state judge has ordered that five Krishna temples already placed under court supervision, including the religion's headquarters in Los Angeles, be sold and the proceeds be paid to the Georges. The other temples are located in Southern California and the New York City area, according to David Liberman, a Los Angeles lawyer for the Krishnas. The sales presumably would be unnecessary if the judgment is paid before they occur. The state Supreme Court refused last November to review the award. Miss George and a friend, 16-year-old Caron Dempsey, visited a Hare Krishna temple in Laguna Beach, Calif., for the first time in 1974 at Miss Dempsey's suggestion. Miss Dempsey later decided to join the religious sect, and persuaded Miss George to attend meetings at the temple. By the fall of 1974, Miss George was wearing a sari while attending school and chanting and praying at a Hindu-style altar in her bedroom. According to court documents, a Krishna official told Miss George to leave her home and live at a temple. She did, spending time with Hare Krishnas in Laguna Beach, San Diego, New Orleans, Buffalo, N.Y., and Ottawa, Canada. The Georges' lawsuit alleged that Krishna officials conspired to keep Miss George from her parents, who learned of her whereabouts in late 1975 only after Miss Dempsey left the religion and told them. Lawyers for the Krishnas say the award won by the Georges amounts to religious bigotry. ``For the first time in this country since the anti-Mormon frenzy of the 19th Century, an entire religion stands subject to destruction and the confiscation of its property at the hands of the state,'' the sect's still-pending appeal says. It adds: ``The proceeding below turned into a trial of what (the Georges') counsel called the `pernicious evil' of the Krishna Consciousness religion, and ... the jury awarded damages ... calculated to bring the religion in this country to an end.'' The case acted on today is Robin George vs. International Society of Krishna Consciousness, 89-1398.

DOC.HEAD: Court Upholds Dismissal of Suit Over Alexander Book
DOC.TEXT: A New York City psychologist who says author Shana Alexander's 1985 book ``Nutcracker'' falsely accused him of having sexual intimacy with a patient failed today in Supreme Court bid to reinstate his libel lawsuit. The justices, without comment, let stand state court rulings that dismissed Herman Weiner's suit. Ms. Alexander's non-fiction book explored the Salt Lake City murder of Mormon millionaire Franklin Bradshaw, a crime for which Bradshaw's 17-year-old grandson Marc Schreuder was convicted. Based on the youth's trial testimony, his mother Frances Bradshaw Schreuder was convicted of masterminding her father's murder. Both are imprisoned. As described in court documents, the book delves into the Bradshaw family's history of emotional disturbance. It purportedly portrays Mrs. Schreuder as a person whose deep emotional disturbances were manifested in child abuse, persistent lying and two stormy, broken marriages. Mrs. Schreuder was a patient of Weiner's for about three years in the 1960s and in 1982. He testified on her behalf during a divorce and child custody proceeding in the mid-1960s. Many other psychologists and pyschiatrists treated Mrs. Schreuder. Weiner is mentioned in two paragraphs of ``Nutcracker.'' The second paragraph concludes by quoting someone who claimed, ``Frances always slept with her shrinks'' and stating that others ``suspected hanky panky.'' New York's highest court tossed out Weiner's suit against Ms. Alexander and the book's publisher, Doubleday & Co., last Dec. 14. The state court relied on a previous ruling in which it placed the burden on some libel plaintiffs to prove those sued ``acted in a grossly irresponsible manner without due consideration for the standards of information gathering and dissemination ordinarily followed by responsible parties.'' The state court said Weiner had not raised a ``triable issue ... as to ... gross irresponsibility.'' The case is Weiner vs. Doubleday & Co., 89-1420.

DOC.HEAD: Brain-Dead Woman's Heart Fails; Husband Objected to Respirator Turnoff
DOC.TEXT: A brain-dead woman's heart stopped beating this morning, hours before a hospital planned to disconnect her from a respirator over the objections of her husband. Isabel McFall, 56, had been unconscious since April 17, when a blood vessel burst in her brain. Officials at St. John Medical Center said declared her brain dead a week later. Her husband, Bill McFall, had picketed the hospital Sunday in protest of the hospital's plans to disconnect the life-support system this morning. He said he wanted his wife to remain on the respirator to give God time to work a miracle. Doctors said she met Oklahoma's criteria to be declared legally dead: no electrical or chemical activity was detectable in her brain. McFall said the hospital called him about 2:30 a.m. today and told him that his wife's heart had failed. ``God took her home. ... God knew there was just such a burden on the family. I was satisfied there was no chicanery and that God had performed his will,'' McFall said. Hospital spokesman Stephen Reynolds said her ``heart stopped beating spontaneously.'' Reynolds said McFall came to the hospital and agreed to disconnect the respirator. McFall had picketed the hospital on Sunday for about 45 minutes, carrying a sign reading, ``Execution, May 9th, 1990.'' The date apparently referred to the original deadline he believes doctors set for turning off the machine that circulated his wife's blood. Hospital officials contended Oklahoma statutes didn't require them to obtain McFall's consent to disconnect the machine, though Reynolds said doctors would have liked the family's approval. Reynolds said the only reason Mrs. McFall was not disconnected from life-support machines sooner was compassion for the family after McFall requested time to adjust.

DOC.HEAD: Bennett Says Drug Probmem May be Peaking
DOC.TEXT: William J. Bennett, the Bush administration's drug policy director, said today he believes the nation is ``beginning to see a peaking of the addiction problem.'' Bennett told state and local drug control officials, however, that any reduction in drug use will not be automatic, but ``if it happens, it will be by the pressure that we bring to bear.'' Bennett spoke at the opening of a two-day conference on state and local drug policy sponsored by his office. ``We may now be seeing a levelling off of addiction,'' Bennett said. ``My sense is that we are now beginning to see a peaking of the addiction problem.'' Bennett also said that in the next three to six months he believes that ``we will at least have some indications'' of the success of the administration's strategy to reduce the supply of cocaine from Andean nations. Asked about his remarks at a news conference, Bennett said, ``What happens in the next three to six months is that the agreement at Cartagena begins to take effect. Funds from the United States will begin to flow.'' He said actions by the Bolivian, Peruvian and Colombian governments would also be moving forward. ``There is encouraging news out of Bolivia in evidence of many farmers selling off coca cultivation plots and using them for other purposes,'' he said. Bennett also said in his speech that ``there is a tendency by critics of the administration's drug policy to overstate civil liberties violations by police.'' ``This is a tough business,'' he said. ``We do not need to abrogate the Constitution or any of its protections, but we are going to have to be both tough and law-abiding.'' Secretary of Education Lauro Cavazos also addressed the conference, saying he believes that ``education is the only long-term solution to the problem of substance abuse in America.''

DOC.HEAD: East Europeans Flooding into East Germany
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 8-12 `At least...of anti-Semitism.' with 4 grafs to UPDATE with new figures showing tens of thousands of East Europeans flooding in, daily numbers rising; pickup 13th graf pvs, `The flood...'
DOC.TEXT: Maj. Harry Kretschmer strolls through a hallway in an East German army barracks filled with squalling children and milling adults. ``Every day there are more. The come here, see the free food and the free housing, and call home. Then more come,'' he says. ``We do not know what to do with them. We are filled to capacity.'' About 700 Romanians and a few hundred Bulgarians have been packed into two barracks at an East German army base on the outskirts of Berlin. Hundreds more are housed in a building once used by East Germany's feared secret police. East Germany, reeling from a creaky economy and its own exodus of citizens to West Germany, suddenly finds itself luring other East Europeans whose countries do not have a wealthy neighbor to help them emerge from four decades of Stalinist oppression. The government said it decided last week to begin housing and feeding the Romanians and Bulgarians who show up daily in train stations with battered bags of belongings, but no money. Many see East Germany now as the new threshhold of the West, a passageway to prosperity. ``I came here for work and to escape the Communists,'' says Taian Neascu, 19, from Bucharest. ``I want to go to West Germany, and go to America.'' About 3,000 Romanians already have flooded into East Berlin in the last two weeks and another 15,000 have crossed the border into East Germany, said Joachim Krabs, a city social services official. He said 650 arrived today alone and that about 20,000 Poles also have arrived in recent weeks. Krabs said the situation was a ``social powder keg'' and called for new laws to limit the flood. Matthias Jahr, a member of the East Berlin Foreigners Commission, said his office has received numerous requests for asylum from Soviet Jews who want to flee a new wave of anti-Semitism. The flood of Romanians began in late April, about the time political strife intensified in the country. Some Romanians believe the revolutionary interim government of acting President Ion Iliescu will not differ substantially from the Communist regime that was overthrown in December. Scores of Romanians began sleeping and wandering the large train station in Lichtenberg, the huge foreign quarter of East Berlin. ``At first we were ignorant of the problem. Then we found all of these people sleeping in the train station,'' said Hannelora Gensch, an East Berlin housing official who runs the complex at the army base in the Beisdorf district of East Berlin. Children typically roam subway and train stations, sent by their parents with cards printed in German: ``We are Romanian, please help us with money.'' Many are sick when they arrive, and most are afraid, Mrs. Gensch said. ``We have had to put people in the hospital because of their fear,'' she said. ``The government has to make a decision on what to do with these people.'' The stream comes just as a wave of resentment of foreigners is sweeping East Germany, fueled mainly by fears that the country will face widespread joblessness as it merges with West Germany and converts to a free market. Violent street clashes between foreigners and East German youth gangs broke out in Lichtenberg a week ago. One Romanian in the barracks, a 36-year-old man who said he drove a taxi in Constanza, said he left behind three young children when he came to East Berlin five days ago. He said he has no plans to return. ``I cannot tell you my name because it would be bad for my family,'' he said. Kretschmer said he believes the motives are more economic than political. Some Romanians at the barracks said they fled because they believed a new crackdown on travel would be imposed after May 20, when Iliescu is widely expected to win the Romanian elections. Most came here on tourist visas, and some said they still planned to go home. But a bearded coalminer from the city of Resita, who refuses to give his name, says he has no plans to return. ``Iliescu and and Ceausescu are the same,'' he says, referring to the hard-line Romanian leader, Nicolae Ceausescu, who was toppled and executed in December. Jahr said the government should discuss visa requirements with other East European countries as a way of limiting the flow. ``We don't want to build a new wall,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Court Refuses to Lift Georgia Judge's Injunction in Abortion Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts grafs 7-21, In other action, with other cases.
DOC.TEXT: A deeply divided Supreme Court today refused to lift a Georgia judge's injunction barring an anti-abortion group from blocking access to abortion clinics in Atlanta. The court, by a 5-4 vote, rejected an emergency request by five members of the group, Operation Rescue, who said the injunction is violating their free-speech rights. The March 29 injunction permanently bars anti-abortion demonstrators within 50 feet of the property line of any Atlanta facility where abortions are performed. Since July 1988, when Atlanta hosted the National Democratic Convention, city police have arrested 1,320 demonstrators at Operation Rescue sit-ins. Many of the protesters barricaded abortion clinics, blocking patients and employees from entering or leaving. City officials sought and obtained the state court injunction. The Georgia Supreme Court refused on April 25 to set it aside. Five members of Operation Rescue then sought emergency help from Justice Anthony M. Kennedy, who referred the request to the full court. In other action, the court: _ Refused to let 30 states sue 26 manufacturers in the nation's highest court over removal of asbestos from public schools and other government buildings. The court, without comment, refused to hear arguments that the manufacturers should pay for such removal. _ Ruled that price-cutting schemes that hurt a competitor's business do not necessarily violate antitrust laws. By a 7-2 vote, the justices killed a lawsuit against Atlantic Richfield Co. (ARCO) by independent gas stations in California and Washington state. The court said that only when a company's price-cutting can be proved to be ``predatory'' and harmful does it violate the Sherman Act, a major antitrust law. _ Squelched a lawsuit charging the United Steelworkers union with negligence in a 1972 Idaho silver mine disaster that killed 91 miners. The justices, by a 6-3 vote, said the state court suit was pre-empted by federal labor law. _ Refused to revive a lawsuit accusing the Reagan administration of unlawfully bombing Libya in 1986 with help from Great Britain. The court, without comment, let stand a ruling that threw out the suit and also ordered the Libyans and their lawyers _ including former Attorney General Ramsey Clark _ to pay penalties and the British government's legal costs. _ Rejected appeals by 13 men convicted in the so-called pizza connection drug-trafficking conspiracy. The court, without comment, let stand a ruling that the men's rights were not violated in what was one of the longest and costliest trials in U.S. history. _ Refused to consider increasing a $5 million judgment that the justices were told already threatens to destroy the Hare Krishna religion. The court, without comment, rejected an appeal in which a California woman sought to have restored millions of dollars in damages a jury awarded her. The award was reduced by appeals courts and now, with interest, totals about $5 million. The court's 5-4 vote in the Operation Rescue case produced strange judicial bedfellows. Joining to deny the emergency request _ and thus leave the injunction intact _ were Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justices Byron R. White, Harry A. Blackmun, John Paul Stevens and Sandra Day O'Connor. Blackmun and Stevens often are characterized as liberals on issues such as abortion and free speech. Rehnquist, White and O'Connor are most often referred to as conservatives on those points. Voting in dissent to lift the injunction were the court's two most consistent liberals _ Justices William J. Brennan and Thurgood Marshall _ and two conservatives, Kennedy and Justice Antonin Scalia. Writing for the dissenters, Kennedy cited a 1977 decision involving Nazis demonstrating in the heavily Jewish community of Skokie, Ill. Kennedy said that decision ``does not distinguish among speakers based on the content of their speech.'' Operation Rescue members Michael Hirsch, Gina Robertson, William Haynes, Steve Britt and Pamela Sekulow said the Atlanta injunction deters them ``from engaging in prayer, picketing, leafleting and other forms of peaceful expression on public forum streets and sidewalks.'' Legal challenges to Operation Rescue demonstrations at abortion clinics have left the organization so far in debt it has closed down its national headquarters in Binghamton, N.Y. Operation Rescue's founder, Randall Terry, spent time in jail until a contempt-of-court fine for violating a similar injunction in New York was paid. Hirsch has stepped down as director of the group's Atlanta chapter, and has not been replaced. The case is Hirsch vs. Atlanta, A-752.

DOC.HEAD: Man Pleads Guilty in Old Murder Case
DOC.TEXT: A man who fled Dallas after his girlfriend's 1960 shooting death and lived a new life for almost 30 years pleaded guilty to a murder charge today. Robert Lee Mitchell, 64, left Dallas for Chicago after the shooting in 1960 and began a new life as ``Billy Jackson.'' He married and had five children and three grandchildren before a computer check of old warrants turned up a fingerprint connection between Mitchell and ``Jackson.'' He was returned to Dallas late last year. Mitchell said then that he would plead guilty, take the consequences and put the killing behind him. But he insisted the shooting of Billie Marie Redmon Phillips, his 29-year-old girlfriend, was really an accident. He said the gun went off during a struggle. Sentencing is set for Friday before State District Judge Ron Chapman.

DOC.HEAD: President of Senegal Meets with Bush
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 3 grafs new with meeting; picks up 3rd graf pvs, Although Diouf's.
DOC.TEXT: President Abdou Diouf of Senegal, concerned that Iraq may be building a missile test site in his backyard, met with President Bush at the White House today. Senegalese officials said Diouf was seeking information about reports based on U.S. intelligence information that Iraq wants to install a testing site for its long-range missiles in Mauritania. Taking advantage of beautiful spring weather, Bush posed for pictures with Diouf in the sun-splashed Rose Garden rather than in the Oval Office, where they held talks. Although Diouf's week-long visit to Washington is being billed as a private one, he has a full schedule of meetings _ including the White House call on Bush, talks with Treasury and Commerce Department leaders and with the heads of the IMF and World Bank. Mauritania and Senegal broke diplomatic relations in August after a minor border dispute flared into violence in both countries in which hundreds of people were killed. The Organization of African Unity has been unsuccessful in efforts to mediate between the two West African neighbors, although it has averted an immediate threat of war. The United States has supported the mediation and tried to maintain its ties with both countries. Privately, however, U.S. officials asked Mauritania whether it had agreed to let Iraq build a missile range on its territory, Assistant Secretary of State John Kelly said last month. Mauritania denied the reports, but Iraq has refused to confirm or deny them. The United States is worried about Iraq's efforts to develop missiles that could carry lethal chemical weapons to Israel or Iran, two countries with which Iraq is technically at war. In recent weeks, U.S. and British agents have intercepted several shipments of devices allegedly intended for Iraq's missile and nuclear weapons programs. Iraq has denied it is building atomic weapons but announced it has developed a missile with a 1,200-mile range. Iraq does not have enough land to test the new missile but Mauritania does. The arid Moslem land bordering the Atlantic Ocean has an area of about 400,000 square miles and is sparsely populated. Both Iraq and Mauritania are members of the Arab League and Iraq has been supplying weapons to Mauritania, said a U.S. official who spoke on condition of anonymity. Iraq enjoys good ties with Senegal too. Senegal is one of the staunchest U.S. allies in Africa, receiving an average of $40 million annually and having strong cultural ties to American organizations. U.S. officials hold up Senegal as an example that multi-party democracy can work in Africa, where tribal divisions have hampered the evolution of Western-style political systems. Diouf took office in January 1981. In 1988 his Socialist Party won 73 percent of the vote and although observers agree there was some election fraud, there was little doubt Diouf won. Diouf has accepted demands by Senegal's creditors, including the United States, for economic changes that would make his government and the private sector more efficient. But he plans to ask U.S. officials, as well as leaders of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, for a more relaxed pace of reform. Senegal owes about $3.6 billion, most of it to other governments, but it has a good repayment record.

DOC.HEAD: Canadian Police Charging Five Mohawks In Reservation Killing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with saying charges will be lodged, but won't give details. Picks up 4th graf pvs `Poeti said...'.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Mohawk Chief
DOC.TEXT: Five Mohawks face arraignment today on charges stemming from the slaying of an Indian during a gunbattle over casino gambling on the reservation, police in Canada said. Quebec Provincial Police declined to identify the five men or say what specific charges would be lodged against them. Police spokeswoman Jeanette Couture said the men were being charged in connection with the May 1 slaying of 31-year-old Harold Edwards. The men were to appear at a proceeding in the Quebec Provincial Court in Valleyfield, just south of Montreal, she said. Four of the men were taken into custody Sunday morning and taken by helicopter to police headquarters in Montreal in connection with the May 1 shooting death of 31-year-old Harold Edwards, police spokesman Robert Poeti said. It was not clear when or where the fifth man was taken into custody. Poeti said an investigation continues as well into the shooting of 22-year-old Matthew Pyke on the same day. Both slayings took place on the Canadian side of the 28,000-acre reservation, which straddles the border. Pyke was said to oppose gambling. Some on the reservation have said Edwards favored gambling; others said he was neutral. The Mohawks are divided over whether to allow gambling on the reservation. The dispute has been marked by gunfire and arson. After the slayings, hundreds of police officers moved in, and the reservation has been largely peaceful. Opponents say the reservation's casinos brings drugs, guns and prostitution. Supporters say they create jobs and revenue by drawing busloads of people eager to play slot machines, craps, roulette and other games.

DOC.HEAD: Waters Surge in Texas, Arkansas, Louisiana
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs the 4th graf, `Over the...', to UPDATE with flood-related murder-suicide. Quote in last graf is cq.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NU1
DOC.TEXT: Louisiana farmers today braced for the most disastrous flooding in 45 years. About 7,000 people were urged to leave low-lying areas in Texas, and workmen dynamited a breached levee to prevent further damage in Arkansas. Highways reopened and flood victims began cleaning up in Oklahoma as National Guardsmen, inmates, farmers and volunteers filled sandbags and shored up levees in Louisiana and Arkansas. ``This is my home. If there was anything I could do, I was going to do it,'' said Rosie Blair, who worked alongside her husband and 14-year-old son in Texarkana, Ark. Over the past three weeks, 13 deaths have been blamed on flooding: 12 in Texas and one in Oklahoma. In addition, a farmer despondent over possibly losing his crops to flooding in northwest Louisiana shot his wife and then himself in what appeared to be a suicide pact, The Times of Shreveport reported today, quoting sources it didn't identify. In Louisiana, heavy weekend rain compounded the flood threat as the Red River continued its rise from Shreveport to Alexandria. The river was expected to crest 5 feet above flood stage in Shreveport on Wednesday and had already overflowed in places. About 60 families in the Shreveport area were evacuated Sunday as the rising Red River pushed into the bayous that usually feed it. ``We expect upwards of about 100 more families to be evacuated over the next few days,'' said Chuck Mazziotti, civil defense director for Caddo and Bossier parishes. Up to 600 square miles, including 200 square miles of farmland, will flood in Louisiana this week and next, and up to 500 homes and camps between the levees and the river will be inundated, said U.S. Sen. J. Bennett Johnston. ``It will be a major agricultural disaster. It'll be a flood event such as we have not experienced since 1945,'' Johnston said after meeting with Army Corps of Engineers officials. In Avoyelles Parish, National Guardsmen joined with about 50 Vick community members to finish a four-mile levee to protect recently planted corn, cotton and soybean fields. In Texas, about 7,000 residents downstream of Lake Livingston Dam, 60 miles northeast of Houston, were told to evacuate their homes along the rain-swollen Trinity River. Officials said water was pouring over the reservoir's spillway at more than twice the normal rate. Sightseers carrying lawn chairs and cameras gathered in southeastern Texas as residents decided whether to pack up and leave. ``I'm going to get as far away as I can,'' said Tina Lapaglia, who spent Mother's Day with her husband and two children at a campground after abandoning their home in Camilla Twin Harbors. ``Tomorrow I'll look for a new place for us to live.'' ``I'm going to stay here as long as I can,'' said John Burch, 32, a fisherman from Liberty. ``My father is a cancer patient and we have to be careful with him.'' Along the Texas-Oklahoma line, on the headwaters of the Red River, only one highway in the Lake Texoma area remained closed Sunday by record flooding one week earlier. The lake had flooded homes and cabins. Downstream, workers blew up a section of a failed levee in Bowie County, Texas, to relieve pressure on a backup levee protecting several communities in Arkansas. Five blasts widened the gap and eased the pressure of flood water pouring through the breach, removing the threat to the final floodwater barrier. ``If the levee goes, we'll be looking at 250 to 300 homes affected,'' said Gary Talley of the Arkansas Office of Emergency Services. More than 100 Guardsmen in southwestern Arkansas sandbagged and helped with flood problems. A helicopter and four river barges patrolled along the river, helping feed cattle stranded on flood-created islands. James Roberts of Foreman was 23 in 1938, the last time major flooding occurred on the Red River. But he said it was nothing like this. ``All my wheat's gone,'' he said. ``I had 320 acres. I'd just got out of a `tight.' And now this. I hope we get some quick relief.''

DOC.HEAD: Court Rules Governor Cannot Withhold Local Aid
DOC.TEXT: Massachusetts' State Supreme Judicial Court ruled today that Gov. Michael S. Dukakis had no authority to withhold $210 million in local aid payments to municipalities. The unanimous decision added more uncertainty to the state's attempts to solve its fiscal crisis. Dukakis made the cut from the current year's budget to help resolve the state's deficit, now pegged at $1 billion. But cities and towns sued the state, led by the town of Brookline, Dukakis' hometown. Dukakis also has threatened to withhold an additional $500 million from local aid payments at the end of the current fiscal year. Municipalities argued that the cuts in funding jeopardize local budgets, threatening schools and other services. ``We're thrilled and hopefully this will help as we go through these troubled times in local government,'' said Paul Moran, spokesman for the Massachusetts Municipalities Association. The high court noted that state law allows the governor to reduce certain allotments when revenues are insufficient to meet expenditures. State law further describes what funds are subject to control by the governor. But the court ruled that the local aid funds ``are not `made available' to any state agency `under the control of the governor or a secretary.''' Dukakis, the unsuccessful Democratic candidate for president in 1988, has battled a state budget crunch almost continuously since that election. He has said he won't seek another term.

DOC.HEAD: South African Leader To Visit Washington Next Month
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela, South African black leader freed after 27 years in jail, will visit President Bush at the White House next month and be feted with a tickertape parade in New York City, organizers announced today. Mandela, head of the African National Congress, will visit Washington and five other U.S. cities toward the end of June, said a news release by Fenton Communications, which represents the ANC. An ANC source in New York said Mandela would arrive in the United States on June 20. A news conference to announce the exact schedule of the visit is scheduled here on Tuesday. Bush issued an invitation to Mandela in a personal telephone call last February, as soon as Mandela was released from prison where he had been serving a life sentence for plotting to overthrow the South African government. The White House has not yet announced when Mandela will meet with the president but administration sources have said the visit would be in late June. Mandela will also address a joint session of Congress _ the highest honor lawmakers can pay visiting dignitaries _ and hold meetings with congressional leaders. He will thank U.S. leaders for their support during his years of incarceration and urge them to preserve economic sanctions against South Africa's government to press its white leadership to dismantle the apartheid system of racial segregation, organizers said. The United States imposed limitations on trade with South Africa in 1986. The Bush administration has indicated it might be willing to ease some of the limitations following some lifting of restrictions on the black population adopted by the government of F.W. De Klerk in recent months. Bush has also invited De Klerk to visit Washington, and officials on both sides are trying to arrange the dates. The ANC, which was recently made legal by De Klerk after being banned for decades, began talks with the government earlier this month to discuss the future of apartheid.

DOC.HEAD: Obscenity Debate Over Group's Recording Reaches Federal Court
DOC.TEXT: The debate over whether the lyrics of a recording by the million-selling rap group 2 Live Crew are obscene moved to a higher level today with the issue's first airing in federal court. U.S. District Judge Jose Gonzalez was asked to determine if ``As Nasty As They Wanna Be,'' which has been removed from store shelves in several Florida counties, should also be banned in Broward County. The county ordered the ban. Lawyers for the Miami-based group then asked Gonzalez to lift the ban. The first witness to testify today, Broward Detective Sgt. Mark Wichner, said he found the recording ``extremely explicit and degrading to the female sex.'' The detective sought and received a ruling from a circuit judge that it was probably obscene. Then, he said he visited Fort Lauderdale-area record stores, warning personnel they could be prosecuted on obscenity charges for selling the recording. On cross-examination, 2 Live Crew lawyer Bruce Rogow said the sheriff's office file on the recording contained ``not one complaint'' from a citizen of Broward County about it. He argued that the police investigation had revealed nothing indicating the recording violated community standards of obscenity. Three of the group's four members _ David Hobbs, whose stage name is Mr. Mixx; Chris Wongwon, known as Fresh Kid Ice; and Mark Ross, who performs as Brother Marquis _ were present for the trial's start. Leader Luther Campbell was expected later, said Debbie Bennett, a spokeswoman for the group's record company. Campbell has used the name Luke Skyywalker but is currently prohibited from doing so pending settlement of a lawsuit by the creators of the ``Star Wars'' movies. John Jolly, attorney for the Broward Sheriff's Office, said before the trial that the purpose of the case ``is to tell us if it is protected First Amendment speech or disposable, unprotected smut.'' ``The tape speaks for itself,'' Jolly said. But there's merit to what it says, according to Rogow. ``Put in its historical context, it is a novel and creative use of sound and lyrics,'' he said. He plans to call music critics to testify about the artistic value of the recording. ``The trouble is you have a bunch of white folks who don't understand the culture,'' Rogow said. ``The primary reason for writing these songs was humor, to make people think and reflect the kind of talk that occurs in the community where the four people who make up 2 Live Crew have lived all their lives.'' The album ``As Nasty as They Wanna Be'' has sold nearly 2 million copies, while a toned-down version of the album has sold about 300,000 copies.

DOC.HEAD: Castro Hale and Hearty, Works up to 16 Hour Days, Cuban Agency Says
DOC.TEXT: Fidel Castro works 14 to 16 hours a day, has stopped smoking cigars and feels as fit as he did 30 years ago, the Cuban President told a group of Spanish journalists, according to reports from Havana today. The Cuban news agency Prensa Latina, monitored in New York, said Castro met recently with the Spanish reporters at the Varadero seaside resort. Castro was invited to the inauguration of a hotel built by a consortium of Spanish and Cuban companies. Noting that on Aug. 13 he will be 64, Castro said he works with as much enthusiasm as on the first day of the revolution that brought him to power in 1960. ``Remember, I don't smoke,'' he said, adding that he did not quit for personal reasons but rather to support a Cuban anti-smoking campaign. ``I didn't find it difficult because my motivation was very strong.'' The Cuban leader said he engages in sports every day, especially swimming and snorkeling. He said he used to play baseball and basketball but he needed two teams and nobody wanted to be referee.

DOC.HEAD: Ferry Boat Sinks, 24 People Drown
DOC.TEXT: A boat carrying people home from a funeral sank in the Blue Nile River, and 24 people drowned, the official Sudan News Agency said Monday. The agency said the accident occurred Sunday night in Wad Medani, 100 miles southeast of the capital, Khartoum. It was unclear from the report the circumstances of the sinking. The Blue Nile, which springs from Lake Tana in Ethiopia, winds through Sudan until joining the White Nile at Khartoum. The White Nile originates at Lake Victoria in Uganda.

DOC.HEAD: 15 U.S. Servicemen Injured in Panama Helicopter Crash
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. military transport helicopter crashed in eastern Panama, injuring 15 American servicemen, a U.S. Southern Command spokesman said Monday. Spokesman William Ormsbee said in a telephone interview that the Black Hawk aircraft crashed at 2:30 p.m. Sunday in the eastern province of Darien. The injured were taken to Gorgas Military Hospital in Panama City. Ormsbee refused to disclose their identities or the extent of their injuries until next of kin were notified. He also gave no details about the crash and did not say if the helicopter was involved at the time in military exercises.

DOC.HEAD: Dr. Merson New Head of Global AIDS Program
DOC.TEXT: Dr. Michael H. Merson, an American public health expert, was appointed Monday as the new head of the World Health Organization's global campaign against AIDS. He succeeds Dr. Jonathan Mann. Mann resigned in March, citing differences with WHO Director-General Dr. Hiroshi Nakajima over program strategy. Merson, 44, a native of Brooklyn, had been acting head of the Global Program on AIDS since March 26 when Mann went on a leave of absence. He joined WHO in 1978 and was previously in charge of the control program on diarrheal diseases and respiratory infections.

DOC.HEAD: Top Sikh Leader Escapes Assassination Attempt; Two Others Killed
DOC.TEXT: A top Sikh leader escaped an assassination attempt, but his driver and an associate were killed, police said Monday. Gurcharan Singh Tohra, 68, chief of the politically powerful Sikh Temple Management Committee, suffered bullet wounds in his arms and legs. His associate, Hardial Singh Rajala, and driver Sardul Singh were killed in the ambush late Sunday. ``The attack was daring. The terrorists came in a mini-truck, and at least two of them opened fire,'' said Paramjit Singh Sandhu, senior superintendent of police of Ludhiana, where the attack occurred. The area is about 90 miles south of the Sikh holy city of Amritsar. ``The target of the terrorists was Mr. Tohra,'' said Kulwesman for the Sikh Temple Management Committee.
