The committee manages Sikh shrines across India and controls funds. Sikh sant Singh, spokeparatists are campaigning for secession of their rich farming state of Punjab from India. Sikhs make up about 2 percent of India's 880 million people, but in Punjab they are in a slight majority. The separatists claim they are discriminated against in Hindu-dominated India.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Official Says Vietnamese Troops Remain in Cambodia
DOC.TEXT: rnment in its civil war, despite claims by Vietnam that it withdrew the last of its troops in September, a U.S. official said Monday. Richard Solomon, assistant secretary of state for Asian affairs, said statements by East European diplomats, some Vietnamese officials, and other sources indicate Vietnamese troops either remained behind or have returned to Cambodia since September. Such reports began surfacing early this year. Vietnam denies the allegations. Solomon spoke at a news conference in Bangkok, where he was visiting as part of a regional tour. ``There apparently are at least advisers operating in combat support roles, intelligence, command and control functions, and actively participating in combat operations going on inside Cambodia,'' he said. ``As far as numbers are concerned, frankly we don't have a clear fix on that. It is probably in the low thousands.'' He said the significant issue was not the exact number of soldiers but rather that their presence showed the Cambodian government remained weak and required Vietnamese support. The government, installed by a Vietnamese invasion in late 1978, has been fighting three guerrilla groups backed by the United States and other countries. Current peace efforts center on a proposal for the United Nations to administer the country on an interim basis and supervise elections. But the Cambodian government and the guerrillas disagree over the extent of U.N. participation.

DOC.HEAD: View of St. Paul's Restored by Bridge Removal
DOC.TEXT: A railway bridge that obscured a famous view of St. Paul's Cathedral in London for 125 years was removed early Monday. The iron bridge was constructed in 1865 across Ludgate Hill. Its removal restored a splendid vista of Sir Christopher Wren's domed cathedral down Fleet Street, across Ludgate Circus and up the hill. The bridge carried a railway between Blackfriars and Holborn Viaduct that is being replaced by a new underground line.

DOC.HEAD: Three Inmates Killed in Escape Bid
DOC.TEXT: Three convicts stabbed two fellow prisoners during an escape attempt and were then shot to death by police as they ran from the jail, officials said Monday. The incident took place Sunday in Tacloban City, 360 miles from Manila, a police report said. It said the three prisoners forced open the jail gate, stabbed two other prisoners, and then fled into a wooded area. The injured inmates alerted police, who opened fire at the fleeing prisoners when they refused to stop.

DOC.HEAD: Czechoslovak TV Starts New Channel
DOC.TEXT: Czechoslovak television started an experimental broadcast on a third channel Monday that incorporates U.S, Soviet and West European programs. The broadcast, which replaced Soviet programming formerly available on the same channel, will reach approximately 30 percent of Czechoslovakia's territory, the Socialist daily Svobodne Slovo said. Of the other two Czechoslovak channels, one broadcasts nationwide, and the other broadcasts in Czech or Slovak, depending on the region. The programming of the third channel was made available by foreign TV stations such as La Sept and TV 5 of France, CNN of the United States and the U.S.-government run World Net and Soviet television. It will include language courses, sports, news, and music, Svobodne Slovo said.

DOC.HEAD: Mongolia Schedules First Multiparty Election
DOC.TEXT: Mongolia has scheduled its first multiparty legislative elections for July 29, China's official Xinhua News Agency reported Monday. In a dispatch from the Mongolian capital of Ulan Bator, Xinhua quoted Mongolia's official news agency, Montsame, as saying the date was set by the Great People's Hural, the national legislature. Currently, more than 93 percent of the 370 seats in the Great People's Hural are held by members of the ruling Communist party. After weeks of demonstrations inspired by the democratic changes elsewhere in the Soviet bloc, the party decided in March to give up its constitutional monopoly on power and allow other parties. The Hural elected in July will in turn elect a president and a new 53-seat standing legislature, called the Small Hural. The Great People's Hural, which generally meets only once or twice a year, voted last week to establish the standing body. The Great People's Hural last week also rejected demands by the new opposition parties for direct presidential elections, and passed a law setting requirements for parties to register. Among other things, each party must have at least 801 members _ a higher minimum than the opposition wanted. The ruling party has about 90,000 members. Five non-communist parties have formed since late last year. Most of their members are young professionals, academics and civil servants.

DOC.HEAD: Police Arrest Man Who Crawls Out of Ceiling
DOC.TEXT: Police arrested an Arab man on Monday after he was spotted emerging from the crawl space in the ceiling at Manila's international airport, officials said. Bomb-sniffing dogs patrolled the Ninoy Aquino International Airport after Khalid al-Hamad, 26, was arrested, police said. Hamad was arrested after employees told police they saw him emerge from the crawl space in the ceiling over Saudi Airlines. Airport police investigator Cpl. Manuel Wong said Hamad refused to say what he was doing in the ceiling and would not disclose his nationality. Police said they were investigating whether Hamad was a member of a terrorist group. Officials have tightened security at the airport since an explosion aboard a Philippine Airlines jet Friday. The blast killed eight passengers, and officials were looking into the possibility a bomb was planted inside the plane.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Moon Probe Encounters Problems
DOC.TEXT: A satellite that began orbiting the moon March 18 has been unable to transmit, leaving Japanese scientists uncertain of its exact position, officials said Monday. Scientists have confirmed with telescopes that the tiny satellite, named Hagoromo, is orbiting the moon as planned. But they have not received any signals from it, said Kuninori Uesugi of the Institute of Space and Astronautical Science. A bad transistor was probably responsible for the failure of the satellite's transmitter, Uesugi said. The satellite was to have sent regular data about its temperature and electrical status, which also would have been used to determine its exact location. Otherwise, Uesugi said, the mission has been successful. Its primary goal was to give scientists experience in successfully targeting orbits. The satellite separated March 18 from a larger satellite, named Hiten. Hiten is continuing to circle Earth.

DOC.HEAD: Policymakers Support Referendum Idea
DOC.TEXT: Legislators of Zambia's ruling party have agreed to hold a referendum on whether Zambia should adopt a multiparty system, it was reported Monday. Both of Zambia's main newspapers said the central committee of the United National Independence Party endorsed President Kenneth Kaunda's proposal for a referendum. Before a referendum can be held, a special session of the national council _ a policy review body of the party _ must decide whether to amend the constitution. The constitution currently forbids referendums. Kaunda adopted the system of one-party rule in 1973, and his party has held power unchallenged since then. Last month, Kuanda proposed to his party that voters be asked to decide the fate of the one-party system. He still opposes a multiparty system, saying it would provoke factional fighting in this southern African nation. Zambia, one of Africa's poorest and most indebted nations, last held a referendum in 1969. That vote endorsed measures by Kaunda to establish a one-party system.

DOC.HEAD: Precede MARJAYOUN
Hezbollah Supporters Stage Sit-In
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with Hezbollah staging hostage protest; EDITS thereafter to CONFORM and TRIM; CHANGES byline. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The Iranian-backed Moslem faction Hezbollah sponsored a women's sit-in today and urged kidnappers to hold on to their Western hostages until Arab prisoners are released by Israel. ``We ask the hostage-holders not to release any more of the foreign captives until all our loved ones are released from the Zionist jails,'' chanted Umm Ahmed, who refused to give her full name. About 50 other women echoed her chant during the one-hour demonstration at a house in Beirut's southern suburb of Bir Hassan used for guests of the United Nations peacekeeping force in southern Lebanon. Umm Ahmed said tearfully that her son Ahmed, 21, was captured by Israeli troops in Beirut during the 1982 invasion, and that she had heard nothing about him since. The leader of an Israeli-backed militia that holds 300 Moslems in southern Lebanon said Sunday he would be willing to trade a ``large number'' for 16 Western hostages held by pro-Iranian Shiites. Gen. Antoine Lahd, the commander of the South Lebanon Army militia, said he would include in the trade three Israeli servicemen and several of his men held by Shiite factions. ``I'm not only prepared to facilitate such a package deal, but I also hope it could happen,'' Lahd said in an interview with The Associated Press at his house in Marjayoun in southern Lebanon. Lahd, 61, a retired Lebanese army officer, commands the 3,000-strong militia that is backed by about 1,000 Israeli troops and patrols Israel's self-proclaimed six- to 10-mile-wide security zone in southern Lebanon. The South Lebanon Army holds the 300 Shiites in Khiam, a small village in the zone, which was created in 1985 after Israel ended a three-year occupation. In Jerusalem, a senior government spokesman asked about Lahd's offer, said: ``I don't think it depends on Lahd or on us but on the other side.'' Asked if there was any sign of movement from the other side, the spokesman said on condition of anonymity, ``none that I know of.'' Most of the 16 Western hostages missing in Lebanon are held by pro-Iranian Shiite factions operating under the fundamentalist Hezbollah, or Party of God. The longest held is Terry Anderson, 42, chief Middle East correspondent for The AP, who was kidnapped in March 1985. Two American hostages, Robert Polhill and Frank Reed, were released by their pro-Iranian captors last month as a ``goodwill gesture.'' Since then, however, there have been contradictory statements from Iran on any further releases. President Bush has refused to deal for freedom for the hostages, who include six Americans. There was no immediate reaction to Lahd's offer from pro-Iranian factions in Lebanon or from Iran. Iranian leaders hoping to improve ties with the West have said all hostages should be freed this year. But radicals argue that holding hostages is a means of confronting the West, which the anti-Western faction considers a cornerstone of the 1979 Islamic Revolution. In the past, kidnappers and their backers have said the release of the Shiites held by Lahd and Israel would help end the hostages' ordeal. They have also said they want help locating four Iranians missing in Lebanon since 1982. Lahd did not mention the four; Lebanese sources say they are dead. The kidnappers and their backers also have mentioned specifically the release of Sheik Abdul-Karim Obeid, a Hezbollah official captured by the Israelis in a raid on his village in southern Lebanon last July 28. Bush recently said that if Israel wanted to free any prisoners he would not object. He also offered to help locate the four missing Iranians. Obeid is held in Israel and out of Lahd's domain, but he said he was optimistic that Obeid could be included in trade. He added, ``I won't release anybody if our people and the Israeli servicemen are not freed.'' The three Israeli soldiers were captured in 1986. Lahd said nine of his soldiers have gone missing in clashes with Moslem factions in southern Lebanon. He said three are held by Hezbollah and one by the mainstream Shiite Amal militia, backed by Syria, but the fate of the others was unknown. In addition to the six Americans, the Western hostages include an Irishman, four Britons, two West Germans, two Swiss and an Italian. One of the Britons is Anglican envoy Terry Waite, and the conservative British weekly Mail on Sunday reported in London that he was alive and well after more than three years as a hostage. A spokesman for the Druse religious sect was quoted as saying Waite is held alone in superior surroundings because he is believed the most important of the hostages. Waite traveled to Beirut in January 1987 to try to negotiate the release of Western hostages, but disappeared eight days later.

DOC.HEAD: Masked Men Fire On Cafe During Gambling Session; Four Dead, Three Wounded
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Rewrites throughout to UPDATE with four dead, police say high-stakes gambling going on, condition of wounded, and recast. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A group of masked men wearing camouflage broke into a high-stakes dice game and began firing at the gamblers this morning, killing four people and wounding at least three others, authorities said. It was the second fatal shooting in eight months at the Glass Key Cafe, a lounge known for gambling in a low-income neighborhood on Fort Worth's east side. ``It appears to have been a robbery of a gambling game,'' Police Chief Thomas Windham said today. ``We have information that it was an extremely high-dollar gambling game with tens of thousands of dollars involved.'' He said he didn't know if any money was taken. Two people were dead on the scene, another was dead on arrival at a hospital, and a fourth died in surgery, police spokesman Doug Clarke said. Windham said as many as 15 people were inside the lounge when the gunmen broke in, but some escaped serious injury by hiding in a back room. Police said four to six men, some wearing camouflage and masks, kicked in the door of the cafe at about 7 a.m. ``They were dressed in camouflage and several of them had on masks. They hollered `Task Force!' and began shooting,'' Clarke said. The cafe's owner, Albert Huey You, told reporters that two men entered the lounge, robbed several patrons who were sitting around drinking coffee, and then began firing what he described as semi-automatic weapons. You said he was nicked in the ear by a shotgun pellet. It was the second such shooting at the same lounge in eight months, said Criminal Investigations chief Randy Ely. Last Oct. 2, one man was killed when several men, hiding inside the building on a Monday morning, ``broke into a dice game yelling `Police!' and shot,'' he said. Ely said connections between the two shootings were part of the investigation but he was unwilling to say whether the two were related. One person was in critical condition and undergoing chest surgery and a 20-year-old was in fair condition with wounds in the arm and chest, said officials at John Peter Smith Hospital. A 17-year-old male left the hospital with arm abrasions, against medical advice, said spokeswoman Drenda Witt. Bob Wood, administrative director for John Peter Smith Hospital, said no slugs had yet been extracted by trauma room workers, but said he doubted the cafe owner was correct when he said automatic weapons had been used in the attack. Kathy Fridge, spokeswoman at Harris Methodist hospital, said a man was brought in dead on arrival with a gunshot wound in the head. She had no other details except that the man was a black male.

DOC.HEAD: Eight Shot Near San Francisco's Chinatown; One Dead
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Rewrites throughout to update with detail on shootings, background on previous attack.
DOC.TEXT: A gunman opened fire on a group of people in the Chinatown area early today, killing one man and wounding seven other people, police reported. The victims apparently were in a group, and they were fired upon just before 2 a.m. as they were getting into two cars a short distance apart. The incidents occurred along the North Beach-Chinatown border. It was uncertain whether there was more than one gunman, police said. Sgt. Jerry Senkir said at least three suspects were being sought. The shooting recalled a 1977 massacre in a Chinatown restaurant that left five dead and 11 wounded. In that early morning assault, three men armed with semi-automatic rifles burst into the Golden Dragon restaurant and began shooting at a crowd of about 75. That was part of bloody gang wars that raged in Chinatown during the 1970s. Authorities declined to suggest a motive in today's shooting. The dead man was identified by coroner's officials as an Asian male, about 35 years old. His name was being withheld pending notification of relatives. The wounded were taken to San Francisco General Hospital. One victim was a pregnant woman, who underwent surgery for a hip wound, said a nursing supervisor who did not give her name. Their names were not immediately released.

DOC.HEAD: Prime Minister Orders Gradual Opening Of Universities
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir today ordered a gradual reopening of six Palestinian universities in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. The move is likely to improve Israel's relation with the United States, which has been strained in recent weeks over Shamir's stepped up settlement activity in the occupied lands and his refusal to accept U.S. Middle East peace proposals. The army closed Palestinian institutions of higher learning shortly after the Palestinian uprising erupted in December 1987, arguing they were hotbeds of anti-Israeli violence. But the United States and Western Europe sharply criticized the measure as collective punishment, and the European Parliament at one point recommended that scientific cooperation with Israel be halted until the universities and colleges were reopened. Shamir spokesman Avi Pazner said the prime minister instructed his adviser for the occupied lands, Shmuel Goren, to meet today with the heads of the six universities to discuss the gradual reopening. Pazner said that ``we will open the first one (university) in the next few days,'' but would not say which one. There are five universities in the West Bank and one in the Gaza Strip with a total of 18,000 students. Pazner said that if the reopening of the first university passed without violence, other institutions of higher learning would also reopen. ``Our aim is to restore normal life. This will test whether we can get life back to normal as much as possible,'' Pazner told The Associated Press. He denied that the decision was aimed at appeasing the administration of President Bush. ``But if it is well-received in the United States, we will be very pleased,'' he said. Sari Nusseibeh, considered by Israel to be one of the leaders of the uprising, said Israel finally was responding to pressure from the United States and Europe to reopen the universities. He cited as an example the recent visit by Czech President Vaclav Havel,who brought up the issue in talks with Israeli leaders. Throughout the closure, instruction has continued in so-called underground classes. But attendance has been sporadic and the education they provide has been far below normal standards. ``Nothing is irreparable. People were able to manage, and so they will be able to pick up as soon as schools will reopen,'' Nusseibeh said. Sixteen colleges that also were closed shortly after the beginning of the uprising were reopened gradually over the past few months.

DOC.SECOND: PM-Saturday Night Live, 1st Ld - Writethru, a0485,0318
DOC.HEAD: Foul-Mouth Andrew Dice Clay Lifts `Saturday Night' Ratings
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `National ratings..., to CORRECT that national ratings expected Thursday sted today.
DOC.TEXT: Foul-mouth comedian Andrew Dice Clay apparently lifted ``Saturday Night Live'' to its highest ratings all season. The show, which was boycotted by cast member Nora Dunn and singer Sinead O'Connor because of Clay's belligerent humor, averaged a rating of 11.6 and got a 31 percent share of the audience in the 24-city overnight Nielsens, NBC said. That was 8 points higher than the Feb. 24 ``Saturday Night Live'' with Fred Savage of ABC's ``The Wonder Years'' as host, NBC said. The highest overnight rating for Saturday's broadcast was in Chicago, where it had a 17.8 rating and a 37 percent share. In New York, the nation's largest TV market, it averaged a 15.2 rating and a 33 percent share. National ratings were to be released Thursday. NBC's New York and Burbank, Calif., offices got 1,764 calls against Clay and 198 in his favor in what was probably the highest number of pre-show protests in the program's 15-year history, NBC spokesman Curt Block said. Clay's appearance, broadcast with a five-second delay to allow bleeps, drew heavy advance publicity because of the boycotts. Clay's act has been branded racist and offensive to women and homosexuals. Security was heavy for the show, NBC said. Guards with metal detectors checked out guests entering both the dress rehearsal and the live broadcast. The only incident in the studio occurred during Clay's opening monologue, when a couple began shouting ``Clay, Clay, go away!'' They were ejected. Clay was paid what an NBC official estimated at $5,000 for his work. During the program, Clay said he was donating his fee to ``Comic Relief '90,'' a benefit for the homeless televised live on HBO Saturday night.

Here, at a glance, are highlights of actions taken Monday by the Supreme Court.
ABORTION PROTESTS
A deeply divided Supreme Court refused to lift a Georgia judge's injunction barring an anti-abortion group from blocking access to abortion clinics in Atlanta. The court, by a 5-4 vote, rejected an emergency request by five members of the group, Operation Rescue, who said the injunction is violating their free-speech rights. The March 29 injunction permanently bars anti-abortion demonstrators within 50 feet of the property line of any Atlanta facility where abortions are performed. The case is Hirsch vs. Atlanta, A-752.
ASBESTOS
The court refused to let 30 states sue 26 manufacturers in the nation's highest court over removal of asbestos from public schools and other government buildings. The court, without comment, refused to hear arguments that the manufacturers should pay for such removal. The case is Alabama vs. W.R. Grace, 116 Original.
ANTITRUST
The court ruled that price-cutting schemes that hurt a competitor's business do not necessarily violate antitrust laws. By a 7-2 vote, the justices killed a lawsuit against Atlantic Richfield Co. (ARCO) by independent gas stations in California and Washington state. The court said that only when a company's price-cutting can be proved to be ``predatory'' and harmful does it violate the Sherman Act, a major antitrust law. The case is Atlantic Richfield vs. USA Petroleum, 88-1668.
MINERS
The court squelched a lawsuit charging the United Steelworkers union with negligence in a 1972 Idaho silver mine disaster that killed 91 miners. The justices, by a 6-3 vote, said the state court suit was pre-empted by federal labor law. The case is United Steelworkers vs. Rawson, 89-322.
LIBYAN RAID
The court refused to revive a lawsuit accusing the Reagan administration of unlawfully bombing Libya in 1986 with help from Great Britain. The court, without comment, let stand a ruling that threw out the suit and also ordered the Libyans and their lawyers _ including former Attorney General Ramsey Clark _ to pay penalties and the British government's legal costs. The case is Saltany vs. Reagan, 89-1497.
PIZZA CONNECTION
The court rejected appeals by 13 men convicted in the so-called pizza connection drug-trafficking conspiracy. The court, without comment, let stand a ruling that the men's rights were not violated in what was one of the longest and costliest trials in U.S. history. The case is Palazzolo vs. U.S., 89-1565.
HARE KRISHNAS
The court refused to consider increasing a $5 million judgment that the justices were told already threatens to destroy the Hare Krishna religion. The court, without comment, rejected an appeal in which a California woman sought to have restored millions of dollars in damages a jury awarded her. The award was reduced by appeals courts and now, with interest, totals about $5 million. The case is Robin George vs. International Society of Krishna Consciousness, 89-1398.

DOC.HEAD: Storm Victims Begin Rebuilding After Devastating Cyclone
DOC.TEXT: Tens of thousands of people were without power or drinking water Monday after India's worst cyclone in a decade, and officials said at least a half-million were left homeless. More than 500 people died. Sea water entered wells and reservoirs of coastal regions in Andhra Pradesh state, which took the brunt of last week's storm. Many people were drinking drain water and also using it to cook, causing stomach disorders, Press Trust of India news agency reported. ``There is no alternative. We can't get water so we have to get along until the sea recedes,'' the news agency quoted a resident as saying in Edumondi village. It said the entire southern coastal area looked ``as if a civilization had come to an end ... with most of the places under complete darkness'' after the cyclone cut power supplies. Hundreds of town and villages were without electricity for the sixth day Monday. Relief officials in the state capital, Hyderabad, said about 500,000 people were uprooted after the cyclone. It began in the Bay of Bengal and started lashing the coast Tuesday with waves up to 33 feet high. It roared into India on Wednesday, flattening houses, sweeping away cattle and uprooting crops, trees and electricity poles. Paddy, the main crop in the fertile region, was badly damaged along with huge tracts of banana and mango plantations. Government officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said more than 100,000 farm animals, mainly goats, cows and water buffaloes, died in the disaster. Bodies of the animals were floating in the inundated towns and villages, news reports said. In Kothapalem, only six of the village's 5,000 houses were standing, United News of India said. The remaining were either submerged or had been washed away. ``The villagers were so dazed that they did not even rush to collect the food packets dropped from air force helicopters,'' it said. ``The people of Kothapalem were seen trying to extricate their valuables and utensils from the heaps of rubble which once formed their homes and hearths. ``They now live with only the clothes they wear,'' United News said. The village is in Guntur district, which alone accounted for 215 deaths. At least 510 people died in Andhra Pradesh state, and 10 people died in neighboring Tamil Nadu state. Relief officials said 6.5 million people had been affected by the storm, which at its peak tore into Andhra Pradesh with winds up to 155 mph. The destruction was worse than that caused by a 1977 cyclone that killed 10,000 people. Officials credited early satellite warnings and evacuations with keeping the death toll low compared to 1977. Most of the casualties occurred when houses, mostly made of mud and palm thatch, collapsed.

DOC.HEAD: Study: Most Teen-Agers Outgrow Personality Troubles in 2 Years
DOC.TEXT: Adolescents with personality disturbances serious enough to be considered disorders usually are just going through ``a phase'' and outgrow them in a couple years, a study presented to psychiatrists suggests. Another researcher called the findings a ``hopeful statement'' for exasperated parents of teen-agers. The study was presented Monday to the annual meeting of the American Psychiatric Association by David Bernstein, a psychologist at the Bronx Veterans Administration Medical Center and the Mount Sinai School of Medicine. He cautioned that for other youths with personality disturbances, the troubles can be an early warning of long-standing difficulties. So, he said, parents should consider getting the adolescent evaluated by a mental health professional if personality problems appear persistent. The researchers focused on 10 types of personality disorder: _ Paranoid, a tendency to view the actions of others as deliberately demeaning or threatening. _ Schizoid, in which a person neither wants nor enjoys close relationships, and often appears cold and aloof. _ Schizotypal, a pervasive pattern of peculiarities in thoughts and behavior such as superstitiousness, bizarre fantasies and preoccupations. _ Histrionic, which involves excessive emotionality and attention-seeking. _ Narcissistic, which includes a grandiose sense of self-importance, extreme sensitivity to criticism and inability to recognize how other people feel. _ Borderline, an instability in self-image, mood and relationships with others. _ Avoidant, a pervasive pattern of discomfort in social settings, timidity and extreme fear of disapproval. _ Dependent, which involves submissive behavior in a variety of contexts. _ Obsessive-compulsive, a pattern of perfectionism and inflexibility in a variety of contexts. _ Passive-aggressive, a pervasive tendency to resist meeting social and business obligations by such indirect means as procrastination or claiming to forget do to things. Such traits appear in many healthy people, but can become a disorder if they form an inflexible pattern that significantly interferes with social or occupational functioning, or causes the person distress. The study included 776 participants drawn from two New York counties. They were interviewed initially at ages 9 to 19, and again two years later. Researchers found that 17 percent could be diagnosed with at least one disorder, including about one-third of 13-year-olds. But of the diagnosable participants, 59 percent were free of any personality diagnosis two years later. Only 39 percent of participants diagnosable for passive-aggressive disorder in the initial interview met criteria for that disorder two years later, and the other disorders were even less persistent. Bernstein did the research with colleague Dr. Larry Siever and Patricia Cohen and her colleagues at the New York State Psychiatric Institute. The study's results do not mean that adolescent problems can be ignored, cautioned Dr. Daniel Offer, director of the Center for the Study of Adolescence at Michael Reese Hospital and Medical Center in Chicago. ``You have to take adolescent problems seriously, some do grow out of it and some don't, and you never know who will and who won't,'' he said. If the troubles are serious and affecting more than one area of an adolescent's life, a mental health professional should be consulted, he said. Offer also said he thinks two years is too brief to be sure the problems are truly gone. But he said the findings constitute a ``hopeful statement.'' ``So many parents have so many negative experiences with teen-age children and they're so pessimistic that I think it's nice to have that kind of statement,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Kohl: Elections for United Germany Could be Held by Year's End
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with Kohl flying to East Germany; Pickup 4th, Asked whether...'
DOC.TEXT: Chancellor Helmut Kohl indicated today that elections for a united German government could be held as soon as December. On Sunday, however, he suffered a devastating loss in state elections and lost control of the upper house of parliament to the opposition Social Democrats, eroding his power to dictate the terms and timing of German unification. Kohl suffered another setback over the weekend when experts from both Germanys failed to agree on key aspects of unification. The chancellor flew to West Berlin later today for talks with East German Premiere Lothar de Maiziere. The two men were expected to discuss the pace of unification. Asked whether there could be all-German elections this year, Kohl said today he was ``standing by'' West German federal elections on Dec. 2. But he also said ``there are discussions'' in East Germany about holding all-German elections this year. Kohl said he thought is was important to discuss the issue ``if that is what's desired.'' Government sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Kohl was signaling that he did not exclude the possibility of all-German elections before year's end. Kohl was scheduled to meet this evening with de Maiziere for their first formal talks on the increasingly tense unification process. On Sunday, his Christian Democrats suffered defeats in two key states _ North Rhine-Westphalia and Lower Saxony. The victories by the Social Democratic Party gave Kohl's opponents control of the Bundesrat, the upper house of West Germany's Parliament. The lower house, the Bundestag, is the main lawmaking body. The Bundesrat acts only as a ratifying body for laws passed by the Bundestag. But Kohl's loss of seats could cause complications for his goal of quick unification. The upper house no longer will be expected to rubber stamp legislation needed for quick unification. The left-leaning Social Democrats have been trying to put the brakes on Kohl's push for swift unification, which they say threatens the jobs and pocketbooks of Germans in both countries. By capturing the upper house of parliament, the Social Democrats will have more influence over the pace of unification. The vote also strengthens their bid to unseat Kohl in national elections in December. The East German Social Democrats said in a statement today the election outcome means ``the influence of Social Democratic policies on the unity process has become distinctly greater because of the election outcome.'' ``The social fears of people in both parts of Germany may no longer be ignored,'' the statement said. Hans-Jochen Vogel, head of West Germany's Social Democrats, said late Sunday the governing party's losses were a sign Kohl was suffering for not taking into account West German concerns over unification. Many West Germans fear they will pay for the hundreds of billions of marks needed to bail out the East German economy. Kohl called the results a ``disappointing defeat'' and acknowledged it may have been generated in part by ``uncertainty'' over unification costs. He accused the leftists of waging a ``fear campaign.'' The election losses came amid another jolt for Kohl _ the failure of a team of experts from both Germanys to agree on key aspects of unification. Late Saturday, delegations from both Germanys completed the draft of a treaty that is to serve as the basis for the economic, currency and social union of the countries by July 2. Dieter Vogel, spokesman for Kohl, said one of the touchiest unification issues _ whether to allow West Germans to buy up East German property _ has been put on the back burner. ``Negotiations will be continued this week on a political level,'' he said in Bonn Sunday. The failure to agree on how to transfer East Germany's state-owned property and industries to the private sector indicates de Maiziere is reluctant to allow West German interests to buy up East Germany's vast state-owned holdings. De Maiziere, like Kohl, favors a quick shift to a free market and fast unification. But he has been under pressure from East Germany's Social Democrats, who are part of his governing coalition, to seek more social guarantees for East Germans and slow the pace of talks. West German Social Democrats have warned that unification has not been properly thought out and could lead to unemployment, weakening of the West German mark and inflation. Specifics of the economic agreement reached this past weekend were not released, but they likely will flesh out details of how West Germany's currency will become the currency of East Germany this summer. West Germany had agreed earlier to trade East German marks for West German marks at a 1-to-1 rate for salaries, pensions and small savings accounts. The West German newspaper Welt am Sonntag also reported on Sunday that West Germany agreed to provide more social guarantees to students and elderly people.

DOC.HEAD: Levinger Carried to Prison Gates on Shoulders of Supporters
DOC.TEXT: Rabbi Moshe Levinger, a founder of the Jewish settlement movement, was carried on the shoulders of hundreds of armed supporters to an Israeli prison today to begin a five-month sentence for killing a Palestinian. The settlers sang the anthem of the settlement movement ``Am Israel Chai,'' which is Hebrew for ``The Jewish People Live.'' Many waved Israeli flags and some raised loaded assault rifles in the air. Levinger pled guilty to death by negligence in the shooting of a Hebron shoestore owner on Sept. 30, 1988. He was originally charged with manslaughter, but the charges were reduced in a plea bargain. He was sentenced on May 1. According to witnesses, Levinger fired indiscriminately after Palestinian youths stoned his car. The victim, Kayed Sallah, 42, was hit in his stomach as he stood before his shop. Levinger and other radical settlers in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip have charged that the army is not doing enough to protect them against Palestinian stone-throwers. ``I'm going to prison because of the army's failure to provide security,'' Levinger, who lives in Hebron, told the Yediot Ahronot daily today. He demanded that former Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin be jailed instead of him for failing to crush the 29-month Palestinian uprising against Israeli occupation of the Gaza Strip and West Bank. Speaking to cheering supporters before entering prison today, Levinger said: ``We are not gathered here because of me but because of the nation.'' Shortly after being admitted to prison, Levinger complained of not feeling well and was examined at nearby Meir Hospital, said Prison spokeswoman Shulamit Meiri. Doctors said Levinger was well enough to serve his term and ordered him returned to prison, Mrs. Meiri said. Levinger is only the second settler to be sentenced to prison for killing a Palestinian since the uprising began. The Israeli Information Center for Human Rights in the Occupied Territories reported 29 Palestinians killed by settlers. At least 685 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli gunfire in the uprising and another 212 have been slain by fellow Arabs for apparently colaborating with Israeli authorities. At least 43 Israelis have been slain. Levinger, a leader of the religious nationalist Gush Emunim, or Bloc of the Faithful, established a 200-member settlement in Hebron shortly after Israel captured it in the 1967 Middle East war.

DOC.HEAD: Town to Honor Mount St. Helens Victim
DOC.TEXT: A cancellation marking and envelope bearing the likenesses of Mount St. Helens and Harry Truman will be Ivydale's tribute to the native son who died in the volcano's eruption a decade ago. The 84-year-old Truman was the only resident who refused to leave the slopes of the mountain in Washington state before it blew its top May 18, 1980. Ivydale postmaster Mary Lou Douglas came up with the idea of honoring Truman, who was born here in 1896 and moved to Washington with his parents in 1908. The envelope pictures Mount St. Helens spewing a plume of smoke that outlines Truman's profile. The cancellation carries the volcano's likeness. Julie Perdue, a sophomore at Clay County High School, did the artwork. Perdue was only five when Mount St. Helens erupted, but she remembers news coverage of Truman. ``That guy got killed because he wouldn't get off. He was quite a character,'' she said. ``He sure cussed a lot.''

DOC.HEAD: Civil Rights Leaders Worry Administration May Oppose Bill
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 10 grafs White House comments on civil rights bill; picks up 3rd graf pvs, The civil...; deletes old graf 6, Arthur Fletcher..., now redundant
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is still concerned about what he regards as hiring quotas in a major civil rights bill pending in Congress, but hopes for changes that will make the measure acceptable, his spokesman said today. ``The president would like to sign a civil rights bill. ... We will be working toward that end,'' White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said. He made the comments shortly before Bush sat down with black civil rights leaders at the first of a series of three meetings this week on the Kennedy-Hawkins Civil Rights Act of 1990, awaiting floor action in both the House and Senate. The Justice Department last month raised the threat of a veto over the quota issue. The bill would undo a series of Supreme Court rulings last year that narrowed protections against job discrimination that minorities had enjoyed since the 1970s. It also would expand protection for women. House sponsors earlier this month adopted compromise language to meet employers' concerns about having to defend their hiring patterns. Fitzwater said there have been changes ``in the right direction. ... It appears to be moving closer to being acceptable.'' ``The problem was that many of the provisions in the bill ended up mandating quotas in one way or another,'' Fitzwater said. He said he would not repeat the veto threat at this juncture, but said, ``We had a very serious problem with the legal assumption that people were guilty until proven innocent. The very basic kind of legal philosophy in this country is the opposite, that you're innocent until proven guilty.'' Arthur A. Fletcher, chairman of the Civil Rights Commission, said in an interview Sunday that conservatives and the civil rights establishment were fighting ``a battle for the president's mind.'' Bush in April urged Congress to take less sweeping action to undo two of the Supreme Court rulings that narrowed protection against job discrimination. The civil rights measures pose a ``critical'' test for the Bush administration, which has sought to improve relations with civil rights organizations that were frayed during the Reagan years, Julius Chambers, director-counsel of the NAACP Legal Defense Fund, said Sunday. ``The course of action being urged by the Justice Department will drown out all the lofty rhetoric and fine-sounding speeches that we have heard from the Oval Office,'' Chambers warned in a speech at the University of North Carolina Law School. ``The toxin of veto will poison all the wells of good feeling towards the president that have sprung up (in) the black community,'' he said. The Leadership Conference on Civil Rights, which is spearheading the lobbying effort for passage of the bill, provided a copy of Chambers' text. Fletcher, in a telephone interview from Norfolk, Va., where he was attending a college commencement, said the White House has arranged a series of meetings this week with outside groups, including prominent black conservatives as well as the leadership of mainstream civil rights organizations. Bush also has a Rose Garden ceremony planned for Thursday to honor Fletcher and other members of the recently reconstituted Civil Rights Commission, mired in controversy for much of the Reagan administration and nearly killed off by Congress last year. Fletcher, a moderate Republican and former assistant secretary of labor in the Nixon administration, said, ``the Kennedy-Hawkins bill is more comprehensive in my view than the administration bill.'' He emphasized that he was speaking only for himself, not for the Civil Rights Commission. He said the conservatives ``do not want to authorize anything that smacks of quotas'' in hiring. Fletcher said he does not regard the Kennedy-Hawkins bill as requiring quotas. The bill would undo the Supreme Court's Patterson vs. McLean Credit Union ruling, which narrowed the ability of minorities to win monetary damages for job discrimination. It would also restore the burden of proof to defendants in cases where employers' hiring practices had a discriminatory impact. Under a 1971 ruling in the case Griggs vs. Duke Power Co., the employers had the burden of proving their hiring practices were required by business necessity. The high court, in a case called Wards Cove Packing Co. vs. Atonio, undid that last year. Ralph G. Neas, executive director of the Leadership Conference on Civil Rights, claimed that the recent adoption of compromise language in the House Education and Labor Committee on the burden of proof has expanded bipartisan support for the civil rights bill _ and increased the administration's anxiety. ``At least a two-thirds majority supports the bill in both houses,'' Neas said. The bill was approved by the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee 11-5 last month and by the House labor panel 23-10 on May 9.

DOC.HEAD: Jordanian Troops Break Up Peace Demonstration With Tear Gas
LaserPhoto AMM1
DOC.TEXT: Jordanian troops and riot police Monday tossed tear gas and smoke bombs at demonstrators to stop them from crossing into the Israeli-occupied West Bank during a pro-Palestinian march. ``There was nothing else for us to do,'' a riot policeman on the scene said. ``We had to stop them by force.'' The 2,500 protesters included scores of Palestinians deported after Israel seized the West Bank from Jordan in the 1967 war. They broke away from a larger group of more than 20,000 marchers. Hospital sources said at least 103 people were injured when the march, called to promote Arab-Israeli peace and an independent Palestinian state, turned violent. Interior Minister Salem Masadeh put the injury toll at only 52. There no immediate explanation for the difference in figures given by the government and hospitals. ``Some elements, probably due to ignorance, have succeeded in ruining this march and its peaceful image for the good cause of the Palestinians,'' Masadeh said in a telephone interview. Police fired machine guns in the air to disperse the demonstrators, while the army tossed tear gas canisters from six tanks. Ambulances raced to the scene amid exploding smoke bombs and tear gas to evacuate the casualties to Shuna Hospital, five miles north of the King Hussein-Allenby Bridge. Some of the injured appeared to have broken limbs. A few were bleeding after being trampled when hysterical crowds ran in all directions. Most of casualties were unconscious after inhaling too much gas, said Shuna Hospital sources, insisting on anonymity. They reported no gunshot wounds. The barrage lasted about 1{ hours, and many teen-agers were seen throwing stones at the tanks and the policemen. It was not clear if any of the estimated 700 policemen or 300 soldiers were injured. The army and police had instructed the crowd to stop 700 yards from the bridge over the Jordan River to avoid antagonizing the Israelis on the other side. But when the demonstrators arrived at that point after a one-hour walk from Hajjaj City, three miles to the north, some 2,500 demonstrators broke away and tried to run toward the wooden bridge. The ground was scattered with Palestinian flags, portraits of Palestinian figures and anti-American and anti-Israeli banners waved during the march. The march was organized by 120 Arab unions and professional associations to mark the 42nd anniversary of the United Nations' partition plan that sliced British-mandated Palestine into Jewish and Arab states. The participants included Jordanian citizens, Arab trade unionists, Jordanian Parliament members as well as Palestinians. Roughly half of Jordan's 3.1 million people come from Palestinian families who fled or were driven out during the 1948 and 1967 Arab-Israeli wars. The demonstrators waved banners saying, ``America is the head of the snake.'' Other slogans read: ``America is the number one enemy of the Arabs as it is the strategic ally of the cancerous Zionist entity.'' The crowd chanted ``We want an independent Palestine state amd homes to shelter our childrens,'' as well as Palestinian songs. Many waved the Palestinian flag and portraits of Khalil al-Wazir, who was deputy commander of the Palestine Liberation Organization. He was killed by a commando unit, widely believed to be Israeli, in April 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Taiwan Military Reportedly to Patrol Seas When Democracy Ship Leaves
DOC.TEXT: Taiwan will send fighter planes and naval ships to patrol local waters when the radio ship Goddess of Democracy leaves port to beam pro-democracy messages to China, local media reported Monday. Military officials quoted by the liberal Independence Morning Post and other newspapers reiterated pledges to protect the ship in Taiwan waters. But Defense Minister Hau Pei-tsun said there would be no escort once the vessel reaches international waters to begin the broadcasts. The reports appeared one day after China again accused Taiwan of supporting the ``illegal activities'' of the ship. Beijing has refused to rule out the use of force to stop the broadcasts. Organizers of the Goddess of Democracy's trip said it would head for international waters Thursday. It is three days behind schedule because of difficulty obtaining Taiwan customs approval to bring broadcasting equipment on board. The ship, sponsored by a coalition of French news organizations, docked at the northern port of Keelung on Sunday. It remained in the harbor Monday to refuel and take on water and other supplies. The Goddess of Democracy is named after the statue erected by pro-democracy demonstrators in Tiananmen Square in Beijing last May. It was destroyed during the June 4 military crackdown that left hundreds, perhaps thousands, of demonstrators dead. The broadcasts are to include a taped message from Chai Ling, one of the student leaders wanted by Chinese authorities for leading the pro-democracy protests in Beijing. Ms. Chai, who escaped to France this year after 10 months in hiding in China, will appeal to the Beijing leadership not to suppress the people's desire for democracy, said Hong Kong journalist Nancy Li. China's paramount leader, Deng Xiaoping, ``thought we wanted him to be killed,'' Ms. Li quoted Ms. Chai as saying. ``But all we wanted was to live a better life. We just wanted to ask him: `Aren't you interested in letting people have a better life?''' Ms. Li, who plans to board the ship to help broadcast, said the programs also will tell Chinese people about the protests that have toppled communist regimes in Eastern Europe. ``It will be good for the Chinese people to know there were other ways to handle protests,'' she said. Project organizers have expressed concern that authorities will refuse to let prominent Chinese dissident Yan Jiaqi, who arrived in Taiwan last week, board the ship to make broadcasts. Local newspapers also said the government will not allow broadcasters recruited in Taiwan to participate. Taiwan's Nationalist government has refused to support the vessel, saying its plan to make unauthorized broadcasts is a violation of international law. Taiwan officials say the ship will not be allowed to return to refuel in Taiwan if it goes ahead with its plans. The Nationalists retreated to Taiwan in 1949 after losing a civil war to Communist forces in mainland China. While the two sides remain technically at war, indirect trade and civilian contacts have increased greatly in recent years.

DOC.HEAD: White House Sees No Quick Solutions at Budget Summit
DOC.TEXT: The White House said today that efforts to strike a budget deal with Congress, a pact that Chief of Staff John Sununu says could include tax increases, will take ``weeks if not months.'' ``I look for this to be a longer process rather than a shorter process,'' presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said on the eve of the first budget summit session. Fitzwater said that Bush will kick off Tuesday's 2 p.m. meeting in the White House with ``opening remarks certainly welcoming the group and applauding their coming together to help solve this important problem.'' ``After that, the fun starts,'' Fitzwater added. He said Bush has ``points he wants to make'' at the opening meeting. ``He'll have general goals about getting the deficit down.'' However, Fitzwater said, Bush would not lay down an opening proposal as such. Bush planned to meet today with Budget Direct Richard G. Darman and Defense Secretary Dick Cheney to help prepare himself for the budget talks. Meanwhile, Darman was to meet with House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., ``to work out meeting procedures,'' Fitzwater said. Fitzwater said that budget negotiators would meet as frequently as daily until agreement was reached. But, he added, ``It will go on probably weeks if not months. It is not the kind of thing where anybody expects to run in and throw a proposal on the table and vote on it.'' ``It's going to be painstakingly worked out sentence by sentence and debate by debate over a longer period of time.'' Fitzwater would not discuss the possibility that the budget summit might result in tax increases, even though Sununu said on Sunday that tax increases were ``a possibility but no certainty.'' But, while not commenting on Sununu's words, Fitzwater said: ``I can assure you that President Bush has the highest confidence in John Sununu and is delighted with the quality of his work.'' ``It is a budget summit, not a tax summit,'' Sununu said Sunday as he sought to calm the storm over his earlier remarks indicating that President Bush had no intention of deviating from his no-new-taxes campaign pledge. The chairmen of the House and Senate budget committees indicated Sunday that gun-shy Democrats will insist that Bush take the lead in proposing any tax increases. Rep. Leon E. Panetta, chairman of the House Budget Committee, said if there are any tax increases in the final package, it will be because Bush wants them there. ``I can assure you that the issue of taxes are not going to be raised or discussed or approved unless the president thinks that they're necessary for deficit reduction,'' Panetta said on CBS' ``Face the Nation.'' Sen. James Sasser, D-Tenn., chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, said he did not intend to be the first to suggest raising taxes ``and I don't think the Democrats will.'' Bush ``would have to propose revenues. ... And the president would have to help sell those revenues to the Congress and to the American people,'' Sasser said on ABC's ``This Week with David Brinkley.'' Sununu, who appeared on NBC's ``Meet the Press,'' told reporters last week that it was the Democrats' prerogative to put tax increases on the bargaining table ``and it's our prerogative to say no.'' Sununu said Sunday that reporters had mistakenly assumed ``that there would be taxes ... in a final budget. The fact is, there's no preconditions means there's a possibility but no certainty.'' Richard Darman, the White House budget director, said, ``we shouldn't consider a tax increase independently of major budget process reform.'' Darman, speaking on the Brinkley show, said Bush would like to emerge from the summit with line-item veto authority _ the ability to kill spending on specific projects or programs without striking down an entire appropriations bill. Darman said a realistic goal for the negotiators is finding budget savings of $45 billion to $55 billion in the first year. Darman warned last week the deficit for fiscal 1991 could run as much as $100 billion over the $64 billion allowed by Gramm-Rudman. ``It's not going to be sensible to try to contract that much in one year,'' said Darman. ``But let's say $50 billion.''

DOC.HEAD: Superpower Missile Swap: A Sign of Post-Cold War Times
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 16th graf pvs, The SS-20, to CORRECT pounds to tons
DOC.TEXT: The superpowers are about to commit an act they've tried mightily to avoid throughout 45 years of Cold War: an intercontinental nuclear exchange. This one, though, will be friendly. Nuclear missiles of the type the United States and the Soviet Union had aimed across the East-West divide _ but are now withdrawing _ are to be propped up, painted and polished, side by side, in museums in Washington and Moscow. It's a small sign of fast-changing times in which military competition is lessening and new symbols of superpower cooperation are replacing Cold War confrontation. A Soviet SS-20 and an American Pershing 2 _ minus their nuclear warheads _ will be displayed at the Smithsonian Institution's National Air and Space Museum. They'll stand in the Milestones of Flight gallery, amid such aviation icons as the 1903 Wright brothers original flier, the Spirit of St. Louis and a replica of Sputnik 1, the Soviet satellite that was the first manmade object placed in Earth's orbit. A separate exhibit in the museum's Space Hall will display pictures of the missiles; copies of the Intermediate-range Nuclear Forces, or INF, treaty, which governs destruction of the missiles and their launchers, and chunks of destroyed INF missiles. The Space Hall exhibit will be titled ``Do Veri, No Pro Veri.'' The Russian proverb, meaning ``trust, but verify,'' was then-President Reagan's favorite way of describing the central message of the INF treaty he signed Dec. 7, 1987. The exhibit opens June 20. A similar display is due to open at Moscow's Central Armed Forces Museum, the city's main military museum, sometime this summer. On Thursday, a team of American officials will arrive in Moscow to swap a disarmed Pershing 2 for the SS-20 that will be shipped in five pieces to the Smithsonian. Later this month, Soviet technicians are to fly to Washington to assemble the SS-20, whose 54-foot length will barely fit inside the museum. The slimmer, lighter, faster and more modern Pershing 2 is 34 feet long. Smithsonian officials had wanted the missiles in place by the time Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev arrived in Washington May 30 for a summit meeting with President Bush, said Gregg Herken, chairman of the museum's space history department. But bureaucratic obstacles set back the original schedule, and Herken said it was not certain whether the exhibit would be finished before Gorbachev leaves June 3. ``It's possible we'll be assembling the SS-20 here while the summit is going on,'' he said, adding that it will be the first Soviet missile ever displayed at the Smithsonian. Herken acknowledged that the exhibit is a departure from the Air and Space Museum's usual practice of showcasing peaceful advances in technology and human accomplishment. He said the museum wanted to commemorate not the missiles themselves but the landmark agreement that brought about their destruction. ``That is an icon of human achievement,'' he said. The SS-20 is the main Soviet missile being destroyed under terms of the INF treaty, which banned all U.S. and Soviet land-based nuclear missiles with ranges of 310 to 3,410 miles. The American missiles in this category are the Pershing 2 and Tomahawk ground-launched cruise missiles deployed in five European NATO countries. The SS-20, which Moscow began deploying in 1979, carries three nuclear warheads with a total destructive power of 750 kilotons, the equivalent of 750,000 tons of TNT. That is about 50 times more powerful than the atomic bomb that destroyed Hiroshima in 1945. The single-warhead Pershing 2 carried a 50-kiloton warhead and was deployed in West Germany starting in 1983. The idea for exchanging INF missiles and putting them on public display began with two Air and Space Museumcurators, Frank Winter and Paul Ceruzzi, who noticed a 1988 newspaper article on the INF treaty that said both sides would be allowed to keep up to 15 disarmed missiles for ``static display.'' Herken said that before the slippage in the exhibit schedule he had tried to interest the Bush administration in using the missile display during the summit as a backdrop for a joint appearance by the leaders. Herken said the White House seemed willing but unofficial word was that the Kremlin wouldn't go along. ``We understand privately that Gorbachev doesn't want to be photographed next to a missile,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Vietnamese Mistook for Koreans, Jumped by Blacks; One Arrest Made
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `Initially, authorities..', to end to UPDATE with police saying one person arrested; add quotes from victim. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Mayor David Dinkins condemned ``eye for an eye'' violence after a gang of blacks attacked three Vietnamese they mistook for Koreans, fracturing one man's skull blocks from a black boycott of two Korean stores. The attack in Brooklyn early Sunday was the latest in a string of incidents that have heightened racial tensions in the city. ``An eye for an eye, a tooth for a tooth, will leave us all toothless and blind,'' the mayor said in his second appeal for racial calm since Friday. The Vietnamese men were set upon by 10 to 15 blacks shouting anti-Korean slurs, authorities said. Tuan Ana Cao, 36, was hit with a baseball bat and was in guarded condition today with a skull fracture at Kings County Hospital. Police announced early this afternoon that there had been one arrest, but gave no details pending a news conference later. Initially, authorities said it appeared the attack began as a robbery attempt and escalated into racial violence, but Cao said no robbery attempt occurred before the attack. Police said there apparently had been a misunderstanding. A few blocks from the site of the attack, two Korean-American grocery stores have been boycotted by blacks since Jan. 18, when a black woman allegedly was roughed up by personnel in one of the stores after she refused to let them look in her purse. As the mayor spoke Sunday, two juries in Brooklyn were deliberating charges against two young white men accused of murdering a black 16-year-old who had entered the mostly white Bensonhurst section to look at a used car Aug. 23. The juries resumed deliberations this morning. Cao told police someone threw a bottle through a window and that he and two other Vietnamese went outside to see what was going on and saw 10 to 15 blacks, one of them yelling anti-Korean slurs and shouting, ``Get out of America!'' The gang attacked the men and fled before police arrived. Cao, interviewed by New York Newsday at the hospital Sunday, said he heard shouts of, ``Kill him! Kill the Koreans! Kill the Chinese! Go back home!'' He said he was shocked by the brutality of the attack, adding in halting English, ``I don't understand.'' Cao said he was unable to see much because his glasses were broken during the beating. The mayor visited Cao at the hospital and called for legislation to increase penalties for mob violence. He also asked business, religious and civic leaders to help quell the unrest. Cao said he had been mugged four times in the neighborhood, but there was no robbery preceding the attack as police initially reported. Police said the erroneous report may have come about because Cao was disoriented because of his injuries or had been misunderstood by an interpreter. Officers plan to reinterview Cao as his condition improves, said Officer Kim Royster, a police spokeswoman.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands March to Protest Desecration of Jewish Graves
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 17 grafs to UPDATE with march beginning, that President Mitterrand participating; pickup 14th graf pvs, `Police sealed...'
DOC.TEXT: Tens of thousands of people, including President Francois Mitterrand and survivors of the Holocaust, marched silently through Paris tonight, protesting the recent desecrations of Jewish cemeteries. Many wore yellow Stars of David. The march initially was organized in response to vandalism last week at a cemetery in the southern town of Carpentras, where tombs were smashed and a recently buried body dug up and mutilated. Another desecration was discovered early today at a cemetery near Paris, where obscenities and swastikas were painted in red on more than 30 tombs. Mitterrand's presence _ not announced in advance _ was believed to mark the first time since World War II that a French president had joined a public demonstration. Premier Michel Rocard, Chief Rabbi Joseph Sitruk and Roman Catholic Cardinal Albery Decourtray were among the throng of marchers who left from the the Place de la Republique. Rocard said he wanted to help show the world that France's ``true image'' was one of tolerance. At the request of Jewish leaders, the country's six largest TV networks agreed to broadcast tonight ``Night and Fog,'' a documentary about Nazi death camps. The coalition of Jewish groups organizing the procession asked that marchers display only authorized banners and posters with the slogan: ``No to racism. No to anti-Semitism.'' Leaders of every major political party except the extreme-right National Front urged supporters to participate, as did human rights groups and many major labor unions. Police meanwhile appealed for witnesses to assist in their investigation of the desecration in Carpentras. Five skinheads were released after being questioned about the crime. The desecration there provoked outrage across France. In Haifa, Israel, over the weekend, about 300 graves were spray-painted with anti-Jewish slogans, and police said a Jew from a nearby town had been arrested as a suspect. Thousands of people went to the cemetery Sunday and relatives wept at the graves of their dead. In Lund, Sweden, 15 tombstones marking the graves of World War II refugees were toppled at a churchyard cemetery during the weekend. A church official said today the graves were not of Jews, but that the vandalism may have been inspired by the other desecrations. Police sealed off the Carpentras cemetery today without explanation, and the widow of the man whose body was dug up reportedly left Carpentras after having received telephoned death threats. Interior Minister Pierre Joxe, along with other political and human rights leaders, has accused far-right politician Jean-Marie Le Pen of implicit responsibility in the desecration by creating an atmosphere of racial hatred. Le Pen, who said in an interview today the government was providing him with bodyguards, once termed the Nazi gas chambers ``a detail'' of history. His National Front favors the expulsion of Moslem immigrants from North Africa. Rocard has invited all main political parties except the National Front to participate Wednesday in a conference on immigration. In a letter made public Saturday, Rocard appealed to invited parties to put aside partisan interests and forge a common stand on the issue. Bernard Deleplace, secretary-general of France's largest union of policemen, urged off-duty officers to join the Paris protest, even though officers not supposed to engage in political demonstration.

DOC.HEAD: Greenhouse Effect Can Disrupt Agriculture Without Raising Temperatures
DOC.TEXT: The build-up of carbon dioxide and other gases in the atmosphere will disrupt agriculture even if it doesn't produce a significant temperature rise, a researcher said Monday. Many researchers believe that the carbon dioxide build-up from use of fossil fuels and destruction of forests will raise temperatures at least several degrees during the next few decades. Some researchers dispute that, however. Their view has been used by the Bush administration to justify a wait-and-see response to the so-called greenhouse effect. Fakhri Bazzaz, a Harvard University biologist, argued at a Rockefeller Foundation symposium on agricultural research that the carbon dioxide build-up will have a direct effect on farms and forests even if it doesn't raise temperatures. ``The cornfields in Illinois are not independent of the fate of the tropical forests,'' he said. While researchers might disagree over the temperature effects of the carbon dioxide build-up, no one disagrees about the carbon dioxide build-up itself. Several decades of research have shown that carbon dioxide already has increased substantially and is continuing to increase, researchers say. Bazzaz, who has grown plants in enclosures with air rich in carbon dioxide, has found that the plants grow faster, but that their leaves may be less nutritious. Leafy vegetables eaten by humans may change their chemistry so much that they will become unpalatable, he said. The accelerated growth of plants in response to increased carbon dioxide might seem beneficial, but that means increases in weed growth as well as crop growth, he said. Plants will grow faster only if they get more nutrients from the soil along with the increased carbon dioxide in the atmosphere, he said. In some circumstances, weeds may be more easily able to overcome crops because the weeds will respond better to the increased carbon dioxide. Because the plants' leaves will contain less nitrogen, insects will have to eat more of the leaves to get the nutrients they need. Thus, crop losses to insects may increase, Bazzaz said. Plants will decompose more slowly, his experiments show, so it will take longer for nutrients to be replaced in the soil. These observations mean that it might be necessary to increase the use of fertilizers and pesticides, he said. In natural areas such as tropical rain forests, the complex relationships among different species will change, leading some to dominate and others to become extinct, he said. One possibly beneficial effect is that plants may be able to survive with less watering or less rainfall. The point of all these findings, he said, is that ``there are a lot of uncertainties here. There is a great need for more research.'' Simple predictions that increased carbon dioxide will lead to more rapid plant growth and thus benefit agriculture are naive, he said. Much more must be learned about the response of individual plants and entire ecosystems to the changes, he said. However, that does not justify government inaction, he said. ``The notion that we don't know enough _ let's wait for more research _ is not a good one. We need immediate action.''

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Precede VILNIUS
Gorbachev Rejects Latvian, Estonian Independence Moves
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs with Gorbachev rejecting Latvian, Estonian independence moves; EDITS thereafter to CONFORM. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today rejected independence moves by Latvia and Estonia, declaring the measures illegal. In presidential decrees read on the nightly news program ``Vremya,'' Gorbachev said Latvia's May 4 declaration of independence and Estonia's March 30 declaration that it was an occupied country violated Soviet law and the constitution. He did not indicate what he would do to counter the independence measures. The Baltic states of Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia were forcibly annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940. Lithuania declared its independence March 11, and the Kremlin responded by imposing an economic blockade on the republic. Latvia and Estonia passed more cautious measures, allowing for an unspecified transition period to independence, but Gorbachev's response showed their moves were equally unacceptable. The presidential decrees, in legal language and read by an announcer, listed which points of the law and constitution the Estonian and Latvian measures violated. Gorbachev rebuked the republics, saying Estonia had acted ``without having consulted with the people of the republic, ignoring its existing economic, political, cultural and legal ties,'' with the Soviet Union. He Latvia also had ``gone against the rights and interests of other subjects of the Soviet federation.'' Gorbachev said Latvia's decree was ``invalid from the moment of its passage'' and issued a similar ruling about the Estonian measure. His announcement came a day after Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis said the three Baltic leaders had sent a letter to Gorbachev and President Bush, asking them ``to take our problem into their hearts.'' He declined to release the text of what he called ``a diplomatic communication'' but said the Baltic leaders also asked Gorbachev to meet with them. The presidents of the three republics met Saturday to re-establish a 56-year-old political bloc and form a united front in their bid for secession from the Soviet Union. Lithuanian Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene, returning from a 16-day tour of Western capitals, told reporters in Moscow Sunday that she would propose that the republic's parliament suspend laws implementing its March 11 declaration of independence. Mrs. Prunskiene also said she believed she had gained ``de facto recognition'' of her breakaway republic from Western governments during her trip abroad. Traveling as a private citizen, she met in the United States with Bush, and with leaders in Canada, France, Britain and West Germany. Although she was warmly received, the West in general has adopted a cautious attitude toward the situation in Lithuania, not wanting to cause more problems for Gorbachev as he wrestles with domestic reform. Mrs. Prunskiene said Lithuania was prepared to suspend those of its new laws that concern Moscow most as a pre-condition for talks, and expected the Kremlin to lift its economic blockade of the republic of 3.8 million. The Kremlin's economic sanctions have caused an energy shortage and resulted in the layoffs of 12,000 workers, according to official reports.

DOC.HEAD: Bright & Brief
DOC.TEXT: Homer Simpson, the boneheaded cartoon dad on TV's ``The Simpsons'' may be the nation's best-known nuclear plant worker, and he has a solid core of fans at the San Onofre Nuclear Generating Station. Homer is to San Onofre employees what Jackie Gleason was to bus drivers when ``The Honeymooners'' show was big _ someone in their shoes but whose shoes they would hate to be in. ``Homer is my hero. He could work here,'' San Onofre engineer Al Meichler said last week. ``Homer sounds like a candidate for upper management,'' said Richard Rice, a nuclear chemistry foreman. Maintenance machinist Pat Daugherty added: ``In the protected area, there's about five guys in there just like him.'' But Southern California Edison Co., which owns the plant on the San Diego County coast, says Homer wouldn't qualify. ``The people we hire are pretty high-quality in terms of intellectual ability,'' said Edison spokesman Dave Barron. ``Homer Simpson couldn't get a job anywhere near here.''

Carol Jong wanted to leave an indelible mark on the University of Kansas. So she did it seven times. In its 103rd edition, the university's 1990 yearbook features photos of Jong in seven different looks. Not under the same name, of course. There's Buffi J. Baker in business. Or Bertha Heffer in engineering. Even Violet Couleur in fine arts. Going the extra mile, try Anne (U.) Rissom in allied health. And Dorrie N. Collum in architecture. Some of the aliases were tailor-made for particular schools while others ``just fit the stereotypes,'' Ms. Jong said. Ms. Jong's roommate tried to join in the prank, submitting fake photos, but all her fakes were rejected from the yearbook, the Jayhawker. ``We wanted to leave our mark at K.U.,'' said Ms. Jong, who's graduating this year with a liberal arts degree. ``Since we're not athletes or student presidents or anything, we wanted to be remembered for something special.'' The Jayhawker staff wasn't amused. ``I mean, it's a great joke as far as she's concerned,'' said Jeannine Kreker, assistant editor. ``But as far as Kansas alumni and everybody who's going to look at this book years from now is concerned, it makes us and the university look pretty silly.'' Not all of Ms. Jong's fakes made it: There's no Penny Sylan in pharmacy.

The staff at the West Overton Museum didn't think people would miss it when they retired one of the oddities on display _ a two-headed calf. The heads, mounted on a board after the calf was born in 1922, had been displayed from 1930 to 1987 at the museum, which specializes in exhibits of farm and industrial implements used in southwestern Pennsylvania. Over the years, the relic was popular with museum-goers, especially children who passed by other industrial and agricultural artifacts to gape. Still, the staff didn't think anyone would notice when the head was taken down and stored because it was deteriorating, said Kimberly Bringe, the museum's director. They were wrong. Parents who had seen the calf as children repeatedly asked about it and several people offered to buy the piece. ``I think people are naturally attracted to oddities,'' Ms. Bringe said. She had the display reconditioned by a taxidermist, and it was put up for the museum's summer season opening Tuesday. ``It's like a shrine,'' said Ms. Bringe. ``I call it the divine bovine.''

DOC.HEAD: Western Union Telegrapher From Scopes Trial Dies
DOC.TEXT: Howard Ross Hale, who as a Western Union telegrapher relayed reporter H.L. Mencken's stories of the 1925 Scopes Monkey Trial, has died at age 85. Hale, who died Saturday, was among eight telegraphers who transmitted stories on the trial, in which school teacher John T. Scopes was charged with illegally teaching Darwin's theory of evolution. Hale estimated the telegraphers sent about 175,000 words daily until the 11-day trial in the sweltering Rhea County Courthouse ended July 21, 1925. It wasn't until later that Hale realized he had been assigned to handle the copy of the most famous reporter at the trial, Mencken of The Evening Sun of Baltimore. ``I think I transmitted every dispatch he wrote for The Sun,'' Hale said in a 1985 intervew. ``But I didn't pay much attention to what was in the stories. ``I do remember that he was critical of (defense attorney Clarence) Darrow for popping his suspenders, and that was a little surprising because most of his comments about Darrow were favorable. ``And I remember that Mencken strutted around like a big gobbler turkey and demanded that his stories be given first priority.'' Hale is survived by his wife, Elsie Parker Hale, four sisters and a brother. A service is scheduled for Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Flight 103 Victims' Relatives Hope For Tough Proposals in Terrorism Inquiry
DOC.TEXT: Relatives of persons killed in the 1988 bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 said Monday they hope to see tough proposals for preventing terrorism when a presidential commission issues its findings Tuesday. The report to President Bush is expected to recommend changes in the Federal Aviation Administration's security operations and to criticize the FAA, the State Department and Pan American World Airways. The seven-member commission investigated government and airline actions before and after the bombing, which killed all 259 people aboard the Boeing 747 and 11 people on the ground in Lockerbie, Scotland. Investigators have said the jet was downed by a plastic explosive concealed in a cassette tape player. The nine-month inquiry did not address criminal aspects of the Dec. 21, 1988, bombing or attempt to evaluate U.S. participation in the British investigation, which has yet to produce any charges. Bush created the commission after relatives called for a full congressional inquiry. Some relatives already have been critical of what they fear the report will contain. Others have said they are ``cautiously optimistic.'' Ted Reina, whose daughter Jocelyn was a flight attendant on the jetliner, said he was concerned the commission could send the ``right signal to terrorists and the wrong signal to the traveling public'' if it slows FAA-mandated installation of sophisticated bomb detectors at high-risk airports. Commission members have said the FAA has not adequately encouraged other technologies. Paul Hudson of Albany, N.Y., whose daughter, Melina, died in the bombing, said he hopes the commission will ask for tough security reforms. Hudson, who heads one of two victims' groups, said he expects the commission's work to lead to changes in State Department consular affairs, which already has acknowledged mistakes in its dealings with victims' relatives.
