Aphrodite Tsairis of Franklin Lakes, N.J., representing the other victims' group, said, ``We are looking for a strong indictment that says the Pan Am bombing was clearly preventable.'' The commission, which includes four members of Congress and is headed by former Labor Secretary Ann McLaughlin, has tried to determine whether errors by any federal agency, the airline, or others might have allowed the bombing to occur. Commission investigators have said, however, that they found no ``smoking gun'' that would lead them to assess blame. Commission members did, during hearings, strongly criticize the FAA and Pan Am for security flaws and the State Department for falldowns in the notification of next of kin and return of personal belongings to relatives. The commission has no enforcement powers, but has drawn up about 60 recommendations into a report of more than 150 pages, according to staff members. FAA officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said they expect the report to be critical of the agency, which has worldwide responsibility for the security of U.S. airlines. Chairwoman McLaughlin met with Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner last week to brief him on the report, but a department spokesman said there was no in-depth discussion and that Skinner did not get a copy. A congressional source said the panel recommends a revamp of the FAA's security office to give it higher visibility. The commission held five public hearings in Washington and traveled to Europe for interviews with aviation and airline officials in France, Germany and Britain. Flight 103 originated in Frankfurt and switched to a different airliner in London before leaving for New York. Other commission members besides McLaughlin include Sens. Frank Lautenberg, D-N.J., and Alfonse D'Amato, R-N.Y.; Reps. James Oberstar, D-Minn., and John Paul Hammerschmidt, D-Ark.; retired Air Force Gen. Thomas C. Richards, and Edward Hidalgo, an attorney and former assistant Navy secretary.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Actress Kate Capshaw and director Steven Spielberg are the parents of a girl, Sasha. Sasha weighed 7 pounds, 1 ounce when delivered Monday at 5:15 a.m. at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center, said publicist John West. ``Everybody is fine. They are doing well,'' West said. The couple is not married. Spielberg has a 4-year-old son, Max, from his marriage to actress Amy Irving. Spielberg and Miss Irving were divorced last year and Miss Irving gave birth May 4 to a boy, son of Brazilian film director, Bruno Barreto. Miss Capshaw starred with Harrison Ford in ``Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom'' and with Michael Douglas in ``Black Rain.'' Spielberg has made such movies as ``1941,'' ``Color Purple'' and ``E.T. _ The Extraterrestrial.''
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For release at 6 p.m. EDT, time set by source
DOC.TEXT: Hey, Cybill Shepherd, lighten up. On second thought, don't lighten up _ go brunet if you feel that way. ``When I think of the classic blondes, I think of Marilyn Monroe _ and her suicide. So there's something tragic about it,'' the actress tells Glamour magazine in its June issue. ``I'm not blond to be more fun; I'm blond because it looks better.'' It's not easy staying yellow. Shepherd recalls that she was a young towhead, ``the `golden girl' of the family.'' ``When my hair started getting darker in my early teens, my mother handed me a bottle of spray-on lightener to help me stay blond. My hair eventually turned a brassy color,'' she said.. ``When I first came to New York to model for Glamour, they wanted a more natural look, so I was sent to a professional colorist for highlights.''
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also moving on sports wires
DOC.TEXT: A Swedish news magazine was ordered Monday to pay $12,500 to retired tennis star Bjorn Borg for defaming him by reporting allegations that he used cocaine. The verdict and unusually stiff sentence followed the non-binding recommendation last week of a jury to convict the magazine ``Z'' for printing the allegations. The allegations were from Borg's former girlfriend, Jannicke Bjorling, who is involved in a custody dispute with him over the couple's son, Robin. A special press court also fined the monthly's editor in chief $830 and ordered the magazine to publish an apology. Borg was to receive $25,000 in court costs. Borg, a five-time Wimbledon champion, is still a sports hero in Sweden though he retired from professional tennis in 1983 and remains aloof from the public. He has been involved in four other court cases this year related to his troubled fashion business or gossip magazine. ``The verdict is extremely important for Borg. Now he can feel that the Swedish people look up to him as the silent but strong person he is,'' Borg's lawyer, Henning Sjostrom, told the national news agency TT. The jury was instructed to ignore the issue of whether Ms. Bjorling's accusations might be true, and to rule only on whether the magazine should have published her unsubstantiated charges. Borg denied that he ever used drugs. The magazine said it had several other sources to confirm that Borg used drugs, but their identities were never disclosed.

Gov. Kay Orr has another constituent. Her second grandchild, Alexander James Gage, was born at 12:30 a.m. Monday at Lincoln's St. Elizabeth Community Health Center. The son of Jim and Suzanne Orr Gage weighed 7 pounds, 15 ounces. He came one day after Mother's Day and the day before the Nebraska primary election in which Mrs. Orr is seeking the Republican nomination for governor. ``It would have been nice to have a Mother's Day present, but a baby is a gift from God and it's just as sweet a present the day after,'' Mrs. Orr said. The Gages have another son, Taylor Christian, 2.

The granddaughter of Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze donned a U.S. Space Camp uniform, but said she's not sure if she would actually like to go into space. ``I think space travel is very interesting _ it's part of the future,'' 11-year-old Sophia Shevardnadze said Sunday after arriving in Huntsville. Sophia and seven other children from the Soviet Republic of Georgia will spend the next week taking part in simulated space shuttle missions aboard orbiter mockups and training on NASA astronaut simulators. This is the first group of Soviet children to participate in a weeklong program of Space Camp activities, officials said. Sophia was accompanied to the Space Camp by her father, Paata Shevardnadze, and his wife, Nino Ahvlediani. Sophia's accommodations at the Space Camp are within walking distance of an exhibit of American-made missiles. Her grandfather was instrumental in negotiating the Immediate Nuclear Range Forces Treaty that led to the elimination of the U.S. Pershing II missile.

DOC.HEAD: Former Sophia University Dean Dies
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To ADD that Laney died Sunday night, INSERT new 2nd graf; pickup 2nd graf pvs, `Laney came...'
DOC.TEXT: American Jesuit priest William Laney, the former dean of Sophia University's international division, died of pneumonia at a hospital, the university said Monday. He was 71. Officials said he died Sunday night. Laney came to Japan in 1953 from Tacoma, Wash., after teaching history at Gonzaga University. From 1959 to 1965, he was dean of the international division at Sophia University in Tokyo. More than 2,000 U.S. military personnel studied under a Veterans Administration program in the international division. Funeral services were scheduled Wednesday at St. Ignatius Church in downtown Tokyo.

DOC.HEAD: Senegalese President Asks More Aid From U.S.
DOC.TEXT: President Abdou Diouf of Senegal asked President Bush for more economic assistance Monday, but the White House indicated there was little hope of more money now for the West Africa nation. White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said Bush told Diouf he was sympathetic to his needs and would consider his request but that ``we couldn't promise any more funds at this existing time.'' Senegal is one of the staunchest U.S. allies in Africa. Senegal receives an average of $40 million annually and has strong cultural ties to American organizations. Fitzwater said the two leaders discussed Senegal's dispute with neighboring Mauritania. The two countries broke diplomatic relations in August after a minor border dispute flared into violence in both countries in which hundreds of people were killed. Diouf also expressed concerns that Iraq may be building a testing site for its long-range missiles in Mauritania, Fitzwater said. Although Diouf's week-long visit to Washington is being billed as a private one, he has a full schedule of meetings _ including talks with Treasury and Commerce Department leaders and with the heads of the International Monetary Fund and World Bank.

DOC.HEAD: Paralyzed Man Wins Reinstatement to Law School
DOC.TEXT: A disabled man has won a federal lawsuit to require Oklahoma City University to reinstate him as a law student. Mark Nation, 30, sued the university last year after he was dismissed because of low grades. Nation, of Del City, alleged that given his handicap, he wasn't allowed enough time to take tests or adequate means to get class notes. He is paralyzed in both arms and legs because of an injury suffered in a junior high school rugby game. ``He couldn't write and the school didn't take steps to compensate his handicap,'' said his lawyer, Rex Friend. Since U.S. District Judge Wayne Alley ruled in Nation's favor two weeks ago, the university has agreed to give Nation a desk that will accommodate his wheelchair, and to allow him twice as long to take exams. The school said it also would provide him with a tape recorder equipped so he can dictate notes during class. A school secretary will transcribe the notes. Friend called the victory ``an extremely valuable precedent'' for all handicapped people.

DOC.HEAD: Caribbean Island Focus of International Arms Scandal
DOC.TEXT: A scandal over the shipment of Israeli arms to a Colombian drug lord has become a political bombshell in this tourist haven, where the ruling family has weathered previous scandals. The island gained international notoriety in the late 1970s for allowing the testing of weapons for South Africa. It was in the news again in the early 1980s for harboring fugitive American financier Robert Vesco. Now, Israel has accused Prime Minister Vere Bird's eldest son, Vere Jr., 54, of ordering weapons for Antigua's 80-man army that mysteriously ended up in the hands of Colombia's Medellin drug cartel. Vere Jr., a Cabinet minister, has denied wrongdoing but resigned his Cabinet post pending the outcome of a judicial inquiry, the equivalent of a U.S. grand jury investigation. Another son of the prime minister, Lester, 52, deputy prime minister and sometime rival of his older brother, is spearheading the local investigation, shrugging off any possible conflict of interest. The Bird family, which has dominated the island's politics for more than three decades and grown wealthy while doing it, has long been accused of corruption in connection with developing the island's booming tourist industry. But this affair, with its suggestion of a government link with the sinister world of international drug trafficking and gunrunning, is a bombshell by comparison. ``This latest one shocked us to the core,'' said Anglican Archbishop Orland Lindsay. Tim Hector, a leftist opposition leader, said he thought the nation could be in danger of a coup if the prime minister's son were charged. ``I believe we are teetering on the brink ... of a possible military seizure of power and control by Vere Bird (Jr.),'' he said. Vere Jr. is said to command the army's loyalty. Last month, Israel said it had shipped weapons to the Caribbean island in April 1989 on the understanding they would be used exclusively by the Antigua Defense Force. Israel said the arms were ordered by Vere Jr., who identified himself as the minister of national security. There is no such ministry, but Vere Jr. does act informally as his father's national security adviser. The Antiguan investigation determined that the weapons arrived here on April 24, 1989 and were shipped the same day to Santa Marta, Colombia. Colombian officials say soldiers found 232 Israeli-made weapons in February during a search of ranches seized from Gonzalo Rodrigues Gacha, a reputed kingpin of the Medellin cartel who was killed in a gunbattle with police last December. The weapons included machine guns, submachine guns, assault rifles, pistols, shoulder-fired rockets and infrared night scopes. The Outlet, a weekly newspaper published by Hector's Antigua Caribbean Liberation Movement, said the weapons deal was arranged by two Israelis, Maurice Sarfati and Col. Yair Klein. Sarfati, a former Israeli army officer, once operated a melon farm in Antigua but went bankrupt and reportedly is being sought by U.S. authorities for defaulting on $1.3 million in loans. Colombian officials have accused Klein, a reserve officer in the Israeli army, of organizing, training and equipping paramilitary groups, and declared him a fugitive from justice. Klein said in Israel that the arms shipment was originally intended for a training school he wanted to set up in Antigua for Panamanian rebels opposed to Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, who was ousted by U.S. forces last December. When plans for the school fell through, Klein said, the Panamanians wanted the weapons shipped to Panama, but somehow they were diverted to Colombia. Many questions remain, among them whether anyone in the Antiguan government was aware the arms shipment was headed for Colombia. In Antigua, a former British colony of 80,000 only nine miles wide and 12 miles long, the government is largely a function of one family, the Birds. Vere Bird Sr., the 80-year-old prime minister, first rose to prominence in the 1930s as a union organizer in the days of colonial sugar plantations and has led the nation all but five of the past 34 years. His Antigua Labor Party controls 15 of the 17 seats in Parliament. Vere Jr. is the minister of public works and communication. Lester, the deputy prime minister, is also leader of the ruling party and minister of foreign affairs, economic development, tourism and energy. Antiguans take it for granted that either Lester or Vere Jr. will succeed their father, who is in declining health, and many believe the outcome of this scandal could help settle the matter. The brothers, both British-trained lawyers, have both weathered previous scandals. In 1987, Vere Jr. was implicated, but never charged, in an investigation of a government project to repave the runway of the island's airport. He had formed a private company to carry out the project, which was supposed to cost no more than $3.5 million but ended up costing $11.5 million. It was Lester who helped Vesco when the fugitive surfaced in Antigua in 1982 with a bizarre plan to buy half of Barbuda, Antigua's small sister island, and establish a principality called the Sovereign Order of New Aragon. Vere Jr. is widely regarded as his father's favorite. Lester, who was an All-American long jumper at the University of Michigan in 1960, is seen as the brighter of the two. In separate interviews, the brothers played down their rivalry and the possible impact of the scandal on their political futures. ``I clearly had no intention of ... reducing (this matter) to a question of a fight for power within the domestic situation,'' Lester said. ``After all, he is still my brother.'' Vere Jr. would not discuss specifics of the case, but said: ``I've never been associated with anything of the kind and would never be.'' About his relationship with his brother, he said: ``Whenever I meet him, it's a most amicable ... relationship. When we leave, I don't know what transpires.'' The Antigua government has hired a Washington, D.C., attorney, E. Lawrence Barcella Jr., to head a team that has flown to Israel to get evidence. A British jurist, Louis Blom-Cooper, has been named to conduct a judicial inquiry, which is expected to open hearings in June.

DOC.HEAD: Homeless Protesters in Abandoned HUD Housing Arrested
DOC.TEXT: Squatters protesting a shortage of housing for the poor were arrested Monday and removed from property owned by the Department of Housing and Urban Development, but said they would return. ``We're planning on going back in as soon as people are released,'' said Charles Viebahn, a spokesman for Up and Out of Poverty, an advocacy group for the homeless. He said the sites had been occupied since May 1. HUD spokeswoman Patricia Mack said department officials made citizens arrests and removed 12 adults and four children from the properties, one warehouse and four single-family and duplex houses. Police Sgt. Phil VanTassel said police observed the arrests at HUD's request. He said no one resisted arrest. Mack said the adults were charged with trespassing and released. She said HUD officials planned to remove all furnishings and other belongings from the occupied property. ``Everything from milk to the beds,'' she said. ``I imagine by now they are back out on the street or back in our houses. We don't know. We're not standing watch outside.'' Mack said the four children, between ages 5 and 13, were taken temporarily to St. Joseph's Home for Children in Minneapolis while their parents were booked. Viebahn said the group wants HUD to release 10 percent of its abandoned property nationwide for use as homeless shelters run by homeless people. The protesters should apply for HUD's existing housing programs if they need places to live, Mack said. She said one of the houses occupied by the protesters has been sold. ``These folks are just choosing not to come into our system,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Radical Students Battle Police; Auto Workers Vote to Strike
LaserPhoto SEL2
DOC.TEXT: About 300 radical students demanding the ouster of President Roh Tae-woo hurled firebombs and rocks at riot police in front of a Seoul university Monday, and police responded with tear gas. In Ulsan, 200 miles southeast of the capital, union leaders at South Korea's largest carmaker announced a general strike Tuesday. At the world's largest shipyard, also in Ulsan, workers voted to return to their jobs. Both companies are subsidiaries of the Hyundai group, one of South Korea's largest conglomerates. Government officials have warned they will move swiftly to crush any illegal labor protests.On April 28, 12,000 police firing tear gas burst into the Ulsan shipyard to crush a strike. The facility has not reopened. Students at Seoul's Hankuk University of Foreign Studies shouted ``Oust Roh Tae-woo!'' at police who tried to disperse the demonstration. Similar anti-government protests involving several hundred students were reported in the southern cities of Kwangju and Iri. It was not known whether there were any arrests or injuries. Students demanded that Roh's gigantic new ruling party be disbanded and a public mandate be held on the merger, which brought Roh's old ruling party together with two opposition groups. The coalition was formed early this year. Roh's government is under mounting public fire for economic failures that have triggered inflation and pushed up housing costs. Roh's popularity is at an all-time low. Also Monday, the nation's largest opposition party demanded the release of a prominent dissident arrested on charges he helped organize last week's anti-government demonstrations, the largest and most violent since 1987. About 100,000 militant students and dissidents joined in last Wednesday's protests in Seoul and 16 other cities. The government last week warned against violence and launched a crackdown on dissidents and radical students. The Party for Peace and Democracy said Kim Keun-tae, winner of the 1987 Robert F. Kennedy Human Rights Award, was ``not involved in recent violent demonstrations.'' The party called on the government ``to stop immediately the selective suppression of dissident elements.'' Kim, 43, chairman of the executive council of the National Alliance of Democratic Movements, was arrested at his brother-in-law's apartment Sunday on the southern island of Cheju. In Ulsan, officials of the Hyundai Motor Co. threatened to file a complaint seeking punitive actions against union leaders organizing what they said was an ``illegal'' work stoppage. Hyundai Motor's walkout had been expected since Saturday, when 27,000 workers voted to strike. They said 22 rounds of talks with management to negotiate higher pay and better working conditions had bogged down. Workers of the Hyundai car plant want a 19 percent pay raise and a cut in the work week from 44 to 42 hours. The company has offered a 5.95 percent increase in pay. The average salary is $620 monthly. At the nearby shipyard, the 24,000 workers voted to start work on Wednesday. They had been on strike to pressure the release of jailed union leaders.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Gets 5 Years for 18th Drunken-Driving Charge
DOC.TEXT: A woman who has been charged with drunken driving 18 times was sentenced Monday to a maximum five years in prison, drawing an outraged reaction from the prosecutor. ``It's just disgusting,'' said Assistant State Attorney Lisa Porter. ``It's an insult to society. ... This case is just incredible.'' Dollie Louise Fazekas is to begin serving the sentence after completing a one-year term imposed last month in another county for violating probation on a previous DUI charge. Prosecutors expected the 46-year-old defendant to serve about 18 months of the new sentence, counting credit for good behavior and time routinely deducted from sentences because of prison crowding. During the past 15 years, she has used 14 aliases, nine Social Security numbers and six dates of birth, according to authorities. Last month, her driver's license was revoked for life. Ms. Porter concedes there is no record of anyone being injured in three accidents listed on a six-page printout of Ms. Fazekas' traffic record. But the relatively short prison term for such a repeat offender shows the need for legislative reform, the prosecutor argued. ``It's a problem for the people of the state of Florida,'' Ms. Porter said, ``when you've got the Dollie Fazekases running around in cars and no way to punish them.''

DOC.HEAD: Friends, Family Remember Serviceman Slain in Philippines
With AM-Philippines
DOC.TEXT: A serviceman shot to death in the Philippines was mourned Monday as a victim of seemingly irrational political violence. On the day U.S. and Philippine negotiators began discussing the future of American military in that country, about 450 people gathered at the Church of the Nativity to remember Gunnery Sgt. John Fredette, 34. The Most Rev. Joseph F. Maguire, urged the bereaved to abandon thoughts of revenge and enshrine Fredette in their memories. ``If his goodness will go on ... then he will not have died in vain,'' said Maguire, bishop of the Springfield diocese. Fredette was attacked by gunmen May 4 in a nightclub district in Olangapo, a town 50 miles west of Manila. Two airmen were killed Sunday, bringing to eight the number of U.S. servicemen killed in such attacks since April 1989. Philippine officials have arrested two men in connection with Fredette's death, but there has been speculation they were not involved. The U.S. government is investigating. Fredette's shooting followed threats in Philippine newspapers that an American serviceman would be killed before the talks on extending the leases of six U.S. military bases in the country. No claims of responsibility were made following Fredette's shooting, but U.S. officials believe rebels were responsible. Fredette's casket was carried past the Mount Carmel school, which he once attended. He was buried in the nearby western Massachusetts town of South Hadley. The bishop described Fredette as a ``vital and sparkling'' man who was taken by ``the cruel and irrational act of violence.'' Family members have described Fredette as an athlete and a man dedicated to a military career. ``It's sad. I just want the assailants brought to justice. That's about all we can do here,'' his brother, Mark Fredette, has said. Fredette had been living in Buena Park, Calif., with his wife, Julie. He left the United States last month for a six-month tour in Japan, Hawaii and the Philippines. In addition to his wife, survivors include his parents, Armand and Augustine Fredette of Chicopee, three brothers and five sisters.

DOC.HEAD: Baby Sitter Who Allegedly Abducted 5-year-old Appears in Court
DOC.TEXT: A former baby sitter charged with abducting a 5-year-old girl should remain in custody until his trial on kidnapping charges, a prosecutor argued Monday. Kenneth M. Cole II, 24, appeared in U.S. District Court on a criminal complaint charging him with kidnapping. He is accused of abducting Nicole Ravesi, and holding her for 39 days. FBI agents found the pair Thursday in a Florida Panhandle fishing village. U.S. Magistrate Robert B. Collings scheduled a detention hearing for Wednesday. Cole does not enter a plea until prosecutors file an indictment. Cole was a former co-worker of Nicole's mother and had babysat for the youngster after losing his job as a bus driver. Police say he was obsessed with Nicole and snatched the girl April 3 from her mother's car. Assistant U.S. Attorney Martin Murphy recommended the detention hearing ``on the grounds that no condition or combination of conditions will reasonably assure the appearance of the defendant at trial or the safety of the individual.'' Cole's attorneys said they had no objection to the detention hearing. Cole, of Holliston, could be sentenced to life imprisonment and a $250,000 fine if convicted. Collings granted a request by Cole's parents to speak with their son briefly Monday. They declined to comment as they left the courtroom.

DOC.HEAD: Panel Recommends Entertainer's Son To Head Indian Gaming Commission
DOC.TEXT: A Senate committee recommended Monday that Anthony Hope, a lawyer and son of entertainer Bob Hope, be confirmed as chairman of the Indian Gaming Commission. Hope testified last week before the Senate Select Committee on Indian Affairs on his qualifications to become the first chairman of the new commission, established to oversee gambling on Indian reservations. A graduate of Georgetown University and Harvard Law School, Hope was a partner in the accounting firm of Touche Ross & Co. and formerly worked for Mutual of Omaha. He also worked in New Hampshire for George Bush's campaigns in 1980 and 1988 and has served in management capacities for various non-profit organizations. The three-year gaming commission chairmanship pays $83,600 annually. Hope and two other commission members, yet to be named, will inspect gambling premises, do background checks on employees, levy fines and enforce ordinances. Sen. Daniel Innouye, D-Hawaii, chairman of the Senate Indian commmittee, said he expected Hope to be quickly confirmed by the full Senate.

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Warn Americans to Go Home As Talks Begin
LaserPhotos MLA7,11
DOC.TEXT: Communist rebels warned Americans Monday to ``go home'' and police clashed with protesters as U.S. and Philippine negotiators began talks on the future of six American military bases in the country. At least 42 people were arrested and five hospitalized in Manila as police clashed with anti-bases protesters during daylong rallies. The bases talks opened one day after assailants believed to be Communist guerrillas killed two U.S. airmen near Clark Air Base, 50 miles north of Manila. No one claimed responsibility for the killings, but U.S. and Philippine officials suspect the rebels. The State Department said Monday the United States was ``shocked and saddened'' by the murders, which it said were aimed at disrupting the talks. The negotiations will determine whether the United States can retain Clark Air Base, the Subic Bay naval base and four smaller installations after the lease expires Sept. 16, 1991. President Corazon Aquino has refused to say whether she supports an extension of the lease. In December, U.S. jets from Clark helped suppress a military revolt that nearly toppled her four-year administration. During the opening session Monday, chief U.S. negotiator Richard Armitage said the United States will remain a power in the Pacific regardless of the outcome of the talks. They are expected to last until the end of the year. Armitage, a former assistant secretary of defense, urged the Philippines to decide whether the bases serve its defense interests. Armitage said that if the Philippines wants the bases closed, ``leave we shall, as expeditiously as possible and with our pride fully intact.'' In a sometimes caustic opening statement, Foreign Secretary Raul Manglapus, chief Philippine negotiator, said the United States has often fallen short of its financial commitments to the Philippines. He said tens of thousands of Filipinos died fighting the Japanese in World War II ``not to save the Philippines ... but to keep the war from reaching Australia and eventually the American mainland.'' ``Even before the Filipino soldier had finished fighting and dying for America, he was judged by the American Congress to be worth only half of the pay of the American soldier,'' Manglapus said. U.S. and Philippine officials had expressed fears that the Communist New People's Army would try to kill Americans to disrupt the talks. Late Sunday, assailants shot and killed Airman John H. Raven, 19, of Delta Junction, Alaska, and Airman James C. Green, 20, of Craig, Colo., outside a hotel near Clark. A companion, Airman 1C Randall Moore, 23, escaped. They were among 280 airmen and support personnel assigned to the 8th Aircraft Generation Squadron on temporary duty from Kunsan Air Base, 110 miles south of Seoul, South Korea. Police Capt. Gener Manguni said it appeared the rebels were responsible for the killings because of the style of the attack. Two or three Filipinos approached the Americans and shot them in the back of their heads with .45-caliber pistols, the rebels' favored weapon in street killings. On Monday, U.S. officials canceled off-post leaves for the 40,000 troops, military dependents and Defense Department civilians at all six bases. In a statement to news organizations, the New People's Army denounced the bases talks. ``Go home immediately or suffer the agony of attrition,'' the rebels said. ``The NPA pledges that all its territorial and unit commands, all officers and men, will carry out their mission _ to the last man if necessary _ of expelling U.S. imperialism out of our country.'' The rebels are believed to have killed eight Americans since April 1989. Most surveys show that supporters of the bases outnumber opponents, but opposition is growing because of Filipino nationalism and Congress' decision to cut aid to the country. Any new bases agreement must also be ratified by two-thirds of the 23-member senate here, where anti-bases sentiment is strong. In the largest protest Monday, about 3,500 people including workers, students and Roman Catholic nuns heard speakers denounce the bases. They chanted ``U.S. bases, pests!'' and carried banners urging the government to send the Americans home. ``Americans must be driven away,'' said Crispin Beltran, chairman of the left-wing labor May First Movement. ``And those who refuse must be buried here.'' Bases opponents from Australia, New Zealand and the United States joined the protest. Outside Clark, about 800 opponents of the bases hung a ``termination notice'' on the main gate as about 1,000 supporters of the bases, mostly bar maids, shouted and jeered. Police kept the two groups apart and there were no incidents. During the talks, Manglapus also raised the issue of the aid cuts. In 1988, the Reagan administration pledged $962 million over two years to keep the bases through 1991. Congress, however, cut $96 million from the Bush administration aid request for the Philippines. Filipino officials see that as a breach of the agreement. ``Dollars are important, but it is the solemn word that is here at issue,'' Manglapus said. ``The bilateral relations of any two nations can look forward to no significant future if no one can count on the other's word.'' Manglapus said the Philippines appreciated Washington's budgetary problems but suggested the United States reduce military spending to provide more money for aid.

DOC.HEAD: Chamorro Says Nicaragua Desperate for U.S. Aid
DOC.TEXT: Nicaraguan President Violeta Chamorro sent an urgent plea to President Bush for the $300 million in aid pending in Congress, the White House said Monday. Presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Bush, in response to Mrs. Chamorro's cable, called the speaker of the House, Rep. Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., earlier Monday to reiterate his unhappiness with Congress' pace on the bill. ``The president expressed to the speaker his strong feelings that Congress has toyed with this bill and has ignored the real problems in Panama and Nicaragua,'' Fitzwater said. He said Foley told Bush he would ``do his best'' to move the legislation. The aid for Nicaragua, which includes money to help disband and repatriate the Contra rebels, along with Bush's companion $500 million request for Panama, has been snarled in Congress for two months. Other measures added to the legislation, ranging from space research to grasshopper control, have increased its total price tag to $3 billion. And the Senate added to the bill a veto-threatened provision to allow the District of Columbia to pay for poor women's abortions. Fitzwater called congressional delay on the measure ``outrageous'' and accused Congress of turning its back on ``people with a real crying need.'' ``Let's get it down here and get on with the task,'' Fitzwater said. In her cable to Bush, Mrs. Chamorro ``lays out a very humanitarian plea,'' Fitzwater said. She expressed ``a sense of emergency'' to Bush, Fitzwater said. ``This democracy is having enough troubles taking over from a communist regime, making all the adjustments in management, policy and philosophy, without having to also face the fact that the people are very much in need of this support and aid in terms of everything from food, clothing, housing, all sorts of things,'' Fitzwater said. The request also includes money for farm equipment, seed and fertilizer; for health and education programs; for energy purchases, and for manufacturing equipment and spare parts. Fitzwater said that Mrs. Chamorro also mentioned that strikes in her country by civil servants loyal to the old Sandinista regime were posing ``a very serious problem'' to her two-week old government. The spokesman, while renewing the administration's appeal for congressional action on the bill, said that Bush will still veto the measure if it arrives on his desk with the Senate abortion provision.

DOC.HEAD: Justices Hear, Join in Flag-Burning Arguments
DOC.TEXT: Supreme Court justices, setting the stage for a decision with major political implications, joined lawyers in spirited arguments Monday over flag burning, patriotism and freedom of expression. In arguments before the justices, the Bush administration's top courtroom lawyer, Solicitor General Kenneth Starr, argued that a new federal law to protect Old Glory does not violate free speech any more than a regulation limiting an outdoor loudspeaker's volume. Congress can protect ``those things that are special to us as a people,'' Starr said. ``Nothing prohibits the legislature from protecting symbols against physical attack.'' But civil rights attorney William Kunstler said, ``Respect for the flag must be voluntary. Once people are compelled to respect a symbol, they are no longer free.'' The law, the Flag Protection Act of 1989, was Congress' response to the high court's 5-4 ruling last June that struck down a Texas law banning flag burning and desecration. The court is expected to rule by late June or early July. If the law is struck down, a proposed constitutional amendment to protect the flag likely would become a leading issue in congressional and state legislative races this fall. Outside the court Monday, demonstrators exchanged taunts and slogans. Shawn Eichman, arrested last year for burning a flag here, said, ``I`m just one of the thousands of women who is taking a cold, hard look at the system defending us. ... Women have less protection than a flag.'' Six opposing demonstrators carried a sign saying, ``Flag burning is a hate crime.'' The two groups stood just feet apart as they chanted and shouted at each other. But there was no violence. Justice Harry A. Blackmun, seen by sponsors of the federal law as a potential swing vote, was silent throughout Monday's arguments. Blackmun voted last year to strike down the Texas law. But in a 1974 ruling, he indicated he might go along with some laws to protect the flag's ``physical integrity.'' Justice Antonin Scalia, who last June voted to invalidate the Texas law, pounced on Starr's argument that the federal law is not aimed at a particular viewpoint. ``In fact there is only one viewpoint'' expressed by flag burners, Scalia interjected. ``I hate America.'' ``You do not deface, defile or trample the flag to show your love for the country,'' Scalia added as laughter filled the crowded courtroom. Justice Anthony M. Kennedy, who also voted last year to strike down the Texas law, noted demonstrators in Eastern Europe defaced their countries' flags to protest communist regimes. ``Would you be concerned if Eastern European countries punished people for demonstrating with a defaced flag?'' Kennedy asked Starr. ``It's almost an internationally recognized form of protest.'' Starr said the U.S. law is acceptable because it does not single out any particular protesters. Justice John Paul Stevens asked Kunstler whether it would violate the Constitution to ban car dealers from using the flag in advertisements ``to promote the American economy.'' Kunstler said that would be a form of commercial speech ``unworthy of constitutional protection.'' Outside the court, Sen. Joseph Biden, D-Del., who supported the new law as an alternative to a constitutional amendment, said the issue may be blunted regardless of how the court rules. ``The majority of the members of Congress want to protect the flag,'' he said. By contrast, Rep. Don Edwards, D-Calif., said the issue is so divisive that the House probably would reject a proposed constitutional amendment. Amending the Constitution requires approval by two-thirds of the members of the House and Senate and then ratification by 38 state legislatures. While the Bush administration is defending the law, President Bush and Republican leaders have said they would prefer a constitutional amendment to ban flag burning. There would be no need for such an amendment if the justices uphold the law. Democratic congressional leaders were the prime sponsors of the Flag Protection Act. Starr told the justices Monday that the law does not violate freedom-of-expression protections in the Constitution's First Amendment. Justice Byron R. White said Starr appeared to be comparing flag burning to using a loudspeaker to get public attention. ``This is like an over-loud loudspeaker,'' White said. ``That is an apt analogy,'' said Starr, adding that the law is ``content neutral'' and is not aimed at limiting the flag burner from getting across any message. But Kunstler said the law's intent is obvious _ to limit free speech by those who oppose U.S. policies. Quoting Thomas Jefferson, Kunstler added: ``It's as if Congress ordered us to fall down and worship a golden image.'' Monday's oral arguments marked the first time in nine years the justices held such a session after April. They are reviewing rulings by federal judges in the District of Columbia and Seattle who said the law violates First Amendment rights. The law was challenged by demonstrators who burned American flags in the two cities.

DOC.HEAD: Refugees to East Germany Straining Newly Open Country
DOC.TEXT: East Germans cut off from the world by four decades of Stalinist rule now find the world rushing to them, and the deluge is severely straining the nation, officials said Monday. East Berlin and East German officials held a news conference to outline what they said has been a flood of impoverished foreigners lured to East Germany because of its imminent economic unification with West Germany. East Europeans are flooding East Germany at a rate of 500 a day, and tens of thousands have arrived in recent weeks to seek work in a land of rising joblessness, the officials said. ``If quick regulations for the integration of foreigners are not created, the problem will become a social powderkeg,'' said Joachim Krabs, an East Berlin social services official. About 18,000 East Europeans, most of them Romanians and Bulgarians, have entered the country since late April. About 20,000 Poles also have applied for citizenship in recent weeks, and several thousand Italians have entered the country. About 650 East Europeans arrived on Monday morning alone at the train station in the East Berlin district of Lichetenberg. ``We no longer know how we can control this enormous influx,'' said Gerhard Kielmann, a Foreign Ministry official. ``Most of them are fleeing their poor economic situation in their homeland.'' Lichetenberg has become a way station for East Europeans entering the country on tourist visas. Hundreds wander the area with their belongings. Children beg for money and scores of families often sleep in the station. Krabs said about 600 Romanians and other East Europeans live in the train station. ``The hygiene situation has taken on catastrophic proportions,'' he said. He said many are carrying infectious diseases. About 1,100 other East Europeans, most of them Romanians and some Bulgarians, have been housed for the last week at an army barracks on a base on the outskirts of Berlin. Another 300 are housed in another building. An estimated 15,000 have crossed the border and were believed heading for East Berlin, the officials said. They said about 80 percent of the newcomers from Eastern Europe are gypsies. The number of refugees is now averaging about 500 a day. East Germany's sudden attraction is, in a way, a result of the mass flight of 500,000 East Germans to West Germany in the past year. Many were fleeing the former socialist government that was toppled in October, but the exodus continued after the country's borders were opened in November. The flight of East Germans contributed to East Germany's economic problems and the push to unify the nation with West Germany. The West German currency is to be circulated in East Germany on July 2 as part of a merger of the nations' economies and social systems. East Germany, however, is expected to face widespread unemployment as scores of factories are closed down when they are forced to compete in a free market. Unemployment already has begun rising as East German consumers get more access to better Western goods. The tensions over joblessness have led to clashes between foreigners and East Germans in factories and on the streets in recent weeks. A melee broke out in Lichtenberg a week ago when gangs of foreigners and young East Germans squared off outside a discotheque. East Germany is home to tens of thousands of Vietnamese, Cubans and Mozambicans brought in by the former Communist government to fill menial jobs. East Germany has no system for dealing with asylum seekers. A government working group has been trying to arrange lodging and other aid for foreigners. Mario Sander, the federal government's deputy commissioner for foreigner questions, said that within days a ``charitable structure'' must be created for dealing with the foreigners' housing and food needs.

DOC.HEAD: EPA Campaign Offers `Tips' to Destroy the Earth
By STEPHANIE SCHOROW
Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: Forget oil spills, factory pollution and toxic waste. You, too, can destroy the Earth. And the federal government will even tell you how. The Environmental Protection Agency has launched a reverse-psychology campaign dubbed, ``How to Destroy the Earth,'' through public service announcements provided to radio and television stations, magazines and newspapers. The advertisements explain how to waste electricity, overuse paper products and release toxic chemicals into the air and water. The EPA hopes the offbeat campaign will encourage consumers to adopt household and work habits that will aid environmental cleanup, said Julie Belaga, regional EPA administrator, at a news conference Monday. The TV spots, for example, feature a smirking announcer. ``Want to destroy the Earth with your car? No problem. Drive everywhere!'' ``Hey, want to kill a few trees?'' he inquires, tossing up sheets of photocopy paper or pulling down a stream of paper towels. ``Lights? Leave them on! Especially when you're not there!'' The print ads are mini-lessons in destruction. Under bold letters declaiming, ``How To Destroy the Earth,'' they suggest, ``Use phosphate detergents'' or ``Pour used motor oil into the ground.'' The campaign is starting in New England, and EPA officials plan to take it nationwide. The campaign includes billboards, bumper stickers, buttons and a booklet, slightly larger than a matchbook, with 38 tips on destroying the Earth. All the ads come with a disclaimer _ ``The Earth. If you want to save it, find out what you're doing to destroy it'' and a toll-free information number. The ads were designed to ``answer questions the public asks us over and over and over again: `What can I do to help,''' Belaga said. What the EPA wanted to avoid was the too-earnest approach of public service announcements, especially with a public saturated by recent Earth Day publicity, according to agency officials. The new campaign ``is, shall we say, subtly aggressive,'' Belaga said. ``This certainly isn't the bureaucratic, traditional approach.'' The ads may grab attention, but will they actually encourage people to turn off lights, avoid plastic foam products, use clotheslines instead of dryers and recycle paper at the office? Stavros Cosmopulos thinks so. He's the chairman and creative director of the Boston-based advertising agency that created the ads. ``These suggestions _ or suggestions in reverse, if you will _ are doable things,'' he said. ``I'm doing it. We don't use Styrofoam cups any more.'' His firm, Cosmopulos, Crowley and Daly, and several other private companies donated their services for the campaign. Paul G. Keough, EPA deputy regional administrator, said the yearlong campaign uses an individual rather than a ``global'' approach to environmental problems. He said businesses may feel an impact, however, if consumers start pressuring companies through their buying habits.

DOC.HEAD: CBS Annonces One-Hour Summer Series
DOC.TEXT: CBS, which like NBC and ABC is making new efforts to keep viewers during the summer with new programs, said Monday it will premiere a one-hour series, ``Northern Exposure,'' this summer. No date has been yet for the show. It stars Rob Morrow as a young New York physician who, fresh out of medical school, faces culture shock when he becomes the sole doctor in a small Alaskan village. The series was created by Joshua Brand and John Falsey, who was behind NBC's ``St. Elsewhere'' and ``A Year in the Life.'' Production of the show has begun in Bellvue, Wash., CBS said.

DOC.HEAD: Sullivan: Statistics Show Nation Winning Drug War
DOC.TEXT: Cocaine-related medical emergencies in the United States showed a 20 percent drop in the fourth quarter of 1989, Secretary of Health and Human Services Louis Sullivan reported Monday. ``We are making significant headway in our efforts to establish a drug-free America,'' Sullivan told state and local officials at a conference called by the Office of National Drug Control Policy. Sullivan's announcement came in the wake of a congressional report that said the number of hard-core cocaine addicts in the country was more than twice what had been estimated earlier. The report released last Thursday by the Senate Judiciary Committee set the figure at 2.2 million, compared with an estimate of 862,000 made earlier by the National Institute of Drug Abuse. Sen. Joseph Biden, D-Del., committee chairman, said the report was ``as alarming as it is tragic'' and showed that the administration's strategy for dealing with the drug crisis was faulty. William J. Bennett, the national drug control policy director, asked about Biden's remarks at Monday's conference, said, ``If the strategy is flawed, he needs to tell us how. He needs to make his case.'' The Republican governor of Delaware, Michael N. Castle, said the Judiciary Committee report shows that neither the supply of cocaine nor the demand for it have been diminished sufficiently. ``Just last week we heard that one person out of every 100 in this country is a hard-core cocaine user _ one of every 40 in New York City!'' Castle said. ``If we couple this with a 1989 survey of high school seniors in which many of them said that crack and cocaine were more available now than in the past, we know that we have neither stemmed the flow nor sufficiently stifled demand.'' Sullivan told his audience, ``The fourth quarter data from the Drug Abuse Warning Network, or DAWN, which reports drug-related emergency visits, shows a significant decrease _ indeed a drop of nearly 20 percent _ in the number of cocaine-related cases.'' He said the data was particularly welcome after ``several years of increases in reported incidents, followed by the steady levels of incidents found in last year's quarterly reports.'' The secretary said the decrease ``was noted in virtually all metropolitan areas of the DAWN system'' and was also reflected in preliminary fourth quarter figures from reports of cocaine-related deaths by medical examiners. The reports, Sullivan said, ``are not smoke-and-mirrors projections, assumptions, extrapolations, or hunches, like some you've heard recently.'' ``Today's results are hard-and-fast data, reflecting actual, reported incidents of cocaine-related medical emergencies. As such, they confirm what several surveys have indicated over the past year: that we are making significant headway in our efforts to establish a drug-free America.'' Bennett, speaking earlier, said, ``We may now be seeing a levelling off of addiction. My sense is that we are now beginning to see a peaking of the addiction problem.'' The drug control director also told the state and local officials that stemming drug usage would not come automatically, but ``if it happens, it will be by the pressure that we bring to bear.''

DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court Upholds Limits on Anti-Abortion Protests
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS last graf, bgng Operation Rescue, with two grafs to ADD comment from Terry
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court refused Monday to let an anti-abortion group protest at abortion clinics in Atlanta, voting 5-4 to leave intact a Georgia judge's injunction. The vote focused on free-speech rights more than abortion and crossed ideological lines. The court rejected an emergency request by five members of Operation Rescue who said the injunction is violating their free-speech rights. In Atlanta, Operation Rescue spokesman Bob Jewitt called Monday's action ``a little stumble along the way,'' adding, ``We feel we'll be victorious in the long run.'' Lynne Randall, who operates a clinic that has been a frequent target of the protests, welcomed the action. ``We have to balance women's right to privacy with people's right to protest,'' she said. The controversy is still alive in the Georgia courts, but Monday's action means Operation Rescue protesters for now cannot go within 50 feet of the property line of any Atlanta facility where abortions are performed. In other matters, the court: _Heard a spirited debate over flag burning, an issue with big political stakes and clashing views over patriotism and freedom of expression. The court must decide by July whether a federal law protecting ``Old Glory'' from desecration is constitutional. _Killed a lawsuit against Atlantic Richfield Co. by independent gasoline dealers in California and Washington state. The court, by a 7-2 vote, said price-cutting schemes that hurt a competitor's business do not necessarily violate federal antitrust laws. _Voted 6-3 to squelch a lawsuit that charged the United Steelworkers union with negligence in a 1972 Idaho silver mine disaster that killed 91 miners. The court said such state court action is pre-empted by federal labor law. _Refused to referee an attack by 30 states against 26 manufacturers over the removal of asbestos from public schools and other government buildings. The court's vote in the Operation Rescue case from Atlanta yielded strange judicial bedfellows. Voting to lift the March 29 injunction were the court's two most consistent liberals, Justices William J. Brennan and Thurgood Marshall, and two of its most conservative members, Justices Anthony M. Kennedy and Antonin Scalia. Brennan and Marshall are strong supporters of abortion rights, but also are strong supporters of free-speech rights. Kennedy and Scalia oppose broad abortion rights but have more moderate track records on free-speech issues. Writing for the four, Kennedy cited the court's 1977 decision that refused to block Nazis from marching in the heavily Jewish community of Skokie, Ill. Kennedy said the 1977 ruling ``does not distinguish among speakers based on the content of their speech.'' But Justice John Paul Stevens, who cast a decisive vote to leave intact the Atlanta injunction, said the court was not drawing any content-of-speech distinctions. Stevens noted that in 1977 the American Nazi Party ``did not have a similar history of illegal conduct in the jurisdiction where the march was scheduled,'' and he called Operation Rescue members ``a class of persons who have persistently and repeatedly engaged in unlawful conduct.'' Also voting to leave the injunction intact were Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justices Byron R. White, Harry A. Blackmun and Sandra Day O'Connor. Stevens and Blackmun are strong supporters of abortion rights. Rehnquist, White and O'Connor are not. Since July 1988, when Atlanta hosted the National Democratic Convention, city police have arrested 1,320 demonstrators at Operation Rescue sit-ins. Many of the protesters barricaded abortion clinics, blocking patients and employees from entering or leaving. Operation Rescue members Michael Hirsch, Gina Robertson, William Haynes, Steve Britt and Pamela Sekulow said the Atlanta injunction deters them ``from engaging in prayer, picketing, leafleting and other forms of peaceful expression on public forum streets and sidewalks.'' The state judge who issued the injunction is considering a request to modify it, and a formal challenge to the injunction is before the Georgia Supreme Court. Similar legal challenges to Operation Rescue demonstrations at abortion clinics in other states have left the organization in deep debt. Operation Rescue founder Randall Terry, who spent time in jail until a contempt-of-court fine for violating a similar injunction in New York was paid, called Monday's action ``an outrage.'' ``Our rights are being denied because we're pro-life Christians. If we were homosexuals, does anyone really think that we would be denied access to a public sidewalk,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Republicans Eye Spending Cuts; Nobody Wants to Bring Up Taxes
DOC.TEXT: Congressional Republicans said Monday they hope to use budget negotiations to force domestic spending cuts, while all sides insisted they would not be the first to broach a possible tax hike. At the White House, where the talks open Tuesday, spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said President Bush would not make specific proposals to lawmakers. Instead, he said, the president would lay down his goals for the talks. The budget summit is designed to find $50 billion or more in deficit savings _ either through spending cuts, tax increases or a combination of the two. Democrats expressed lingering distrust toward the administration's motives in convening the sessions. They cited White House Chief of Staff John Sununu's comments last week that higher taxes would not be considered by the president, despite White House assurances that everything _ including tax increases _ is negotiable. ``There is a lot of unease among Democrats,'' said Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine. Republicans countered that partisan remarks such as Sununu's were inevitable. ``I don't see how you can start one of these summits without political rhetoric or polarization,'' said Sen. Pete Domenici of New Mexico, ranking Republican on the Senate Budget Committee and one of the negotiators. The talks are aimed at finding enough savings to hold next year's federal deficit to no more than $64 billion, the target set by the Gramm-Rudman balanced-budget law. Fiscal 1991 begins Oct. 1. White House budget chief Richard Darman has said that $60 billion to $100 billion in deficit reduction might be necessary. But he and GOP lawmakers have said that a $50 billion package might be a more realistic goal for the negotiators. Whatever budget cuts emerge will have to be enacted in the heat of an election year in which the entire House and one-third of the Senate is up for grabs. Bush did not plan to begin the bargaining by laying down a specific budget proposal, said Fitzwater. He said Bush has ``points he wants to make'' at the opening meeting. ``He'll have general goals about getting the deficit down.'' An administration official, speaking on the condition he not be identified, said that it could take a week and a half for opening statements to be completed and real work to begin. Besides Bush, four top administration officials and 21 congressional leaders are scheduled to attend the sessions. Participants have said the bargaining could take weeks or months. Republicans said Monday that they are especially eager to control the growth of benefits such as Medicare, farm price supports and federal employee retirement programs. Such programs together account for about half of all government spending. By law, these programs expand automatically each year as inflation cuts purchasing power and the number of recipients grows. As a result, GOP lawmakers want the talks to produce changes that will rein in the growth of these benefits in the future. They also want budget changes that will ensure that the cuts are saved, rather than simply transferred to other forms of spending. ``You have to be able to say the money isn't spent, but it has to go as designed to deficit reduction,'' said Domenici. ``There is no way we can do that under current processes.'' Bush proposed limiting the growth of these programs by $13.9 billion, an amount supported by Sen. Phil Gramm, R-Texas and another negotiator. ``We ought to begin with the president's number,'' said Gramm. ``Let Congress decide exactly how to save the money.'' Democrats said the reason for the $150 billion annual deficits of recent years was insufficient revenues and excessive defense spending, not deficiencies in the budget process. ``That's akin to oiling the crank shaft on the Titanic 1{ hours after it hit the iceberg,'' the Senate Budget Committee chairman, Sen. James Sasser, D-Tenn., said of the GOP call for tightened budget procedures. Mitchell said that after a weekend in Maine meeting constituents and talking by telephone with fellow Democrats, he found that many in his party believe Bush was never serious about his ``no new taxes'' campaign promise. ``A great many Democrats expressed the view to me that the president's campaign pledge was phony, that everybody knew it, and now will have to be broken,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Text of Gorbachev Decrees on Baltics
With AM-Soviet-Baltics, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev issued two presidential decrees Monday declaring Estonian and Latvian independence moves invalid. The text of those decrees, as transmitted by the Soviet news agency Tass and translated from Russian by The Associated Press, follows: Presidential Decree on Estonia On Declaring Invalid the Resolution of the Estonian Supreme Soviet, ``On the State Status of Estonia'' On March 30, 1990, the Supreme Soviet of the Estonian Soviet Socialist Republic unilaterally, without consulting with the people of the republic, ignoring the existing economic, political, cultural and legal ties in the Soviet Union, passed a resolution, ``On the State Status of Estonia.'' By so doing, it violated Articles 2, 70, 71, 73 and 75 of the Constitution of the U.S.S.R., and the U.S.S.R. law, ``On the procedure of resolving questions connected with the exit of a republic from the U.S.S.R.'' On the basis of points 1 and 2 of Article 127, and of Articles 74 and 173 of the U.S.S.R. Constitution, I resolve: 1. To declare the resolution of the Estonian Supreme Soviet of March 30, 1990 ``On the State Status of Estonia'' invalid from the moment it was passed. 2. To consider as illegal any acts of governmental agencies and officials, and also citizens, performed on the basis of this resolution. The President of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics M. Gorbachev Moscow, The Kremlin

May 14, 1990 Presidential Decree on Latvia On the Declaration of the Latvian Supreme Soviet, ``On the Restoration of the Independence of the Latvian Republic'' On May 4, 1990, the Supreme Soviet of the Latvian Soviet Socialist Republic passed the declaration ``On the Restoration of Independence of the Latvian Republic.'' In it is announced that the declaration of the Latvian parliament of July 21, 1940, on the entry of Latvia into the U.S.S.R. does not have legal force. At the same time it talks about the renewal of the validity of a series of articles from the Latvian Republic's Constitution of 1922. The declaration in question was passed by the Latvian Supreme Soviet in a violation of Articles 70, 71, 73 and 75 of the Constitution of the USSR, and also the U.S.S.R. law of April 3, 1990, ``On the procedure of resolving questions connected with the exit of a republic from the U.S.S.R.'' It goes against the rights and interests of other subjects of the Soviet federation, of the U.S.S.R. With its passage, the Constitution of the Latvian Soviet Socialist Republic, which provides for the holding of a referendum on the exit of a republic from the Soviet Union, was also violated. On the basis of points 1 and 2 of Article 127, Article 74 and 173 of the Constitution of the U.S.S.R., I resolve: To declare the declaration of the Supreme Soviet of the Latvian Soviet Socialist Republic of May 4, 1990, ``On the Restoration of the Independence of the Latvian Republic'' void of legal force from the moment of its passage. The President of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics M.S. Gorbachev Moscow, the Kremlin May 14, 1990

DOC.HEAD: Study Boosts Argument for AZT Treatment of Symptom-Free AIDS Infections
DOC.TEXT: A new study shows that some AIDS-infected people without symptoms may be helped by the drug AZT even if certain key immune cells appear normal. The findings by scientists at the University of California, Los Angeles, will be published Tuesday in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences. People who are infected by the AIDS virus but have no outward symptoms often display reduced levels of certain immune system white blood cells known as T-cells. Doctors generally determine how badly the AIDS virus has hurt the body's disease-fighting immune system by measuring T-cells. That's because T-cells activate many parts of the body's defense system, including other white blood cells called monocytes and macrophages. Macrophages are grown-up versions of monocytes. Both types of cells are found in various body tissues, where they act as scavengers that gobble up debris and invading microbes to help combat disease. A low T-cell count often is the justification used by doctors in deciding whether the antiviral drug AZT should be prescribed for AIDS-infected people who haven't yet developed overt symptoms. The new study found that, in the test tube, the virus can directly cause defects in monocytes and macrophages regardless of whether T-cells are damaged or not, said Dr. David Golde, chief of blood diseases and cancer at UCLA. The researchers also showed that AZT significantly reduced the AIDS-induced damage to macrophages and monocytes. Both findings suggest AIDS-infected people might benefit from AZT therapy even if their T-cell levels are not abnormally low, Golde said. But he emphasized that he wasn't advocating AZT treatment for all AIDS-infected people with normal T-cell levels, only those who are tested and found to have damaged macrophages. The study was conducted in Golde's laboratory by research biologist Gayle Cocita Baldwin, Golde and others. AZT has been used for three years to treat patients severely ill with AIDS symptoms. In March, the Food and Drug Administration recommended that adults infected with the deadly virus be treated with AZT even if they do not yet have symptoms of the disease. The recommendation stemmed from federally sponsored studies showing that AZT slowed the progression of AIDS in infected patients with early symptoms or without any symptoms. But the recommendation also was based on the work of a scientific advisory panel that said AZT should be used only on symptom-free patients with reduced T-cell counts. The new study suggests the drug might help even AIDS-infected people with normal T-cell counts. Researchers have known for some time that monocytes and macrophages are defective in people infected by the AIDS virus. But they didn't know if the virus directly attacked macrophages and monocytes to make them defective, or if they were defective simply as a secondary result of the viral attack on T-cells, Golde said. To perform the study, Baldwin and her colleagues took monocytes from human blood, infected them with the AIDS virus, then let them grow into macrophages. They found the infected macrophages were defective in their disease-fighting ability. ``What we found is that in pure cultures of monocytes and macrophages, the AIDS virus itself causes the function of these cells to be defective,'' Golde said. Certain strains of the AIDS virus are more likely to damage monocytes and macrophages, while other strains seem to attack mainly the T-cells, Golde said. ``It may be that certain patients are infected with strains that would have their major impact on macrophages and monocytes, and in those patients antiviral therapy would appear to be useful'' even if T-cell counts weren't dramatically reduced, he added.

DOC.HEAD: Rally Carries Dow Jones Average to Record High
LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: The Dow Jones industrial average on Monday soared to a record high closing. The widely followed average of 30 blue-chip industrial stocks finished up 19.95 at 2,821.53, topping the record close of 2,810.15 set on Jan. 2. Broader market indicators also advanced strongly, and about two issues rose in price for every one that declined on the New York Stock Exchange. The recent rally _ which has seen the Dow industrials rise more than 176 points since April 27 _ has been attributed to a sudden favorable swing in economic indicators. The swing has reduced worries that inflation and interest rates were heading higher. Interest rates kept falling Monday after dropping sharply on Friday. Yields on long-term government bonds, which topped 9 percent a few weeks ago, had dropped to the 8.58 percent-8.60 percent range by late Monday. Falling rates are seen not only as stimulating business activity, which would be good for corporate profits, but also as reducing the returns on interest-bearing investments such as bonds, which prompts some investors to switch funds to the stock market. Brokers say the drop in rates touched off a rush to buy stocks among money managers at investing institutions who had been sitting on large cash reserves.

DOC.HEAD: D.C. Mayor Arraignment Tuesday on Additional Charges
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Marion Barry, already facing a total of eight cocaine possession and perjury charges, will be arraigned Tuesday on six more drug-related charges, court officials said Monday. A federal grand jury indicted Barry, 54, Thursday on five misdemeanor cocaine possession charges and a misdemeanor charge of conspiracy to possess cocaine. The new, broader indictment, which includes the earlier charges, alleged that Barry ``possessed cocaine and crack with other co-conspirators at more than twenty locations, including private residences, hotels, government offices and business establishments and on boats.'' The indictment accused Barry of conspiring to possess cocaine and possessing the drug between the fall of 1984 and his arrest in January in a FBI sting operation at a downtown hotel. Since his arrest, Barry has spent seven weeks in South Carolina and Florida rehabilitation programs for treatment of what he said was abuse of alcohol and prescription drugs. The earlier indictment included five misdemeanor cocaine possession charges and three felony perjury charges. Barry's attorney, R. Kenneth Mundy, on Friday said the new charges were ``unduly burdensome'' on the eve of the scheduled June 4 trial and ``unfair to the defense.'' Barry has not announced whether he will seek a fourth, four-year term in this year's election. However, he has increased his campaign-style appearances in recent weeks.

DOC.HEAD: Explosion at Army Building Injures 7; IRA Claims Responsibility
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with seven wounded, details. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: A bomb hidden in a flowerbed outside an army office exploded before dawn Monday and injured seven people, officials said. The Irish Republican Army claimed responsibility. Scotland Yard said the time bomb containing plastic explosives was buried outside the front entrance of the Directorate of Army Education in Eltham, southeast London. Commander George Churchill Coleman, head of Scotland Yard's anti-terrorist branch, said the bomb could have had a timer set ``a couple of hours or many days'' before the explosion. ``It's important to warn everyone, particularly military personnel and those involved in Irish affairs, about this fairly new development,'' he said. ``This device was buried and was not visible to the naked eye.'' Four men and three women were treated for minor injuries, said a spokesman for Brook Hospital in Greenwich. One of the men, Trevor Hills, was blown across a room in the blast and suffered two broken ribs. Hills is responsible for resettling soldiers into civilian life. All of the injured were civilian employees of the directorate. The directorate commander, Lt. Col. John Simmonds, said the explosion overturned a car in the parking lot and shattered several windshields. ``There's no doubt about it, we were lucky,'' Simmonds said. ``Fortunately nobody was in the car park, everyone was in the building.'' ``There was a very loud explosion,'' said Lucy Hawker, a nearby resident. ``My first thought was that a bomb had gone off _ and it could only be at the army institute.'' The building is the headquarters for the Royal Army Education Corps. Authorities said the approximately 50 army and civilian employees at the center were evacuated and were all accounted for. Defense Minister Archie Hamilton said increased security measures, such as plastic film laminated to windows, prevented more serious injuries. The film prevents the glass from shattering. ``It is extremely difficult to ever get 100 percent security in any establishment,'' Hamilton said. ``We're talking about a predominance of civilians here, and there are no markers to indicate that it is a Ministry of Defense establishment.'' In a statement signed by the Irish Republican Publicity Bureau, in Dublin, the Irish Republican Army said: ``An active service unit planted a device containing over 10 pounds of plastic explosives after penetrating security procedures. ``This institute is a facility for the training of British army officers to a high level in maintaining military and colonial domination in our country,'' the statement said. In its campaign to create a unified socialist state in Ireland, the IRA has claimed responsibility for attacking other army installations in Britain and Europe. In the worst of the attacks, an IRA bomb killed 11 bandsmen at the Royal Marine School of Music in Deal, Kent last September.

DOC.HEAD: New York Drama Critics Honor `The Piano Lesson'
DOC.TEXT: ``The Piano Lesson'' by August Wilson was chosen Monday as best play of the 1989-90 theater season by the New York Drama Critics Circle. ``Privates on Parade'' by Peter Nichols was picked as best foreign play, and ``City of Angels,' a 1940s detective musical by Cy Coleman, Larry Gelbart and David Zippel, won best musical. It was the fourth time Wilson has won the best play award, getting the honor in 1984 for ``Ma Rainey's Black Bottom,'' in 1987 for ``Fences'' and in 1988 for ``Joe Turner's Come and Gone.'' The following are members of the New York Drama Critics Circle: Clive Barnes of The New York Post; John Beaufort, The Christian Science Monitor; Michael Feingold, The Village Voice; William Henry III, Time; Richard Hummler, Variety; Howard Kissel, Don Nelsen, and Douglas Watt, the New York Daily News; Mimi Kramer and Edith Oliver, The New Yorker; Jack Kroll, Newsweek; Michael Kuchwara, The Associated Press; Jacques le Sourd, Gannett Newspapers; Julius Novick, The New York Observer; William Raidy, the Newhouse group; Frank Rich and Mel Gussow, The New York Times; John Simon, New York; Jan Stuart, 7 Days; Linda Winer, Newsday; Edwin Wilson, The Wall Street Journal.

DOC.HEAD: Demjanjuk Lawyer Appeals War Crimes Conviction, Charging Bias
LaserPhoto JRL2
DOC.TEXT: Retired Ohio autoworker John Demjanjuk, who is under a death sentence, appealed a war crimes conviction to Israel's Supreme Court on Monday and his attorney's key argument was that the trial judges were biased. A three-judge panel ruled in April 1988 that Ukrainian-born Demjanjuk, 70, was ``Ivan the Terrible,'' a cruel guard who operated gas chambers at the Nazis' Treblinka death camp in Poland in 1942-43. More than 850,000 Jews perished there. Demjanjuk was sentenced to die under a 1950 Israeli law allowing prosecution of Nazis and collaborators. He was extradited from his home in Cleveland in February 1986 after an Ohio court stripped him of his citizenship for lying about a Nazi past on immigration forms. Demjanjuk says he is a victim of mistaken identity and was held in German POW camps during the time in question. Demjanjuk's Israeli attorney, Yoram Sheftel, told the five-justice Supreme Court panel he challenged the conviction on 10 separate points. The most significant is ``the bias of the court,'' he said. Sheftel said, ``It should lead to the clear conclusion that the conviction should be canceled and especially in a case where the sentence is capital punishment.'' Demjanjuk, clad in a dark brown prison uniform, listened impassively from a witness stand throughout the proceedings, guarded by two policemen. He muttered ``good morning'' in Hebrew as he came into the courtroom, handcuffed, and then embraced his son, John Demjanjuk Jr. The defendant's wife Vera also attended. She refused to speak to reporters. Sheftel also accused the Justice Department's Office of Special Investigations of failing to provide all evidence in Demjanjuk's case to the defense, and said conducting the defense ``was like a boxing match with one contestant standing with his hands tied behind his back.'' The office hunts suspected Nazis in the United States. ``The OSI claimed we got all the documents,'' although many weren't forwarded, Sheftel complained. The lawyer said a hostile atmosphere was created by news reports and the judges' treatment of the defense during the 17-month trial. He claimed trial judges Dov Levine, Dalia Dorner and Shmuel Tal subscribed to a clipping service that delivered twice daily reports from newspapers which carried biased reports. He said the judges briefed reporters on occasion. He said frequent shouts and interruptions came from the audience at the trial, which was held in a converted movie theater. ``Not only was an appearance of justice lacking but justice in fact was not done,'' said Sheftel. He said the judges interrupted defense cross-examinations and intervened in the proceedings. He also argued that the judges dismissed conflicting testimony from one of five Treblinka survivors whose testimony was crucial to Demjanjuk's conviction. He said the survivor missed picking out Demjanjuk in a 1980 photo lineup _ ``This is 20 percent of the evidence, one of five key witnesses it raises a significant question.'' Sheftel claimed the prosecutors inflamed emotions unnecessarily by dwelling on the history of the Holocaust, in which 6 million Jews died. Prosecutor Yonah Blattman interrupted Sheftel once in the first five hours of arguments, saying Sheftel's grounds for claiming bias ``are not legal or factual arguments and are not worthy of being brought before the court.'' Chief Justice Meir Shamgar overruled the objection. The defense lawyer also challenged Israel's jurisdiction to try Demjanjuk as a war criminal. He said Israel's extradition treaty with the United States and the warrant under which Demjanjuk was deported allowed for trying a suspect on murder charges but not genocide or mass murder. Sheftel outlined other points challenging the verdict that he said he would detail in the coming five weeks of court sessions. A major point is the defense claim that a key piece of prosecution evidence, the so-called Trawniki Card, is a forgery. The card, supplied by the Soviet Union, says Demjanjuk was trained at an elite Nazi SS camp to be a concentration camp guard.

DOC.HEAD: Domestic Call Deadly for Two Chicago Policemen
With AM-Cafe Shooting, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: It was a call for a domestic disturbance, one of more than one million that the Chicago police respond to every year. For 20-year veterans Gregory A. Hauser and Raymond C. Kilroy, it was to be their last call. The partners and friends were shot to death outside a house where they answered a report of a disturbance between a grandmother and her grandson _ on Mother's Day night. It happened just two days before National Police Memorial Day, held annually on May 15 to honor officers killed in the line of duty. Domestic violence is ``probably the most common call the police get and probably results in the greatest number of injuries to police because one number correlates to the other,'' said John Dineen, president of the Fraternal Order of Police Chicago Lodge. Dineen canceled his trip to Washington, D.C., to join observations of the national holiday. ``For our officers,'' he said, ``to make sure they get the proper burial, the memorial they deserve here.'' Police did not know Monday afternoon when the funerals would be. When off work, Hauser and Kilroy were business partners who ran a locksmith business out of a truck on their days off to supplement their police salaries, said fellow officer Harold Brown. Hauser was 43, married, and the father of two boys and a girl, ages 7 to 15. Kilroy, 46, was single. Both patrolmen had spent Mother's Day with their families before reporting for duty, said Chicago Police department spokeswoman Tina Vicini. ``Both of them are hard-working guys,'' said Brown. ``They were both nice guys. Just super nice guys.'' On Sunday night, the officers went to the working-class Northwest neighborhood and later called for backups, police said. Hauser and Kilroy were found with gunshot wounds to the head and body. More than 100 officers working with dogs poured into the neighborhood.
