After a several-hour manhunt, the suspect was cornered under a porch. Roman Chavez, 23, was charged Monday with two counts of first-degree murder and one count of armed robbery, the latter because authorities said he took one of the officers' guns. Anthony Calabrese, supervisor of the homicide division of the state's attorney's office, said, it was too early to say whether that gun was used to kill the officers. He also declined to discuss a motive for the slaying. Calabrese said Chavez was arrested eight times as a juvenile and four times as an adult _ the most recent arrest in suburban Elmhurst in February for battery and eluding of a police officer. Chavez had lived with his grandmother for six or seven years ago, after his parents divorced, said Nickie Carsello, who lives next door. ``He was fine when he first moved in,'' she said. ``He used to help out. He put our air conditioner in the window. He would cut our lawn. He was a real nice kid.'' But four years ago, Chavez's step-grandfather was killed by a train he didn't see as he stepped across railroad tracks near the home. After that, there was a transformation in ``Sammy,'' as Chavez was known to the Carsellos. Ms. Carsello said the home shared by Chavez and his grandmother, probably in her 70s, was a blight on the neighborhood, consisting otherwise of neatly kept single-family homes. She recalled asking the grandmother, ``Why don't you have him cut your lawn?' ... She said I'm afraid to talk to him, he might hurt me.'' Chavez was being held without bail in Cook County Jail and has been assigned a public defender. A preliminary hearing was scheduled for June 1. ``Now we'll go through the process of the wakes and the funerals,'' said Dineen. ``Then comes the trial _ the offender _ that's when you begin to wonder if there's any justice in the world. After the trial comes the appeals where the offender does his best to stay out of jail. And you have two police officers who are dead. They have no trial, no appeal, just execution.''

DOC.HEAD: Attorneys Call Florida Decision Legal and Symbolic Victory
DOC.TEXT: Neither time nor distance wipe out child support obligations, the Florida Supreme Court told a Virginia woman who was abandoned nearly 22 years ago while pregnant with her third child. The result of the woman's long, draining legal battle is expected to affect family courts in other states, some attorneys said Monday. ``The biggest thing I feel is a sense of satisfaction,'' Patricia Bennett, 44, of Springfield, Va., said. ``It was a tremendous amount of work, (but) this will affect thousands.'' Bennett, a non-lawyer who represented herself in oral arguments before Florida's high court more than two years ago, said she thinks last week's decision could be followed by courts in other states. She listed California, Texas, Ohio, and West Virginia as states that remain havens for delinquent parents. In its ruling, the Supreme Court said that Florida judges can jail for contempt parents who have not paid out-of-state child support awards and that back child support awards must be paid, even after children become adults. Attorneys who filed friends of the court briefs supporting Bennett's case agreed with her Monday that the ruling was significant both legally and symbolically. ``Legally, of course, this decision is only binding in the state of Florida,'' said Sally Goldfarb of New York, a staff attorney for the NOW Legal Defense and Education Fund. ``But frequently in family law matters, courts look to the decisions of other states in order to get insights.'' ``Because so many out-of-state cases are mentioned we suspect it will have national prominence,'' said Joe Boyd of Tallahassee, who represents the state Department of Health and Rehabilitative Services. But also important is the message the ruling sends to delinquent parents, the two attorneys said. ``The court forcefully and eloquently stated that child support obligations become stronger with time and that no parent should be permitted to turn his back on the children whom he abandoned,'' Goldfarb said. ``I guess `Read my lips' is what the Florida Supreme Court has said,'' Boyd said. Bennett and her ex-husband, Oscar Gibson, were married in 1964; five years later he disappeared. In 1985, Bennett found him living with a different name and a different wife in rural Lutz, Fla., and her legal struggle to get back child support from him resumed. Bennett's daughters now are 21, 22 and 23. The eldest has a 16-month-old son. A CBS movie called ``Runaway Father,'' based on her story, is being made. Once children reach 18, parents who raised them are ``not magically reimbursed for personal funds spent nor debts incurred due to nonpayment of child support,'' Justice Gerald Kogan wrote in Thursday's majority opinion. ``Hardships suffered by a family do not disappear,'' Kogan said. ``A family's feelings of indignation from abandonment by the nonpaying parent or from past reliance on public assistance are not forgotten.'' Bennett received welfare for two years after Gibson left her. But since then, however, she has earned a bachelor's degree and a master's degree in business adminstration. She works now as a financial analyst for the Internal Revenue Service and has applied to law school. Bennett's ex-husband, now known as James Parker, has been making $100 payments every week since 1987. But the insurance claims adjuster said he'd have to make payments to wipe out $148,536 in back payments, interest and expenses a Virginia court said he owes. ``Probably until I'm dead,'' Parker said. Mark Kelly, who represented Parker, said he thought the ruling ``really gives the party (trying to collect) twice as much leverage as they had before.''

DOC.HEAD: Defense Lawyer Wants To Question Chilean Secret Police Officials
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS new 7th graf, A Chilean, to ADD recent compensation announcement; ADDS two grafs at end with investigation development in Chile; ADDs byline
DOC.TEXT: A lawyer for a Cuban exile said Monday he'll seek to question two former leaders of Chile's secret police who allegedly ordered the assassination of ex-Chilean ambassador Orlando Letelier. Attorney Paul Goldberger's client, Dionisio Suarez Esquivel, was ordered Monday by U.S. District Court Judge Aubrey Robinson to stand trial beginning Sept. 10 on charges that he helped carry out the Letelier killing. Suarez was arrested April 11 in St. Petersburg, Fla., after 12 years as a fugitive. He is charged with conspiracy, murdering a foreign official, two counts of murder and using explosives that result in death. Letelier and an aide, Ronni Moffitt, died when a bomb attached to the car in which they rode was detonated in Washington on Sept. 21, 1976. The Chilean government has refused to extradite the two former Chilean secret police offials. Juan Manuel Contreras Sepulveda and Pedro Espinoza Bravo were indicted along with Suarez and five other people in 1978. It will be up to the judge to decide whether to order depositions from Contreras and Espinoza for the Suarez case. A Chilean official did say Saturday that Chile has agreed to pay compensation to the families of Letelier and Moffitt. But the announcement by acting Interior Minister Belisario Velasco was not expected to affect the criminal cases. An outspoken critic of the Chilean regime of Augusto Pinochet, Letelier had been the ambassador to the United States under the Marxist government of Salvador Allende. The government's chief witness against Suarez is expected to be Michael Townley, a U.S. citizen who worked for the Chilean intelligence service, DINA. In court, Goldberger said U.S. officials had refused to extradite Townley, who apparently is in the U.S. government's witness protection program. Townley had been implicated in a murder case in Argentina involving an exiled Chilean general, Carlos Pratz. Pratz died in a bomb blast. Prosecutors did not comment on Goldberger's assertion that the U.S. had turned down an Argentine request to turn over Townley, who admitted planting the bomb in the Letelier killing and served a 40-month prison term. Goldberger also represented another defendant in the Letelier case, Guillermo Novo Sampol. Sampol, now living in the Miami area, was convicted of perjury. Appearing in court, Novo said he had no objection to Goldberger representing Suarez. Prosecutors have said they might call Novo as a witness against Suarez. Outside the courtroom, Novo said he is involved in fund raising for Suarez's legal defense. On April 24, the Chilean Suprme Court ordered the reopening of an investigation in Chile into the Letelier assassination. The ruling came after a woman named Liliana Walker, a Chilean security agent, said in newspaper interviews that she had helped in the preparations for the assassination. She said she accompanied another agent, Armando Fernandez Larios, to Washington in 1976 to helped in the groundwork. Fernandez left Chile secretly in 1987 and surrendered in the United States, where he admitted participating in the preparations. Goldberger said he wants to question Walker as well as the two former DINA officers.

DOC.HEAD: University President Under Fire For Lavish Spending Habits
DOC.TEXT: The University of South Carolina's president has spent hundreds of thousands of dollars on gifts for donors, office artwork and teaching salaries for celebrities such as Robby Benson and Jihan Sadat. Now James B. Holderman's lavish spending, which has given him trouble for years, has once again raised the ire of state lawmakers, who have warned him to spend public funds more wisely if he wants to keep his job. ``People are tired of it,'' Rep. Herb Kirsh said Monday. ``I feel things will be different from here on out. The public is demanding it. South Carolinians don't like that kind of spending.'' Legislators earlier this month blasted Holderman after local newspapers revealed he spent $533,898 in the past year on items such as $800-a-night hotel rooms for himself, $6,400 on sculptures for his office and $163,000 for meals and receptions for potential donors. Many of the expenses were charged to Holderman's $500,000 discretionary account _ which is funded with receipts from vending machines and concessions _ and his state-issued American Express card. By comparison, Clemson University President Max Lennon has a discretionary account of $18,000. Holderman has defended his spending as a vital part of fund-raising for the state-supported university of 40,000 students, saying his efforts have helped raise $25 million for USC in the last year. But he promised to keep his expenses down following public criticism. He said the fallout from the latest revelations has ``taught me the difficulty of taking a macro view of things.'' ``Some people tend to take a micro view of things, and that's where there seems to be a misunderstanding,'' he said last week. But if Holderman wants to remain at the helm of the state's flagship university, state lawmakers and his own board of trustees have insisted that he curb his spending. Kirsh said Holderman has set a bad example for students. If he does not follow spending guidelines being set by the newly elected board of trustees, the legislator said he would favor Holderman's dismissal. ``He's only doing it now because of the public outcry,'' Kirsh said. Board of trustees chairman Michael Mungo has also made it clear that Holderman must control his spending according to the guidelines or face dismissal. Holderman, who has presided over the university since 1977, first drew criticism in 1986 when it was revealed he ran up generous hotel bills during fund-raising trips and bought expensive gifts for donors. He then came under fire for spending huge amounts of money to recruit celebrities such as Benson, an actor and director who has taught filmmaking as an artist-in-residence since 1988. The school has paid Benson $158,367 in salary and expenses and $15,600 for rent, while Holderman has kicked in $10,000 from his discretionary account for moving and travel expenses. In addition, the university still holds about $23,000 in unpaid bills from the production of Benson's latest movie, ``Modern Love,'' which was filmed in South Carolina. Benson has said the bills will be paid and the school will receive 2 percent of the movie's profits. Benson's two-year contract expires Tuesday and no new contract offer has been made, school spokeswoman Debra Allen said Monday. Benson did not return calls left at his office Monday seeking comment, but he has said he would leave if his work was not appreciated. Other prominent personalities hired by Holderman for fat contracts include Jihan Sadat, widow of the late Egyptian President Anwar Sadat, who was paid $200,000 to teach a course in Egyptian culture for three semesters in 1985 and 1986. In contrast, ``Deliverance'' author James Dickey was hired in 1969, before Holderman came aboard, and receives an $80,000 annual salary to teach four writing courses. He pays his secretary's salary and his expenses out of his own pocket. The university under Holderman's leadership also has been criticized by lawmakers for sloppy bookkeeping and using public funds, employees and equipment to operate the school's 10 private fund-raising foundations.

DOC.HEAD: U.S., Iran Sign Small-Claims Settlement
DOC.TEXT: The United States and Iran have signed a $105 million lump-sum settlement of small U.S. claims rising out of the Islamic revolution, the State Department announced Monday. Department officials said that the talks leading to the settlement of more than 2,300 U.S. claims of up to $250,000 each were not linked to the recent release of two U.S. hostages held by pro-Iranian kidnappers in Lebanon or to the fate of the six Americans still held there. Negotiations still are underway on about $400,000 worth of small Iranian claims against the United States, most of them filed by Iranian soldiers in training in the United States who were ordered expelled after the 1979 Iranian revolution. The settlement of the U.S. claims must now be approved by the Iran-United States Claims Tribunal, established in the Dutch city of The Hague under the 1981 Algiers Accords. The accords set the terms for the release of the Americans held hostage at the U.S. Embassy in Tehran for 444 days. Although the agreement represents a step toward repairing badly frayed U.S.-Iranian relations, officials noted there are still deep divisions over larger claims made by Iran as well as over the hostage question. Margaret Tutwiler, the State Department spokeswoman, noted that President Bush has said repeatedly that a good place to start the normalization of relations ``would be the release of all American hostages.'' The settlement signed Sunday does clear the way for the tribunal to deal with about $16 billion in major contested claims. As to the outstanding Iranian small claims, a senior U.S. official who briefed reporters on the settlement on the condition he not be identified said the claims include some $10 billion for military properties. He said that while the United States believes there is value to some of the Iranian claims, for others running into the billions of dollars, ``our view and the Iranian view of what these totals are are far apart.'' Once the tribunal approves the settlement of the U.S. small claims, the $105 million will be paid to the United States in one lump sum. Final distribution to a large variety of claimants _ including many Americans who lost their personal possessions when they fled Tehran after the revolution against the government of Shah Mohammad Reza Pahlavi _ will be made by the Justice Department's Foreign Claims Settlement Commission. The U.S. official said that there is no way to predict how long that might take, but past experience indicates it could take two to four years. U.S. officials said that payments will be made far faster than if the tribunal were to attempt to settle the cases one by one. The settlement accord was signed late Sunday night by Timothy Ramish, U.S. agent to the tribunal, and Ali Nobari, the Iranian agent, according to an American official at the tribunal. The negotiations were conducted for the United States by Judge Abraham Sofaer, the State Department's chief legal adviser.

DOC.HEAD: Showers And Thunderstorms In Mississippi Valley
DOC.TEXT: Showers and thunderstorms spread over the Mississippi Valley on Monday, and temperatures dipped into the chilly range around the Great Lakes. Showers and thunderstorms were over Minnesota and Wisconsin, as well as over southern Missouri and northern Arkansas. Afternoon temperatures were only in the 40s and 50s across northern sections of the Great Lakes region and the Mississippi Valley after a night when temperatures dipped into the 30s and 40s. Morning lows were also in the 30s and 40s in the northern Plains and the Pacific Northwest, and into the 20s and 30s in the northern and central Rockies. Youngstown, Ohio, dipped to a record low of 33. Elsewhere, a few showers and thunderstorms were over extreme southern Florida, and a few showers were over central Texas and the central Rockies. Heavier rainfall totals for the six hours up to 2 p.m. EDT were 0.65 of an inch at Texarkana, Ark., and 0.62 of an inch at Rochester, Minn. A storm system moving southeastward out of the Pacific Northwest began spreading strong, gusty wind into the Southwest. Flooding continued in parts of Texas, Arkansas and Louisiana, especially along the Trinity and Red rivers. Monday's low for the Lower 48 states was 15 at Dillon, Mont.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Rejects Latvian, Estonian Independence
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to EXPAND on the Soviet decrees, details. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Monday declared independence moves by Latvia and Estonia ``illegal and invalid'' but gave no hint whether he would retaliate with sanctions as he has with Lithuania. In two presidential decrees, read Monday on the nightly TV news program ``Vremya,'' Gorbachev clearly rejected a weekend appeal by the three Baltic presidents to recognize their statehood. The decrees said Latvia's May 4 declaration of independence and Estonia's March 30 declaration that it was an occupied country violated Soviet law and the constitution. In Latvia, officials said they awaited an anti-independence protest outside the Parliament building and a republic-wide political strike Tuesday. Helicopters dropped leaflets on the Latvian capital of Riga on Monday calling for the strike and protest. The Soviet Union forcibly annexed Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia in 1940. Lithuania declared its independence March 11 and began passing laws toward that end, enraging Moscow and bringing on an embargo of oil, natural gas and other raw materials. Gorbachev's initial response to Lithuania's declaration paralleled Monday's decrees: he declared it ``illegal and invalid'' and asked Lithuania to rescind it. Latvia and Estonia passed more cautious measures, allowing for an unspecified transition period to independence, but their moves proved equally unacceptable. The presidential decrees, in dry, legal language, listed the points of the law and constitution violated by the Estonian and Latvian measures. Gorbachev rebuked the two republics, saying Estonia acted ``without having consulted with the people of the republic, ignoring its existing economic, political, cultural and legal ties'' with Moscow. He said Latvia had ``gone against the rights and interests of other subjects of the Soviet federation.'' Gorbachev called Latvia's decree ``invalid from the moment of its passage,'' and the same went for Estonia's measure. On Saturday, the three Baltic presidents revived a 1934 Council of Baltic States, pledging cooperation and asking Gorbachev and President Bush to discuss their independence at the U.S.-Soviet summit opening May 30. In Lithuania, Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene said Monday her government still wants to compromise with Moscow. ``We are ready to compromise on isues that are vital to the Soviet Union, defense, borders, customs, military presence.'' she said. She declined to go into specifics, but said she would make definite proposals before Gorbachev meets Bush so he could ``make serious decisions before going to Washington.'' In Latvia, the helicopter leaflets urged citizens to ``take to the streets'' Tuesday and ``demand the restoration of Soviet power,'' said Aris Jansons, chief aide to Latvia's president. The leaflets called for a strike at 10 a.m. Tuesday and told workers to converge on parliament, where ``a handful of traitors and political adventurers who are deciding our fate instead of us should tremble at the voice of the working class.'' Earlier Monday, more than 100 Soviet army officers tried to enter the Latvian Supreme Soviet parliament, leading to a scuffle in which a Latvian radio reporter and several women were slightly injured, reports said. The scuffle, which involved mothers of Latvian soldiers who were killed, ended when Latvian President Anatoly Gorbunov invited in some officers to air their complaints, Jansons said in a telephone interview. Soviet officers repeatedly have demonstrated against independence in front of the parliament. Latvia's declaration of independence has stirred protests from among the 46 percent of the population that is non-Latvian and from many army officers stationed there. Latvia has 2.8 million people. On Friday, Latvia's police force said it would submit to orders only from Moscow and ignore commands from the Latvian government, Jansons said. He said this made the government concerned for the security of the parliament building Tuesday, and many people feared the lawmakers would be blocked from entering. Members of various grassroots organizations plan to try to defend the Supreme Soviet building and the parliament's independence move Tuesday, said Anda Anspoka, a spokeswoman for the Latvian People's Front. ``They are going to stand there and do their best, picketing and expressing their opinions,'' she said. The building was guarded previously by police and People's Front volunteers. Jansons said groups dominated by ethnic Russians in all three republics appeared to be coordinating a regional anti-independence action for Tuesday, and sources in Vilnius confirmed plans for a Baltic-wide protest. Pavelas Gilis said Russian-dominated Communist parties planned to stage political meetings throughout Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia on Tuesday. Gilis is a secretary of the Lithuanian Communist Party that broke with its Moscow parent party in December and backs independence. Since annexation 50 years ago, the non-native population has swelled to almost 50 percent in Latvia and Estonia, where anti-independence movements are stronger than in native-dominated Lithuania. A Soviet colonel told a Vilnius news conference Monday the Lithuanian government was denying medical care to officers and their families, and hostility was running so high that Soviet officers changed into civilian clothes before going onto the streets. Col. Konstantin Golubeyev, political commissar for Soviet armed forces in Lithuania, also said unidentified assailants fired into a Soviet officer's apartment.

DOC.HEAD: Unusual U.S. Senate Hearing Entertains 300 Children
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf to restore dropped word, Human, in title of committee.
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Edward Kennedy turned actor Monday, portraying a Harvard Square train station in an algebra lesson that helped turn a U.S. Senate hearing into a lively variety show for 300 children. The young audience also met 4-foot robot, a Harvard scientist who showed them a telescope that can be made for less than $1 and a fifth-grade teacher who borrowed a real dinosaur skull for a make-believe trip to the Western desert to study paleontology. The setting was a hearing to take testimony for a Senate bill aimed at boosting education in math, science and technology. In a departure from the customary decorous exchange of testimony and questions, the hearing was held in a theater at the Museum of Science and included middle school youngsters from the Boston area. Teachers with novel methods and program instructors deploying high technology showed how they inspire enthusiasm among children in science and math. The need for enthusiasm is dire. According to figures gathered by the Labor and Human Resources Committee about the 24,000 U.S. high schools, 7,000 offer no physics course; 4,000 offer no chemistry and 2,000 offer not a single biology course. Among the nation's elementary and high school science teachers a full 60,000 are unqualified to teach that subject. Half the faculty jobs in U.S. graduate schools of engineering are held by foreigners because of a dearth of American engineering teachers. Yet it is projected that by the year 2006, America will be short 675,000 scientists and engineers, and by 2000 industry will be short 2 million technicians. Just 10 years from now the country will need 300,000 more science teachers. Kennedy and Sen. Mark Hatfield, R-Utah, are cosponsors of the Excellence in Math, Science and Engineering Education Act, which is now before Kennedy's Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee. The bill sets out a 10-year schedule of appropriations, starting with $125 million for improving and monitoring science and math education. It would direct more attention as well to technological training in industry and to bringing more women and minorities into the field. The Labor committee is expected to vote on the bill soon and, if it passes muster, send it to the Senate floor this summer. Among the presentations at the hearing was the algebra lesson invented by Boston teacher Robert Moses. It translates the abstractions of A plus B equals C into reality. Moses enlisted Kennedy along with nine students to stand in front of the auditorium to represent train stops on the Red Line subway route connecting Boston and Cambridge. Three children played the train, chug-chugging between the stations. Such lessons, conducted over time and interspersed with trips on real trains, are used to teach children the concept that a variable like ``x'' or ``y'' can, in algebra, stand for a real number. The also help relate math to real life. The problem may go even deeper than the need to make math and science more relevant, however. Jane Holdsworth of The Thames Science Center in New London, Conn., told Kennedy that while wheeling in her robot to make her presentation, a little girl asked her if the robot bites. ``I hope we're getting to the day when we know that robots don't bite,'' Holdsworth said. ``And that math and science don't bite. They're fun.''

DOC.HEAD: Thornburgh Reassigns 2 Top Aides
DOC.TEXT: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh reassigned two top aides Monday in what appeared to be an attempt to dispel the perception he is surrounded by a tight circle of loyal aides. Robert S. Ross Jr., Thornburgh's chief of staff, will spend the next two to three months organizing a new office of international affairs, then return to private legal practice, said senior department officials. David Runkel, Thornburgh's press secretary who has endured stormy relations with reporters, has been reassigned to be director of communications, said the officials, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. The changes took effect Monday. Thornburgh was in the process of selecting a new director of the Office of Public Affairs, who will serve as the department's chief spokesman, the officials said. The changes were disclosed by officials close to Thornburgh just three days after Deputy Attorney General Donald B. Ayer announced after just six months in office that he would resign on May 25. The same day that Ayer disclosed his plans to leave, the White House announced its intention to nominate Assistant Attorney General William Barr to be the new deputy attorney general. Ayer decided to leave because he felt he lacked the traditional authority usually given a deputy attorney general to oversee the day-to-day operations of the department, according to administration sources. One source said Ayer was kept out of the decision-making process by Thornburgh's top aides. Ross, who functioned as Thornburgh's chief of staff, retained many of the responsibilities normally given to the deputy attorney general, one official said. Officials said that Barr would be given the authority that Ayer sought but was never given as part of Thornburgh's effort to turn management of the department over to the deputy and the assistant attorneys general. Thornburgh has run an extremely tight ship, holding decision-making power among a small circle of aides who worked for him when he was governor of Pennsylvania. Both Ross and Runkel, members of a trio that includes longtime aide Murray Dickman, served as top aides to Thornburgh in Harrisburg. Dickman is expected to remain on the attorney general's staff, which is expected to play a more ``low-key role'' in department operations, officials said. ``It was never his (Thornburgh's) intention to have a small personal staff attempting to run the department,'' said one official. ``When the dust settles, you are going to see a Washington team in place,'' said another official. Ayer was given the unpleasant and difficult assignments of defending the Bush administration's opposition to undoing a series of Supreme Court decisions on civil rights that Democrats in Congress are anxious to blunt. Ayer's resignation was announced two weeks after the disclosure that he had been ordered to withdraw a letter expressing Justice Department support for sentencing guidelines for corporations convicted of crimes. Runkel said the letter was unauthorized because Thornburgh had not seen it before Ayer sent it to the U.S. Sentencing Commission, which is considering whether to implement the guidelines. Runkel has been accused by reporters of giving them misleading or incomplete information. An FBI investigation ordered by Thornburgh of unauthorized leaks of information about a criminal probe involving the office of Rep. William H. Gray III, D-Pa., named Runkel as a ``secondary source'' of the story. Thornburgh defended Runkel's conduct, but the disclosure of his close aide's role proved politically embarrassing.

DOC.HEAD: Bush to Nominate Californian, Virginian
DOC.TEXT: President Bush will nominate Robert E. Lamb, the assistant secretary of state for diplomatic security, as ambassador to Cyprus, the White House said Monday. Lamb, 53, of Alexandria, Va., is a career foreign service officer. If confirmed by the Senate, he would succeed Bill K. Perrin. The White House also said Bush will nominate: _Lourdes G. Baird to be the U.S. attorney for the central district of California. Ms. Baird, 55, is now a Los Angeles Superior Court judge. A native of Quito, Ecuador, she would succeed Robert C. Bonner, who is being nominated to head the Drug Enforcement Administration. _Dr. James Wilson Holsinger Jr., 51, as chief medical director at the Department of Veterans Affairs. He is currently medical director for the McGuire VA Medical Center in Richmond, Va. _Jonathan R. Steinberg as associate judge of the U.S. Court of Veterans Appeals. He is currently chief counsel and staff director for the Senate Committee on Veterans Affairs. Steinberg, 51, lives in Potomac, Md.

DOC.HEAD: Outpouring of Fan Affection for Sammy Davis Jr.
DOC.TEXT: Sammy Davis Jr.'s losing fight with cancer has elicited a torrent of affection from fans, ranging from phone calls to tourist pilgrimages to the entertainer's home. ``The outpouring of love from friends, those we know and those we don't, has been almost overwhelming,'' Davis' wife, Altovise, said in a news release Monday. ``I want to thank everyone who has sent thoughts and prayers to Sammy. It means so much to him and to our family.'' The couple marked a wedding anniversary Friday. ``I'm so grateful that we were able to share our 20th anniversary last Friday at home together,'' Mrs. Davis said. ``Sammy continues to rest comfortably at home. Everything possible is being done for him.'' There was no change Monday in the medical condition of the 64-year-old song-and-dance man, said his publicist Susan Reynolds. Outside Davis' gated estate, television news crews, reporters and photographers kept a vigil. Tourist vans rolled past slowly each hour with occupants pressing against the windows and taking snapshots. Davis' doctor, Irving Posalski, confirmed over the weekend that Davis was dying from throat cancer and that he was surrounded by family. The entertainer was released from Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in March and his condition has deteriorated since. Leanne Peckham, representing a group called Friends of Sammy Davis Jr., set up a telephone hotline late Friday for well-wishers wanting to send Western Union mailgrams to Davis. It costs $6.75 for a 55-word message. There were 498 calls Saturday, the last day a count was available, said Virginia Reese of Western Union's central office in Los Angeles. Davis, first diagnosed and treated for carcinoma of the throat last September, suffered a recurrence of the cancer earlier this year.
Eds: Western Union mailgram number is 1-800-257-4900, ask for hotline No. 9696.

DOC.HEAD: Prime Minister Orders Reopening of Palestinian Universities
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 5 grafs after 4th graf `The United' to UPDATE with Palestinian killed in Gaza Strip, settler leader sentenced. Pickup 5th pvs, `Shamir spokesman' and edits thereafter to trim
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir on Monday ordered a gradual reopening of six Palestinian universities in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, which were closed shortly after the Palestinian uprising began 2{ years ago. The move is likely to improve Israel's relations with the United States. They have been strained in recent weeks over Shamir's increased settlement activity in the occupied lands and his refusal to accept U.S. Middle East peace proposals. The army closed Palestinian institutions of higher learning shortly after the anti-Israeli uprising broke out in December 1987. The government said the universities were hotbeds of anti-Israeli violence. The United States and Western Europe sharply criticized the measure as collective punishment. The European Parliament at one stage recommended scientific cooperation with Israel be frozen until the universities and colleges were reopened. In the occupied Gaza Strip, meanwhile, paramilitary border police fatally wounded a 19-year-old Palestinian after masked youths attacked the patrol with knives and axes, the army and Arab reports said. Hospital officials identified the slain youth as Hamis Abdel Rahman Abu Husah, from the Shati refugee camp. His death raised to 657 the number of Palestinians killed by soldiers during the 29-month-old rebellion. At least 212 Palestinians have been slain by their Arab brethern on suspicion of cooperating with Israeli authorities. Forty-three Israelis have also died in the violence. Also Monday, Rabbi Moshe Levinger, a founder of the Jewish settlement movement, began serving a five-month sentence for killing a Palestinian during a stone-throwing incident. Levinger is the second settler sentenced to prison for killing an Arab since the uprising began. The Israeli Information Center for Human Rights in the Occupied Territories reported that in that time 29 Palestinians were killed by settler gunfire. Shamir spokesman Avi Pazner said the prime minister instructed his adviser for the occupied lands, Shmuel Goren, to meet with the heads of the six universities to discuss conditions of the reopening. Goren said the first university would open within two days. There are five universities in the West Bank and one in the Gaza Strip, with a total of 18,000 students. Goren said authorities were encouraged by the declining bloodshed in recent months but also warned the heads of universities that if violence recurs, the facilities would be closed immediately. ``I'm not sure they can control their students. But at least they promised that they can do it. If they (the students) use these institutions as a base for violence, we will not be able to continue,'' Goren told The Associated Press. Underground leaders of the uprising have said in recent leaflets resumption of studies was a top priority and that students should not give the army an excuse to close facilities. Pazner and Goren denied the decision to reopen schools was aimed at appeasing the Bush administration. ``We hope it will bring us a good reaction from the United States and Europe, but our main consideration was security,'' Goren said. Sari Nusseibeh, considered by Israel to be one of the leaders of uprising, said Israel was responding to pressure from the United States and Europe to reopen the universities. ``It means that they (the Israelis) are beginning to yield to pressure,'' Nusseibeh said. He noted Czech President Vaclav Havel brought up the issue in talks with Israeli leaders during a recent visit. Throughout the closure, instruction has continued in so-called underground classes. But attendance of the makeshift classes was sporadic, and the education they provided was far below the normal standards. Especially hard-hit were science students who had to do without lab facilities. The six universities are Bethlehem University, Islamic University, Bir Zeit University, Hebron University, An-Najah University and Jerusalem University. It has two branches _ Abu Dis College of Science and Technology and the Ramallah Community College.

DOC.HEAD: Baby-Sitter Charged in Boy's Death, Sex Assaults
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Lenard as first name is correct.
DOC.TEXT: A partially blind man was charged Monday with first-degree murder and sexual assault in attacks on three of four children he had been baby-sitting. Authorities were still gathering evidence in the case involving the fourth child, a 7-year-old girl, and other charges might be filed later against Lenard Johnson, 37, said Montgomery County State's Attorney Kathryn Dobrinic. The prosecutor said she planned to seek the death penalty if Johnson is convicted of murder in the stabbing death of 11-year-old Donald L. Buske of nearby Litchfield. Three girls, ages 7, 11 and 13, were taken to a Litchfield hospital for treatment and observation and later released. Johnson was released from a Springfield hospital, where he was treated for an apparently self-inflicted knife wound to the stomach and cuts to his wrist, shortly before a court hearing in Hillsboro. He faces two counts of first-degree murder, one accusing him of killing the boy with intent; the other, of committing the murder in the course of another felony _ home invasion. He also is charged with two counts of aggravated criminal sexual assault. ``I think the evidence will show that he had cared for the children earlier in the evening and he was taken home and then returned to the home later'' and broke in and committed the crime, Ms. Dobrinic said in a telephone interview. Circuit Judge E.C. Eberstacher read the charges to Johnson and told him he could expect a minimum sentence of six years in prison if found guilty of any of them. Johnson displayed no emotion. He only nodded yes or no in reply to the judge's questions. Eberstacher scheduled a bond hearing for Tuesday and appointed a lawyer for Johnson. Neighbors described Johnson, who lived alone, as a familiar figure often seen walking. They said he collected disability payments because of his impaired vision. One neighbor, Dave Belt, said Johnson told him he had moved from the Chicago area several years ago to ``get away from the crime and violence of the city.'' Authorities said the boy and the 7-year-old girl were siblings, and the two other girls had been visiting them for the night. The children's ordeal began Friday night after the boy's mother, Susan Emerson, got off work about 10:30. She and her husband, James, went out, leaving the children with Johnson. When the parents returned home, they found everything apparently normal and Emerson took Johnson back to his own home. But while he was out, authorities said, Mrs. Emerson's 7-year-old daughter told her mother she had been assaulted. When Emerson returned, the couple took the girl to the hospital, telling the other children to lock the house and let no one inside, according to police and neighbors. The hospital advised police of the assault. After the parents left, Johnson sneaked back to the house, tearing open a screen and lifting a front window to enter, authorities said. Once inside, authorities contend, Johnson killed the boy, then assaulted the two girls, isolating himself in the bathroom with them briefly after police arrived. The standoff ended about 15 minutes later, and police said they found Johnson suffering from stab wounds.

DOC.NOTE: EDS: Inserts new 3rd graf: ``Later in,'' and ADDs 6 grafs with Sen. Mitchell's comments; corrects category code
DOC.HEAD: Bush Has No Plans to Ask for Changed Endangered Species Act
DOC.TEXT: The White House, rejecting complaints by Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan, said Monday that President Bush does not want to weaken the nation's primary law protecting endangered animals and plants. ``We have no plans to change the act at this time,'' White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said. Later in the day, Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell also assured there would be no such move. Lujan expressed concern last week that the 17-year-old Endangered Species Act was threatening jobs and economic development. ``It's just too tough an act, I think,'' Lujan told the Denver Post. ``We've got to change it.'' Asked if Lujan was at odds with Bush on the matter, Fitzwater said, ``It means he (Lujan) gave his views and they're important, but there's been no decision to make any change.'' Bush has said he wants to be known as ``the environmental president.'' In a speech in the Senate, Mitchell said Lujan was mistaken when he claimed the Endangered Species Act was used to block development or threaten jobs. He said only three projects in every 10,000 were withdrawn or canceled between 1979 and 1986 because of concerns about the welfare of a species. In 1987, the General Accounting Office reviewed over 3,000 consultations related to the effects of water projects in the West on species and found that none was canceled as a result, said Mitchell. ``The Endangered Species Act also provides an exemption process to balance economic and conservation interests when an irreconcilable conflict exists between the needs of the species and the necessary federal action,'' said Mitchell. ``It has only been used twice in the act's history.'' Mitchell said ``mankind benefits from the enormous diversity of plant and animal life on our planet'' _ for instance, 40 percent of all medicines have components derived from plants. ``Who among us, Secretary Lujan or anyone else, can now predict which of the obscure plants and insects or animals now being decimated may hold the genetic key to the next medical miracle?'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING a0679 to clear garble in header
1.25 Billion Emergency Cabinet Plan for Settling Soviet Jews
DOC.TEXT: The Cabinet on Monday approved an emergency plan to spend an additional $1.25 billion to absorb the 150,000 Soviet Jews expected to arrive this fiscal year. The funds, if approved by Parliament, would be an increase to the 1990 budget that earmarked $900 million to help resettle an estimated 40,000 Soviet Jewish immigrants. No date has been set for the vote in Parliament. The new immigration package includes $50 million for housing, $56 million for education and $8 million for job training. David Boaz, the director of the Finance Ministry's budget division, said that under the emergency spending plan, the government would build 45,000 units of public housing, up from 3,000 last year. Boaz said most of the units would be built in Israel's central region, from the cities of ``Ashkelon to Haifa to east Jerusalem.'' This appeared to be in contradiction to statements by Housing Ministry officials that no construction would take place on occupied territory. Arab east Jerusalem was captured along with the West Bank from Jordan in the 1967 Middle East war. Israel annexed east Jerusalem and declared the united city the nation's capital. The United States has said the status of Jerusalem should be negotiated in peace talks with the Arabs, and opposes Jewish settlements on captured land. Boaz said the most difficult problem in resettling the Soviet Jews was in providing jobs for the immigrants, many of whom are academics and technicians and face stiff competition from a highly skilled Israeli labor force. Israel has a 9 percent unemployment rate, and Labor Ministry officials have said it was ``well above that'' for university graduates. The 13-member Cabinet of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's transition government voted on each item of the plan. Each section won the approval of at least 10 ministers. ``We succeeded in getting across the sense of emergency, that Israel is not prepared for this flood of immigrants,'' Boaz said.

DOC.HEAD: Andrei P. Kirilenko, Ex-Politburo Member, Dead at 84
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with date of death, quote. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Andrei P. Kirilenko, a former Politburo member who once was believed in line to succeed Leonid I. Brezhnev as Soviet leader, has died, the official news agency Tass reported Monday. He was 84. Cause of his death Saturday was given by Tass only as a ``grave illness.'' Reports of Kirilenko's ill health surfaced when he dropped from sight in September 1982 and his retirement from the Communist Party's ruling Politburo, where he had been a full member since 1962, became known a month later. After Kirilenko retired, Yuri Andropov and Konstantin Chernenko became leading candidates to succeed Brezhnev. Andropov was named Soviet leader upon Brezhnev's death on Nov. 10, 1982, and Chernenko succeeded Andropov when he died in 1984. Kirilenko, who had close ties to Brezhnev dating to the 1930s when both shared regional party duties in the Ukraine, served for seven years as party leader in the industrial city of Sverdlovsk. When Brezhnev succeeded Nikita S. Khrushchev, Kirilenko's stature also rose, and in 1966 he was named Central Committee secretary for internal political questions and party work, taking charge of day-to-day party activities. He also was given overall supervision of heavy industry, giving him important connections with the Soviet defense establishment. As Brezhnev's health worsened, Kirilenko stood in for him at important party functions. Although Kirilenko's sudden fall from power in 1982 officially was attributed to ill health, he appeared in public to show his respects when Brezhnev lay in state, standing far from other members of the Politburo. Reports circulated that his demise actually occurred because his son defected to the West. Tass did not mention any survivors, in keeping with the traditional Soviet practice of not reporting on the personal lives of officials. It said only that, ``The memory of Andrei Pavlovich Kirilenko will be held dear to those who knew him.''

DOC.HEAD: For Richer, Then Poorer: Wedded Couple Robbed At Gunpoint
DOC.TEXT: A couple who had just vowed to love each other for richer or for poorer were robbed at gunpoint of about $13,000 in cash and gifts, plus their car, just after they left their wedding reception, police said Monday. Still shaken from the robbery, Anthony and Diane Rohr, both 22, left for their honeymoon Sunday on a cruise ship in the Caribbean. ``I made sure they did,'' Antoinette Rohr, the groom's mother, said in a telephone interview Monday. ``Why should they suffer more?'' ``If they stay here, they'll think about it. By being away, maybe they can put it behind them,'' Mrs. Rohr added. The couple was still clad in their wedding finery when four ski-masked gunmen forced them and two relatives from the car as it was stopped for a red light early Sunday, police said. Their 1989 car was commandeered by the bandits, who also got away with cash and checks worth $13,000, as well as the bride's bouquet and the top of the wedding cake. The car was found abandoned later Sunday, police said. Police declined to say what, if anything, was left in the car. Authorities were questioning residents in the area where the car was found to see if any witnesses saw the bandits, said police Sgt. Joseph Piriano. He said detectives had some leads they were working on, but refused to give any details. The newlyweds were waiting at the red light when a car driven by the bandits pulled in front of them. Two of the bandits, carrying handguns, broke the driver's side window of the Rohrs' car, placed a gun to the driver's head and demanded money from the group, police said. Also in the car were Rohr's brother, Billy, and his wife, Maria, who is five months pregnant. ``They took the bride and threw her on the pavement,'' William Rohr Sr., the groom's father, told the Daily News. ``How could anyone do that on a wedding day?''

DOC.HEAD: Precede BONN
Kohl Hints at All-German Elections This Year
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout UPDATE with Kohl, de Maiziere meet in West Berlin, quotes, other. No pickup. CHANGES byline
DOC.TEXT: Chancellor Helmut Kohl, possibly aiming for joint German elections as early as December, met with East German Premier Lothar de Maiziere on Monday to discuss the pace of unifying the two countries. Kohl, staggered by state election losses Sunday, was concerned about his plan for speedy unification. He said in Bonn before flying Monday to West Berlin he was certain his conservative Christian Democratic Union party would have ``good chances'' in an all-German election. De Maiziere leads Kohl's sister party in East Germany. De Maiziere said after their 3{-hour meeting that he and Kohl discussed the coming introduction of the West German mark as the East German currency and the treaty that will link the two states on the way to unification. The draft of the unification treaty guarantees private ownership, competition and unfettered pricing practices. A copy of the treaty was obtained by The Associated Press. Kohl told reporters in West Berlin the unification process must proceed step by step. He said he and de Maiziere did not discuss a date for an all-German election, adding that such talks would come later. ``It was a talk between friends in a friendly atmosphere,'' Kohl said. In Bonn, Kohl said federal elections are still planned for Dec. 2 in West Germany, but hinted they could turn into elections for a united German government instead. As recently as April 28, Kohl told his European Economic Community colleagues in Dublin that joint elections were expected late next year, rather than this year. Kohl noted Monday that in East Germany ``there are discussions'' about having all-German elections this year. The chancellor had conceded a ``bitter defeat'' in Sunday's vote as he spoke to reporters in Bonn after a strategy session with other Christian Democratic leaders. The opposition Social Democrats won control of the upper house of Parliament, the Bundesrat, through election victories in the states of North Rhine-Westphalia and Lower Saxony. This could strengthen Social Democratic chances of defeating Kohl in December federal elections. The lower house, the Bundestag, is the actual law-making body. But Bundesrat approval is needed for legislation that has direct consequences for the finances of West Germany's 11 states. That could give Kohl weighty problems as he tries to push through his unification plans. The election setback came amid another jolt for Kohl _ failure of a team of experts from both Germanys to agree on key aspects of unification. The left-leaning Social Democrats have been trying to put the brakes on Kohl's push for rapid unification, which they say threatens the jobs and pocketbooks of Germans in both countries. East German Social Democrats said in a statement Monday that the election outcome means ``the influence of Social Democratic policies on the unity process has become distinctly greater because of the election outcome.'' ``The social fears of people in both parts of Germany may no longer be ignored.'' Expert delegations from both Germanys late Saturday completed the draft of a state treaty that is to serve as a basis for an economic, currency and social union of the countries by July 2. But West German government spokesman Dieter Vogel conceded a touchy issue _ whether to let West Germans buy up East German property _ was tabled. ``Negotiations will be continued this week on a political level,'' Vogel said Sunday. Failure to agree on how to transfer East Germany's state-owned property and industries to the private sector indicates de Maiziere is reluctant to allow West German interests to buy up East Germany's vast state-owned holdings. De Maiziere, like Kohl, favors a quick shift to a free market and fast unification. But he has been under pressure from East German Social Democrats, who are part of his governing coalition, to seek more social guarantees for East Germans and slow the talks.

DOC.HEAD: Four Killed in Attack on Dice Game; 3 Dead in Chicago, San Francisco
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 18th graf to CORRECT that five others treated at hospital sted four.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto FW1, FW2
DOC.TEXT: Masked men wearing camouflage clothes and ski masks burst in on a high-stakes dice game and opened fire Monday, killing four people and wounding three. It was a day for street violence and mourning in other cities as well: Gunmen with automatic weapons killed one man and wounded seven people on the edge of San Francisco's Chinatown, and Chicago police charged a man with killing two officers the night before. In Fort Worth, the gunfire erupted about 7 a.m. at the Glass Key Cafe, a bar in a poor neighborhood known to police as a gambling and drug hangout and the scene of a similar attack in October. Four men broke into the game, shouted ``task force,'' and began shooting, police said. Up to 15 people were inside. Some scrambled into a back room and others ran outside to escape the gunfire, said Police Chief Thomas Windham. ``It appears to have been a robbery of a gambling game,'' Windham said. ``We have information that it was an extremely high-dollar gambling game with tens of thousands of dollars involved.'' The chief didn't know if the gunmen got any money before escaping in a car. Two people were killed inside; two were pronounced dead at a hospital. The clothes and ``task force'' reference could have been intended to make the gamblers think they were being raided by police, said Police Capt. Randy Ely. He noted similar tactics were used in a March attack on another gambling spot in which one person was slain. Monday's attack also was similar to a shooting Oct. 2, when several men hid inside the Glass Key and opened fire on gamblers, Ely said. One man was killed. No arrests have been made and police are unwilling to say if the shootings are related. The Glass Key is home to illegal gambling, drug deals and violent crime, Windham said. The bar's owner, Albert Huey You, told reporters two men entered the lounge, robbed several patrons who were sitting around drinking coffee, and then began firing what he described as semiautomatic weapons. He said a shotgun pellet nicked his ear. In San Francisco, a group of people leaving a nightclub about 2 a.m. were attacked by at least one gunman spraying automatic weapons fire. Police said they were seeking three men in the attack outside the Purple Onion nightclub in the North Beach district, on the edge of Chinatown. All the victims had Asian surnames said authorities, who declined to speculate on the motive. A man about 35 years old was killed, and seven other people were wounded. The most seriously hurt was Margaret Lee, 26, who is three months pregnant. She was in serious to critical condition after undergoing surgery for a hip wound, said a spokeswoman for San Francisco General Hospital. Five others were treated for less serious gunshot wounds at the hospital and one was treated at the scene. The dead man's name was withheld. In Chicago, two veteran police officers, longtime friends and partners, were shot to death after being called to quell a Mother's Day argument between a man and his grandmother. Investigators said Officers Gregory Hauser, 43, and Raymond Kilroy, 47, called for backup officers. Authorities released few other details. The grandson, Roman Chavez, 23, was charged with two counts of murder and one count of armed robbery, the latter for allegedly taking one officer's gun. Investigators had yet to determine if that was the gun that fired the fatal shots. In the Fort Worth case, the dead were identified as Robert L. Satterwhite, 30, of Austin; James W. Lacey, 56; Joe D. Wafers, 54; and Timothy V. Carter, 45, all of Fort Worth. A 30-year-old man was in critical condition at John Peter Smith Hospital. A 20-year-old still was in fair condition at the hospital. A 17-year-old male left the hospital against medical advice with abrasions to his arm.

DOC.HEAD: Two Arrests in NYC Bias Attack; Bensonhurst Jury Still Out
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf to CORRECT arrested man's age to 18 sted 19, CORRECT charge to criminal mischief sted malicious mischief.
DOC.TEXT: Police on Monday arrested two members of a group of blacks who allegedly cracked the skull of a Vietnamese man during a confrontation punctuated by racial slurs. The crime was classified as a bias assault, but Police Commissioner Lee Brown stressed that it was not a premeditated attack, having grown out of a chance encounter. The fight also wasn't related to a black-led boycott of two nearby Korean-American grocery stores, Brown said. Sunday's attack exacerbated tensions in a city where race relations are under such strain that Mayor David Dinkins, the first black ever to hold the office, made a televised appeal Friday for an end to bigotry and hate. Also Monday, two juries continued deliberating in the Bensonhurst racial attack case. Two white youths are charged with murder in the death of a black teen-ager killed by a mob he encountered in the predominantly white Bensonhurst neighborhood. The grocery boycott began Jan. 18, after a black woman allegedly was roughed up by workers in one of the stores because she had refused to let them look in her purse. Though boycott organizers insist it isn't racially motivated, pickets outside the stores have shouted anti-Korean slurs. The two teen-agers arrested Monday live near the scene of black-Vietnamese melee in the Flatbush neighborhood of Brooklyn. Ulner Alsaint, 18, was charged with felonious assault and possession of a dangerous instrument, a claw hammer, Brown told reporters. A 13-year-old girl, whose name was withheld, was charged as a juvenile with criminal mischief. Alsaint is accused of hitting Tuan Ana Cao over the head, fracturing his skull. Cao was listed in guarded and stable condition at Kings County Hospital, where he was interviewed by detectives from the police bias squad. Brown said the incident began early Sunday, when about 10 black teen-agers leaving parties gathered in front of an apartment building. The 13-year-old girl threw a beer bottle, shattering a window in the ground-floor apartment. ``Six Vietnamese men were eating at a table close to the window,'' Brown said. ``Some of the Vietnamese men left the apartment to find out what happened and a dispute erupted.'' Each side accused the other of starting the trouble, and each accused the other of having at least one knife, though no knives were found. The blacks screamed ``Koreans get out of America!'' and other slurs against Koreans, Chinese and Japanese. Because of that, the crime was classified as bias-related. ``There's absolutely nothing to suggest that they went to that location because of Asians being in that apartment,'' Brown said. There also was no indication the teen-agers had taken part in the grocery boycott, he added. Alsaint, who told police he carried the hammer for self-defense, said he struck Cao while defending himself. In a goodwill gesture, a group of about 25 black high school students went shopping Monday at one of the stores under boycott, the Red Apple, led by history and economics teacher Fred McCray. McCray, who is black, said the students ``came to me and suggested we do something to change this.'' ``Why teach the children to hate one another?'' asked one student, 18-year-old Darrell McDuffie. In the Bensonhurst case, separate juries deliberated second-degree murder and other charges in the Aug. 23 death of Yusuf Hawkins, 16. The defendants, both 19, were Keith Mondello, accused of being the ringleader of a mob that attacked Hawkins and two friends with baseball bats and a pistol, and Joseph Fama, accused of firing the fatal shot.

DOC.HEAD: 12 Killed, 55 Wounded in Renewed Shelling in Beirut
DOC.TEXT: Rival Christian fighters traded gunfire as artillery barrages in east Beirut raged until nightfall Monday. Twelve people were killed and 55 wounded in the clashes, police said. The deaths raised to at least 954 dead and 2,677 wounded the toll since rebel army Gen. Michel Aoun moved against Samir Geagea's Lebanese Forces militia on Jan. 30 in a bid to seize control of the Christian enclave north of Beirut. Shells fell on east Beirut, the Christian sector of the capital, from nightfall Sunday to nightfall Monday, trapping tens of thousands of civilians in underground shelters for a sixth day. Patriarch Nasrallah Sfeir, spiritual head of the Maronite Catholic sect, to which both leaders and most of their fighters belong, issued a new cease-fire appeal. ``Stop this mad bombardment of the last 24 hours. Lay down your arms to force your commanders to go to the negotiating table,'' the patriarch said in the appeal broadcast by Christian radio stations. Sfeir's appeal had no immediate impact. The thunder of shell fire continued well after its broadcast. Beirut's independent An-Nahar daily reported Monday that efforts by Iraq to broker a truce between Aoun's troops and Geagea's militiamen have failed because ``the conflict has passed the point of no return.'' Iraq has supplied arms to both Christian factions, which oppose Syrian President Hafez Assad. Syria maitains some 40,000 troops in Lebanon under a 1976 Arab League peacekeeping mandate. Iraq is Syria's main Arab rival and has sought to thwart Syrian ambitions in Lebanon to take revenge for Assad's open support of Iran during the 1980-88 Persian Gulf war. Aoun's troops and Lebanese Forces militiamen fought with automatic weapons in alleyways of east Beirut's Badaro and Sin el-Fil districts. They also lobbed hand grenades at each other's fortifications in hit-and-run raids, police reported. But neither side gained any ground. The two sides have fought each other to a virtual stalemate since the clashes began. The Lebanese Forces remain in control of more than two-thirds of the Christian enclave. Police said Aoun's 155mm howitzers in the Metn mountains overlooking the capital pounded coastal positions held by the Lebanese Forces in and around the port cities of Jounieh and Byblos. Geagea's militiamen responded with barrages of rockets fired from mobile 40-barreled launchers. Clouds of smoke from burning buildings shrouded the already devastated neighborhoods along the Mediterranean coastline and the hills around the shell-battered presidential palace in Baabda, where Aoun has his headquarters. Communiques from Aoun's command said four Lebanese Forces tanks were destroyed in Kesrouan province, northeast of Beirut. The Lebanese Forces claimed in a communique that its militiamen infiltrated into Aoun's territory south of Kesrouan and ambushed a convoy of Aoun's crack 8th brigade, ``killing all its occupants.'' The communique gave no details.

DOC.HEAD: Salvadoran Courts Clear Most Defendants in Two Key Cases
DOC.TEXT: Judges in two notorious human rights cases have absolved all but three of 17 defendants, most of them military men. Only two of those still facing charges Monday _ one in each case _ are in custody and subject to trial. A third is at large. The cases involve the 1988 massacre of 10 peasants and the kidnap-for-profit of several businessmen. While attention has been focused on the six Jesuit priests slain by soldiers last November, developments in these two cases have gone virtually unreported. Each, however, at one time was considered a crucial test of a judiciary supposedly reformed to foster respect for human rights in a society chararacterized by widespread violation of such rights. The main motive for Vice President Dan Quayle's visit to El Salvador in February 1989 was to impress on the goverment and military Washington's expectations regarding prosecution of the case known as the San Francisco massacre. On Sept. 21, 1988, soldiers of the Jiboa Battalion rounded up suspected collaborators of leftist guerrillas in the hamlet of San Francisco, 25 miles east of San Salvador. According to extensive testimony from soldiers, a detail blindfolded seven men and three women, tied their hands behind their backs and marched them off. About a mile down the trail, the soldiers halted their prisoners and bunched them together. Witnesses said Sgt. Rafael Villalobos detonated a mine he had placed next to the campesinos, then joined other soldiers in spraying the dead and wounded with assault rifle fire. The army first reported the 10 deaths as guerrillas killed in combat. Then it said the peasants were killed by guerrillas in an ambush of the army column escorting them. But a week after Quayle's visit, the military _ faced with a mountain of evidence _ said Maj. Mauricio Beltran was responsible. After 20 months of compiling evidence and taking testimony, Judge Alcides Guandique dropped charges against seven defendants but ruled Beltran and Villalobos had to stand trial for murder. An appeals court absolved Villalobos on the ground he limited himself to carrying out Beltran's order. The higher court also noted what it called technical errors in reporting investigation results. Beltran's trial by jury is not expected for at least two months. According to U.S. officials closely following the case, his conviction is far from assured. Those same officials reacted with disgust to the appeals court ruling, but would not be quoted for the record. Late last month, authorities dismissed charges against six of eight men charged with participation in a ring that kidnapped at least five wealthy businessmen between March 1982 and February 1986. An army major and three lieutenants were among the eight men indicted. Those four and the four civilians charged were friends or associates of cashiered army Maj. Roberto D'Aubuisson. Only three of the eight defendants were captured, and one of them escaped last year. Along with D'Aubuisson, founder of the governing ARENA party, the defendants were linked to rightist death squads that killed thousands of suspected leftists in the early 1980s. D'Aubuisson has denied such involvement. Judge Jorge Serrano, who was handling the case and who reportedly turned down offers of bribes to dismiss charges, was killed by a death squad on May 11, 1988. San Salvador's 3rd Criminal Court cited lack of evidence in dismissing charges last month against six defendants, including three current or former army officers. The court ordered a trial for former army Lt. Isidro Lopez Sibrian, who is in jail, and businessman Orlando Llovera Ballete, who escaped. The National Association of Private Enterprise, to which several kidnap victims belonged, reacted angrily to dismissal of charges. ``The decision demonstrates a lack of responsibility of some judges who allow themselves to be influenced by those who wield pressure of individuals or of groups,'' said the association, and asked the Supreme Court to investigate. The court, in full-page newspaper ads, responded that the judiciary was independent and that the association should mind its own business.

DOC.HEAD: Former Bulgaria Leader Won't be Tried Before June Elections
DOC.TEXT: Former Bulgarian leader Todor Zhivkov will not be tried for abuse of power until after June's national elections, the first free balloting in more than 40 years, the chief prosecutor said Monday. Zhivkov, 78, was ousted as president and Communist Party leader in November after 35 years of autocratic rule. Bulgaria's Communist Party, like most other communist parties in eastern Europe, has begun to call for democratic reforms and has targeted its previous leaders as responsible for many of the failures of the past. Zhikov has been charged with misappropriation of state property, inciting ethnic hostility _ ethnic Turks were the target of a violent assimilation campaign under Zhivkov _ and abuse of power. Misuse of state property, the most serious charge, carries a maximum penalty of 30 years in prison. Investigations against Zhivkov are scheduled to conclude by May 18. Chief Prosecutor Evtim Stoimenov said it would be impossible to begin a trial against the former leader until after the two-stage national elections, scheduled for June 10 and June 17. Zhikov is in detention.

DOC.HEAD: Commission Rejects Complaint Alleging Illegal Donations
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Election Commission, voting along partisan lines, has rejected allegations that a political action committee for foreign car dealers made illegal contributions to two Republican Senate campaigns in 1988. The commission did allege a lesser violation against one of those campaigns, that of Florida GOP Sen. Connie Mack, saying it failed to disclose information about its donors in the final days of the campaign. The Mack campaign agreed to settle the case by paying a $3,500 fine, according to commission records released Monday. The agency's decisions on the major allegations were made in a closed meeting six months ago. But they were not made public until Monday because of the confidential negotiations with the Mack campaign on the lesser allegation. The case involved the Auto Dealers and Drivers for Free Trade PAC, which spent more than $3 million to influence 1988 congressional elections, relying heavily on so-called independent expenditure campaigns. The commission's general counsel had urged the commission to open an enforcement action by accusing the Auto Dealers PAC and the Mack campaign of violating election laws. That recommendation alleged a $326,000 advertising campaign by the PAC supporting Mack did not meet the standards for independent expenditures and therefore was an illegal contribution to Mack. But the six-member commission's three Republican appointees refused to accept the recommendation; four votes are needed for the panel to begin an enforcement action. Two Democrats voted to accept the recommendation; one was absent. In the case of the second campaign, the unsuccessful 1988 re-election bid of Nevada Sen. Chic Hecht, the commission voted 5-0 to accept the general counsel's recommendation to dismiss the allegations made by the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee. That group's election-eve complaint alleged the spending by the Auto Dealers PAC on behalf of Mack was illegal because there was coordination between the PAC and the campaign. Mack was in a close race with Democratic Rep. Buddy McKay, and the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee unsucessfully sought a pre-election ruling from the commission ordering the PAC's Florida spots off the air. Mack ultimately won by just 35,000 votes of more than 4 million cast. PACs and other groups are allowed to pay for ads and other materials supporting or opposing candidates, but such efforts qualify as independent expenditures only if there is no contact or coordination with the campaigns. If there is coordination, the ads would be considered contributions and subject to limits. The dealers' PAC already had donated the maximum amounts to Mack and Hecht before launching the advertising campaigns. In its complaint, the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee said that the PAC and Mack campaigns both had hired the same advertising firm, Multi-Media, and a Texas-based political consultant, Karl Rove. And it said the Auto Dealers PAC's $521,000 effort to support Hecht used ads virtually identical to official Hecht ads, suggesting collaboration. In response, the dealers PAC said it retained Multi-Media and Rove for 1988 campaign activities but hired a separate firm for the Florida ads. Still, the FEC general counsel said the PAC failed to prove there was no coordination and recommeded the commission open an enforcement case. The commission's reasons for rejecting the recommendation were unclear. The panel traditionally includes in the public record a statement explaining its vote but has yet to do so. In recommending dismissal of the portions of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee dealing with Hecht, the FEC's general counsel said the PAC's ads were similar to official campaign ads but ``not of a likeness which would indicate cooperation or coordination.''

DOC.HEAD: Quake Measuring 5.2 Shakes Central Chile; No Casualties Reported
DOC.TEXT: An earthquake shook a 450-mile section of central and southern Chile on Monday afternoon but no casualties or major damage was reported, authorities said. The Seismological Institute of the University of Chile said a quake measuring 5.2 on the Richter scale struck at 5.34 p.m. EDT and was centered 80 miles south of Santiago. Preliminary radio and police reports indicate the quake caused only minor damage at some old adobe houses in the rural zone south of the capital. The Richter scale is a gauge of the energy released by an earthquake as measured by the ground motion recorded on a seismograph. A quake measuring 5 on the scale is capable of causing considerable damage.

DOC.HEAD: Researchers Plans Test Of Vaccine To Protect Unborn From AIDS Virus
DOC.TEXT: A synthetic version of an AIDS virus fragment may be tested later this year to determine if it can protect unborn babies from developing AIDS, a New York researcher announced Monday. Dr. Arye Rubinstein, professor at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine in New York, said studies in his lab have shown that mothers infected with human immunodefiency virus (HIV), which causes AIDS, will not pass the disease to their unborn if their immune system develops a particular type of antibody. Rubinstein said the body's immune system makes this antibody in response to a specific protein found in the gp120 molecule, which is part of the surface of the HIV virus. That specific protein is called the principle neutralizing domain, or PND. In a paper published in the May issue of the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, Rubinstein said his laboratory was able to correctly identify infants who would become HIV-infected by assessing the level of this PND antibody in their blood of their mothers. Rubinstein said that blood samples from 15 women, all at high risk for HIV infection, were analyzed for the presence of the PND antibody. Later, babies born to these women were given blood tests at regular intervals for a year. All of the mothers tested positive for the HIV virus, but only 11 of the 15 babies born to these women developed the disease. And each of the four babies that remained disease-free was born to a mother whose prenatal blood tests showed a high level of the PND antibody. ``This study provides ... evidence that protective antibodies might prevent infection by HIV in the developing fetus,'' Rubinstein reports in the paper. In a talk Monday at the Town Forum on AIDS sponsored by the Institute for Advanced Studies in Immunology and Aging, Rubinstein said his group plans to conduct trials later this year of a vaccine that uses a synthetic version of the PND protein. Rubinstein said his group would use the synthetic PND protein in a vaccination of pregnant women who test positive for HIV. It is hoped, he said, that the protein would stimulate the women's immune systems to produce the antibodies. ``This approach could provide immunity to fetuses of women who are infected with the HIV virus,'' said Rubinstein. The study will be conducted in a clinic in South Bronx, but no date has been set for the vaccine trial to begin.

DOC.HEAD: Customs Seize 37 Tons of Equipment Destined for Iraq
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 9 grafs with Aziz's ``big lie'' remark, Iraq theatens to sue confiscating countries, journalist hanged as spy had asked Iraqi permission before going to site.
DOC.TEXT: Customs authorities at Frankfurt Airport confiscated 37 tons of machinery suspected of being parts for a ``super cannon'' destined for Iraq, West German television reported Monday. The brief report on the ARD television network said 17 cases containing various equipment were seized by customs officials. The shipment originated in Belgium and arrived in Frankfurt via Switzerland. The cases were slated to be picked up by Iraqi Airways in Frankfurt, ARD said. The report said authrities suspect the seized equipment could be parts for Iraq's so-called ``super cannon.'' According to the report, the machinery was declared as oil industry equipment. The ARD report Monday night gave no other details. Spokesmen for the Frankfurt Prosecutor's office could not be reached late Monday to comment on the report. Border police and customs officials at Frankfurt Airport declined to comment. Authorities in Britain, Italy and other European countries have made similiar seizures of Iraqi-bound equipment in recent weeks. Italian investigators are probing whether steel parts seized in Italy could be parts of the ``super cannon'' that is allegedly capable of firing nuclear or chemical warheads into Israel and Iran. After meeting with Italian officials, Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz on Monday said the steel parts were needed for petrochemical projects. Authorities last week announced the seizure of nearly 100 tons of steel tubing and other parts about to be shipped out of Italy to Jordan to be transported overland from there, presumably to an assembly point near Baghdad. The Italian Foreign Ministry said only that Italian Foreign Minister Gianni De Michelis met with his Iraqi counterpart Aziz but did not say what they discussed. Aziz was in Rome to meet with U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar. Nearly all the seized components came from a foundry in the Umbrian city of Terni that is part of ILVA SpA, a state-owned company that is the world's fifth-largest steelmaker. Police officials on Saturday said it appeared the Terni foundry was making pieces that would make up the rear end of a giant artillery gun. They theorized that the section was to have been assembled in Iraq and joined to the front end, alleged pieces of which were seized in Britain several weeks ago. On Monday, prosecutors in Terni said an Italian is being questioned on suspicion of illegal arms trafficking in the case. They said interrogation of foundry technicians and managers was continuing. Aziz on Monday called reports about an Iraqi super gun ``a big lie, which originated from London.'' Iraq said Monday it would take legal action against Britain, Italy, Turkey, Greece and any other countries that take ``illegal'' measures to stop imports of equipment purchased by Iraq. The official Iraqi News Agency, monitored in Cyprus, quoted an unidentified Industry Ministry spokesman as saying the parts were purchased from European companies, and paid for. Also on Monday, British Broadcasting Corp. television reported in London that an Iraqi government official has acknowledged that executed journalist Farzad Bazoft informed Iraqi authorities of his plans to visit a weapons plant.
