The London-based journalist for the Observer weekly newspaper was arrested in September while investigating reports of a major explosion at the Al-Iskandaria military complex south of Baghdad. Bazoft confessed to spying on Iraqi TV, but retracted the confession at his trial. He was hanged March 15. The BBC quoted an unidentified Iraqi minister as saying Bazoft applied for official permission to visit the complex. The BBC said it was the first such Iraqi acknowledgment. Bazoft was a stateless Iranian who traveled on British papers.

DOC.HEAD: Government Declares Strikes Illegal, Threatens Mass Firings
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with Sandanistas threating to widen strike. Pickup 4th pvs, `Rosales, in...' Edits to trim
DOC.TEXT: The government on Monday decreed strikes by public workers illegal, urged an immediate return to work and threatened to fire anyone who does not comply. Unemployed Nicaraguans said they would be glad to take the jobs of the striking public workers. Labor Minister Francisco Rosales accused the recently ousted Sandinistas of fomenting the strikes to hobble the 19-day-old government of President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, and gave workers until Tuesday to return to work. Sandinista labor leaders said they would widen the strikes on Tuesday, shutting down telephone service, public transportation, schools and banks if the government did not back off from its threats. ``There will be an escalation of the strikes, and we hope we don't have to paralyze the country, because we have the capacity to do it,'' Lucio Jimenez of the Sandinista Workers Central told reporters. He also said an attorney was petitioning the Supreme Court asking that the Labor Ministry decree declaring the strikes illegal be revoked. ``We're still not calling a general strike; we're giving dialogue and negotiation an opportunity,'' Jimenez said. But he added: ``As long as there is no solution, we can't disarm. The strike is our weapon.'' Rosales, in a news conference broadcast live on national TV, said the government made the decision after efforts to negotiate an end to the strike failed. He said negotiations in progress since last Friday had been blocked several times by ``hotheads.'' ``It's a matter of them (Sandinistas) trying to torpedo the negotiations,'' he said, adding: ``It is very clear to us that this is a political problem, not a labor one.'' ``Now the way out of this problem is in the hands of the Sandinista Workers Central and the National Union of Employees,'' Rosales said. Presidential spokesman Danilo Lacayo said about 10,000 public workers out of 150,000 nationwide were on strike. Workers are demanding either a 200 percent raise or a minimum monthly salary equivalent to $150. They also want a law guaranteeing their rights reinstated, and guarantees that there will be no retaliation against the strikers. Nicaragua's currency, the cordoba, has been devalued four times in less than a month and retail prices have soared. The workers earlier rejected a government offer of an across-the-board 60 percent pay raise. Airport workers have also threatened to join the strike. Since Thursday, airport employees have been on a partial strike, handling only passenger flights. All other duties _ diplomatic pouches, air freight, mail and customs _ have been put on hold. A complete strike could close Managua's international airport. On Monday morning, workers at the Finance Ministry were holed up inside the building and about 200 people waited outside to pay their taxes or start work. Some people in the crowd shouted to the strikers: ``Bums! Go back to work!'' Six anti-riot police vehicles, including one with a tear-gas grenade launcher, arrived and an officer with a loudspeaker told the crowd to disperse. Judicial workers also were on strike Monday. With Nicaragua's high unemployment, it is unlikely the strikers could shut down the system. Estimates of the unemployment rate run as high as 45 percent. ``If they don't want to work, we want to work. Why don't they give us those jobs?'' said Alba Yeni Mendoza, an unemployed typist with two children whose husband is in jail. Mrs. Mendoza was in a group of about 25 women standing in front of the presidential building, demanding to speak with Mrs. Chamorro about their imprisoned relatives. Mrs. Chamorro decreed an amnesty when she took office April 25. Carlos Lopez, president of the Regional Committee of the Unemployed, said his group had 3,000 members and ``we're willing to fill those jobs.'' He also attributed the strikes to the Sandinista Front which Mrs. Chamorro's 14-party coalition defeated in the Feb. 25 elections.

DOC.HEAD: Ambassador Says Free Trade Agreement Can Be Reached With Mexico
DOC.TEXT: A free trade agreement with Mexico could take less time to negotiate than the one with Canada, the Mexican ambassador said Monday. ``We can go faster. I think the key issues are going to be fewer,'' Gustavo Petricioli, Mexico's ambassador to the United States, told the Border Trade Alliance. ``If we can agree on the fundamentals, the basis of our positions on both sides, we can move very, very fast.'' Members of the alliance, a loose-knit group of business leaders and government officials from Texas, New Mexico, Arizona and California, said Petricioli's message was another sign Mexico is serious about doing away with trade barriers. ``It's happening. You can see the countries cooperating,'' said Gene Gibbs, chairman of a Brownsville, Texas, bank. The two countries are informally negotiating free trade, Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher has said. ``It's not going to be like some member of Congress makes a speech `We're going to have free trade manana.' That's not going to happen,'' said Rep. Kika de la Garza, D-Texas. Some trace the beginning of the U.S.-Canadian agreement, which took effect last year, to a 1965 agreement largely freeing trade in automobiles and their components between the two countries. Others say the two countries worked on free trade for about 10 years. Serious negotiating did not begin until after Prime Minister Brian Mulroney made an agreement a major policy goal in 1986. Mexico and the United States have not made a similar commitment to negotiate an agreement. Despite greater cultural differences, Petricioli said a free trade agreement between the United States and Mexico could be achieved much more quickly because the Canadian agreement would provide a model. But he said, ``We are looking for a good deal for Mexico, not any deal.''

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf: ``Dubcek was,'' with three grafs on Quayle meeting bgng: ``Lithuania and,''
DOC.TEXT: Alexander Dubcek on Monday rejected the idea that he might have averted the 1968 Soviet-led invasion of Czechoslovakia with more caution or adroitness in pursuing ``Prague Spring'' reforms. ``The short answer is that I wouldn't have done it differently ... it would have been against the needs of our people,'' Dubcek, Czechoslovak Communist Party chief at the time of the invasion, told a news conference at the U.S. Capitol. ``I must say I am very pleased that I have kept my principles because if I hadn't, I would be in the shoes of other people who just can't face their people any more,'' he added, referring to ousted leaders in Poland and Hungary. Dubcek was restored in Prague's peaceful revolution last winter as federal assembly president after living for two decades in political disgrace and isolation. He said his efforts a generation earlier to create ``socialism with a human face'' were indispensable. The proof, he said, is that today ``I can face the people in the public squares'' _ unlike now-discredited orthodox communists in other Eastern European countries. Commenting on the new democratic government's probes of the past two decades of hardline rule, he said he is against ``collective guilt,'' meaning communists should be judged by specific actions, not party membership. He said he did not know the details of recent Prague demonstrations calling for ex-leaders to be punished, and noted that measures are being taken to recover wrongly-diverted stolen public assets. While efforts are being made to identify those former comrades who signed the letter inviting Warsaw Pact armies to intervene in Czechoslovakia, Dubcek said, ``it doesn't really matter how many signatures there were. Nothing can justify the invasion, which was the doing of the respective countries ... a decision of the governments of the participating countries.'' Czechoslovakia was invaded by units from Poland, Hungary, East Germany and Bulgaria in addition to the Soviet Union. Lithuania and the other Baltic republics seeking independence from Soviet rule need should engage Moscow in prolonged negotiations and take pains to avoid provoking the Soviet military, Dubcek told Vice President Dan Quayle, according to Quayle's spokesman. The meeting with Quayle concluded Dubcek's first trip to North America for talks with U.S. and Canadian government, legislative and business leaders. The Czechosovak official was flying home aboard a government plane during the night, aides said. Vice Presidential spokesman David Beckwith described as ``a good meeting'' the Quayle-Dubcek talk of more than 30 minutes. Citing long delay for Congressional approval of urgent U.S. aid for Nicaragua and Panama, the vice president asked Czechoslovakia to be patient for clearing of final Congressional action to allow its goods to gain U.S. tariff concessions on its goods known as ``most favored nation'' treatment, the spokesman said. At the time of the Prague Spring, Dubcek said, Czechoslovakia's traditions of democracy and scientific and industrial skills made it ripe for changes even though ``we attempted something not possible for us to reach at that time.'' Dubcek, a backer of Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev's reform movement, appealed for understanding of ``Gorbachev's difficult legacy'' of economic, domestic and foreign relations problems. ``It is necessary to alter views about the Soviet Union and not be against everything there,'' he said. The Soviet Union ``needs help in many fields, diplomatic, economic and political first of all,'' Dubcek added. Czechoslovak and Soviet conditions are very different, he said, but the two countries today share aims of democratization, decentralizing their economies and easing divisions between the people and the state.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Says Iran Replied to Iraqi Letter on Peace Talks
With AM-Germany-Iraq
DOC.TEXT: Iran has given an encouraging reply to Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's letter about stalled peace efforts, Iraq's foreign minister, Tariq Aziz, indicated Monday. Aziz said he discussed the status of peace talks during a 90-minute meeting Monday evening with U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar, who has proposed holding direct talks between the two nations. Perez de Cuellar and Aziz came to Rome for the meeting. Aziz announced last week that Hussein sent a letter to Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani, but said only it was a letter of peace. Observers said Saddam proposed new negotiations over the status of the Shatt-al-Arab waterway, the dispute over which led to the 8-year-long Iran-Iraq war. A U.N.-sponsored cease-fire halted the war in 1988, but peace talks faltered over sovereignty over the waterway and Iran's demand for a withdrawal of Iraqi troops still on Iranian territory. Aziz did not say if Rafsanjani himself replied to Hussein's letter.

DOC.HEAD: Mohawk Charged With Murder in Reservation Violence
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to UPDATE with innocent plea.
DOC.TEXT: SALABERRY-DE-VALLEYFIELD, Quebec (AP) _ An opponent of gambling on the St. Regis Indian Reservation was charged with second-degree murder Monday in the death of a fellow Mohawk, two weeks after gun battles triggered a police intervention. Doug George, 35, pleaded innocent to the charge in Quebec Provincial Court and was returned to custody. George, one of five Mohawks arrested in the May 1 killing of 31-year-old Harold ``Junior'' Edwards, surrendered to Quebec Provincial Police on Sunday night. His brother, David George, 42, pleaded innocent to dangerous use of a firearm and was released on his own recognizance. Authorities have yet to file charges against the other three Mohawks arrested Sunday, Roger Mitchell, Steve Lazore and Ken Lazore, all from the anti-gambling faction. Their attorney, Philip Schneider, noted that in Quebec, people must be arraigned in court within 24 hours of their arrest. ``The fact that there is no sworn information after 36 hours in detention against these three people to me is an indication they don`t have a strong case against them,'' Schneider said. The strife-torn reservation straddles the U.S.-Canadian border, reaching into Quebec and New York state. The Mohawks are bitterly divided over whether to allow gambling on the reservation. Casinos provide jobs and income, but attract outside influences. Members of the pro-gambling Warriors Society, a self-appointed reservation security force, said Edwards was neutral on the gambling issue. He was working in a yard near the scene of a gunbattle between the Warriors and the anti-gambling faction, according to those who found his body. Police estimate 5,000 rounds were fired in the fight. The bitter divisions that have ripped the reservation since casinos first mushroomed on a strip of a New York state highway in late 1988 were reflected at the packed courthouse. Mohawks on both sides of the issue avoided speaking to each other. Four of the five suspects were arrested early Sunday. They were taken from their homes in the Quebec section of the reservation and brought to provincial police headquarters in Montreal, police spokesman Robert Poeti said. Poeti said an investigation also continued into the shooting of Matthew Pyke, 22, who was killed the same day in the same section of the reservation in Snye, Quebec. Pyke was opposed to gambling. Since the slayings, Canadian and New York state police have sealed off the reservation with numerous roadblocks, keeping non-residents out and effectively closing down the casinos, along with many of the other businesses on Mohawk land. The reservation has been peaceful since the police moved in, with the exception of a drug raid last week by Canadian officials, who arrested 21 people and seized marijuana and cocaine worth $800,000 in U.S. currency.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Tanker Leaks Oil off Sweden after Collision
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with amount spilled, coast not threatened, CORRECTS ship's name to Volgoneft 263, not Volgonest. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: A Soviet tanker leaked about 1,000 tons of crude oil off southeast Sweden after colliding with a West German freighter in the fog early Monday in the Baltic Sea, the Swedish coast guard said. It said no one was hurt in the collision about 70 miles southeast of Karlskrona between the tanker Volgoneft 263, carrying 4,500 tons (31,500 barrels) of crude, and the freighter Betty, loaded with potatoes. The tanker carried a crew of 21 and the freighter a crew of five. Neither ship was in danger of sinking, and the German vessel made port with a hole in its bow, escorted by a coast guard vessel, officials reported. The Soviet ship remained at sea and transferred the rest of its cargo to a sister ship. Clean-up operations were under way. Six coast guard vessels, including three specially equipped for such operations, were attacking the slick, which did not immediately threaten the coastline. The Swedish national news agency TT said the Volgoneft 263 was hit midship by the freighter.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Bid for Observer Status Expected to be Approved
DOC.TEXT: Members of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade are expected to approve the Soviet Union's application for observer status with the international trade forum, trade sources said Monday. The sources, who declined to be further identified, said GATT's council on Wednesday was likely to agree to Moscow's request to become an observer at the market-oriented trade body. Such a decision would take immediate effect, enabling Soviet representatives to attend the 96-nation council, GATT's top decision-making body that deliberates on trade disputes and other mainstream issues affecting global commerce. First-hand knowledge of changes in the world trading system are regarded as important to back up the Soviet economic and trade reforms being championed by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Even if the application for observer status is approved this week, the Soviet Union would not be privy to the so-called Uruguay Round of talks, intended to draw up comprehensive new agreements to liberalize trade in areas such as agriculture and textiles. Nor would the Soviet Union automatically qualify for multilateral trading benefits enjoyed by many of GATT's full members. About 30 countries are currently classed as observers, including China, which is seeking full membership. President Bush last December dropped Washington's long-standing opposition to a Soviet presence in GATT. But the United States argued that Moscow should wait until the end of the Uruguay Round in December before being admitted. GATT's council in April deferred decision pending further informal consultations. The Geneva-based forum acts as a rule-book for international trade and sponsors trade-liberalizing accords. Its members account for more than four-fifths of world trade.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper: FBI has Dozen Suspects in $200 Million Art Theft
DOC.TEXT: The FBI has identified about a dozen suspects in the $200 million theft of artworks by Rembrandt, Vermeer and others from the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum, a newspaper reported Monday. The suspects are in various countries and federal agents are closely watching their movements, The Boston Globe reported, quoting unidentified sources. One suspect in the March 18 heist was spotted recently at Boston's Logan International Airport, the paper said. The FBI didn't respond Monday to a request for confirmation. Some suspects reportedly were named by informants; others are individuals who have used methods similar to those of the two men who disguised themselves as police to fool museum guards. They took two paintings and an etching by Rembrandt, three prints and two charcoals by Edgar Degas, one painting each by Edouard Manet, Jan Vermeer and Govaert Flinck, and a bronze dating to the Chinese Shang Dynasty, 1,200-1,100 B.C. The thieves got into the museum about 1:15 a.m. by telling a guard they were investigating a disturbance. They lured one guard away from alarms by asking for his identification after saying there might be a warrant for his arrest. The thieves bound and gagged the two guards and partly disabled the museum's security system. Investigators said the theft may have been done under contract because the thieves left behind works more valuable than some they stole. The FBI said agents in several U.S. cities and foreign capitals have been checking hundreds of leads, the paper said. A $1 million reward offered by two art auction houses has encouraged tips.

DOC.HEAD: Threat of Flooded Farm May Have Triggered Murder-Suicide
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf, `That threat...,' with 3 grafs to update with tornado. Pick up 7th graf pvs, `The threat...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto XGR1, LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: The steadily rising Red River forced more Louisiana families to evacuate Monday and may have contributed to a murder-suicide by a farmer. Evacuations also continued along Texas' Trinity River, where 7,000 were urged to head for high ground. The Red River had started to recede in parts of Arkansas, but 100 National Guardsmen, reinforced by two helicopters hauling sandbags, labored to prevent the collapse of a levee guarding the town of Garland. Since April 15, 13 deaths have been blamed on flooding: 12 in Texas and one in Oklahoma. Damage to Texas agriculture alone has been estimated at between $500 million and $700 million during the past two weeks, since heavy rain fell in Oklahoma and northern Texas, in the watersheds of the Trinity and Red rivers. The Red River is expected to flood 600 square miles of Louisiana, including 200 square miles of cropland, said Maj. Jack Scherer of the Army Corps of Engineers. A tornado brought more misery Monday night, injuring three people and destroying several homes near the west Texas city of Abilene. Several buildings in the communities of Radium and Tuxedo were destroyed, said Tracy Daniel of the Jones County Sheriff's Department, who was unable to provide further details. Three people injured by the storm were treated at Hamlin Memorial Hospital but only one was hurt badly enough to be hospitalized, officials said. The flooding may have led a farmer in northwestern Louisiana to kill his wife and himself, a neighbor said. DeSoto Parish farmer James McMullen, 58, shot his 58-year-old wife, Billie, and then himself Sunday, said sheriff's Capt. Marvin Melton. The threat of losing all of his crops may have been too much for McMullen, said neighbor and close friend Tommy Dugan. McMullen's 300 to 400 acres of wheat and 800 to 900 acres in cotton were threatened by flooding. ``I don't think it's flooded yet, but they must of been depressed about something,'' Melton said. The couple left a note but it did little more than detail funeral arrangements, he said. An estimated 250 families have or may have to flee their Shreveport and Bossier City homes as the Red River was expected to rise to its highest level in 45 years. In Texas, operators of the Lake Livingston Dam on the Trinity River increased the release of water from the dam to make way for the river's approaching flood crest, augmented by heavy rain Saturday upstream at Crockett. The flood gates were opened wider Monday to let water roar through at a rate of about 71,500 cubic feet per second and the dam's record of 75,000 cfs, set in 1973, likely would be topped by Tuesday, officials said. Normal flow is 20,000 cfs and anything over that causes flooding. ``This is the largest slug of water we've ever seen come down the Trinity River to Lake Livingston. We're going to have to make the largest releases we've ever made,'' said John Jadrosich, spokesman for the Trinity River Authority. The river's crest, which started in the Dallas area, is expected to reach Lake Livingston in a week, and the dam then may have to release up to 100,000 cubic feet per second, he said. Below the dam, an estimated 7,000 people were urged to evacuate. ``What's scary is what we know is coming,'' said Alanna Shaver, whose family left their Hardin home in favor of a trailer next to a Red Cross shelter where 50 people had already taken refuge. Texas Agriculture Commissioner Jim Hightower said flooded regions combine to produce 33 percent of the state's wheat crop, 66 percent of the oats and 49 percent of the hay. Hightower said damage also includes: _In Houston County, 50,000 acres, including 20,000 acres of crop land, are under water. _The majority of the $1.3 million wheat crop in Henderson and Anderson counties has been destroyed. _The Texas prison system, largest single farm operator in the mid-Trinity River basin, expects to lose $500,000 from flooding of corn, cotton, grain sorghum and other crops. They expect 27,000 acres of crop and pasture land to be under water and 5,000 head of cattle to be evacuated. In southwestern Arkansas, about 100 National Guardsmen sandbagged both sides of the levee at Garland, working to patch leaks boiling up underneath the dam, said Gary Talley of the state Office of Emergency Services. ``Garland is in a serious situation and will remain so for the next several days,'' he said. If the levee breaks, 250 to 300 houses would be affected in the town of 660, he said. Although the river crested Sunday, he said, ``it's going to be the end of the week before we're really out danger down there ... and that's provided we get no more really heavy rain.'' Almost 1,000 people have been evacuated in Arkansas, Talley said. His agency estimates damage to roads and other public property will be at least $10 million. Damage to private property can't be assessed until the water recedes. The agency also estimates 300,000 to 450,000 acres of farmland has been damaged. Flooding was mostly over in Oklahoma, except for spots like Lake Texoma, on the Texas-Oklahoma border, which rose to about 27 feet above normal; the Army Corps of Engineers says it may be five to six weeks before it is near normal again. Oklahoma Gov. Henry Bellmon requested federal disaster aid Friday for 36 of the state's 77 counties, saying more than $5 million in flood damage was reported to state roads and highways. The Red Cross estimated 380 Oklahoma families were affected by the floods.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev to Visit Minnesota, California After Summit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf: ``We have,'' with three grafs bgng: ``Gov. Rudy,'' quotes from Minnesota governor confirming White House call
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Arms Summit Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev may visit California and Minnesota after concluding summit talks with President Bush early next month at the White House and at Camp David, U.S. officials said Monday. Gorbachev wants to meet with businessmen in both states and perhaps speak at Stanford University near Palo Alto, Calif., officials said. An affiliate of Stanford is the Hoover Institution on War, Revolution and Peace, which has the world's largest collection of material on the 1917 Communist Revolution in Russia and houses noted scholars of the Soviet Union. ``They expressed a desire to travel beyond Washington,'' one official said. ``Nothing has been finalized so this is just a tentative indication of his plans.'' The news caught officials in both states by surprise. ``There's no truth to it as far was we can tell,'' said Mary Ann Seawell, a Stanford spokeswoman who said she checked with the university president's office. Gorbachev and his wife Raisa have a longstanding invitation to see former President Ronald Reagan and his wife Nancy in Los Angeles. However, Reagan spokesman Mark Weinberg said he was unaware of any plans for a get-together. Officials said the Minnesota stop would be in Minneapolis but it was not clear what Gorbachev would do there. Gov. Rudy Perpich of Minnesota said the White House told him to expect a decision on a Minnesota visit by Gorbachev in the next week, possibly in the next 48 hours. ``I think it's bigger than the Super Bowl,'' which Minnesota's Vikings entry of the National Football League will host in 1992, said Perpich. But the governor said he had no idea what the Soviet leader might want to see. When Perpich was asked where he would most like to take the visitor, the governor replied, ``Hibbing, to visit my father and mother.'' Gorbachev is to arrive in Washington on May 30 for his second summit with Bush, following their meeting on the island of Malta last December. White House statements have indicated the talks would conclude by June 3. Commenting on Gorbachev's travel plans, a U.S. official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said, ``He has always said he wants to see more of America.'' Another official said, ``After the summit where Gorbachev goes is purely up to the Soviets.'' A Soviet advance team returned to Moscow late last week after working with White House planners on an itinerary and sites for the summit. The summit schedule was to have been announced Monday, but was delayed for at least 24 hours as the White House tried to pin down Gorbachev's post-summit travel plans. White House officials believe that Gorbachev will arrive at Andrews Air Force Base outside Washington on Wednesday evening, May 30. A formal welcoming ceremony is planned the next day at the White House, along with a State Dinner that night. During the day, Bush and Gorbachev are to hold talks at the White House. June 1, the second day of their meeting, has been reserved for signing any agreements that result from the meeting. Gorbachev also is expected to give a reciprocal dinner for Bush. On June 2, the two leaders are to go to Camp David, the presidential retreat in Maryland's Catoctin Mountains. Originally, Gorbachev was to have spent the night at Camp David. However, officials say it now appears likely he will leave in the evening. Gorbachev has been to the United States twice. In December 1987 he held a summit meeting in Washington with Reagan. The two leaders signed a treaty to abolish the two nations' intermediate-range nuclear missiles. Then, in December 1988, Gorbachev met with Reagan in New York. In a telephone interview, Reagan spokesman Weinberg said, ``No one involved in planning President Gorbachev's visit to the United States has been in contact with our office.'' He recalled that Reagan, before leaving office, talked with Gorbachev in a farewell phone call and invited him to visit. Gorbachev also invited Reagan to visit the Soviet Union, Weinberg said. He said the invitations had been renewed in subsequent communications between Gorbachev and Reagan.

DOC.HEAD: Arizona Governor Calls Special Session on King Holiday
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with possiblity first vote could be Tuesday and opponents' plans for amendments; moves up names of states without King holiday. Pick up 9th graf pvs: `Adding King Day...' DELETES final graf to conform.
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Rose Mofford called the Legislature into special session Monday to consider a new Martin Luther King holiday, hoping to forestall a referendum on the issue that has scarred the state's image. The bill to create a new paid holiday for state employees could face a key Senate vote as early as Tuesday, but additional votes could take until Friday. It would replace a bill Mrs. Mofford signed last year to trade in the paid Columbus Day holiday for a holiday in honor of the slain civil rights leader. Last year's bill was ``a mistake that the legislature made,'' Mrs. Mofford said Monday. Asked why she had signed it with much ceremony if she considered it such a mistake, Mrs. Mofford replied: ``You don't veto a moral issue. I never thought that it would come to this.'' In its present form, the bill would make both King day and Colombus days state holidays. But opponents said they might offer amendments to create space for a new King Day by combining separate state holidays for Washington and Lincoln or to to offer state employees a ``cafeteria-style'' choice of which holidays to honor. Controversy over a King holiday has dogged the state's politicians for years. Democratic Gov. Bruce Babbitt declared a holiday by executive proclamation as he was about to start a presidential bid in 1986. But Republican Attorney General Bob Corbin called it an illegal usurpation of the Legislature's role and Republican Gov. Evan Mecham rescinded it days before it would have taken effect. The ensuing uproar included protest marches, tourist boycotts and convention cancellations by national organizations. The furor also fueled a recall drive against Mecham, but a Senate Court of Impeachment ousted him on other grounds before the recall vote could be held. Forty-seven states have some sort of official holiday honoring King. Arizona has an unpaid holiday for him proclaimed by Mecham _ the third Sunday in January. The other states without official King holidays are Montana and New Hampshire. The bill before the legislature would add the third Monday in January to the list of paid holidays for state employees and retain Columbus Day as a paid holiday. Adding King Day to the holiday list rather than swapping it for Columbus Day would cost the state an estimated $500,000 to $3.5 million, but Mrs. Mofford, a Democrat, said the cost was worth it to avoid bad publicity over the lack of a King holiday. ``I would trade that any time for the amount of money it could cost us in the end,'' she said, citing new boycotts including a threatened boycott involving the National Football League's Super Bowl. ``I'm embarrassed because we're being referred to as a racial state.'' Last year's measure is in legal limbo pending a statewide vote because a coalition of Columbus supporters and King opponents gathered nearly twice the 43,350 signatures needed to force a referendum. Monday's bill would wipe out the referendum, but King opponents and Mecham have promised to gather new signatures and force the issue back on the ballot. Mrs. Mofford said she did not fear a referendum but believed lawmakers should decide the issue. The state constitution gives opponents of the measure 90 days from the time the session ends in which to gather the signatures required for a referendum. Last year's bill was approved in the fall, allowing referendum backers to gather signatures in pleasant weather and during street fairs and football games. This year's 90-day period would take place during summer's blazing heat, when there are few large gatherings. Mecham, who is running for governor again, has promised to put up to 4,000 of his volunteers into the field to help gather signatures, and organizers predict they'll get the signatures within two months.

DOC.HEAD: De Klerk: Apartheid Changes Weren't to Curry Foreign Support
DOC.TEXT: South African President F.W. de Klerk said Monday during a Portuguese stopover on his European tour that his country's recent reforms in apartheid were not designed to gain international support. ``We're not doing what we're doing for foreign consumption. ... Whatever the European Community does, that will not change our policy and will not change our commitment to follow that policy to its logical consequences,'' de Klerk said after talks with Portuguese Prime Minister Anibal Cavaco Silva. De Klerk, however, warned that if the 12-nation European Community retained economic sanctions against his white minority government it could slow reforms of the apartheid system of racial segregation. After meeting with de Klerk, Cavaco Silva told reporters:``Portugal understands that the European Community must give a positive sign to support the reforms.'' Most European Community nations have opposed the lifting of sanctions before further reforms are implemented. De Klerk arrived in Lisbon Monday for a two-day visit. Earlier this month de Klerk opened talks with an African National Congress delegation led by Nelson Mandela and reached a broad agreement to work for an end to political violence and prepare the way for black entry into government. De Klerk's reforms have allowed South Africa to break out of decades of international isolation because of its racial policies. De Klerk's nine-nation European tour is the most extensive by a South African leader since his National Party won elections in 1948 and imposed the apartheid system. The party has held power ever since. The South African leader flew to Portugal after stops in France and Greece. He is due to leave Lisbon Tuesday for Belgium. Later stops in the 18-day tour are planned in Britain, West Germany, Switzerland, Spain and Italy.

DOC.HEAD: Four Killed In Crash of Navy Helicopter
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 3 grafs at end with witnesses' description of crash. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A Navy helicopter crashed into the Atlantic Ocean just off the beach Monday, killing all four people aboard, the Navy said. Their bodies were recovered Monday evening by divers who located the fuselage of the SH-2 Sea Sprite helicopter, said Jim Kaufmann, a spokesman at the Jacksonville Naval Air Station. The crash occurred about 200 to 300 yards offshore roughly two miles south of Ponte Vedra Beach, situated a few miles south of Jacksonville in northeast Florida. The downed helicopter was one of three en route from the Atlantic Underwater Test and Evaluation Center on Andros Island in the Bahamas to its home base at Willow Grove, Pa., said Veronica Schauer, a Navy spokeswoman at Jacksonville Naval Air Station. ``We have recovered some wreckage,'' she said. The names of the missing crewmen were not immediately released. The cause of the crash was under investigation. The helicopter was attached to Helicopter Anti-Submarine Squadron Light 94, a reserve squadron, she said. One witness said he saw something fall from the helicopter before the accident. ``We were watching the helicopter come up the coast when something fell off,'' said Ronnie Ruffner. ``It came from the front. I couldn't tell if it was someone diving out or not.'' Duke Dubose saw the helicopter spiral and then plummet sideways into the ocean. ``It looked like the back rotor quit, and it started to tailspin,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Death Penalty Appeal Focuses on Quality of Psychiatric Advice
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RETRANSMITTING to include writethru designation. SUBS grafs 12, 13 and 16 to CORRECT that appeals court members are judges sted justices.
DOC.TEXT: Attorneys for double murderer Robert Alton Harris argued before an appeals court Monday that he should be spared the gas chamber because he got inadequate psychiatric advice at his original trial. If the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals panel agrees with the argument, it could open hundreds of cases to challenge, an attorney for the state argued. Harris, now 37, was convicted of the 1978 murders of two San Diego teen-agers whose car he wanted for a bank robbery. Following a long series of appeals, he was sentenced to die in the gas chamber April 3, in the first execution in California since 1967. But a 9th Circuit judge, John Noonan, stayed the execution four days before it was to take place. On Monday, a three-judge 9th Circuit panel that included Noonan was asked to decide if it's proper to go back and evaluate the competence of the psychiatric advice given the defense in Harris' original trial in 1979. His attorneys argued the original jury should have been told about his extensive mental disorders. The arguments centered on a 1985 U.S. Supreme Court ruling that established a defendant's constitutional right to ``a competent psychiatrist who will conduct an appropriate examination.'' Defense lawyers say new studies found Harris suffers from organic brain damage, fetal alcohol effect and other traumas from childhood and prenatal abuse. Harris' lawyers contend those disorders should have been detected by the psychiatrists who aided his original trial lawyer _ and that the jury, given such evidence, probably would not have sentenced him to death. The defense is asking the court to order a fact-finding hearing in a lower court on the competency of the psychiatric advice. Their ultimate goal is to get a new trial on Harris' sentence, if not the murder verdict. The state Attorney General's office, defending the death sentence, disputed the claims of incompetence. State lawyers went on to argue that the claims of incompetence are beside the point because the Supreme Court guaranteed only the right of access to a licensed psychiatrist, which Harris had. Defense lawyer Charles Sevilla countered that the right to competent psychiatric aid ``means more than a licensed warm body.'' But Judge Arthur Alarcon told him the same argument had been rejected by three other federal courts, including two appeals courts. Judge Melvin Brunetti suggested the defense was trying to expand the scope of the Supreme Court's 1985 ruling, Ake vs. Oklahoma. Deputy Attorney General Jay Bloom said a ruling in Harris' favor would open ``maybe hundreds, who knows, thousands of cases'' to challenge, in areas far beyond psychiatry. ``Any expert could be subject to attack,'' Bloom said. ``Anyone could come in and say, `I don't agree.' ... Why should someone who comes along 12 years later be any more qualified than the original jury?'' The judges questioned defense lawyers closely on whether the court could evaluate the work of Harris' psychiatrists, who gave confidential advice to Harris' trial lawyer, Thomas Ryan, but didn't testify. Alarcon noted that evidence of Harris' alleged mental disorders might have been inconsistent with his defense at trial, which blamed the shootings on his brother, Danny. Defense lawyer Michael McCabe replied that Harris' lawyer had lacked the competent psychiatric evaluations he needed to make a sound decision on strategy.
