Editors
Managing Editors
DOC.TEXT: A summary of developments in the news industry for the week of May 7-14:
DOC.HEAD: Press Institute Urging Stepped-Up Efforts To Free Journalists
DOC.TEXT: The International Press Institute said May 8 it would ask the United States, Britain and U.N. organizations to step up efforts to get journalists held hostage in Lebanon freed. Institute director Peter Gallinor noted in a speech that five years had passed since the kidnapping of Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, and British journalist John McCarthy. ``We will send messages from this assembly to U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar, UNESCO and the governments of the United States and Britain asking them to increase their efforts in getting (the hostages) released,'' Gallinor said. He said there was hope U.N. organizations might achieve what others have not been able to do. Two American hostages were recently set free, but six other Americans are still in captivity along with 10 other Westerners. The hostage held longest is Anderson, who was kidnapped March 16, 1985.
DOC.HEAD: Florida, Freedom Newspapers Stock Disputes Continue
DOC.TEXT: The state of Florida is seeking to join the St. Petersburg Times in a legal battle over stock dividends with a minority shareholder group led by Texas billionaire Robert M. Bass. Bass' name was also mentioned as majority owners of Freedom Newspapers Inc. of Irvine, Calif., created a voting block to thwart unwanted suitors. Florida Attorney General Bob Butterworth filed a motion May 9 to intervene in U.S. District Court in Tampa, saying he wanted to help fend off an ``attack by profiteers.'' ``In short, the Attorney General has an interest in this case because it involves the administration of a charitable organization in Florida,'' Butterworth said. Bass is working with Poynter-Jamison Ventures Limited Partnership. The group filed suit in February against the Times Publishing Co. and the Poynter Institute, a non-profit journalism school that uses St. Petersburg Times stock dividends to support its operations. The Bass group wants the Times to redeem certain stock in the company, thus giving the partnership a more equitable return on its investment. ``The relief sought by the Ventures partners would significantly diminish the future resources of the Poynter Institute,'' Butterworth said. Bass is aligned with relatives of the late Nelson Poynter, who founded the Institute and set up the unusual stock arrangement. The group, which owns 40 percent of the voting stock, gets only 5.7 percent of the dividends of Times Publishing. The Times has refused to redeem the disputed shares, saying it wants to protect journalistic integrity of the newspaper and the institute. At Freedom, majority shareholders representing two families asked merger lawyer Martin Lipton to create an agreement that votes their shares as a block, essentially barring them from selling their stock to anyone but members of the families. The action is meant to ``signal to anybody who is thinking of making a raid on the company that we're determined to remain a privately held, closely held, family company,'' Robert C. Hardie, chairman of Irvine-based Freedom Newspapers, said May 4. The company owns The Orange County Register, 26 other daily newspapers and five television stations. Dissident shareholder Harry Hoiles has threatened repeatedly to sell his stock to an outside party, and majority owners were concerned that he might align himself with Bass. Hoiles was accompanied to several Freedom meetings this year by attorney Glen Johnson, whose firm works with the Robert M. Bass Group. Hoiles has said he has not talked to any Bass officials about selling his stock to the Fort Worth investor. Hoiles has been battling the families of his sister, Mary Jane Hardie, and late brother, Clarence H. Hoiles, for more than a decade in an effort to split up the company and take his share of the assets. As heirs to founder R.C. Hoiles, the three families each hold about one-third of the shares of Freedom. The majority stockholders contend that Hoiles is entitled only to the value of his stock, not the assets. Hoiles lost lower and appellate court cases to break up the assets but has said he plans to bring the case to the state Supreme Court.
DOC.HEAD: Jury Finds Nothing Improper in Comics Switch
DOC.TEXT: A jury found The Dallas Morning News did not set out to wreck its rival in obtaining 26 comics and features that had been running in the Dallas Times Herald. The Harris County jury voted 10-2 on May 8 to reject the Times Herald's claim for at least $33 million in damages. The Times Herald had contended The Morning News and its parent, the A.H. Belo Corp., violated antitrust laws by taking over the features in a move to drive the Times Herald out of business. The features, which ran in the Times Herald until last fall, included Doonesbury, The Far Side, Dear Abby and Erma Bombeck. Times Herald attorney Wayne Fisher said the newspaper will appeal. ``We disagree that the conduct of our competitor was legal or proper in any way,'' the paper said in a statement. ``In fact, it was wrong in many ways _ wrong morally, wrong ethically, wrong for the profession of journalism and wrong for Dallas and its people.'' Belo Chairman Robert Decherd said: ``The most important thing now is for our two companies to go about making the best newspapers we can and benefit the communities we serve. We feel strongly we've been vindicated.'' Decherd denied The Morning News intended to drive the Times Herald out of business. The Morning News said it obtained the comics and features as part of a joint venture with Universal Press Syndicate Inc. of Kansas City, the distributor of the features, to get into the TV programming business. Witnesses for Belo and the syndicate testified that Universal Press required all its features in the Times Herald be moved to The Morning News as part of the venture. The venture will use syndicate comics characters in TV programs and commercials to encourage newspaper readership. The Times Herald had asked for $33 million in actual damages and unspecified punitive damages. The $33 million would have been tripled had the Times Herald been successful in its lawsuit.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Hostage Release Captures Public Attention
DOC.TEXT: The American public is more interested in the release of U.S. hostages held in the Middle East than any other news story so far this year, a survey released May 10 said. Forty-six percent of those surveyed said they paid close attention to the April release of Robert Polhill and Frank Reed, according to the Times Mirror News Interest Index. The index periodically measures public interest and awareness of the news. The response marked the first time in 1990 that more than one-third of the public had focused intense interest on an individual news event, the survey said. Political change in Eastern and Central Europe earlier had been the most consistently watched story, generating interest among about 30 percent of respondents since September. The second most popular story in April was the celebration of Earth Day, which 31 percent of respondents said they watched closely. Stories about the Lithuanian independence movement interested 27 percent of those surveyed. Twenty-four percent of respondents said they closely followed news of the Hubble Space Telescope and of difficulties in taking the 1990 census, and 18 percent were interested in stories about renewed inflation and rising interest rates. The civil war in Cambodia drew the least attention among readers, generating interest from 4 percent of respondents. May Day protests in Moscow interested just 9 percent, the survey said. The Times Mirror News Interest Index is based on a telephone survey of 1,218 adults 18 or older, conducted May 3-7 under the direction of the Princeton Survey Research Associates. The margin of error is plus or minus 3 percentage points.
DOC.HEAD: Columnist Suspended Two Weeks by Newsday
DOC.TEXT: Newsday suspended columnist Jimmy Breslin after he obscenely insulted an Asian-American reporter and phoned a radio personality to joke about it on the air. The 61-year-old Pulitzer Prize-winning columnist was suspended for two weeks without pay, Don Forst, editor of New York Newsday, said May 9. Breslin launched into a tirade in the newsroom May 4 after Ji-Yeon Mary Yuh criticized his column from the previous day in an internal computer message as sexist. In an expletive-laced outburst, Breslin referred to the 25-year-old reporter as ``a yellow cur'' and ``slant-eyed.'' The woman was not present at the time. Breslin later was reprimanded by his editors and apologized to the staff in a computer message. Forst said the paper had believed the reprimand and apology were sufficient until hearing Breslin's on-air conversation, which indicated ``a lack of sensitivity to what has been and continues to be a painful episode.'' The conversation took place May 8 with Howard Stern, a WXRK-FM personality who is known for racial and ethnic jokes and who tangled with the Federal Communications Commission over his sexually frank language. ``I have one social problem coming out of all of this,'' Breslin said on the air, explaining that his nephew is to marry a Korean woman in September. ``Now does this mean I can't go to the wedding?'' he said. Calls to Breslin at Newsday and at home were not immediately returned. A group of Newsday reporters, including Yuh, had asked for Breslin's suspension or for the paper to print a column about bias against Asian women. They had also threatened to withhold their bylines on stories. After the meeting, Newsday editors listened to a tape of the radio show and decided to discipline Breslin, New York Newsday reported. The suspension was applauded by a representative of one Asian-American group. ``Basically, we are glad that management had decided to do the right thing,'' said Jeannie Park, a board member of the Asian American Journalists Association.
DOC.HEAD: Former Clovis News Journal Publisher Accused of Embezzlement
DOC.TEXT: Former Clovis News Journal Publisher James Griffin was arraigned May 7 on a charge of embezzling more than $20,000 from the newspaper. Court documents allege Griffin used the newspaper's money for personal expenses, including $57,000 for the purchase of a $125,000 motor home and $18,421 for a Mustang convertible for his stepdaughter. The Clovis Police Department filed a complaint against Griffin on May 4 following a five-week investigation based on information provided by Freedom Newspapers, which owns the News Journal. Griffin, 60, had been publisher since 1973. He resigned March 26 and was replaced by Bill Salter, former editor of The News-Herald in Panama City, Fla. An affidavit filed in the case alleges that Griffin used $8,493 to build a garage for the motor home, $13,510 for personal expenses, $10,431 for a son's expenses, $5,992 for loan payments, $5,617 for insurance on personal belongings, $2,423 for his stepdaughter's wedding reception and $125 for his mother's medical expenses and personal bills. The affidavit said most of the checks were written and signed by Millie Teeters, office manager and head bookkeeper of the News Journal, upon receipt of handwritten notes from Griffin instructing her to write the checks. Teeters, who was granted immunity from prosecution in the case, said she was only following instructions from Griffin, the affidavit said. She said Griffin cashed personal checks from a petty cash fund, then took back the checks and had her reclassify the charges and spread them to various expense accounts.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Court Lists 12 Organizations That Will Transmit Opinions
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court announced May 11 the selection of a dozen organizations that will make the court's opinions quickly available via computer beginning next month. The organizations will be able to reach thousands of subscribers by providing the opinions electronically within minutes after they are announced. They are: The Associated Press, the Bureau of National Affairs, Commerce Clearinghouse, the Department of Justice, Mead Data Central, the National Clearinghouse for Legal Services, the Supreme Court Opinions Network, the Thomson Group, United Press International, UUNET, West Publishing and a consortium of Case Western Reserve University, the National Public Telecomputing Network and the Interuniversity Communications Council. Each organization will pay $500 this year to participate and will provide its own computer connection to the computer system through equipment lent to the court by the Supreme Court Opinion Network.
DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Stops Publication After 76 Years
DOC.TEXT: The Clearwater Sun folded May 8, ending a struggle with powerful metro competitors in St. Petersburg and Tampa. The newspaper, founded 76 years ago, switched to weekly publication last summer. ``We were unable to make an effective business,'' said a statement from Bruce E. Coury, publisher of Clearwater Newspapers Inc. The Sun's circulation dropped from more than 50,000 in 1980 to less than 15,000. In previous years it went through a succession of independent owners until it was bought in 1971 by Jefferson Pilot Publications. In the mid-1980s, the Hearst Corp. bought the Sun and four Texas newspapers. Hearst Vice President Roger Greer broke the news to employees, some of whom said they were sad but not shocked. ``We're not dumb. We work here, we know what's going on. ... We can see the war between the St. Pete Times and the Tampa Tribune,'' said Nick Klasne, an editor.
DOC.HEAD: Munro Steps Down as Co-Chairman, Co-CEO of Time Warner
DOC.TEXT: In a long-planned change of command, J. Richard Munro said May 8 he was stepping down as co-chairman and co-chief executive of Time Warner Inc., the media and entertainment behemoth he helped create. Munro, 59, made the announcement at the first annual meeting of Time Warner shareholders since the company he ran for a decade, Time Inc., completed its acquisition of Warner Communications Inc. earlier this year. Munro became chief executive at Time in 1980, and has shared the chairman and chief executive posts with Warner boss Steven J. Ross since Time bought a controlling interest in Warner and changed its name last year. Munro said previously that he planned to serve as chief executive for only 10 years. He reaffirmed last year in announcing the deal with Warner that he intended to keep to that timetable. Succeeding Munro as co-chief executive is Time president Nicholas J. Nicholas Jr., 50. Ross, 62, becomes the company's sole chairman and plans to share the chief executive's post for four years, when he will leave that job entirely to Nicholas. Time Warner is a world leader in magazine and book publishing, films, recorded music, TV production and cable TV systems. The company lost $256 million on revenue of $10.8 billion last year, mainly because of costs associated with its purchase of a majority stake in Warner. Nicholas said a top priority is reducing the company's $10.8 billion debt.
DOC.HEAD: Safire Tells Syracuse Students To `Edit' Life
DOC.TEXT: Life is a process of editing that requires a willingness to revise, New York Times columnist William Safire told Syracuse University graduates May 6. Safire advised them to edit out of their lives the temptation to show off their knowledge, but to never edit out their passion. ``That's creative editing, that's what we're here for,'' said Safire, who defined editing as ``adding shape, significance and grace to what you do.'' Safire received his biggest applause when he told the graduates that he dropped out of Syracuse University as a sophomore in 1949. He went to work for the New York Herald Tribune, became a speech writer for Richard Nixon, and joined the Times as a columnist in 1973. Safire won the 1977 Pulitzer Prize for Distinguished Commentary for his series on the financial dealings of Bert Lance, President Carter's budget director. Syracuse University established a $1 million endowed faculty chair in Safire's honor two years ago.
DOC.HEAD: Gannett Changes Billboards Near Schools, Churches
DOC.TEXT: Gannett Outdoor of Chicago said May 7 it was tightening its policy against locating alcohol and tobacco ad billboards within 500 feet of churches and schools. Such billboards now will display the message, ``This is a non-alcohol and non-tobacco location'' when they are awaiting sale to advertise other products, spokesman Stephen Shinn said. About 100 billboards would be affected. ``This issue has been raised in many urban areas, most notably Detroit, Chicago, Dallas, Houston and New York,'' Shinn said. ``People have taken things in their own hands and defaced billboards, whitewashed them.'' Gannett Outdoor owns about 1,200 billboards in the Chicago metropolitan area. It owns billboards in 15 other cities and holds contracts for advertising on mass transit in six more.
DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court Reinstates Libel Suit
DOC.TEXT: A state appeals court on May 8 reinstated a libel suit filed by a former CIA-owned airline against a television station over a report on drug-carrying planes. The 3rd District Court of Appeal reversed a Dade Circuit Court decision dismissing the case against WPLG-TV and ordered a trial on defamation claims by Southern Air Transport. The evidence tended to show that WPLG-TV didn't give the cargo carrier ``a fair opportunity'' to respond to the drug allegations in a series aired in 1987, the appeals court ruled. The judges agreed with the lower court that Southern Air was a limited public figure, which in legal terms means the airline would have to prove the station knew its story was false or aired it with reckless disregard for the truth. Southern Air received widespread publicity before the series as a supplier for U.S.-based Contra rebels fighting Nicaragua's ruling Sandinistas. The station's report included an informer's statement that she watched as drugs were loaded on a Southern Air plane in Colombia. The same woman repeated the allegations before a U.S. Senate committee. Other defendants in the case are the station owner, Post-Newsweek Stations of Florida, reporter Susan Candiotti and four others involved in the series production.
DOC.HEAD: Man Crashes Truck Into Buffalo News Building
DOC.TEXT: A man being chased by police crashed his pickup truck into the front door of the Buffalo News building May 7 and ran into the newsroom, demanding to see a reporter who had written stories about his effort to avoid deportation. Serge M. Germano was apparently upset that his bank would not let him withdraw $1,000, said police and reporters who witnessed the incident. No one was injured. Germano was arrested on charges of reckless endangerment and criminal mischief, four traffic violations and possession of marijuana. Police Lt. Kevin Kelly said an officer saw the driver run a red light and gave chase. The driver took an expressway downtown, got off near the newspaper building and crashed into its front door. The reporter had written a series of stories between 1977 and 1985 about Germano, an Italian citizen who enlisted in the U.S. Navy during Vietnam and then used his status as an alien to get out of the military. A stipulation on his discharge that he could never become a U.S. citizen led to years of difficulties with the immigration authorities.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Lawsuit Claims Paper Invades Privacy by Publishing Divorce Lists
DOC.TEXT: A Newport newspaper's inconspicuous list of divorces could become a test of a state's right to bar public information from being reported by the news media. The U.S. Supreme Court has refused to say whether states can put off-limits otherwise public information by invoking privacy concerns. A Newport divorce lawyer contends Rhode Island's privacy law is such a shield. Attorney Thomas W. Kelly is suing The Newport Daily News on behalf of a woman who wants to keep her name out of the newspaper's monthly listing of divorces granted in Newport County Family Court. A hearing in the case was scheduled for May 14. ``The Supreme Court has opened the door for the first time,'' said Kelly, citing its June 1989 ruling clearing The Florida Star newspaper after it published the name of a rape victim despite state law against such publication. The paper was not liable for invasion of privacy, the high court ruled, but there might be a ``zone of personal privacy within which the state may protect the individual from intrusion by the press.'' Rhode Island's 10-year-old privacy law provides the right to be secure from ``unreasonable publicity'' of a fact ``which would be offensive or objectionable to a reasonable man of ordinary sensibilities.'' Kelly acknowledges his chances of winning are slim, but argues his client is entitled to privacy because she is not a prominent figure and has not run for public office. He wants the newspaper to ``discern the newsworthiness'' of the divorces it publishes. Jane Kirtley, head of the Reporters Committee for the Freedom of the Press, said the lawsuit is frivolous. In open court, she said, ``the press' role is to act as a surrogate for that portion of the public which cannot be there.'' Harvard University law professor Alan Dershowitz, who defended Newport socialite Claus von Bulow on charges he attempted to murder his wife, said there is ``no possibility'' a state can bar publication of a public record. ``The only way for the state to get around that is to say divorce is not a matter of public record _ but of course it is,'' Dershowitz said. David B. Offer, the newspaper's editor, said divorces are noteworthy, regardless of the people involved, because of their effects on the community, its businesses, schools, churches and welfare programs. ``Some may call that voyeurism or scandal,'' Offer said, ``but it seems to me that if (divorces) are of interest to a segment of the community that people have a right to read about them in a community newspaper.''
DOC.HEAD: Paper Asks Town To Halt Newsletter
DOC.TEXT: The Daily News-Sun has asked the nearby town of Surprise to stop publishing a municipal newsletter. ``The town of Surprise lacks the statutory authority to engage in the publishing business,'' News-Sun Publisher Sam Marocco said in a letter to town officials May 8. ``We see the solicitation of advertisements as a direct violation of state laws. Furthermore, we have several First Amendment concerns over a government pursuing the newspaper business.'' Mayor Roy Villanueva said May 9 he was unaware that ads had been solicited. ``This didn't come up before the council,'' Vice Mayor Clark Maxon said. ``Somebody became overzealous, knowing we're short of funds, and thought advertising was a way to pay for the newsletter.''' Town Councilman Danny Arismendez defended the newsletter. ``A newspaper wouldn't publish a lot of the stuff. This is important information for our residents,'' Arismendez said. Surprise Today is published under guidance of the town manager. The town pays printing and mailing costs.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Looking for Civilian Editor
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon is seeking an experienced civilian journalist to edit the Pacific edition of the military newspaper Stars & Stripes, which ran into charges of censorship and mismanagement under its military editor. Jordan E. Rizer, director of the Defense Department's American Forces Information Service, said May 10 the agency also will consider a recommendation by Pentagon-appointed ombudsman Philip M. Foisie that a civilian editor be named for the European edition. Foisie, a former editor with The Washington Post, was named last summer to make recommendations in light of a study by the congressional General Accounting Office that found evidence of censorship and improper management at the government-run daily paper. The Society of Professional Journalists assisted the GAO in its investigation.
DOC.HEAD: K-III to Buy Automotive Industry Publisher Ward's Communications
DOC.TEXT: The publishing concern K-III Holdings LP said May 7 it has agreed to buy Ward's Communications from Thomson Corp. of Canada. Ward's publishes the weekly newsletter Ward's Automotive Reports. It also publishes the monthly magazines Ward's Automotive World and Ward's Auto Dealer, along with biweekly newsletters and the annual Ward's Automotive Yearbook. Thomson, based in Toronto, had put Detroit-based Ward's up for sale in early March, citing a strategic decision by its information publishing group. A Thomson spokesman said several parties expressed interest but declined to say how many bids were received. Ward's has been in business since 1924 and was acquired by Thomson in 1981.
DOC.HEAD: New Pan-European Newspaper Hits the Newsstands
DOC.TEXT: The European, a new English-language weekly newspaper printed in Britain, France, West Germany and Hungary, and sold throughout Europe, hit the newsstands May 11. The first edition sported the front-page headline ``One Money for Europe.'' The story reported that 60 percent of those polled in Britain, Denmark, France, Italy, West Germany, the Soviet Union and Switzerland wanted to see one European currency. It added that a majority thought Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev would be the most popular choice as president of a united Europe. It said the second choice was President Francois Mitterrand of France. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain and West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl shared third place. More than 1 million copies of the first issue were printed; 600,000 at a plant in northwest London and the rest at plants in Roubaix, France; Hannover, West Germany, and near Budapest, Hungary. The paper, which costs the equivalent of 83 cents in Britain, is being distributed throughout Europe, including Scandinavia. It is owned by Robert Maxwell, 66, Britain's second-biggest newspaper publisher. The Czechoslovakian-born Maxwell has publishing, printing and communications interests in two dozen countries. In an interview last week Maxwell told The Associated Press that with the crumbling of the East Bloc and as the 12-nation European Community moves closer to unity, a newspaper for all of Europe was an idea whose time had come.
DOC.HEAD: No Censorship, but Control Is Another Question
DOC.TEXT: Censorship ended with the fall of Nicolae Ceausescu in December, but the opposition says state control of television and major newspapers is just as effective. Spokesmen for independent news outlets and parties say telling the opposition story is extremely difficult as Romania approaches its first free elections in 44 years, scheduled for May 20. The chief target of criticism is the National Salvation Front, which dominates the interim government and is suspected by many of seeking to bring back a milder form of communism. Many ranking members of the Front, including interim President Ion Iliescu, are former Communists who had been critical of Ceausescu. Front leaders profess democratic ideals, including a commitment to freedom of the press. The Human Rights Law Group, based in Washington, D.C., said after a fact-finding tour in late April that many Romanians believed the Front controlled the government. It said the Front's advantages ``are amplified by the government's control of television, printing presses and newsprint, distribution of national and opposition print media, international communications networks, and air and ground transport.'' ``There are widespread complaints that the newspapers distributed by the government, especially those of opposition parties and certain independent papers, often fail to reach their destination, are not delivered promptly or are returned when they could have been sold,'' the monitoring group said.
DOC.HEAD: Noticias del Mundo Announces International Editions
DOC.TEXT: Noticias del Mundo, the nationally distributed Spanish-language daily newspaper, said May 4 it plans international editions in Europe and Latin America within three months. The European edition will appear first in Spain before moving into France and Germany, said spokeswoman Gladys M. Rosa. The Latin American edition will originate in Venezuela within three months, she said. ``We started out as a little Spanish-language newspaper, and in 1990 we've come of age,'' said Publisher Phillip V. Sanchez. ``We are making a huge investment in this project, taking a dream and making it a reality.'' The paper is available in 74 U.S. cities and will go on sale in San Francisco and San Jose this month, Rosa said.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: NBC May Offer Affiliates 24-Hour News Service
DOC.TEXT: NBC, which once tried to buy 51 percent of Cable News Network, is planning its own 24-hour news service for its affiliates, NBC News president Michael Gartner said May 7. The affiliates could use the service as part of their own broadcasts or when NBC is ``dark'' and not broadcasting. The plan likely will be presented to affiliates at their annual convention, on June 3-6 in Washington, D.C. The proposal drew praise from James R. Sefert, chairman of the NBC affiliates' board, although he emphasized he didn't have full details of it. He likened it to an extension of an NBC News service called A-News, which sends affiliates news reports from NBC News and NBC affiliates. NBC executives have told him in broad terms what the new service would be and ``I think it's terrific,'' said Sefert, president of Cosmos Broadcasting Corp. in Greenville, S.C. ``I really can't comment until I see the full proposal,'' he said when asked if he thought NBC-affiliated stations would approve the idea. ``But the outline sounded good.'' ``It's too early to tell,'' CNN spokesman Steve Haworth said when asked about NBC's plan, which could prove a rival for CNN, at least with NBC affiliates that also take CNN service. ``We still are studying it,'' Haworth said. ``But we've developed very strong relationships with 220 broadcast affiliates over the 10 years that we've been in business. We're certainly confident that those relationships will persist.''
DOC.HEAD: Rochester Radio Station Shares Frequency With Cuban Broadcasts
DOC.TEXT: WHAM-AM is sharing its frequency with broadcasts from Cuba, apparently because of the dustup over Radio Marti, an FCC official said. The Federal Communications Commission notified the station's managers on May 8 that Cuba is broadcasting radio programs at 1180 kilohertz, the frequency used by the Rochester station. Rockie Patterson, an FCC electronics engineer, said monitors in Washington, D.C., picked up the Spanish-language programs from Cuba. ``They have started a broadcast station on that frequency, and we've sent telexes asking them to get off,'' Patterson said. ``We know from intercepts of Cuban broadcasts that this is in response to TV Marti.'' WHAM has received complaints about the Cuban interference from listeners as far north as Maryland, but not from farther north, said station manager Jack Murphy. TV Marti has been broadcasting television programs to Cuban audiences with backing from the U.S. government. Cuba has responded with broadcasts aimed at people planning to visit the Caribbean nation, Patterson said. ``What tourists they hope to reach, I'm not sure, because I doubt that there are many Americans interested in going there,'' he said. ``It's annoying, but there's absolutely nothing we can do about it,'' Murphy said.
DOC.HEAD: Religious Broadcasters, Churches Cautioned After CBN Bombing
DOC.TEXT: Some religious broadcasters and churches have been warned by federal officials about opening mail following the explosion of a bomb sent in a package to the Christian Broadcasting Network in April. ``What I've done is made a mass mailing to members of the National Religious Broadcasters asking them to be aware of anything suspicious that comes through the mail,'' said Cedric W. Lawrence Jr., a spokesman for the U.S. Postal Inspection Service in Richmond. Lawrence said the warning was not intended to frighten, but to make the ministers aware of possible problems. He said he sent letters to 185 high-profile religious broadcasters as well as religious groups. On April 27, a small package exploded in the mailroom at the CBN complex in Virginia Beach when a guard attempted to open it. The guard, Scott Scheeper, 33, was hit in the leg by several pieces of shrapnel and was hospitalized for several days. A mail bomb exploded Jan. 30 at the church of the Rev. John Osteen in Houston. Osteen's daughter was slightly injured when she opened a shoebox-sized package. Both packages were mailed from small towns in Bladen County, N.C., investigators said. Postal inspectors have released two similar composite drawings of men suspected of mailing the packages.
DOC.NOTE: MORE
Eds: RETRANSMITTING TO MAKE IT ``Jordan,'' sted ``Johnson'' in 3rd Personnel item
DOC.HEAD: Major Union Rejects NBC's Contract Offer
DOC.TEXT: A major broadcast union that struck NBC for 17 weeks in 1987 has overwhelmingly voted to reject a ``final'' offer the network made on March 30, a spokesman for the union said. John Krieger of the National Association of Broadcast Employees and Technicians (NABET) said no strike authorization vote had been taken, and union members will continue working pending developments. NABET members, whose NBC contract expired on March 31, rejected the network's offer by an 81 percent margin, with 1,601 voting against the four-year proposal and 354 voting to accept it. The union says it has 2,373 members at NBC and NBC-owned facilities in New York and in Burbank, Ca.; Washington, D.C.; Chicago, and Cleveland. Although 1,300 of the members are engineers and technicians, the union also represents newswriters, building maintenance employees, couriers, operations directors and some employees at NBC News bureaus in the U.S. NBC's offer would give NABET members a 5 percent bonus if they approved the contract by June. Over the next three years, they would get pay raises of 3 percent, 3 percent and 4 percent.
DOC.HEAD: Harvill To Become Publisher of Tampa Tribune
DOC.TEXT: H. Doyle Harvill, vice president and executive editor of the Tampa Tribune, will become publisher of the newspaper and chairman of the Tribune Co. on July 1, the newspaper announced May 9. He succeeds Richard F. Pittman, 67, who is retiring after 44 years with the newspaper. Harvill, 60, spent much of his journalism career in Tampa, serving as a copy editor, reporter, city editor and then managing editor of the Tampa Times, which ceased daily publication in 1982. He left Tampa in 1974 for an executive position at Media General Inc. headquarters in Richmond, Va. In 1976, Harvill became executive editor of The Greenville (S.C.) News and Piedmont, flagship newspapers of Multimedia Inc. He later was named a vice president of that company, and in 1982 became publisher and president of the Montgomery (Ala.) Advertiser and Alabama Journal. He returned to Tampa in 1986 as vice president and executive editor of the Tribune.
DOC.HEAD: Bell Named Chanute Tribune Editor-Publisher
DOC.TEXT: Tom Bell, general manager of The Olathe Daily News for the past three years, assumed new duties May 7 as editor-publisher of The Chanute Tribune. Bell replaced F.M. Harris III, who resigned. Both newspapers are owned by Harris Enterprises. Bell, 35, was formerly a photographer and reporter, and worked for the Harris group's electronic publishing venture, Harris Electronic News, before that venture ended.
DOC.HEAD: Jordan Named Editor, Publisher of Terrell Tribune
DOC.TEXT: Bill Jordan, publisher of the weekly Kaufman Herald since 1975, has been named editor-publisher of The Terrell Tribune, a sister newspaper published six days a week. He replaces Noble Welch, who moves to editor and publisher of The Henderson Daily News in East Texas. All three are members of the Hartman Newspapers Group. Jordan was a sports writer for the Tribune in 1975 before joining the Herald. He also was general manager at the Tribune, directing advertising and production for it and the Herald. Jordan has twice been awarded the Texas Press Association's top honors for weekly newspaper column writing and has won several other awards for news writing and editorials.
DOC.HEAD: Stockholders Add Burleigh to Board
DOC.TEXT: Stockholders of the E.W. Scripps Co. on May 14 elected Executive Vice President William R. Burleigh to the board of directors and re-elected nine members. Burleigh, 54, was named executive vice president in March. He was senior vice president of Scripps' Newspapers-Publishing division from 1986 until this March, and was vice president and general editorial manager from 1984 until 1986. Burleigh is a member of the board of directors of The Associated Press. Scripps publishes 19 daily newspapers, owns nine television and five radio stations and operates cable television systems with 567,000 basic subscribers. The company is the worldwide syndicator and licenser of comics including ``Peanuts'' and ``Garfield.'' Re-elected to the board were Scripps President Daniel J. Meyer; Nicholas B. Paumgarten, a managing director of First Boston Corp.; Frederick W. Smith, chairman of Federal Express Corp.; John H. Burlingame, a partner in the law firm of Baker & Hostetler; Jack R. Howard, chairman of Scripps Howard Broadcasting Co., a Scripps subsidiary; Lawrence A. Leser, president of Scripps; Charles E. Scripps, chairman of the board; Paul K. Scripps, vice chairman of the board, and Robert P. Scripps.
DOC.HEAD: New York Newsday Names New Editors
DOC.TEXT: Ernest Tollerson has been named New York Newsday editorial page editor, the newspaper announced May 8. He replaces Thomas Plate, now editorial page editor of the Los Angeles Times. Editor Don Forst also named Patricia Cohen deputy metro editor for politics and government. Cohen was formerly an editorial writer. Tollerson has been both an op-ed editor and deputy editor of the editorial pages since 1986. Previously he was state bureau chief for The Philadelphia Inquirer in Trenton, N.J., and worked for the New York Daily News and The Wall Street Journal. Cohen joined the newspaper in 1986 after positions with United Press International in New Delhi and freelance work in Washington, D.C.
DOC.HEAD: Ritter Named GNS Editor
DOC.TEXT: Robert W. Ritter, former executive editor of The Denver Post, has been appointed editor of Gannett News Service. Ritter, 43, left the Post in November and has been a general executive in Gannett's newspaper division. GNS Executive Editor Ron Cohen will work on special projects and improving writing and editing, according to GNS President Nancy Woodhull.
DOC.HEAD: Spratling Appointed Bureau Chief in San Francisco
DOC.TEXT: Rick Spratling, Associated Press bureau chief in Wisconsin for the past five years, was named bureau chief in San Francisco. AP President Louis D. Boccardi announced the appointment May 8. Spratling will direct AP operations in northern California and northern Nevada. Spratling, 48, has been bureau chief in Milwaukee since January 1985. He joined the AP in Miami in 1977 and was named news editor in Boston three years later. In 1984 he was named acting bureau chief in Milwaukee during the illness of Chief of Bureau Dion Henderson. Spratling is a native of Murray, Utah, and a graduate of the University of Utah. He worked for The Salt Lake Tribune and KUTV-TV in Salt Lake City before joining the AP there in 1968 and becoming news editor. He left to become news director at KUTV in 1970 but returned to the AP in Miami. Spratling succeeds Peggy Walsh, who resigned.
DOC.HEAD: Reader's Digest Association President Takes Early Retirement
DOC.TEXT: The Reader's Digest Association Inc. said May 7 its president and chief operating officer, Richard F. McLoughlin, has decided to take early retirement for personal reasons, effective June 30. George V. Grune, chairman and chief executive, will assume the title of president and chief operating officer indefinitely, the company said. McLoughlin is 61 and Grune is 60. The company's normal retirement age is 65. McLoughlin said he is retiring to spend more time with his wife, Anita, who has undergone a series of back operations over the last several years and is in almost constant pain.
DOC.HEAD: Gibbons Resigns From Transcript
DOC.TEXT: Managing Editor Ann C. Gibbons of The Transcript has resigned effective May 23 after seven years at the newspaper. Gibbons started as arts and lifestyles editor, was named city editor in 1986 and became managing editor the next year. The newspaper, published six days a week with a circulation of about 11,000, was sold by Ingersoll Publications Co. to American Publishing Co. in January. Gibbons said she is considering job offers out of state.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.TEXT: Ralph Clark, a former publisher and general manager of the Grand Island Independent, died May 6 from Parkinson's disease at age 79. Clark entered the newspaper business at age 13 in 1923, working as a Linotype operator and printer on several Kansas and Nebraska weeklies. Later he became an ad manager at Augusta and Larned, Kan., and was ad manager of the weekly Columbus (Neb.) News for five years before coming to Grand Island. Clark was an advertising salesman at the Independent for six years, became advertising manager in 1949 and general manager in 1963. He was publisher for several years before retiring in 1977. Survivors include his wife, Alice, a daughter, two granddaughters, a sister and several nieces and nephews.

William B. Coltin, who worked as a reporter and editor at The Daily News for more than 50 years, died May 10 of a stroke at age 78. Coltin died at Anna Jaques Hospital 10 days after suffering the stroke. Coltin was 16 years old when he first worked for the News in 1927, filing stories while in high school in this northeast Massachusetts city. Three years later, he was hired as a reporter. Coltin went on to become a sportswriter, photographer and finally city editor, a job he held for 25 years until he retired in 1984. He continued reporting as a senior correspondent for the paper until his death. He also wrote for The Associated Press and United Press International, as well as for various Boston newspapers, including the Boston Herald and The Boston Globe. Survivors include his wife of 53 years, Raelene; a son, a daughter, two brothers and a sister.

Pauline Frederick, a broadcaster whose distinguished career in network journalism paved the way for other women, died May 9 of a heart attack at age 84. She suffered the heart attack while visiting relatives in suburban Lake Forest. Frederick worked for five years as an ABC correspondent before moving in 1953 to NBC, where she served as United Nations correspondent for 21 years. She covered the Cuban missile crisis and China's entrance into the United Nations. In 1976, Frederick moderated the second debate between Gerald Ford and Jimmy Carter, becoming the first woman journalist to moderate a presidential debate. She was also the first woman elected president of the United Nations Correspondents Association and the first to receive a George Foster Peabody Award for achievements in broadcasting. She was married to the late Charles Robbins, former reporter and managing editor of The Wall Street Journal. She has no other immediate survivors.

Newspaper and television reporter Gene McLain died May 9 after a bout with emphysema. He was 74. Known as ``The Bulldog'' for his aggressive style, McLain packed a gun in his early years on the police beat and once solved a murder case. McLain worked at The Arizona Republic for about 27 years and was managing editor of the Scottsdale Progress, which he helped transform from a weekly to a suburban daily. McLain worked at KPNX-TV in Phoenix for 15 years until he retired in 1980. In 1973, he received the Virg Hill Newsman of the Year Award from the Arizona Press Club. He is survived by his wife, Inez, two sons, three grandchildren; one great-grandchild; two brothers; and one sister.
DOC.HEAD: AP Cited in Three Foreign Reporting Categories
DOC.TEXT: A reporter and two photographers for The Associated Press were cited May 7 by the Overseas Press Club for outstanding coverage of news in Romania, China and Iran. The club, at its annual banquet, also observed a minute's silence and announced it was sending cables of protest to the 18 nations where 76 journalists are imprisoned. The AP's two first-prize winners were Mort Rosenblum, for his reporting from Romania, and a photographer who covered the funeral of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini but who remains anonymous to avoid reprisal. A citation went to Jeff Widener for his photo of a Chinese man standing in front of a line of tanks. A newspaper reporting prize also was awarded to Nicholas Kristof and Sheryl WuDunn of The New York Times for the China coverage that also won them a Pulitzer Prize earlier this year. Another repeater from the Pulitzers was David Turnley of the Detroit Free Press, cited by the press club for his photos from China and Romania. The awards list: Hal Boyle Award for newspaper or news service reporting _ Rosenblum; Kristof and WuDunn. Bob Considine Award for newspaper or news service interpretation _ Jackson Diehl of The Washington Post, articles on Eastern Europe, with a citation to Claudia Rosset of The Wall Street Journal, on China. Robert Capa Gold Medal for photo reporting or interpretation requiring exceptional courage or enterprise _ Turnley; citations to Widener and to Christopher Morris of Black Star for Time magazine, for photos from Panama. Olivier Rebbot Award for photo reporting _ Peter Turnley, Newsweek, for the fall of Romanian President Nicolae Ceausescu, with citations to Bill Gentile for his book, ``Nicaragua,'' and James Nachtwey of Life magazine for ``Death Zone.'' Best newspaper or news service photo reporting _ AP anonymous photographer; with citation to Ron Jacques Haviv of Agence France-Presse from Panama. Ben Grauer Award for spot radio reporting _ Gary Matsumoto of NBC Radio, for stories on Eastern Europe, with citation to Steve Futterman, NBC-Mutual Radio, for reports on China. Lowell Thomas Award for radio interpretation or documentary _ CBS News Radio for ``Europe 1989,'' with citations to Duc Nguyen and Peter Breslow and National Public Radio for stories on Vietnam revisited. Television spot news _ Dan Rather and CBS News for ``The New Face of Communism,'' and Bernard Shaw of CNN for stories on China. Edward R. DOC.HEAD: Harvard University Announces 1990-91 Class of Nieman Fellows
DOC.TEXT: The 12 journalists selected as Nieman Fellows at Harvard University this fall were announced May 8. The fellowship was established in 1938 with a gift from Agnes Wahl Nieman and gives journalists in mid-career a chance to study at the school for one year. Foreign journalists to be named as Niemans will be announced later, the school said. The American fellows in the 53rd Nieman class are: _ Jim Amoss, 42, associate editor, The Times-Picayune in New Orleans. _ Betty Winston Baye, 44, assistant editor, Neighborhoods, The Courier-Journal, Louisville, Ky. _ John Carlson, 41, reporter-Iowa City bureau chief, The Des Moines (Iowa) Register. _ Tim Giago, 55, publisher, the Lakota Times, Rapid City, S.D. _ Joel Greenberg, 34, West Bank reporter, Jerusalem Post. _ Marcia Slacum Greene, 37, reporter, The Washington Post. _ Dale Mezzacappa, 39, education writer, The Philadelphia Inquirer. _ Kevin Noblet, 37, Santiago, Chile, bureau chief, The Associated Press. _ Ana Puga, 29, Latin American correspondent, Houston Chronicle. _ Barbara Ross, 41, reporter, New York Daily News. _ Charles Shepard, 35, investigative reporter, The Charlotte (N.C.) Observer. _ Katherine Skiba, 33, reporter, The Milwaukee Journal.
DOC.HEAD: Dallas Sports Editor Wins Red Smith Award
DOC.TEXT: Dave Smith, deputy managing editor and executive sports editor of the Dallas Morning News, is the 1990 winner of the Red Smith Award, presented annually by the Associated Press Sports Editors. Smith, 51, is the first non-writer to win the award, named in honor of the late Pulitzer Prize-winning columnist for The New York Times and presented for outstanding contributions to sports journalism. He was selected by a vote of APSE's past 14 presidents, who also submit the list of nominees. Dave Smith began his career in 1961 at the Mansfield (Ohio) News-Journal in Mansfield, Ohio. He spent seven years at newspapers in Miami and Fort Lauderdale, Fla., before becoming sports editor of The Boston Globe in 1970. He moved to the Washington Star in 1978 and to the Morning News in 1981. Smith will be honored at a luncheon June 29 at the APSE convention in Boston.
DOC.HEAD: Reuter Foundation Announces Awards
DOC.TEXT: The Reuter Foundation has awarded fellowships to eight journalists to study in Britain, France and the United States. Three will study at Oxford University, England, two at Stanford University and two at Bordeaux University, France. The Oxford fellowship is in memory of Najmul Hasan, a Reuter correspondent killed in 1983 while covering the Iran-Iraq war. A Reuter news release May 8 said the fellows were from Argentina, Costa Rica, Jamaica, Israel, Brazil, India, the Philippines and Zaire. The foundation was started in 1982 to help journalists from developing countries learn to use information technology and to provide research opportunities for them.
DOC.HEAD: `Garfield' Creator Wins Cartoonist of the Year Award
DOC.TEXT: Jim Davis, creator of fat cat ``Garfield,'' was named Cartoonist of the Year on May 5 by the National Cartoonists Society. After six years as a nominee, Davis, of Albany, Ind., won the ``Reuben'' _ the cartoon world's equivalent of the Oscar _ for the cynical, overfed Garfield, featured on television specials and many novelty items as well as newspaper cartoons. The award was presented during the group's annual meeting, aboard a cruise ship in the Caribbean, said Selma Gore, spokeswoman for the society. The award, a 16-inch bronze statue designed by the late cartoonist Rube Goldberg, founder of the 44-year-old society, shows eight people tangled together around an inkstand. Awards for excellence also were given in five categories. Johnny Hart of Endicott, N.Y., who draws ``B.C.'' and ``Wizard of Id,'' was honored for best newspaper strips and panels. The newspaper editorial and sports award went to Pat Oliphant of Falls Church, Va.

Andy Rooney, suspended by CBS for three weeks after being quoted as making remarks offensive to blacks and homosexuals, says special interest groups are squelching debate on television and in politics. The United States has become a nation ``that doesn't say what it thinks about so many things'' for fear of those groups, he told a meeting of the Constitutional Rights Foundation in Los Angeles. ``There are organized minorities for almost every cause, and politicians, along with network executives, are scared to death of them.'' ... John Quinn, the former editor in chief of USA Today, criticizes the excessive use of unnamed sources. ``I pity the poor reader who is asked to believe `informed sources,''' Quinn told the Nevada State Press Association. ``If the press required informed sources to put their names in stories, there would be a lot less lying.''
DOC.HEAD: End Industry News

DOC.TEXT: White House Chief of Staff John Sununu says tax increases are ``a possibility but no certainty'' in the budget deal the Bush administration is trying to strike with leaders of Congress. ``It is a budget summit, not a tax summit,'' Sununu said Sunday as he sought to calm the storm over his earlier remarks indicating that President Bush had no intention of deviating from his no-new-taxes campaign pledge. Budget negotiations are scheduled Tuesday between top Bush administration officials and 21 of the most powerful members of the House and Senate. The chairmen of the House and Senate budget committees indicated Sunday that gun-shy Democrats will insist that Bush take the lead in proposing any tax increases.

A presidential commission on terrorism is expected to call for changes in federal aviation security operations without laying blame for the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103. The seven-member commission headed by former Labor Secretary Ann McLaughlin is giving its report to President Bush on Tuesday, followed by a briefing at the White House for relatives of some of the 270 people killed in the Dec. 21, 1988, bombing over Lockerbie, Scotland. Bush appointed the panel after family members demanded a congressional investigation into government actions before and after the attack. The relatives withdrew the demand pending outcome of the nine-month presidential inquiry. Investigators in Britain say the Boeing 747 was downed by a plastic explosive concealed in a radio cassette player by still unidentified terrorists.

The collapse of the ``Massachusetts miracle'' touted by Michael Dukakis in his failed 1988 presidential campaign is giving Republicans their best hope in years to take the governor's office. But Democrats are far from doomed, and a Democratic former attorney general who served with Dukakis now appears to be the favorite to succeed him. After three terms as governor, Dukakis is not seeking re-election. Republicans, who have been locked out of the governor's office for 16 years, are fighting to end what they call ``one-party rule'' in the state. The GOP's prospects rose as a slump in the state economy and a slowdown in tax collections led to burgeoning deficits. Dukakis and his fellow Democrats got the blame for mismanaging the state's finances. Former Attorney General Francis X. Bellotti, who leads the candidates in public opinion polls, has been a frequent critic of current policies even though he was a past Dukakis supporter.

Politicians moved to take over the process of unifying Germany this week after a group of technical experts found only limited success in meshing the economies of two very different nations. Expert delegations from both Germanys over the weekend completed the draft of a state treaty that is to serve as a basis for an economic, currency and social union of the countries by July 2. But West German government spokesman Dieter Vogel conceded that one of the touchiest issues of unification _ how to shift East Germany's state-owned property to the private sector _ has been put on the back burner. ``Negotiations will be continued (this) week on a political level,'' Vogel said in Bonn on Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: The Show Goes on for the Georgia Peach
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: In his later years, the great Ty Cobb came home to Georgia in a fitful attempt to find peace. Now, a drama trying to find the essence of the tempestuous Cobb has come to Georgia, too. ``Cobb,'' a look at the legend by playwright Lee Blessing, is now playing at Atlanta's Alliance Theatre, after its rookie production last year at the Yale Repertory Theatre. The play is directed by Tony winner, Lloyd Richards, named best director for the Broadway production of August Wilson's ``Fences.'' Richards is in his 11th season as artistic director of the Yale Rep; Yale's success with the work last year led Alliance officials to bring the production to Atlanta. ``It's important for me, in one sense, to take a play about Cobb and bring it down here,'' Blessing said. ``I hope Atlantans will take a look at Cobb _ who is from north Georgia, and more identified with the state than any athlete ever has been ... and recognize something in what I've created that really rings true to them.'' In getting the acclaimed play ready for the Alliance and for a run at San Diego's Old Globe Theatre later this year, Blessing has rewritten parts of the work, ``to sharpen some things up, make some arguments stronger, make some things funnier, get rid of some dead wood,'' he said. Still, the play remains a look at the tormented soul of the man known as ``The Georgia Peach,'' the record-setting batter and base-stealer who died renowned for his performance on the baseball field, but vilified and virtually friendless. ``He developed _ and earned _ a reputation as the meanest man in baseball,'' Blessing said. The audience sees four characters in argument with each other and with themselves. Three are Cobb himself: the 20-year-old Peach, just launching his fabulous career; the 40-year-old Ty, his playing days nearing an end; and the 70-year-old Mr. Cobb, four years from the grave. The fourth character is also, in a way, a part of Cobb: Oscar Charleston, a gifted and fiery ballplayer known as ``the black Cobb.'' Charleston, relegated to the Negro Leagues throughout his long career, never won the public acclaim Cobb did, never was documented statistically the way Cobb was and didn't make the Hall of Fame until 1976. And the Cobb characters, struggling to mold their myth, cannot bear to hear it. ``This play is, in every sense, a dispute,'' Blessing said. ``Cobb disputing with himself, disputing with Charleston, disputing with the audience. ``The convention of the play is that he has an interest that goes beyond the grave. He wants not only to have been in the record one of the best baseball players who ever lived, but he is still fighting for his myth. ``It's justifiable, I think, to create a play in which the myth is arguing with itself, and disputing what it is to us _ and, in a sense, pleading with us to be something better than it fears we're making it.'' Blessing, a devout follower of the game, hopes his audience will learn something about Cobb the man _ and about Oscar Charleston, too. ``I have been a baseball fan all my life, but it was only in researching this play that I even discovered the name Oscar Charleston,'' he said. ``Some of the black players still alive today would tell you he was the best player who ever lived.'' Still, the author of the Tony-nominated diplomacy drama ``A Walk in the Woods'' is a playwright, not a baseball historian. And Blessing said he has been careful to create a play with emotion, humor and something for even ``anti-baseball fans'' _ those who believe baseball fanatics probably ought to be committed. ``There's plenty here for a person who is interested in studying a human life. There's even things for people who want to be entertained _ honest,'' he said with a chuckle. Blessing called the Alliance one of the most significant theaters in the United States. And he doesn't necessarily view Atlanta as a double-A stop in the ascension to Broadway's major league. ``I've long since stopped having New York as a goal,'' he said. ``If a play goes to New York, that's fine. But for me, the Alliance is a goal. Yale was a goal. ... I'm very excited about resident theater in this country, and what it's contributed. ``I don't think a person's really a complete playwright without being in New York, in a sense, but I don't think a person's really a complete playwright without being in a resident theater.'' The Alliance presentation runs through June 3.

DOC.HEAD: Today In History
DOC.TEXT: Today is Sunday, May 20, the 140th day of 1990. There are 225 days left in the year.

Today's Highlight in History: On May 20, 1927, Charles Lindbergh took off from Roosevelt Field in Long Island, N.Y., aboard the ``Spirit of St. Louis'' on his historic solo journey to France. On this date: In 1506, Christopher Columbus died in poverty in Spain. In 1830, the first railroad timetable was published, in the newspaper ``Baltimore American.'' In 1861, North Carolina voted to secede from the Union. In 1861, the capital of the Confederacy was moved from Montgomery, Ala., to Richmond, Va. In 1902, the United States ended its occupation of Cuba. In 1926, inventor Thomas Edison expressed the view that Americans would prefer silent movies over talking pictures. In 1932, Amelia Earhart took off from Newfoundland for Ireland to become the first woman to fly solo across the Atlantic. In 1939, regular transatlantic air service began as a Pan American Airways plane, the ``Yankee Clipper,'' took off from Port Washington, N.Y., bound for Europe. In 1961, a white mob attacked a busload of ``Freedom Riders'' in Montgomery, Ala., prompting the federal government to send in U.S. marshals to restore order. In 1963, the U.S. Supreme Court set aside the convictions of 31 students arrested for staging sit-in civil-rights protests at lunch counters in fourth southern states. In 1970, some 100,000 people demonstrated in New York's Wall Street district in support of U.S. policy in Vietnam and Cambodia. In 1984, former Argentine President Isabel Peron, ousted from office by a military coup in 1976, returned to her homeland. Ten years ago: Voters in the Canadian province of Quebec voted down a pro-independence referendum. George Bush won the Michigan Republican primary, while Ronald Reagan and President Carter won primaries in Oregon. Five years ago: The FBI arrested John A. Walker Jr., who was later convicted of spying for the Soviet Union. Israel released more than 1,100 Arab prisoners in exchange for three Israeli soldiers. The United States began broadcasts to Cuba on Radio Marti. One year ago: During China's pro-democracy protests, Beijing officials ordered CBS and Cable News Network to end their live on-scene reports. Comedian Gilda Radner died in Los Angeles at age 42. Today's Birthdays: Actor James Stewart is 82. Comedian George Gobel is 71. Actress Constance Towers is 57. Singer Joe Cocker is 46. Singer-actress Cher is 44. Ron Reagan is 32. Thought for Today: ``There is a Law that man should love his neighbor as himself. In a few hundred years it should be as natural to mankind as breathing or the upright gait; but if he does not learn it he must perish.'' -- Alfred Alder, Austrian psychoanalyst (1870-1937).

DOC.TEXT: Today is Monday, May 21, the 141st day of 1990. There are 224 days left in the year.

Lindbergh covered a distance of more than 3,600 miles in 33{ hours. On this date: In 1542, Spanish explorer Hernando de Soto died while searching for gold along the Mississippi River. In 1832, the first Democratic National Convention got under way in Baltimore. The delegates would nominate President Jackson for a second term. In 1840, New Zealand was declared a British colony. In 1881, Clara Barton founded the American Red Cross. In 1919, a proposed federal amendment to give women the right to vote passed the U.S. House of Representatives by a vote of 304-to-89. In 1924, 14-year-old Bobby Franks was murdered in a ``thrill killing'' by Nathan Leopold Jr. and Richard Loeb, two students at the University of Chicago. In 1941, a German U-boat sank the American freighter SS ``Robin Moore'' in the South Atlantic. In 1948, in a message to Congress, President Truman urged statehood for Alaska. In 1956, the United States exploded the first airborne hydrogen bomb over Bikini Atoll in the Pacific. In 1959, the musical ``Gypsy,'' inspired by the life of stripper Gypsy Rose Lee, opened on Broadway with Ethel Merman in the role of Gypsy's mother, Rose. In 1968, the nuclear-powered U.S. submarine ``Scorpion,' with 99 men aboard, was last heard from. (The remains of the sub were later found on the ocean floor 400 miles southwest of the Azores.) In 1979, former San Francisco City Supervisor Dan White was convicted in the shooting deaths of Mayor George Moscone and Supervisor Harvey Milk. In 1981, Socialist Francois Mitterrand assumed office as president of France. Ten years ago: Ensign Jean Marie Butler accepted her degree and commission from the Coast Guard Academy in New London, Conn., becoming the first woman to graduate from a U.S. service academy. Five years ago: Patti Frustaci of Riverside, Calif., who was expecting septuplets, gave birth to six live babies, three of whom died in the following weeks. One year ago: Thousands of native Chinese marched in Hong Kong, Paris, Tokyo and scores of other cities in a worldwide show of support for the pro-democracy demonstrators in Beijing. Today's Birthdays: Novelist Harold Robbins is 74. Actor Raymond Burr is 73. Thought for Today: ``Ideals are like stars; you will not succeed in touching them with your hands. In 1900, the modern Associated Press, the successor to various regional news organizations bearing the AP name, was incorporated in New York as a not-for-profit news cooperative. Today's Highlight in History: On May 23, 1934, bank robbers Bonnie Parker and Clyde Barrow were shot to death in a police ambush as they rode inside a stolen Ford Deluxe on a road in Bienville Parish, La. Haldeman and John Ehrlichman and former Attorney General John N. Mitchell in connection with their Watergate cover-up convictions. DOC.HEAD: The Art of Breaking a Campaign Promise
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Campaign promises are not uttered under oath, and President Bush will not lack for company should he decide to renege on his vehement vow against new taxes. Ronald Reagan did it, on the same subject, at least a dozen times _ and all without sacrificing the impression that he was an unyielding tax cut man. Bush, of course, has not undone his read-my-lips, no-new-taxes refrain from the 1988 campaign. All he has done is to ask congressional Democrats to bargain on the budget without preconditions, a process that is to begin today. Going in without preconditions does not mean that there will be an identifiable tax increase as part of the bargain coming out; it's a good bet that in the end, the Republican White House will just say no. The reasons wouldn't have a lot to do with the sanctity of a 1988 campaign pledge. With Cold War and defense concerns ebbing, the no-tax stance may be the best issue the Republicans have going for them. Furthermore, for some conservatives it is more than an issue _ it is a policy by which they mean to starve the welfare state for funds. There is also the dilemma of a government that has run up massive deficits in boom times facing the prospect of a need for more taxes just when the economy could be slipping. Campaign pledges are another matter. They are made by the dozens, and they come with no vote-back guarantee. Dissatisfied voters can only wait until the next election, and by then, the issues may have changed and bygone promises may be forgotten. That is as old as politics. Cicero wrote about electioneering in Rome, and his guidelines still apply: ``All men have a feeling, that they would rather you told them a civil lie than give them a point-blank refusal ... If you make a promise, the thing is still uncertain, depends on a future day, and concerns but few people, but if you refuse, you alienate people to a certainty and at once, and many people, too.'' The damage depends on the issue. A promise broken by Lyndon B. Johnson was the undoing of his presidency. Campaigning in 1964, Johnson said he was not ``about to send American boys 9,000 or 10,000 miles away from home to do what Asian boys ought to be doing for themselves.'' But he did, after winning landslide election, and the Vietnam war was the burden that led him to renounce candidacy four years later. Richard M. Nixon was wily enough to leave some room for maneuver in his campaign promises. In 1968, for example, he said he would end the war and win the peace, although he didn't say how or when. It ended, but not on those terms. The last Americans withdrew from Saigon in 1975, and North Vietnam took over. Nixon, who had resigned the White House over Watergate by that time, said Congress forced the defeat by restricting and then refusing funds for the war. Jimmy Carter promised in 1976 that he'd balance the federal budget in his first term. He couldn't come close. Reagan upped that ante, saying he would balance it and cut taxes. He got the tax cut, but deficits soared. Reagan blamed it on a recession and on Congress. He made an art form of raising taxes while presenting himself as the arch-foe of tax increases. As governor of California, he said he would not tolerate a tax increase and declared his feet were planted in cement on the matter. When he had to have a tax increase anyhow, he said the sound people heard was the cement cracking. As president, he confounded the Democrats by championing one giant tax cut and then approving a series of increases. Sen. George Mitchell, D-Maine, now the majority leader, says Reagan proposed or signed 13 tax increases, ``and in the process convinced the American people that he was against all of them.'' Backing off a campaign pledge is, as Mitchell said, ``a rather commonplace occurrence in American history.'' Nixon said last week that Bush can change his position with ``no problem at all. He can say `I believed at the time, but the situation has changed and I'm dealing with it.''' That's one way to scrap a promise. In ``The Earl of Louisiana,'' A.J. Liebling recounts another, the story of a lobbyist who sought repeal of a state tax on movie tickets. He campaigned for Earl Long for governor on the strength of a promise of repeal. But when Long won, he recommended extension of the tax. ``The fellow went to see him and he said `I told my clients that you said you wanted their support and you wouldn't block removal of the tax. What do I tell them now?'' ``You know what old Earl said? ``He said `I'll tell you what to tell them. Tell them I lied.'''

DOC.HEAD: Green Acres is Back
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, ``There are ... make-believe farm,'' to CORRECT Eddie Arnold to Eddie Albert; PICKS UP 5th graf, ``Gabor _ who ... move special.''
With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Can you sing the theme to ``Green Acres?'' Do you remember Arnold the Pig? Goofy Lisa? Mr. Haney? Oliver Wendell Douglas? This Friday on CBS, they're all down on the farm again in ``Return to Green Acres,'' a made-for-TV movie with the original Hooterville cast, save one _ Hank Patterson, aka Mr. Ziffel, dad to Arnold the Pig, who died awhile back. There are three Arnold the Pigs for this production (even pigs need stand-ins), and Eddie Albert and Eva Gabor reprise their roles as a successful Manhattan lawyer and his ditzy wife. They played the characters from 1965 to 1971, when CBS ended its price supports for their make-believe farm. Gabor _ who is sixtysomething, dahling, and don't push your luck by asking what digit comes after the six _ is back on the publicity trail these days doing interviews to promote the movie special. At her Beverly Hills mansion a few days back, a reporter, a photographer, a CBS publicist and Gabor's own publicist sit downstairs waiting for Zsa Zsa's younger, ``nicer'' sister to make an entrance. ``I'm sorry I'm late,'' she says, breezing into the living room with her make-up artist trailing behind. Much discussion ensues about the best place to shoot photos. Gabor keeps up two conversations at once _ one admonishing the photographer to not get too close ``and don't shoot me from below, dahling, always shoot a woman from up high,'' and the other with her make-up artist, ``What do you think, dahling? I think they'll be OK.'' Photos done, Gabor turns her attention to the rug, where her dogs have had an accident. ``Please don't step on the wet spot,'' she says and rings for the maid to bring a towel to cover the offending dampness. The photographer leaves. The make-up artist leaves. Gabor turns her attention to the interview, with the CBS publicist taking notes. ``Here we are back again,'' she says. ``Except for `Lucy,' I don't know of any other show that's been on as much as `Green Acres.' It's on in Africa, it's everywhere.'' People recognize her no matter where she goes, she says, oftentimes mistaking her for her cop-slapping sister, Sari (aka Zsa Zsa). Being mixed up with her sister is something she has had to deal with most of her life. ``It does not help to be from a family where there is so much chaos,'' she says, and laughs. ``I walk down the street and people yell, `Hey, Zsa Zsa,' and I say, `Not Zsa Zsa _ Eva!' '' Eva has been married five times, but now is single. She owns the largest wig company in the world. She plays tennis, dines often with pal Merv Griffin and grows a bushelful of roses and orchids. She employs one secretary, two maids and five gardeners to look after her sprawling estate. ``It's a tragedy,'' she says. ``It keeps me broke.'' She was happy to do ``Green Acres'' revisited, she says. ``We are all back and kicking,'' she says. ``Pat Buttram (Mr. Haney), said, `Everyone of us is looking at the other and saying, `My God, have they got old.' Except for me, of course.'' Playing Lisa Douglas is not easy, she says. ``People think comedy is easy to do. It's not, it's harder.'' And though she loves the part, dahling, she thinks it has stereotyped her. ``Hollywood typecasts you always. It's very difficult to get out of that. I was never given a chance to do a performance where the audience can see that I'm a serious actress. I know I'm a good actress,'' she says. When she arrived here from Budapest, Gabor signed with Paramount Pictures and did two unmemorable movies _ ``Forced Landing'' in 1941 (``A B picture only to those too lazy to go down the alphabet,'' she wrote in her 1954 autobiography ``Orchids and Salami'') and 1942's ``Pacific Blackout.'' Paramount soon dropped her. Television, however, was kinder, as Gabor tackled variety shows, guest appearances and even Chekhov, co-starring with Boris Karloff in ``Uncle Vanya.'' ``I have worked since I was 16,'' she says. ``I never knew where my next meal was coming or how. Nobody ever gave me anything. They took. ``Once you do a character like Lisa Douglas, no one thinks of you as a dramatic actress.''

Elsewhere in television ... RYAN WHITE REMEMBERED: On Saturday, ABC will rebroadcast last year's docudrama ``The Ryan White Story,'' first shown in Janary 1989, depicting the true-life story of the hemophiliac teen-ager's battle to attend public school after being diagnosed with AIDS. It is being rerun to commemorate White's death on April 8 at age 18. Singer Elton John, who befriended the youngster, will read a tribute during the broadcast. ``He was the center of a storm that mingled hatred, fear and ignorance in a poisonous blend,'' John said. ``But he tolerated the venom directed at him.''
