DOC.HEAD: BC-SPECIAL EDITION
Outdoors: Boating Safety
LaserPhotos NY700, NY701, NY702
DOC.TEXT: Boating is getting safer, in part because of the war against drinking while boating, but many, many more lives would be saved if people wore life vests while on the water. When you're in the water, it's too late to look under the seat and find a life vest. Figures from the National Marine Manufacturers Association show that while the number of boats increased from 9.6 million in 1973, when a record high of 1,754 fatalities was recorded, to 17.3 million in 1988, only 946 people died in boating accidents in 1988. That's a fatality rate of 5.5 deaths per 100,000 boats in 1988. ``Public opinion is turning against drinking and driving,'' says Capt. Bill Griswold, chief of the Coast Guard Auxiliary's Boating and Consumer Affairs Division. ``We will continue to educate the public about the dangers of boating and drinking.'' He said 50 percent of all boating fatalities are alcohol related. More and more states are recognizing the problem and passing ``boating while intoxicated'' laws. Whether or not a person is intoxicated, four out of every five boating deaths is by drowning. Federal law now requires that every boat carry one personal flotation device per passenger. Many fishing tournaments, such as those run by the Bass Anglers Sportsman Society, require that not only must each contestant wear a PFD while the boat is running on its outboard motor, but that the driver's jacket be hooked to an ignition kill switch. A kill switch shuts off the engine if the driver is thrown overboard. That means the boat is still in the area if the victim can swim back to it. Despite those examples, ``most people simply do not believe anything will happen to them'' and do not wear their PFDs, according to NMMA. But all it takes is a bump on the head, or the shock of hitting cold water to render a person helpless for a few minutes, and by that time the victim may be a fatality statistic. Makers of PFDs have realized that making a better looking, more comfortable PFD is a key to getting people to wear them. In addition to making a wide variety of PFDs for specific purposes, such as water skiing or kayaking, they come in varieties of colors and patterns and are lighter and more comfortable. PFDs for fishermen are being made with numerous pockets for lures or other tackle. The Coast Guard has adopted five categories of PFDs. Here's a rundown to help you decide which you want in your boat: _ Offshore life jacket: Best for open, rough or remote waters where someone overboard may be in the water a while. It will turn an unconscious person face up in the water. It's drawback is it can be a bulky unit. _ Near-shore life vest: Best suited for boating in calm, inland waters where a victim will be picked up quickly. It's more comfortable, but will not necessarily turn over a person face down in the water. _ Flotation aid: A lighter and more comfortable vest for use where there will be help on the scene fast. It's the most popular type of life vest, but it will not necessarily turn over a face-down victim. _ Throwable device: This is not recommended for children and non-swimmers. It can be a cushion, ring, buoy or any device that will keep afloat someone who can hang onto it. _ Special use device: These are legal for only special uses. They are inflatables, or combinations of permanent and inflatable flotation. When inflated they provide the same buoyancy as an offshore jacket, but are less reliable because they have to be inflated and can be punctured, rendering them useless.

DOC.HEAD: BC-SPECIAL EDITION
Outdoors: Hall of Fame
LaserPhotos NY703, NY704, NY705
DOC.TEXT: Thirty years ago, Bob Kutz had a dream. He wanted to create a museum to show off the achievements of sport fishermen and to keep records of those achievements. Today, the National Freshwater Fishing Hall of Fame's record book, the 1990 edition published in April, contains thousands of records for 125 species of freshwater fish. Its awards program makes it possible for the average angler to hold a certified world record. The program includes world records in five categories: rod-reel, ice fishing, pole-line-no reel, fly fishing and miscellaneous methods and state records for the United States. ``It's taken a lot of work by mostly a lot of volunteers over the years,'' says Ted Dzialo, who has taken over as director. Kutz remains active as public affairs director. His wife, Fannie Kutz, continues as business manager. The hall is centered in a 7-acre complex of museum buildings and fishing offices in Hayward, Wis. Its symbol is a 4{-story tall, city-block long walkthrough fiberglass muskellunge. It's open jaw is an observation platform that can hold 30 people. The museum attracts more than 100,000 visitors per year. Its displays range from a 150-year-old Chippewa Indian birchbark canoe to 300 classic and antique outboard motors. In addition to prize mounts of freshwater fish, there are thousands of lures, rods, reels and accessories on display in the museum. Pools at the museum are used for children's fishing contests. ``We wanted something which would be pleasant to visit and yet have all the information to tell the story of sport fishing,'' Dzialo says. Its records program is probably its best known ``and there still are a lot of open places there,'' he says. The rod-reel division is broken down into line classes by the test-strength of line. The bigger the fish the more line classes for the species. Fly fishing also is broken down into line classes. There are no line classes for what in essence is cane pole fishing. In the ice fishing category there are records for pole-line and tipup fishing. Proper records and photographs are essential for having a potential record certified, Dzialo says. Here are some tips for would-be record holders. First, if you have a big fish on, land it yourself. Don't let someone else touch the line. You may have someone net or gaff the fish. Get the fish to a certified scale as soon as possible. These scales, used for trade, have a seal showing the last time it was inspected. Weigh the fish in front of two witnesses _ not your fishing companions _ and get their names, addresses and signatures. Measure the girth, fork length and total length of the fish. Make pictures. Color pictures are best. Hold the fish broadside for positive identification. One trick is to lay it next to a yardstick. If it's a picture of you holding the fish, get the camera in close, so the fish is easily seen. They want to see the fish, not your feet. Have a fisheries biologist identify the fish and give you a short, written, signed report. Freeze the fish. It won't hurt it when it comes time to mount your trophy. Save the first 25 feet of line, from the hook or lure, to be sent with your application. For fly fishing, save about 15 inches of the tippet, leaving the fly or hook attached. This is so the line can be tested to see if it is in the line class where you claim your record. (To get a world record application write or call the National Fresh Water Fishing Hall of Fame, Box 33, Hall of Fame Drive, Hayward, Wis. 53843. Phone 715-634-4440.)

DOC.HEAD: BC-SPECIAL EDITION
Outdoors: Fishing Lures
LaserPhoto NY706
DOC.TEXT: A fisherman can spend a good deal of time pondering the impressive display of baits at a major sporting goods store, trying to decide what to buy to fill the tackle box. At today's prices, you can spend the proceeds of a winning state lottery ticket buying fishing lures. The best advice is to buy a couple of several varieties, try them, and then buy more colors and types of what works for you. This is a rundown of some basic types of lures, to use as a guide. You may want to try some or all of them. The most common bait is the plastic worm. It also is about the cheapest. It's most commonly used for bass, but is effective for other species, such as walleye. Pick out several colors. Get a couple packs of dark-colored ones, such as black, purple or motor oil, a couple with two colors and couple with sparkles. The most effective color usually is determined by the color and clarity of the water you're fishing, so variety allows experimentation. Crankbait is a generic type word used to cover a variety of lures. There are several varieties. Most use a plastic lip to make them wobble and throb in the water. The one that doesn't is a stickbait. It floats and you must impart action to it by wiggling, jerking or twitching your rod tip. Then come surface baits or shallow divers. They have small lips which either impart wobble or pull them slightly below the surface. For diving crankbaits, the size of the plastic lip usually determines the depth at which the lure will run. The bigger the lip, the deeper the dive. The deep-divers are designed to be worked along the bottom, digging into the mud and bouncing off branches. Most of these baits will float, so start the retrieve with very fast turns on the reel to get them to working depth, then slow them down. When they strike an underwater obstacle, lower your rod tip to give them slack and usually they will float free. Another variety of crankbaits are the lipless, plastic ones which use the top of the lure to impart diving action. These dive to a variety of depths and often include rattles to add noise to the vibrations designed to attract fish. One last variety of crankbaits are the poppers and chuggers. They have concave faces or very wide lips and are designed to bubble and gurgle when retrieved, usually in short jerks. They stay on top of the water and are best fished at dusk, dark and dawn, imitating frogs. Spinnerbaits are about the most versatile lures around. They can be fished on top or on the bottom, at almost any depth. They come in a wide variety of colors and blade combinations. They can be pitched right up against the bank and retrieved, surviving in places most other lures would hang up. Generally, the larger the blade, the slower a spinnerbait can be worked through the water and still stay on top. Their cousins, the buzzbaits, are designed almost entirely for topwater use, and are best fished in low-light conditions. Spoons and jigs are a unique class of lures in that most can be fished straight up and down. Some spoons can be retrieved horizontally, but most are designed to be fished up and down with a flick of the wrist, imitating a dying baitfish falling from above. Some jigs, hooks with a lead head and maybe a bit of skirt attached, also have a flashing spinner and are designed to be fished naked. Others are designed to be hooked through a second bait. These lures are especially effective in colder water. Spinners are a combination of a hook or hooks, a spinner, possibly a bit of deer hair or rubber and a blade to flash. They come in all sizes, from tiny ones to take trout and bluegills, to sizes that look like dangerous weapons, designed for muskellunge. One more thing: Be sure put get some plain, ordinary hooks, several sizes, from 2-0 for large bass, walleye or pike, to about a No. 8 for small panfish. With hooks in your tacklebox, you can always buy a few minnows, crickets or worms and be reasonably sure you will at least catch a mess of bluegills for an excellent dinner.

DOC.HEAD: BC-SPECIAL EDITION
Outdoors: Bass Bugging
LaserPhoto NY707
DOC.TEXT: For bass bugs, hair is now. The noble art of bugging for bass with a fly rod has been dominated by bugs of cork, balsa and plastics since the 19th century. Today, bugs of hair and feathers are making inroads on the hardbody fish foolers. They come closer to looking alive than the standards of the past. Since they are soft, the fish take a millisecond or so more to catch on to the fact they are eating something that just ain't for real. Of course, there are the tried and true flyrod teasers, like the redoubtable ``Harry Mary'' and the upscale minnow imitations like the ``Mudlerminnow.'' But the hair bugs of today will go well past those. In addition to hair poppers that are in the same body style as the bugs of yore, that pop and gurgle as they are jerked, slid or pulled across the surface, you can now dig a bit deeper in the water with a diver which on retrieve plunks and submarines an inch or so below the surface and zooms up like a wounded baitfish. Some have even fashioned frogs that have legs and wiggle like they are alive. Hair is, at least for three-thumbed tiers like myself, easier to shape than balsa or cork. Colors run the full spectrum. One of the top sellers is the deer hair version of the always popular ``Bumblebee Bug.'' A bass rig flyrod will be from 8 feet to 9 feet. Any more length puts in the class with Ma Bell timbers. The line should be in the 8-to10-weight class. Some folks say they can use their midsize trout gear, but they must lift weights. Casting technique has to be modified a bit to throw the larger bugs. The leader, generally seven feet will work, needs to be very stiff at the butt and again rather stiff at the tippet. Using the one-foot Orvis braided leader link, taper it down from 30 lbs. to 20 lbs. Then a tippet of 10 lbs. or 15 lbs., depending on the cover you are fishing. Fish caught on bugs, as with flies, are usually lip hooked so it is easy to unhook and release them without damaging them. Though a beam will get very ambitions every now and then, the large size of the real bass bugs, size 1 to 2 in most cases, will keep most of the panfish intimidated and off your hook. The sound of a bass clobbering your bug is much like that of an icebox hitting the water after a two-story fall. It can be unnerving in the daylight and absolutely terrifying at night. If the bass is a jumper, the hair bug will be harder to throw than the hardbody type because it is lighter. The lightness of the hair bug also helps in casting. Bass don't make long runs like trout and saltwater fish, but they bulldog down and then jump and tailwalk about, giving the angler as much sport as you can get doing anything you let other people watch you doing. Try it!

DOC.HEAD: BC-SPECIAL EDITION
Outdoors: Skunk Trapper
LaserPhoto NY708
DOC.TEXT: When her husband suggested the family could use more cash, Janice Henke got herself a job _ trapping skunks. ``When I come in from an unsuccessful skunk expedition, my husband won't let me come in the house unless I take off every stitch, including my sneakers, and hang them in the tree,'' says Mrs. Henke, who lives far enough outside of Glens Falls, N.Y., that there are no neighbors nearby. Then it's into a shower and ``I leave my clothes outside for a week or so.'' Most of the skunks live through the ordeal and only about one in 20 takes a shot at her with its personal perfume, she says. As both a licensed wildlife rehabilitator and licensed nuisance wildlife agent, she must first decide which situation applies when a potential customer calls. ``You have to decide who's distressed. Is it the people or the creature?'' she says. ``Generally, it's the people.'' The animal is in distress if it can't get away. If the animal could leave if it wanted to, but doesn't care to just now, it's the people who are in distress. If it's the people who are distressed, the cost is $25 per skunk. Normally, it's a simple matter of setting a box trap outside the hole the skunk is using to get under a building or through a fence. But there are exceptions. ``The lady called me in a panic because, she said, `there's a skunk in my washing machine,''' Mrs. Henke says. ``I'd never had that before.'' The skunk apparently fell into the machine after climbing through a basement window broken by the woman's children. Skunks are a major problem in upstate New York where they are attracted to man's warm dwellings and groomed lawns,'' said Mrs. Henke in an interview during this year's North American Wildlife and Natural Resources Conference in Denver. She is a lobbyist for the National Trappers Association and executive vice president of Furbearers Unlimited. As winter approaches, skunks begin to den up and sometimes a dozen or more will hole up under a house or mobile home. Disputes among skunks are settled in a manner that leaves a very unpleasant aroma for the homeowner above. Mrs. Henke uses a wire box trap, ``which is pretty good sized, so when the animal considers entering it, it won't touch his sides or back. I used a Twix bar for bait, caramel flavor.'' Next morning, if the homeowner finds an occupied trap ``I'll come with my skunk blanket.'' It's an ``old yellow blanket'' with a hole in it so she can watch the animal while she moves up on it, holding the blanket up so it can't see a human. Some skunks react aggressively to the approaching blanket, stamping their front paws. She waits, then lowers the blanket over the cage, ``figuring if he's going to spray he's going to do it now or never.'' Then she wraps the cage in the blanket, places the package in the back of the pickup truck and takes it to a spot on state land where ``hopefully there aren't any houses around.'' ``Then I uncover the end of the cage, remove the door, and if he doesn't come out by himself, I pick the cage up and give him a heave-ho, and he rolls over and gets up and trundles off through the woods.'' While buildings, with such things as warm water pipes, are a source of comfort, lawns are a source of food. Lawns are full of grubs, primarily the larvae of June bugs and Japanese beetles, she says. ``They hunt those by smell and they dig and it looks like a lawn has been ravaged by a pick of hogs if the skunk has been really industrious,'' she says. Then, it's time for the wire trap and old yellow blanket.

DOC.HEAD: BC_SPECIAL EDITION
Outdoors: Director
DOC.TEXT: The director of the U.S. Fish and Wildlife service sees the challenge of the '90s as a balancing act between traditional supporters and new constituencies _ with heavy burdens on the scales. ``We're not primarily a recreation agency, but I do see us needing to broaden our mission,'' to provide visitor recreation on the nation's 450 national wildlife refuges, John Turner says. ``But we do need to continue to support the resources and the users that are the backbone of the agency with their dollars and their years of effort, and that's the hunters and fishermen,'' he says. ``Obviously, the interests of this society are expanding to non-consumptive uses and more total use of wildlife and we need to expand our programs to meet those growing needs.'' Turner, a Wyoming legislator since 1970 and operator of a guide-outfitter service, was confirmed by the Senate July 31. He is in charge of managing the country's 93 million acres of wildlife refuges at a time when ``the complexity of the issues facing wildlife at times seems overwhelming,'' but also at a time ``when the polls show the people have never had a greater interest in wildlife.'' ``This is a time of great opportunity to do things for diverse life forms, for habitat, which I think is part of America's roots.'' ``Our main focus has got to be the wild critters and the habitats that are entrusted to us and that gives us a full platter,'' Turner says. During an interview at the North American Wildlife and Natural Resources Conference, Turner talked about his vision for the refuge system. He says he wants to expand Americans' interest in the total value of wildlife. ``I'm really concerned about the future of the consumptive users,'' hunters and anglers, he says. ``We need to teach kids how to fish and we're failing in the mission. We need to try to bring kids, especially minorities, into the out of doors.'' ``We need to relate to blacks and kids out of the urban areas. We're used to relating to a white population,'' he says. He is worried about the anti-hunting movement. ``I welcome their concern for wildlife, but their energies, they're so misdirected and self-destructive. We ought to all be working for the welfare of wildlife and habitat. ``We ought to be joining forces and save for later the question of what to do with the surpluses and how to manage non-game populations. (The anti-hunting movement) is just terrible destructive, perhaps the most destructive part of the conservation movement today,'' he says. Turner also said he wants to see business and the private landowner in the conservation movement. ``Their good will is going to be essential to the enhancement of the resource and we haven't always done a good job of earning it,'' he said. ``I see new opportunities to join hands with these private landowners. That is going to be the key to whether or not we succeed.''

DOC.HEAD: BC-SPECIAL EDITION
Outdoors: Loon
LaserPhoto NY709
DOC.TEXT: The loon is a quick change artist, switching from its drab, smoky-gray color of winter for much more formal dress, complete with necklace and sequins for summer in the north. Its haunting, penetrating call brings a vision of North America's wilderness to those lucky enough to hear it. ``The loon is associated with beautiful, pristine settings; natural lakes that aren't denigrated by pollution,'' says Carroll L. Henderson, nongame wildlife supervisor with the Department of Natural Resources in Minnesota, which is home to the largest loon population in the 48 states. About 12,000 loons nest in Minnesota. The loon needs the clear, clean waters of remote lakes because ``they depend on eyesight to catch fish under water,'' Henderson says. Introduction of carp into clear waters has hurt the bird because the fish's grubbing along the bottom makes the water turbid. Its eyes are red because of a special filter to provide better underwater vision. A tough, aggressive bird when it comes to protecting its nest from wolves or other predators, the loon has enough size to deter many animals seeking a meal. The common loon, the only one of four North American species that nests in the United States, weighs 8 to 12 pounds, three times the weight of a Mallard duck. Its body is three feet long and it has a wingspan of five feet. ``But they're set so low in the water, people don't realize they're that big,'' Henderson says. The reason they sit so low in the water is their bone structure, which helps make them superb swimmers and fish catchers _ but also makes takeoffs difficult, if not downright hazardous. Loons' bones are more dense than those of most other birds, which makes them heavier. Because of the weight, they can dive to depths of 200 feet and remain submerged several minutes. The same powerful legs which make them such good swimmers are a handicap on land. The legs are set far back on the body, behind the balance point, so a loon has difficulty walking. Because of its weight, a loon needs at least 75 feet, and often as much as two football fields, depending on weather and wind direction, for a running, flapping, splashing takeoff. Once airborne, it can reach speeds of 75 mph. Its landing style also is different. Most water birds land with their bodies at an up angle, their webbed feet outstretched to hit the water like skis. A loon hits low and hard, pounding into the water on its breast.

DOC.HEAD: BC-SPECIAL EDITION
Outdoors: Knives
DOC.TEXT: A dull knife is dangerous! ``When your knife isn't sharp, you pull, tug, try to force it and sooner or later it's going to slip,'' says Peter Kuhn, a knife expert with Lansky Sharpeners of Buffalo, N.Y. ``That's when you get hurt.'' For years, man got sharp edges by chipping flakes of a flint or other crystallized stone, which often produces edges of razor sharpness. More recently, metal blades have been sharpened by drawing a stone across the blade or drawing the blade across a stone. The critical things for sharpening a knife is the angle at which the knife and stone meet _ and that that exact angle be maintained through the sharpening process. Changing the angle even a few degrees will lead to rolling the edge and reducing sharpness. There are many types of sharpening stones. Like sandpaper, they range from coarse _ for removing a lot of metal in a hurry _ to ultra-fine for putting the finishing polish on an edge. All should be held at the same angle to the edge. The Lansky system solves the problem of exact angle, as do other systems, by holding the blade in a jig or vice. The sharpening stones, which come in several degrees of fineness, attach to a guide rod which feeds through a hole in the jig. The rod keeps the stone at the same angle to the blade, stroke after stroke. The jig provides angles of 30, 25, 20 or 17 degrees, ``but you really don't need the 17 degrees for a knife, that's like a razor,'' Kuhn says. He says a 25 degree angle on a blade is about the best for a quality knife that needs a good working edge. It takes a little time to work a very dull blade to brilliant sharpness and, obviously, longer blades take more time than short ones. A jig may have to be moved on the blade of a long hip knife. It's best to use a jig mounted on a workbench or table top to begin work on a dull blade. That way you have both hands free to work the sharpening stone. But once you get a sharp edge on your knife, unless you abuse it, it will take only a few strokes occasionally on a pair of sharpening roads, or a folding V-sharpener to get the edge back in mint condition.

DOC.HEAD: SPECIAL EDITION
Outdoors: Lyme Disease
DOC.TEXT: Anyone venturing outdoors this summer should be careful of a new disease that's causing ripples of worry among outdoor sportsmen. The ailment is Lyme disease, so named because it was identified in 1975 near Old Lyme, Conn. The real culprit was the tickborne infection. There is no vaccination or cure, so the keys to fighting the disease are insect repellents and poisons. Tests conducted by research entomologist Carl Schreck of the U.S. Department of Agriculture found properly used repellents provided 80 percent to 90 percent protection against ticks. The Atlanta-based national Centers for Disease Control reported 6,000 cases of Lyme disease in 1988, the last year for which figures were available, double the number in 1987. It was reported in 43 states. Symptoms are similar to many other illness, low grade fever, fatigue, head and body pain. The tick bite itself usually is unnoticed. But within a month of being bitten, a red rash appears around the bite on about two-thirds of those bitten. Sometimes it is solid, but usually it has a brighter outer edge and little or no color in the middle. Although it can vary greatly in size, up to coverage of a whole arm or thigh, it usually is about 4 inches in diameter. The rash is a signal to get to a doctor for help. A blood test usually will confirm the disease by detecting the antibodies the body's immune system is turning out to fight it. It can take two months or more for those antibodies to show up, so a test after the first couple of weeks usually produces a false reading. There are two ways to get the disease _ by going into areas infected with disease-carrying ticks, or having pets go into those areas and bring the ticks to you. Use tick sprays, dips, powders and collars to help your pet avoid tick bites. Proper clothing and repellents can provide nearly complete protection when outdoors. Wear long-sleeved shirts and long pants when outdoors where they may be ticks. Tuck pants into high socks to keep ticks from crawling into clothing. Keep your boots or shoes laced up. Wear a hat. Wear light-colored clothing, making it easier to spot a tick before it crawls through a buttonhole. Tightly woven fabrics are harder for ticks to climb. Collared shirts help keep ticks from climbing up onto your neck. Two types of products add to your armor. First is an insecticide, such as permethrin, which is designed to be sprayed on clothing _ not your skin. Second is a repellent containing deet (diethyl-meta-toluamide) which can be sprayed on clothing or directly on exposed skin. Spray clothing thoroughly, especially around places like laces in boots, at the top of boots, or where pants go into socks, places where ticks may find entry between layers of clothing. Check your clothing and your body after an outing. A tick is no larger than a good-size pinhead and can be very difficult to spot. If you find a tick attached to your skin, don't try any of the old wives tales about removing ticks with a lighted cigaret or anything else. That may cause the tick to regurgitate fluid into the bite. Use a fine-jawed tweezers to grab the tick as close to your skin as possible and slowly pull it straight out. Do not squeeze the tick's body. That simply injects its fluids into the bite.

DOC.HEAD: BC-SPECIAL EDITION
Outdoors: Manatee
DOC.TEXT: The 1980s ended as a disaster for the West Indian manatee. A record 174 of the huge, endangered mammals were found dead in the United States last year, primarily because they were struck by boats and barges in Florida waters, according to the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service's regional office in Atlanta. So far, 1990 is even worse for the sea cows. A record 74 manatee deaths were reported in January alone, most of that due to the ``Christmas freeze'' that sent temperatures plunging in north Florida. The service has been studying manatee deaths since 1974. The FWS said there were 510 deaths in those 15 years for which a cause could be found. Of that number, 418 were attributed to the animals being struck by boats or barges. Seventy-eight died when they were crushed or drowned in floodgates of locks in canals and 50 were killed by humans. Some were shot, others caught in fishing nets or lines. The population was estimated at 1,000 animals in 1980, and aerial surveys of warm-water refuges in December found 1,200 individuals. The manatee has been around for 60 million years, evolving from four-footed animals about the time the dinosaurs were on their last legs. Because of the deaths in 1989, the state of Florida proposed stringent new measures to help protect them. The measures include establishment of manatee protection plans in those Florida counties that had the highest rates of boat-manatee collisions last year. They also call for creation of new manatee protection zones, where boats may travel only at reduced speeds to help prevent collisions, and controlling expansion of new boating facilities in areas inhabited by manatees. The state also is planning stepped up enforcement of all laws to protect the species. The big, slow moving animals simply can't get out of the way of fast boats. The animals, which can reach a length in excess of 10 feet and a weight of more than 1,000 pounds, lounge in rivers and canals feeding on plants. Although they do move out into salt water, they spend most of their lives in fresh water. They winter in warm water areas, such as springs, and have found new habitat in the warm-water discharges of power plants as far north as south Georgia. Crystal River National Wildlife Refuge on Florida's Gulf Coast was established as a haven for manatees. Merritt Island National Wildlife Refuge on the Atlantic Coast also has areas closed for manatee protection.

DOC.HEAD: SPECIAL EDITION
Outdoors: Fish Bells
LaserPhoto NY710
DOC.TEXT: Think you've heard all the fish stories? As this one is told, the shad, a most sensitive fish, was terrified at storms and troubled waters, and delighted in quiet and musical sounds. So, some wise old German fishermen hooked some wood to their nets and hung a number of small bells on them. When the nets moved, the bells chimed in harmony and the fish were lured to their destructions. The story comes from Terry Mayer, a designer of bell jewelry and a bell hobbyist. She's designed a fish bell, introduced by Cartier's in 1980, as well as a whale bell in sterling silver and a fish whistle-bell, among others. In researching styles for her fish bells, she found references to bells ringing in markets in ancient Greece to announce the arrival of a fresh catch and ancient Indian Ocean sailors ringing bells through the dark night to frighten away ``monster'' fish. She notes the connection between fish and bells in many other nations. In Japan, for instance, the carp is the national emblem of boyhood, the symbol for swimming courageously against the stream of life. Wind-bells with brass pendant carps were formerly used in celebrations of Children's Day thoughout the Far East and bronze carp bells are given to boys today as a revered toy. In Italy, some fishermen hook a bell to the fishing pole to alert them to a bite and in India, brass bells in teardrop shapes are called ``fishing bells.''

DOC.HEAD: SPECIAL EDITION
Outdoors: Living
DOC.TEXT: Americans seem be spending more time outdoors lately, including entertaining outdoors. In a recent survey, 73 percent said their families have become more interested in spending time outdoors at their home since 1986 and half of the respondents said they are spending more time entertaining outdoors. The survey was conducted by the Better Homes and Gardens Consumer Panel. As a result of the outdoors interest, says John Cashmore, Weyerhauser LifeWood program manager, Americans are also looking more at new products for their outdoor environments. He says outdoor millwork products for building decks and high-tech, low-voltage lighting fixtures are among the products gaining new interest. The new outdoor millwork products, Cashmore says, offer consumers more variety than dimensional lumber _ decorative spindles and railings, lattice panels, turned finials and posts with notches and grooves for easier assembling. Technological advancements in low-voltage outdoor lighting also have expanded the number of fixture styles available. ``We know people are doing more outdoor dining, lounging and entertaining,'' says Tom Swain, Toro lighting marketing manager. ``So it only makes sense that the dinner parties may continue after sunset. The night is a much friendlier place if it's tamed by lights.'' The Better Homes and Gardens Consumer Panel survey said 60 percent found ``lightscaping'' their deck and yard with low-voltage lighting of interest to them. The survey also said 74 percent would build their outdoor project themselves.

DOC.HEAD: SPECIAL EDITION
Outdoors: Tennis
DOC.TEXT: The ball is back in play at the court, according to a survey sponsored by the American Tennis Industry Federation. More than 20 million Americans over 12 years old played tennis in 1988, and a steady core of enthusiasts play regularly, according to the survey, conducted by Audits and Surveys, a public opinion firm that projected the figures from a sample of 4,000 households. ``Tennis participation boomed in the 1970s, then declined,'' says Brad Patterson, the ATIF's executive director. ``We believe the decline bottomed out in the mid-1980s and that participation has been growing ever since.'' Thirty-eight percent of all players say they played more in 1988 than in the year before, while 27 percent say they played less. Fifty-seven percent said they would like to have played more and 39 percent say they plan to play more this year, compared to 13 percent who plan to play less. ``These positive attitudes are one indication that the sport is in good health,'' says Patterson. The sampling indicates that most people who play tennis do so because they think it's good exercise (61 percent). Competition was important to 32 percent, followed by fun (22 percent) and the social aspect (14 percent). Only 23 percent participated in organized match play, and 30 percent of the players say they keep score less than half the time. ATIF represents 112 manufacturers, distributors and importers of tennis products.

DOC.HEAD: SPECIAL EDITION
Outdoors: Quarter Horses
DOC.TEXT: American quarter horses are status symbols overseas, and exports in 1989 rose 22.3 percent over the previous year, reports the American Quarter Horse Association. The first three months of l990 show an additional 7 percent increase, the association says. ``They (foreigners) come to America to buy because we know how to breed. Although they have good breeding stock, they don't utilize it because they don't know how,'' says Carol Rose, owner of the American Quarter Horse Ranch in Gainesville, Texas. ``The American qaurter horse is more versatile compared to other breeds. They are easier to ride and have a much calmer temper. They are a pleasure horse.'' The Germans and Japanese are among the best customers for the horses, according to the association. Bob Crosthwaite, president of a Seattle horse-exporting company, regularly sends quarter horses for use in El Rancho Grande, Japan's first dude ranch, which opened in 1975. ``It's a fad over there,'' he says. ``They are into the Western way of life. People want to get on a horse who have never even seen a horse.'' Exporting is time-consuming and expensive. Quarantines of about two weeks, with tests and vaccinations, are monitored by the U. S. Department of Agriculture, says David Harpman, a veterinarian who specializes in exporting horses from Houston for several Texas breeders. During that period, a travel agent arranges the flight and shipping stall. Once the horse arrives in its destination country it is usually quarantined again, with the owner responsible for the cost. ``Each country has different regulations for which the owner must be responsible,'' Harpman says. ``This can be a costly fee for the buyer. The shipping alone can cost as much as $3,000.''

DOC.HEAD: SPECIAL EDITION
Outdoors: Eating Out
DOC.TEXT: If you dine out under the sky during the summer, take extra precautions to avoid food poisoning. ``Between 20 and 80 million people, or up to a third of the population, suffer from food poisoning each year,'' says Kay Stanfill, assistant professor of clinical dietetics at the University of Oklahoma Health Services Center. She rates the hazards of bacterial contamination a far greater threat to food than pesticides. Picnickers should be wary of undercooked or raw meat, poultry, eggs or fish _ prime areas for the growth of salmonella, she points out. Raw eggs that are cracked should never be used, and meats such a poultry and fish should always be thoroughly cooked. Chicken on the rotisserie is done when you cut into it and ``there are no pink juices running from the drumstick, which is the part that cooks the slowest,'' Stanfill says. ``Pork also should be well done and not have any pink juices running from it.'' Beef can be cooked rare, but she advises eating it soon after. Food poisoning victims can suffer diarrhea, fever and vomiting lasting two to seven days, beginning any time from 12 to 36 hours after they eat contaminated food, Stanfill says. ``It might be so mild that they wouldn't even know they had it, but it can escalate up to being fatal.'' She cites the United States Department of Agriculture's ``Seven Commandments of Food Safety'': _ Wash hands before handlng food. _ Keep it safe _ refrigerate. _ Don't thaw frozen food on the kitchen counter. Use the refrigerator. _ Wash hands, utensils and surfaces again after contact with raw meat and poultry. _ Never leaver perishable food out longer than two hours. _ Thoroughly cook raw meat, poultry and fish. _ Freeze or refrigerate leftovers promptly. Stanfill adds that you should be sure you are cooking food long enough in the microwave and not serving undercooked food that may look done but isn't.

DOC.HEAD: BC-SPECIAL EDITION
Outdoors: Briefs
DOC.TEXT: The Texas Parks and Wildlife Commission, which oversees a park system used by 21 million people a year, offers some suggestions to make your picnic more friendly to the environment. _ Use biodegradable paper plates _ not plastic. Even better, take washable plates, cups and silverware which you re-use. _ Pack sandwiches in biodegradable waxed paper, or re-usable containers you take with you. _ If you bring soap, make sure it is low-phosphate and biodegradable. _ Pack a paper sack for your trash and put it all in the garbage can. _ Take empty aluminum cans back home and sell them to a recycling center. _ Use cloth napkins and table covers instead of paper throwaways. _ Use cleaning cloths instead of paper towels. _ Be especially careful with six-pack rings that hold beer of soda cans together _ they can be a real disaster for birds and marine life. They are practically invisible in the water and birds and fish get caught in them and die. If you use them, cut the rings before you throw them in the trash. If you see any six-pack rings somebody has used to trash the environment, pick them up and put them in a garbage can.

Nearly 32 million sets of footprints were laid down on the 3,100 miles of abandoned railroad corridors converted to trails, the Rails to Trails Conservancy says. ``If these miles of trails were connected, they would stretch all the way from Boston to Los Angeles,'' says Peter Harnik, RTC's director of programs. There are 242 rail-trails in 34 states. An additional 200 to 300 corridors are in some stage of being converted from railroad to trail. Wisconsin has the most rail-trail miles, 466.3. California and Washington each have the most trails, 22 apiece. The longest trail is 145 miles, Washington's John Payne Pioneer Trail.

The federal government provided the states with $297 million this year to help finance fish and wildlife restoration programs. The money came from federal excise taxes on firearms, ammunition, fishing tackle; import duties on fishing tackle and pleasure boats and some of the motorboat fuel tax. Distribution of sport fish restoration funds is based on a formula which considers the number of license holders and a state's size and population. The largest chunk of wildlife restoration and hunter education money, $5.45 million, went to Texas. California, Michigan and Pennsylvania each got more than $4 million. The smallest amounts, $689,500, went to Delaware, Rhode Island, New Hampshire, Hawaii and Vermont, among the states. Alaska, California and Texas got the largest amount of fisheries money, $8.99 million, followed by Michigan, $7.2 million, Minnesota, $6.5 million and Wisconsin $6.1 million. Every state got at least $1.78 million.

You don't have to see an animal to know there's been one in the area. There are five basic types of signs most animals leave behind and a sharp-eyed observer can find them and learn from the clues they provide. The first is tracks. In sand or mud, any animal will portray its presence. The second is scats, or droppings. Not only can they be identified by species, and sometimes by male or female of the species, but scientists analyze them to tell what foods the animals ar using. Plant-eating animals leave their marks. Whitetail deer, which have no upper incisor teeth, leave a ragged edge on the stems of plants they break off. The head of a catfish lying on the bank often means an otter recently dined. Rotted logs that have been torn up often are the remains of a restaurant where skunks or foxes dug out grubs. Construction signs are among the most obvious. Beavers build dams. Most birds and squirrels build nests. Many animals excavate dens. Animals often leave bits of themselves behind. That includes a bird's feather, a snake's skin or the antlers of deer, elk or moose. Animals hairs caught on branches or around holes in trees tell of the animals using them. An experienced sign reader can be your guide. There are several good field guides available to help the beginner interpret what he sees during a walk in the woods.

Those rugged mountain bikes can take you places you can't get on foot or by car, but some expertise is needed to get the best out of them. Mount Snow in Vermont offers weekend instruction for these doughty two-wheelers throughout the summer. If you're a beginner, you will learn shifting, balance, weight transfer and body position. If you're experienced, you will move on to log jumping, stream crossing and technical maneuvers. Clinics on bike maintenance, repair and map reading also are included. Classes take place on the 140-mile trail network in the Green Mountain National Forest, and participants can use the trail system for add-on days after the classes. Bikers can bring their own machines or rent from the school. For more information about classes and costs, call 1-800-451-4211.

Outdoor summer fun for many is following the bouncing ball. But this is no ordinary ball; it's a balloon in a sack. The balloon ball, called Balzac, is created by blowing up a regular balloon inside a washable cotton sack. It can be folded up and stuffed into a pocket, packed in a knapsack or thrown in a saddle bag. After a day of play, the balloon can be popped and the cotton sack thrown into the washing machine.

The outdoor gourmet has a help in ``The AYH Outdoor Food Book,'' distributed by the Pittsburgh council of the American Youth Hostels. The paperback contains recipes, menus and suggestions from experienced trip leaders, the council says. There are sections with recipes covering all meals and snacks made outdoors, and the book also offers advice about gadgets, utensils, stove data, and how to pre-measure and pre-bag foods at home. The book costs $3 plus 82 cents postage from the council's publication department, 6300 Fifth Avenue, Pittsburgh, Pa. 15232. Proceeds will benefit hostel development.

``Outdoor Woman'' is the title of a new newsletter about hiking, fishing, camping and other open-air activities for women. Editor Patricia Hubbard says the publication is ``for women who want to preserve our environment and experience the joy of playing outdoors.'' For more information, call 914-358-1257.

DOC.NOTE: $adv17
For release Thursday, May 17, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Heart Resuscitation in Nursing Homes Works Only Rarely, Study Says
DOC.TEXT: Nursing home residents whose hearts have stopped are so rarely helped by cardiopulmonary resuscitation that perhaps homes should not even offer to try it, researchers suggest. Failing that policy change, residents who want to avoid resuscitation should get their doctors to record that wish in their medical records and should legally appoint somebody to speak for them, said researcher Dr. Thomas Finucane. Cardiopulmonary resuscitation, called CPR, involves forceful thrusts to the chest and blowing air into the mouth. That amounts to a ``meaningless assault'' when performed on nursing home residents who have only a tiny chance of benefit, researchers said. And it imposes costs, such as the nursing time taken from other areas of patient care, they said. Moreover, the community of residents may be disrupted by ``this generally futile, violent event, often inflicted on a frail and failing neighbor.'' Finucane practices geriatric medicine at the Francis Scott Key Medical Center in Baltimore and is on the faculty of the Johns Hopkins School of Medicine. He and his colleagues discuss the issue in the March issue of the Journal of the American Geriatrics Society. They checked hospital and ambulance records for nursing home residents older than 65 who underwent CPR and then were taken to a hospital. Results showed that 102 of 117 were pronounced dead in the emergency room and 13 others died later in the hospital. Only two survived hospitalization, one of whom died two weeks after release, and the other eight months after. ``We conclude that the benefits of cardiopulmonary resuscitation initiated in nursing homes are extremely limited,'' the researchers wrote. Even if a patient is resuscitated, he is likely to be in pain from broken ribs and may suffer brain injury from the period his brain lacked oxygen, Finucane said in a telephone interview. Currently, nursing homes generally require that CPR be attempted on all residents unless a specific order to the contrary is written, researchers said. In principle, Finucane said, a do-not-resuscitate order can be written after the doctor discusses CPR with his patient, if the resident can participate, and the family. ``What actually happens is, in many, many cases, no one ever talks to the family about it. And when you do talk to the family about it, many times the family is extremely conflicted,'' Finucane said. ``The family feels terrible because they're putting their relative in a nursing home,'' and now the doctor is essentially asking about letting the relative die. ``They feel this intensifies the abandonment in some way. So one common thing is that families make very unrealistic requests to resuscitate patients.'' As for a request for CPR by the nursing home resident himself, Finucane compared it to a patient asking for repeated futile cancer surgeries or for all the blood in a blood bank, even if the blood type does not match. A better approach might be not to do CPR unless the patient or family signs a form asking for it, he said. Yet, some family members may do so unrealistically, ``and then there will be unprotected older people who will undergo meaningless violence,'' he said. So he said he ``reluctantly'' favors simply not offering CPR, even though that removes the option of informed consent to the procedure, and the chance of reviving the few people who would benefit. ``It's a tradeoff,'' he said. ``It is a flawed proposal, but I believe it is the best on the menu right now.'' Ethicist Bart Collopy of The Third Age Gerontology Center at Fordham University in New York, said the new work raises ``a crucial question. Just from a medical viewpoint, the notion of routinely pursuing futile treatment is quite dubious.'' Collopy said he would prefer that CPR be included as part of a discussion of an overall care plan with the resident and family. Failing that, he suggested that decisions on CPR be made individually. Denying CPR to older people as a group might encourage similar blanket denials of other treatments, he said. The key question he said, is whether CPR would give nursing home residents a benefit ``by their definition, not our definition.''

DOC.HEAD: Foundation, Commissions, Allies Continue Congressman's Work
By CATHERINE WILSON
Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: The loudest round of applause came when an advocate complained that buses for homebound seniors arrived hours early or late and sometimes dropped people at doctor's offices and supermarkets but never returned for them. For people robbed of their mobility, Julie Shaw told the state's Pepper Commission on Aging, the bus was a lifeline but an unreliable one. Members of the state commission wanted to know who was responsible for the bus service and promised to follow up on the complaint. One of the commission's duties is to act as a watchdog for seniors. The fledgling commission, which hired its staff at the first of the year, is one of two bearing the name of the late U.S. Rep. Claude Pepper, Mr. Senior Citizen. Since his death last May 30, the two commissions, the Mildred and Claude Pepper Foundation, and his allies have guaranteed his legacy will spread beyond his work over a 43-year political career. A congressional report in March by the Bipartisan Commission on Comprehensive Health Care, commonly known as the Pepper Commission, called for a $66 billion-a-year plan for mandatory health insurance for all Americans and long-term medical care. The Pepper Foundation, created by the congressman three years before his death, has received a $10 million grant from Congress to fund philanthropic works. Beneficiaries include Florida State University, which will be the home of the elder statesman's official papers and a Pepper Institute on Aging at the Tallahassee campus. ``I'm not sure if anybody can replace Claude Pepper,'' said Cal Broughton, a legislative representative with the American Association for Retired Persons in Washington. ``They don't replace somebody like that. There will be a number of people that will take up a number of issues and a number of causes.'' People across the country knew that a complaint to Pepper got action, and the wily politician could be a gadfly or turn on his Southern charm to get what he wanted. His Washington office became a central processing station for complaints by senior citizens about federal services and by the disadvantaged about just about anything. In Congress, Pepper's legendary oratory played a pivotal role in the repeal of mandatory retirement and helped protect Social Security from cuts. The General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, is still producing reports requested by Pepper, said Kathy Gardner, a former aide to Pepper as a staff member on the House Select Committee on Aging. His legislation to create the National Institute on Deafness, the 13th unit in the National Institutes of Health, passed just before his death, and regulations setting minimum training standards for nurse's aides at nursing homes were published in March under a Pepper bill. Although Pepper's name was widely associated with the ill-fated catastrophic health care bill, he opposed its financing method. In his final illness, he had a wry smile over the stirrings of public dissent, which would lead to repeal, Gardner said. Other politicians have absorbed Pepper packages or platforms on comprehensive national health insurance, nursing home care, home health care and youth programs, she said. Across the nation, Pepper's name has been given to the National Institutes of Health administration building, a Center on Aging at the University of Michigan and an award from the Mount Sinai Hospital geriatrics department in New York. ``Almost daily I hear of some new program, building, award et cetera that has been named after him,'' said Frances Campbell, a longtime legislative aide who chairs the Pepper Foundation. In Florida, where Pepper began his political career as a 28-year-old state legislator, elderly issues are a priority in a state long viewed as the nation's retirement mecca. The state Pepper Commission set two priorities for the spring legislative session: boost state aid for the poor living in group homes who don't require nursing home care and reinstate senior education programs cut three years ago. ``Nationwide, roughly 12 percent of the population is over 65,'' said Edward Annis, a state commissioner and retired chief of surgery at Miami's Mercy Hospital. ``In Florida, we're approaching 19 percent. Among those are many affluent citizens who come down here and merely change their residence from other states. But among those are great numbers of people who have a rough time getting along.'' At a recent hearing in Lauderhill, commissioners were told of state legislation to require doctors to accept Medicare patients, the hidden rate of elderly suicides, the need for adult day-care for Alzheimer's patients, the danger of hypothermia, and cuts in services to the blind elderly. With the Pepper name in the commission title as a daily reminder of his political passions, commission Executive Director June Noel said, ``I think we have to remember what he stood for while we go about our business.'' ``He will have a lasting legacy,'' said John Rother, legislative director of AARP. ``As long as people refer to him and appeal to his memory in attempting to build support, that's an indication that there's a real legacy.''

DOC.HEAD: No New Slots Available for Elderly in Federal Nutrition Program
DOC.TEXT: Elderly participants in a federal nutrition program for the needy won't be shoved out, but others hoping to join may have to find food elsewhere, a federal official says. Cost overruns and food shortages prompted the U.S. Department of Agriculture in January to ask that states drop some elderly people from the program to make room for poor women, infants and children. But that drew some opposition, particularly from Sen. Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz., whose office argued that the agency was creating competition between groups of poor people. The federal bureaucracy ``caused a problem where these two groups were pitted against each other,'' said Tim Gearan, a DeConcini aide who specializes in nutrition appropriations. The 11-year-old program, called FOOD Plus, operates in 18 states and the District of Columbia. The 278,000 participants, more than a third of them elderly, are provided food from federal surplus commodities. USDA had said in a January directive that programs would have to be trimmed to September 1989 levels and that elderly participants might have to be replaced with needy infants, children and women who were either pregnant or had small children. ``We're not bumping any people off the program right now, but we're not accepting any new ones,'' said Phil Shanholtzer, a spokesman for the U.S. Department of Agriculture. Gearan and Shanholtzer agreed that the problem lies, at least in part, with the way USDA acquires food. Another problem, Shanholtzer said, was that most states had exceeded their authorized case loads, which ``hadn't been a real big deal'' as long as there was plenty of money. However, he added, shortages of dairy products, which must be included in the food packages, forced the USDA to buy non-fat dry milk and canned milk on the open market. ``Surpluses were not as readily available as in past years,'' Shanholtzer said, adding that milk purchases ``sucked up quite a bit of money.'' Gearan said the USDA shouldn't have anticipated a dairy surplus. Shanholtzer said the USDA has enough money to continue the program for the remainder of the year. But Gearan said FOOD Plus generally needs to be better funded and better operated. ``We really think we can do a better job,'' he added. ``These people are really destitute. They're selling their furniture. They can't skimp on their utility bills, but they will skimp on their food bills.''

DOC.HEAD: Study Says Single Elderly Prefer Living Alone
DOC.TEXT: Single elderly people prefer living alone to sharing homes with family members, a study shows. ``Most elderly persons have chosen to live in their own households, with a spouse while he or she is alive, and alone when they become widowed,'' two researchers reported in the May issue of the Journal of Gerontology: Social Sciences. The journal is published by the Washington-based Gerontological Society of America, an association of researchers in aging. Jacqueline Lowe Worobey of Rutgers University in New Jersy and Ronald Angel of the University of Texas at Austin studied 2,498 unmarried elderly people. The study group consisted primarily of non-Hispanic white female widows. More than half of those studied were at least 80 years old, and 40 percent had annual incomes less than $7,000. Worobey and Angel asked participants whether they preferred living alone, moving into another person's home or having someone move into theirs, or entering a nursing home. ``Although the formation of an extended household is an obvious mechanism by which people might pool their resources in order to increase their aggregate well-being, this option is not readily adopted,'' the researchers said. ``The strains associated with living (with family members) appear to outweigh any advantage that may result from pooled resources.'' The study did not provide exact figures as to the percentage of respondents in each group.

DOC.HEAD: Getting the Fat Out and Keeping the Flavor In
DOC.TEXT: ``I've got to find a better way of getting John to cut back on fat and cholesterol than shrinking the size of his hamburger. He was furious.'' My friend Letitia's lament is due to the fact that many of us are faced with changing a lifelong habit. Meat was not only eaten every day, but often in two or three meals a day: bacon at breakfast; lunch meat or leftovers from the roast for sandwiches; and the focal point of dinner. And although many of us are willing to cut back, not everyone wants to give up meat completely. The fat is where the flavor is, no doubt about that, whether it's the skin of chicken or turkey, or the layer of fat around a chop or steak. So if we're going to give up that fat, what have we got to replace it? To the rescue come cooking techniques that have become very popular. Year-round grilling (which can be done in a fireplace in winter), rotisseries, oven broiling, quick sauteeing. With these go marinades that impart wonderful exotic flavors to meat. This is not a new way of cooking. It's embracing many cultures. We have the great and favorite peasant dishes, couscous, cassoulet, curry feijoada, picadillo. All these are served with or without meat. So couscous can be made with lamb or chicken or vegetables. So can curry and cassoulet. Let's look at Chinese food. The balance is often one-third meat to two-thirds vegetables, yet the food is beautiful and delicious. We also don't have to give up our favorite foods. I'm happy to fry chicken for a picnic, but I find when I remove the skin and dip the chicken in a beaten egg and equal amounts of shredded parmesan cheese and breadcrumbs, and bake it at high temperatures, it's crunchy. Or rub skinned turkey legs with a little oil and oregano and crushed red peppers, bake at high heat and it's crispy. You can also skewer beef, lamb, chicken or fish shish kebab-style with vegetables and broil only four to eight minutes for a delicious entree. You marinate first with herbs and oil and sometimes wine or vermouth for a rich flavor. And old-fashioned meat loaf? Why not? Bake one up, cut into portions, ziplock and freeze extra servings. Or buy a pound of ground meat, season with mustard and egg and milk and fresh dill, and roll into 24 meatballs. Four or five make a serving that is bountiful and fun to eat. Breaking the habit doesn't have to be so hard after all.

Chicken Moroccan 4 servings 1 pound boneless, skinless chicken breasts, rinsed and patted dry, and cut lengthwise into thirds, and then into one-inch cubes (about 30 pieces) 3 medium-size garlic cloves, finely chopped 3 small shallots, finely chopped { teaspoon dried thyme { teaspoon coarse (kosher) salt \ teaspoon freshly ground white pepper \ cup finely chopped Italian, or flat-leaf, parsley 3 tablespoons corn oil Place chicken in a medium glass or stainless steel bowl. In a small bowl, stir together the remaining ingredients, reserving 2 tablespoons oil. Add to the chicken and mix thoroughly. Marinate, covered, four hours in refrigerator, stirring two or three times. Remove chicken and drain. (You may freeze chicken at this point.) In a large skillet over medium heat, heat the remaining 2 tablespoons oil. Add chicken and saute three or four minutes, stirring frequently, until lightly browned. Do not overcook. Remove and transfer to a plate. Serve immediately.

Skillet Skirt Steak 2 servings coarse (kosher) salt or regular salt 6 ounces skirt steak, washed and patted dry, trimmed of fat In a heavy skillet over high heat, spread coarse salt to cover bottom of skillet. Heat until salt flakes and forms a crust. Place the steak flat on the salt. Reduce heat to medium-high. Cook until rare, about two or three minutes a side. Transfer steak to cutting board. Scrape off the salt and cut diagonally into one-inch-thick slices. For skirt steak with lime juice: Place steak in a flat dish. Add \ cup freshly squeezed lime juice and 2 dashes tamari or good-quality soy sauce. Marinate about one hour. Then proceed as above.

DOC.HEAD: Once Settled, Rhubarb Can Take Care of Itself
DOC.TEXT: In slang, a rhubarb is a noisy argument, but in the garden rhubarb behaves like a model citizen. With scarcely any help from me, this attractive vegetable thrives quietly in a corner, its rosy stalks coming up year after year for my favorite pies. How did such an easygoing plant lend its name to quarrels and fights? Well, it seems theater people discovered that muttering ``rhubarb'' over and over creates the sound effect of anger in crowd scenes. Red Barber, a famed baseball broadcaster, widely used the term for hassles on the diamond. And a comic author of the 1940s, H. Allen Smith, wrote a novel ``Rhubarb,'' featuring a pugnacious cat with that name. Actually, the taste of rhubarb has an extra-tartness that inspired poets long ago to use the word to convey emotional bitterness. In pies and sauces, you need plenty of sweetener to bring out the vegetable's best qualities. Moreover, the plant has a dangerously split personality: Only the stalks are edible; the big green leaves are poisonous and must be trimmed off after harvest. Rhubarb and asparagus generally are the only perennials grown in the vegetable garden and usually occupy end spaces, leaving middle areas for annuals like tomatoes, corn and beans. As a perennial, rhubarb is ideal for an elderly gardener seeking lighter chores. You plant it once; after that, it just about takes care of itself. Cold-hardy, rhubarb needs winter dormancy and is not usually grown in areas where winters are too mild. You can raise rhubarb from seed, but most people save a year by putting in roots obtainable from seed houses and nurseries or from a neighbor happy to give away root divisions. I've found that one well-established plant _ cut back from three I planted 20 years ago _ easily takes care of pies for me and my wife nowadays, with some stalks left over to give away. Prepare the soil well before planting, mixing in rotted manure or compost. For three plants, you'll need a bed about 3 feet wide by 10 feet long. The plants eventually get large, so space them about 3 feet apart. You put in the roots, known as ``corms,'' 3 or 4 inches deep, leaving the tops about 2 inches below the surface. Don't touch first-year growth _ the plant needs time to establish itself _ but start harvesting the second year. To avoid rot, don't cut the stalks with a knife, but grasp them at the bottom and twist, breaking them off beneath ground level. I keep out weeds by mulching with leaves, which also enrich the soil as they decompose. If you don't have leaves, salt hay, obtainable from nurseries, will do as well. In all these years, I've never had to use chemical fertilizer for the rhubarb, nor have I had any problems with diseases or insects. While it needs sun, rhubarb will tolerate some shade. One recommended practice I've followed is to remove flower stalks, which tend to weaken production, as soon as they appear. The pale green pompon size flowers are easily recognizable. In my garden, 50 miles north of Manhattan, rhubarb comes up in March and its stalks are long enough for pulling by mid-May. My plant produces stalks a foot or more long, reddish at the lower end and greener at the top. Five or six of these are plenty for a pie. Some varieties may produce much longer and larger stalks. I've read of stalks weighing 2 pounds, 11{ ounces being exhibited at the Massachusetts Horticultural Society a century ago. Rhubarb was known from antiquity as a medicinal plant, the root being used as a laxative. Now, as a vegetable, it's ranked high in fiber and contains vitamins A and C and some B vitamins and minerals. Native to southeastern Russia, it was reputedly first brought to America from England by Benjamin Franklin in 1770 and was being offered in seed catalogs by the early 19th century. Aside from its popularity in pies, which gave it the name ``pie plant,'' rhubarb has found its way onto gourmet menus in a sauce, say for duck or fish. Botanically a vegetable, rhubarb was classified as a fruit by the U.S. Customs Service in 1947, import duty being lower on fruits than on vegetables. The plant's name just seems to inpspire imaginative use. World War II aviators, for example, called low-altitude strafing runs ``rhubarbs'' because they could see the big-leaf plants in the gardens.
