DOC.HEAD: Bush Criticized for Failure to Call Aging Conference
DOC.TEXT: The head of one of the nation's leading advocacy groups for older people has denounced the Bush administration's failure to call a White House Conference on Aging for 1991. Daniel Thursz, president of the National Council on the Aging, said Bush should ``request money, set a date, and start a planning process in the immediate future'' for a conference next year. The conferences have been held every 10 years since 1961 and draw thousands of delegates from around the nation. Bush has yet to announce whether he'll call a 1991 conference, which Congress authorized _ but didn't require _ in 1987 legislation. Conferences in 1961 and 1971 helped launch programs from Medicare to Meals-on-Wheels. Though marred by politics, the 1981 gathering help fend off Social Security cuts.
DOC.HEAD: Study Finds Satisfaction in Second Careers
DOC.TEXT: Older professionals who move on to second jobs that pay less money and offer fewer benefits may find more satisfaction than they did in previous positions, a study shows. A survey of 24 workers who joined a self-help group for unemployed professionals found that the 16 who found jobs within a year were more satisfied with supervisors, nature of work and likelihood for advancement than they were in previous careers, even though they were less satisfied with salaries. Results of the study were published in the April issue of the Journal of Counseling, published by the American Psychological Association. The author, University of Oregon psychologist Brent Mallinckrodt, examined how professionals over 40 rated new jobs for pay, benefits, satisfaction with co-workers and supervisors, the nature of the work and prospects for advancement. ``It was believed that increased age would predict decreased job satisfaction and instead the reverse happened,'' Mallinckrodt said.
DOC.HEAD: Women's Sexual Interest Doesn't Necessarily Decline with Age
DOC.TEXT: Older women can maintain continued interest in sex if they have a sexually active partner and are free of disease and mental illness, researchers report. ``Although sexual activity in general declines with age, the proportion of elderly women who retain sexual desire and are sexually active is remarkable,'' Drs. Arshang D. Mooradian and Vicki Greiff wrote in the May issue of Archives of Internal Medicine. Anxiety and depression are more common in the elderly than in younger people, and such mental disturbances can spur a loss of sexual desire, the University of Arizona researchers said. They said older women with estrogen deficiency also experience changes related to sexual function, such as reduced vaginal blood flow. But the deficiency can be easily treated, they added. For women who are healthy, sexual activity and interest in sex doesn't necessarily decline with age, Mooradian and Greiff said.
DOC.HEAD: AARP Recognizes Philadelphia Activist
DOC.TEXT: The American Association of Retired Persons named the late Philadelphia activist Max Weiner the winner of its first Consumer Action Award. Weiner spearheaded many consumer victories since establishing the Consumer Education and Protective Association in 1966. He developed a three-step grievance procedure (investigate, negotiate, demonstrate) that has become a model for advocacy groups across the country, AARP said. His successes included defeating hikes in utility and telephone rates, public transportation fares and city taxes, AARP said. Weiner was campaigning to be Philadelphia city controller when he died in October 1989. ``Max Weiner was the consummate consumer advocate,'' Horace B. Deets, AARP executive director, said. ``His innovative strategies and boundless energy set a standard for the nation and countless others have benefited from his work.'' The award was presented April 27 to Weiner's widow, Bessie, at a ceremony in Washington. It was established to recognize an older person who has generated significant change in a company or government agency to benefit consumers.
DOC.NOTE: End advance for May 17

DOC.TEXT: A record drop in vegetable costs contributed to a second straight decline in wholesale prices last month, the government said. The Labor Department said Friday its Producer Price Index for finished goods fell a seasonally adjusted 0.3 percent last month, the sharpest decline since August and the third consecutive moderate report. For the first four months of the year, inflation at the wholesale level was running at a 4.2 percent annual rate, down from 4.8 percent for all of 1989.

Stock prices rocketed to near record-heights as favorable inflation news and falling interest rates drew investors to Wall Street. The Dow Jones average of 30 blue-chip industrial stocks finished up 63.07 at 2,801.58 on Friday, short of the record high close of 2,810.15 reached on Jan. 2. It was the biggest one-day advance for the Dow average this year.

Another big drop in auto demand contributed to a 0.6 percent decline in retail sales in April, the biggest setback in six months. The Commerce Department said Friday sales fell to a seasonally adjusted $148.64 billion last month after a 0.2 percent decline in March. Private economists warned the lackluster sales likely would translate into slower economic growth in the months ahead as businesses face growing inventories of unsold products.

Leaders of top U.S. businesses said the economy will grow only moderately this year and next but will manage to stave off a recession. Inflation is on the way down, they said Friday, predicting the first-quarter annual inflation rate of 8.1 percent would be cut nearly in half. Economic growth will total about 2 percent in 1990 as it accelerates gradually from 1.9 percent in the first half of the year to 2.3 percent in the second, according to the Business Council, 100 chief executives of the nation's largest corporations. Growth will rise to 2.6 percent in 1991.

Amax Inc., the nation's third-largest coal producer, has offered $1.25 billion to acquire industry leader Peabody Holding Co., raising the possibility of a bidding war with a major Peabody investor. The bid on Friday was rejected immediately by Hanson Industries, which owns 45 percent of Peabody and is attempting to buy the rest. Hanson responded by raising its offer for the Peabody shares it doesn't own. The remaining 55 percent of St. Louis-based Peabody is owned by Newmont Mining Corp. of Denver. Hanson, in turn, owns 49 percent of Newmont.

Stroh Brewery Co. wants to buy Heileman Brewing Co. and form a new No. 3 beer maker, Stroh senior vice president and chief legal officer George Kuehn says. But Heileman President Murray Cutbush replied Friday he was skeptical about joining with a company ``that has an absence of strong senior management, an uncertain direction ... and an eroding distributor network.'' Stroh President Roger Fridholm told a business strategists' group Wednesday Stroh still wanted to buy Heileman, according to a story in The Detroit News that Kuehn confirmed Friday.

Great Northern Nekoosa Corp. Chairman William R. Laidig, who failed in his effort to thwart Georgia-Pacific Corp.'s takeover, has resigned. Great Northern said Friday it anticipates Laidig's successor will be Ronald P. Hogan, who is vice chairman of Great Northern and president and chief operating officer of Georgia-Pacific, which expects to complete its $65.75-a-share merger next month.

Donald Trump said his Trump Castle Casino Resort By The Bay is not for sale despite comments from the chairman of Hilton Hotels that he is looking into buying the gaming hall. Trump said Friday Trump Castel is ``not for sale at any price.'' He refused to say if Hilton Chairman Barron Hilton had approached him about selling the casino. Hilton said after the company's stockholders meeting Thursday he might be interested in buying the casino.

A former executive of United Technologies Corp. was sentenced to six months in prison and fined $5,000 for conspiring to obtain inside information about Pentagon competition for a lucrative Navy contract. Roger K. Engel, 49, who was vice president of the company's Norden Systems division in Norwalk, Conn., was sentenced Friday by U.S. District Judge Claude M. Hilton in Alexandria, Va.

Bond prices staged a huge rally in response to evidence of moderation in the economy and inflation. The dollar fell sharply against the Japanese yen but finished higher against most other major currencies. Grain, soybean and precious metals futures prices closed mostly lower; livestock prices were mostly higher; pork was mixed and energy prices fell.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Surge, Dollar Lower
DOC.TEXT: Share prices surged on the Tokyo stock market today, while the dollar fell against the Japanese yen for the fourth consecutive trading day. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average rose 530.51 points, or 1.68 percent, closing at 32,042.65 points. The Tokyo market's main barometer rose 531.88 points Friday. After jumping 459.13 points in the morning session, the Nikkei added only 71.38 more points in the afternoon. A total of 800 million shares traded hands during the day. Satoru Nagayoshi, a trader with New Japan Securities Co., said the market failed to react to the only major movement in the afternoon: a large-scale purchase by U.S. securities trader Salomon Brothers. An analyst with Nomura Securities attributed the recent rise in stock prices to the decline in interest rates abroad, the rise in domestic bond prices and the rapid fall of the dollar. On the exchange market, the dollar closed at 153.35 yen, down 0.80 yen from its finish Friday of 154.15 yen. After opening at 152.45, it fluctuated between 152.45 yen and 153.90 yen. The dollar now has fallen a total of 4.70 yen in the last four trading days. Dealers said the dollar's low opening followed its slump in New York Friday, due partly to U.S. government reports indicating inflationary pressures had been curbed. Inflation tends to push up interest rates, making the dollar more attractive to investors. A U.S. Labor Department report released Friday showed an unexpected 0.3 percent decline in April U.S. wholesale prices, coupled with a 0.6 percent decline in retail sales during the month. Buy orders for the dollar appeared in today's trading, but the upswing did not affect the dollar's overall downward trend, said Masato Nakamura, a currency dealer for Sumitomo Bank. Other dealers interpreted the dollar's recent decline as part of a long-term adjustment to its rise since the beginning of this year. The price of the benchmark 10-year Japanese government bonds rose to 87.69 points by 3 p.m. (2 a.m. EDT) today, up from its Friday close of 87.40 percent. Their yield dropped to 7.020 percent from 7.080 percent.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: Budget Talks Could be Surprise Success
An AP News Analysis
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS graf 13, Besides those... to CORRECT Gramm's state
DOC.TEXT: Even with President Bush's assurance that ``everything is on the table,'' it's hard to imagine a major deficit-reduction agreement emerging from the politically jumpy group he and the Democrats have assembled. But that's why this year's budget summit could be a surprise success. In past times with an atmosphere more conducive to agreement, budget compromises have proven tough. President Reagan convened an emergency summit in 1987 when the crisis on Wall Street scared Republicans and Democrats alike, making conditions excellent for a Big Deal to put the nation's fiscal policy on track toward a balanced budget. The negotiators were a serious and mostly agreeable group. Reagan sent his chief of staff, former Sen. Howard Baker, to lead his representatives. House Majority Leader Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., anchored the Democratic group from Congress. But almost a month of closed-door sessions yielded a plan that only kept things from getting worse. Today, it looks like the federal deficit will run about as high this year as it did then, and the atmosphere for agreement appears worse. Going into this year's talks, there is no clear crisis to spur action, though the administration warns that next year's deficit could run up to $100 billion over the $64 billion deficit limit. No one will use the adjective ``congenial'' for this year's negotiation group. The fact that it's an election year only makes matters worse. Baker, Foley and other key players in the 1987 talks are gone. Baker returned to the private sector, while Foley is now speaker of the House. He, like Bush, will watch the negotiations from a distance. The president's top man this time will be Chief of Staff John Sununu, a strong-willed conservative who already has flirted with sinking the whole effort. At the same time the president was reassuring Democrats he would go into the talks open-minded, Sununu was saying the opposite was really true _ that Bush would kill any tax increase the Democrats proposed. One top Democratic aide said Sununu was making Bush's call for a summit look like ``an invitation to a beheading.'' Besides those attending because of committee or executive branch positions, the other Republicans in the talks specialize in attacking Democrats on the tax issue. House Minority Whip Newt Gingrich, R-Ga., is outspoken on almost anything that could defeat Democrats, and Sen. Phil Gramm, R-Texas, is about as anti-tax as anyone in the Senate. On the Democratic side, Foley appointed Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., as chairman of the talks. Gephardt, who sought his party's presidential nomination in 1988, is one of Bush's most persistent critics and the leading opponent of the president's plan to cut capital gains tax rates. Bush has complained that Gephardt's attacks are too personal, and Bush's spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, compared Gephardt to television's Maxwell Smart. House Majority Whip William H. Gray III, D-Pa., and Sen. Wyche Fowler, D-Ga., also joining the Democratic squad, are seasoned political sharpshooters. Fowler once compared Gingrich to an organ grinder's monkey. But there may be a silver lining in this storm cloud. In 1987, negotiators on both sides seemed hampered by doubt. They were always breaking up to check back with their principals _ Reagan, Senate Majority Leader Robert Byrd or House Speaker Jim Wright. Inevitably, delicate discussions would screech to a halt when details of pending proposals were leaked. This time, checking back with the big guys will be a formality. If this bunch can agree on something, they'll know that the people outside can buy into it. Rep. Silvio Conte, R-Mass., a veteran of previous budget talks and a participant in this year's sessions, says that in 1987 it took 10 or 12 days before the group got over its mutual suspicions and down to business. He expects the same thing will happen this time. When a deal is struck the best thing to do is seal it quickly, he said. Perhaps armored cars could take the negotiators to the White House for a signing ceremony before people begin to pick away at it, he joked. Once the agreement is in place, he predicted, ``you'll hustle up a majority vote.''

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Surge in London
DOC.TEXT: Prices surged higher on London's Stock Exchange Monday, riding a bullish wave that started in New York on Friday. At midday, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-stock index was up 32.3 points or 1.5 percent, at 2,208.2, its highest point of the day. The index last closed above 2,200 on April 18, finishing that day at 2,205.9. Slightly disappointing economic indicators for April failed to dampen the market's spirit as a squeeze on available stock helping buoy share prices, dealers said. The British government reported a 1.0 percent rise in April retail sales from March, and a 2.4 percent gain from April 1989, surpassing market expectations of a 0.3 percent rise in April from March. The April provisional producer price index showed output prices rising 1.0 percent in April from March and input prices falling 0.3 percent in April from March against expectations of output up 0.6 percent and input down 0.1 percent. One dealer said the figures should have caused the market to ease but were ignored because the market was doing so well. The U.K. market's surge followed a strong rise on Wall Street, where the Dow Jones industrial average soared 63.07 points Friday to 2,801.58, and an overnight gain in Tokyo, where the Nikkei 225-stock index jumped 530.51 to 32,042.65. Among individual stocks, the food and clothing retailer Marks & Spencer rose 5 pence, or 8.4 cents, a share to 203 pence after reporting its yearend pretax profit was up 14 percent. Enterprise and Lasmo, the oil companies, rose after Kuwait officially announced it is to cut back on operating spot contracts, leaving more room for the British concerns. Enterprise rose 16 pence to 616 pence a share, while Lasmo rose 18 pence to 401 pence. Bass, the brewery, pub and leisure group rose 24 pence to 10 pounds a share on rumors it had sold its Crest Hotel chain to Trusthouse Forte, the hotels and catering group. The rumors were not confirmed by the company.

DOC.HEAD: Riding Earth Day Momentum, Excelsior Stages Successful Sequel
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to remove reference to Styrofoam; SUBS 16th graf to restore dropped hyphen in Coca-Cola.
DOC.TEXT: In these days of growing environmental concern and overflowing landfills, the comeback of a packing material called excelsior _ long, thin strands of wood nearly forgotten in the age of plastic _ is only natural. ``After the Earth Day celebration, it was phenomenal the interest,'' said Jim LeFevre, assistant branch manager for American Excelsior Co. of Arlington, Texas. ``Our customers are telling us their customers are asking for environmentally safe packaging.'' Despite the pervasive spread in recent decades of plastic foam peanuts and plastic bubble pack, companies like LeFevre's never stopped making excelsior. For the last four decades it was used mainly to cover budding foliage and prevent erosion. Now, it has received a facelift of sorts to make it more palatable to companies packaging everything from cosmetics to delicate dishes. In red, green, blue, orange, purple and every shade between, excelsior made one of the more colorful displays at last week's Eastern Packaging Exposition at New York's Javits Convention Center. It wasn't the only packing product on view that sought to play on the burgeoning sensitivity to environmental concerns. ``There's no question about it. I think most major corporations are going to have a real thrust into using more environmentally safe materials,'' said Philip Thorn, a purchasing manager of Johnson & Johnson Orthopedics in Braintree, Mass. ``Our selling point now is biodegradable and non-toxic. Even our glue is non-toxic,'' Kevin Arnold told customers as he described cardboard-like packaging materials made by Honeycomb Corp. of North Haven, Conn. New laws are forcing some companies to buy biodegradable packaging, said Robert Sadlik, supervisor of Miles Pharmaceutical. Besides, he says, ``Peanuts are getting to be a problem. You open a box and they blow all over the place. Somebody's got to come up with something to replace peanuts.'' Brian Stewartson, sales manager for Ranpak Corp. of Willoughby, Ohio, claims his company already has. The product, ``Padpack,'' consists of thick paper that has been crumbled. ``It's back to the basics. There's no pizzazz,'' Stewartson said. Padpack sales in the Northeast for the first three months of this year were 300 percent above the same period last year. ``There's definitely something going on,'' he said. One product on display was ``Lock 'n' Pop,'' a Key Tech Corp. item that salespeople said could be used instead of plastic wrap to seal boxes and attach them to one another. ``Lock 'n' Pop'' is a clear, non-toxic, and often invisible adhesive, the Ocean, N.J. company boasts in its literature. And it claims to have signed up Coca-Cola, Nabisco, Du Pont, Honeywell, Revlon, Cargill and Ralston Purina. Fred Biesecker, president and chairman of the board of Drug Plastics and Glass Co. Inc. of Boyertown, Pa., conceded that his own company's invention _ a plastic container that uses one-third recycled plastic _ is not the least expensive way to make a bottle. But, he says, ``a better life is not a cheaper life.'' He said he had not thought about recycling plastic before attending a waste seminar in New York two years ago. He smiled as he noted, ``Today I'm introducing a bottle that's got garbage in it.''

DOC.HEAD: Rig Count Jumps by 11
DOC.TEXT: The number of working U.S. oil and natural gas rigs rose for the second straight week, increasing by 11 to total 941, Baker Hughes Inc. reported. The rig count the previous week climbed a modest three after posting declines for several weeks. A year ago, the rig count was 771, Baker Hughes said Monday. Baker Hughes' rig count is the widely watched industry index of drilling activity. It reflects the number of rotary rigs actively exploring for oil and gas as of last Friday, not the number of producing wells. Houston-based Hughes Tool Co., an oil toolmaker company that merged with Baker International Corp. of Orange, Calif., has kept track of the rig count since 1940. In December 1981, at the height of the oil boom, the rig count reached a peak of 4,500. But oil prices plunged to less than $10 per 42-gallon barrel in the summer of 1986, prompting a collapse in the rig count that bottomed out at 663 _ the lowest since Hughes began compiling figures. Among major oil-producing states, Wyoming posted the largest gain with five, followed by New Mexico, four; and Texas, three. Michigan, Ohio, and Pennsylvania each increased by two, while Colorado added one. Louisiana had the largest decline with five followed by Oklahoma, four; Kansas, three; and California, one. North Dakota was unchanged from last week.

DOC.HEAD: Philips President Resigns In ``Crisis'' Over Low Profits
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf after the 7th graf with stock price today.
DOC.TEXT: N.V. Philips announced today the resignation of its president in a ``crisis of confidence'' after the multinational electronics company barely broke even in the first quarter. Cor van der Klugt, 65, will retire on July 1 and be succeeded by his deputy, Jan Timmer, former Philips president Wisse Dekker said at a news conference today. Dekker's announcement followed days of speculation over Van der Klugt's future, set off by Philips' May 3 announcement that it had earned a mere 6 million guilders, or $3.1 million, in manufacturing profits during the first three months of this year. Dekker said the results had caused a ``crisis of confidence'' in the financial world because Van der Klugt had claimed the company was performing far better. ``The problem is that expectations were raised ... and that there is such a huge difference between the expectations and the real results,'' Dekker said. ``That is about the worst thing that can happen to a company,'' he added. After the May 3 announcement, Philips stock plummeted 16.7 percent from 37.70 guilders, or $19.84, a share to 31.40 guilders, or $16.52, last Friday. But Philips stock rose 2 guilders, or $1.05, today as investors were encouraged by the announcement. Van der Klugt's replacement followed a highly unusual intervention by Dekker, Philips' president from 1982-86 and the current chairman of its board of supervisors. The supervisory board maintains an oversight function at Philips, although it is not involved in day-to-day management operations. Dekker said the disappointing figures were primarily the result of poor performance by the company's Integrated Circuits and Information Systems Division. ``It was a great leak from which money simply flowed,'' said Dekker, who refused to disclose specific figures. Gert Lorentz, the division's chief, is also resigning, Dekker said. Philips first-quarter results contrasted with a 222 million guilder, or $116 million, profit in the same period last year. The first-quarter figure for this year did not include a one-time gain of 330 million guilders, or $173 million, from a sell-off of Philips' defense activities, including the Hollandse Signaal radar company. The episode has even prompted public comment from 85-year-old Frits Philips, the last member of the Philips dynasty to have led the firm. He criticized Van der Klugt for not providing earlier warning of the poor earnings levels, according to Dutch press reports. Dekker claimed it was unclear why the poor results were not disclosed earlier. ``Van der Klugt has no proper explanation ... and it's a mystery to me too,'' Dekker said. Ata Kahrel, an analyst with the Amsterdam-based brokerage H. Wesselius and Co., said the flow of information to Philips' management appeared to have failed, but said the reason why remained unclear. Philips' computer division is ``probably just facing a malaise ... With just the slightest drop in demand they're stuck with these huge stocks,'' Kahrel said. Philips itself has blamed its poor performance on currency exchange problems and ballooning interest rates of recent months. The dramatic drop in Philips' stock price has spawned speculation the firm might become a target for a hostile takeover bid by one of its Japanese competitors. Based in this southern Dutch city, NV Philips Gloeilampen Fabrieken has grown from a light bulb factory to one of the world's largest producers of electric appliances and electronic equipment. Its U.S. subsidiary is North American Philips. Van der Klugt, described by the authoritative Dutch newspaper De Volkskrant as a remote, ivory-tower figure, took over from Dekker in April 1986. He had been vice president since 1982. Timmer, who heads Philips' Consumer Electronics Division, has brought the division into the black through cost-cutting measures involving widespread staff reductions, earning him the Dutch business page nickname of ``Hurricane Gilbert.''

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Make Largest Daily Gain Since July
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with closing prices
DOC.TEXT: Shares on London's stock exchange made their largest daily gain since July to finish Monday well above the psychologically important 2,200-level despite sluggish afternoon trading. The Financial-Times Stock Exchange 100-share index closed at 2,214,5, up 38.6 points, or 1.78 percent, from Friday. The intraday low of 2,202 was reached just after the market opened. The Financial Times 30-share index rose 24.7 points to close at 1,733.5. Volume was a relatively thin 375.1 million shares, compared with the moderate 510.1 million shares that changed hands Friday. The Financial Times 500 index finished up 17.56 at 1,193.93. Dealers said strength on Wall Street added fuel to an early rally that was sustained throughout the session and exaggerated by a shortage of stock. Meanwhile, the market largely ignored some gloomy economic news released around midday that showed gains in April in British retail sales and producer prices, pointing to continued high inflation. The government reported a 1 percent rise in April retail sales from March, surpassing market expectations of a 0.3 percent monthly rise, and a 2.4 percent annual increase in sales. The April provisional producer price index showed output prices rising 1.. Some houses have had ``For Sale'' signs for a year, meaning their sellers are eager for action and possibly willing to help with financing. Add at least one more reason: Opportunity exists in a time frame. Youth comes once in a lifetime, and real estate bargains appear only a few times more often. Few segments of the marketplace are more cyclical. There is little question that younger homebuyers have had difficulties in recent years. While the ownership rate fell generally in the 1980s, from more than 65 percent at the beginning to less than 64 percent near the end, the decline was a consequence solely of bad times in the younger age groups. In the age group 25 through 29 years, for example, the 1979 ownership rate was 44 percent, but just over 35 percent in mid-1989. In that time the rate for ages 30-34 fell from 62 percent to less than 54 percent. Meanwhile, in every five-year age grouping from 60 years or more the ownership rate rose. Since 1980, the rate for ages 60-64 has been more than 80 percent. Real estate people point out that in those statistics lies opportunity. They call attention to the likelihood that many older homeowners are not just eager to sell but may be in a position to help with financing. Why should a seller want to help with financing? First, of course, to sell the house, but then to obtain a double-digit rate of return backed by solid collateral. The financing picture is ever-changing, usually for the better. While it is true that many banks have been burned, and therefore are increasingly strict in appraising properties and potential buyers, most still want to lend. Finding the best lender isn't nearly as difficult as it once was, either. With the multiplication of mortgage products, mortgage specialists have become institutions in many communities, and are thoroughly knowledgeable about what individual banks offer. They can choose the right one, and for no fee. At the same time, many real estate agents have developed arrangements with lenders in their areas, enabling them to originate mortgages right from their sales offices. In most instances, the real estate agent will charge a fee. This practice has developed into open warfare between the Mortgage Bankers Association of America, which seeks to have the practice banned, and the National Association of Realtors, which views it as an effective sales tool. For the time being, would-be buyers can afford to let the two groups fight it out, either through legislation or the courts, and accept the best of what either has to offer. They should be aware, however, that a fee may be charged, and they should understand that they, themselves, bear responsibility for making certain that the loan conditions are indeed the best obtainable.

DOC.HEAD: Philips Stock Recovers After President Resigns In ``Crisis''
LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Shares of electronics giant NV Philips bounced back Monday after a dramatic shakeup that saw its president and the head of its computer business resign due to a ``crisis of confidence'' among shareholders. News that President Cor van der Klugt would resign on July 1, a year before his scheduled retirement, pushed NV Philips Gloeilampenfabrieken up the equivalent of $1.05 to close at $17.57 a share in Amsterdam. The company's stock had plummeted 16.7 percent since the May 3 disclosure that Philips, a flagship of Dutch industry, had barely broken even during the first quarter of the year. Philips, the world's second-largest electronics concern after Japan's Matsushita, is a leading maker of lighting equipment, consumer electronics, home appliances and semiconductors. Product brand names include Philips and Magnavox televisions, Polygram records, Norelco appliances and Philips light bulbs. The company also holds a 47 percent stake in the Whirlpool International BV appliance-making joint venture. Wisse Dekker, the former Philips president who heads the company's board of supervisors, told reporters that Van der Klugt had maintained until just before the profit figures were released that the company was doing much better. ``The problem is that expectations were raised ... and that there is such a huge difference between the expectations and the real results,'' said Dekker, who was Philips president from 1982-86. ``That is about the worst thing that can happen to a company,'' he said. Dekker told reporters that Van der Klugt apparently was unaware in advance of the poor first-quarter results, which did not include a one-time $173 million gain from sale of Philips' defense businesses. ``Van der Klugt has no proper explanation ... and it's a mystery to me, too,'' said Dekker, who flew home from a vacation in the United States to deal with the crisis. The board of supervisors maintains an oversight role at Philips although it is not involved in day-to-day management. Dekker said he held several days of intensive talks with Van der Klugt and Gert Lorentz, head of the computer division. Van der Klugt decided to quit after consulting with the board and Lorentz also tendered his resignation. Replacing Van der Klugt will be his deputy, Jan Timmer, whose 38-year track record with Philips includes bringing profitability to its Polygram records subsidiary and the Consumer Electronics Division he now heads. Timmer _ whose reputation for widespread staff reductions has earned him the Dutch business page nickname of ``Hurricane Gilbert'' _ already had been slated to replace Van der Klugt on July 1, 1991. Neither Van der Klugt nor Timmer attended Monday's news conference. Shareholders are expected to approve the personnel changes at an extraordinary meeting expected to be convened about July 1, Dekker said. Jan Stoop, an Amsterdam-based executive of the Barclays de Zoete Wedd investment bank, said Monday's rallying of Philips stock reflected ``pure sentiment that Timmer could be the man to turn 'round the company. ``That is sentiment for the short term, for in the longer term the mood has to be one of wait and see,'' Stoop said. Philips reported a profit of only $3.15 million in the first three months of this year, not including the gain from the defense unit sale. That compared with a profit of $116 million for the corresponding 1989 period. Philips has blamed its poor results on unfavorable currency conversion rates and the soaring interest rates of recent months, although analysts have indicated Van der Klugt's optimistic forecasts indicated problems with the company's control over its far-flung businesses. Dekker said the worst losses were suffered by Philips' Integrated Circuits and Information Systems Division, which faces fierce Japanese and South Korean competition. Dekker would not disclose specific losses at the computer division. Ata Kahrel, an analyst at the Amsterdam brokerage H. Wesselius and Co., said the division was ``probably just facing a malaise ... With just the lightest drop in demand, they're stuck with these huge stocks.''

DOC.HEAD: Court Squelches Lawsuit Over Idaho Silver Mine Disaster
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 3 grafs after penultimate graf, `Writing for ...,' to UPDATE with comments from attorneys. Picks up final graf, `The case ...'.
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today squelched a lawsuit charging the United Steelworkers union with negligence in a 1972 Idaho silver mine disaster that killed 91 miners. The justices, by a 6-3 vote, said the state court suit was pre-empted by federal labor law. The disaster occurred May 2, 1972, at the Sunshine Mine in Kellogg. The U.S. Bureau of Mines said an underground fire apparently started when timbers and debris ignited spontaneously. The miners died of asphyxiation or carbon monoxide poisoning. Families of dead miners sued the union on grounds it appointed a member to the mine's safety committee. The union member had accompanied the company safety engineer in monthly inspections. The union was accused of negligence for the alleged failure of its member to point out or correct such problems as corroded oxygen-breathing equipment and padlocked rescue equipment. The Idaho Supreme Court ruled in 1986 that the union could be sued in state court. But the nation's highest court ordered the Idaho court to restudy its ruling in light of a 1987 decision in which the justices gave unions nationwide more protection against being sued in state courts. That 1987 ruling said such lawsuits generally are pre-empted by federal labor law. The Idaho Supreme Court, after restudying the silver mine disaster case, said the negligence claims in it were different because a union member was on the mine inspection team. Writing for the high court today, Justice Byron R. White said the Idaho court was wrong. White said the negligence claim ``cannot be described as independent of the collective-bargaining agreement.'' ``The union's representatives were participating in the inspection process pursuant to the provisions of collective-bargaining agreement,'' he said. Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justices Anthony M. Kennedy and Antonin Scalia dissented. Writing for the three, Kennedy said none of the union's arguments ``for displacing Idaho law without any trial on the merits has validity.'' George Cohen, the union's Washington, D.C., counsel, who argued the case March 26, called the ruling ``a complete vindication of our position.'' ``The Supreme Court has held that, insofar as a union is enforcing a safety and health article of collective bargaining ... it is governed exclusively by federal labor law principles,'' Cohen said. Coeur d'Alene, Idaho, attorney Ken Howard said he would reserve comment until after reading the court's opinion. The case is United Steelworkers vs. Rawson, 89-322.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Selection Begins in Securities Fraud Case
DOC.TEXT: Jury selection in the securities fraud trial of Ivan Boesky associate John A. Mulheren Jr. began Monday with questions about key players in Wall Street's insider trading scandal. About 100 citizens on the panel of potential jurors were asked in a questionnaire whether they had ever heard of Michael Milken, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. and Boesky, the convicted stock speculator who was Mulheren's one-time friend and business associate. Mulheren, 40, is on trial in U.S. District Court on 41 counts of conspiracy, securities fraud, mail fraud and record-keeping violations involving his relationship with Boesky. The indictment claims that Mulheren and Boesky, then among the nation's most powerful speculators in stocks of takeover targets, schemed to inflate the price of Gulf & Western Inc. shares and conceal ownership of large blocks of stock. Boesky, released recently after serving two years of a three-year prison term, is expected to deliver his first public testimony at the trial. He paid $100 million in penalties and pleaded guilty to one felony to settle the biggest insider trading case ever. Boesky's cooperation with prosecutors aided in many other insider trading cases, including the guilty pleas of Drexel last year and Milken, who ran the firm's junk bond department, last month. Mulheren, whose firm Jamie Securities is now defunct, was known as a daring trader who wore jeans and boat shoes to the office. He carried over his casual style of dressing to the courtroom on Monday, wearing a yellow open-neck shirt and khaki pants. In February 1988, police arrested Mulheren leaving his Rumson, N.J., mansion with a loaded Israeli-made assault rifle and a pair of army fatigues stuffed in a gym bag in the back seat of his Mercedes. According to court documents, Mulheren intended to shoot Boesky and Boesky's chief trader, Michael Davidoff, because ``without them the head hunt would be over.'' Doctors for Mulheren later said the episode happened because Mulheren had stopped taking the prescribed drug lithium to treat manic depression. New Jersey authorities dropped weapons possession charges in exchange for three years of pretrial probation. Mulheren also surrendered his gun collection.

DOC.HEAD: TLC Beatrice Reports Smaller Loss
DOC.TEXT: European food concern TLC Beatrice International Inc. reported Monday that it narrowed its first-quarter loss over a year ago due to strength in its food distribution and grocery products. For the first three months of 1990, the company lost $2.19 million, or 23 cents a share, compared with a loss of $2.50 million, or 25 cents a share, a year ago. Sales rose 25 percent to $310 million from $248 milion. Although TLC Beatrice remained in the red, first-quarter operating income nearly doubled to $3.8 million from $1.9 million, the company said. Before preferred stock dividends the company earned $133,000 in the first quarter, it said. ``Our first-quarter results are encouraging because virtually all of our operating units are performing well,'' Reginald F. Lewis, company chairman and principal stockholder, said in a statement. ``While we expect excellent results for the remainder of the year, our second- and third-quarter figures will determin our full-year results because our ice cream and dessert products are being sold during the warm weather period.'' A group of investors led by Lewis bought Beatrice's international food operations for $985 million in December 1987. The entire company was taken private the previous year by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co., the leader in debt- financed takeovers known as leveraged buyouts. All of the high-yield ``junk'' bonds used to finance the TLC Beatrice acquisition have been retired, according to the company.

DOC.HEAD: President of Sallie Mae To Become Dean of Dartmouth Business School
DOC.TEXT: The president and chief executive officer of the Student Loan Marketing Association, Edward R. Fox, is resigning to become dean of the Amos Tuck School of Business at Dartmouth University. Fox will leave the company, known as Sallie Mae, around Labor Day to assume his new position at the nation's oldest graduate business school, Harry R. King, chairman of the corporation's board, said Monday. Fox was Sallie Mae's first employee 17 years ago when he was hired as its president and chief executive officer. King said the board of directors will meet this week to discuss a successor. Sallie Mae is a federally chartered, stockholder-owned corporation that buys insured student loans and resells them as bondlike investments to the public. It also provides other financial services to financial and education institutions. The corporation owns about 30 percent of all guaranteed student loans outstanding today.

DOC.HEAD: Soybean Futures Fall Sharply; Grains Close Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices fell sharply Monday on the Chicago Board of Trade, extending the previous session's steep losses amid concerns that rainy weather could force an expansion of soybean acreage. Oat futures also closed lower while wheat and corn futures ended mixed. Rainy weekend weather in the Midwest is believed to have slowed the pace of corn planting in the region, which is also the nation's premier soybean belt. With more rain expected this week, analysts said speculation is brewing that some farmers may be unable to plant as much corn as they had planned and will instead sow those acres with soybeans, which can be planted later than corn. Corn planting has been under way for more than two weeks while soybean planting has barely begun. Soybean futures plunged Friday after the Agriculture Department released a crop report containing a higher-than-expected 1990 soybean production estimate. Wheat futures also fell sharply Friday but staged a modest recovery Monday after the USDA announced the Soviet Union had bought nearly 300,000 metric tons of U.S. wheat at subsidized prices. At the close, wheat futures were 1 cent lower to 2} cents higher with the contract for delivery in May at $3.84\ a bushel; corn futures were { cent lower to 2\ cents higher with May at $2.89} a bushel; oats were 3{ cents to 4\ cents lower with May at $1.56{ a bushel; soybeans were 8 cents to 13 cents lower with May at $6.23{ a bushel.

The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, up 91.22 last week, rose 31.98 to 2,833.56 by 3 p.m. today on Wall Street. Gainers outnumbered losers by more than 2 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 1,078 up, 493 down and 452 unchanged. DOC.HEAD: Chief Financial Officer Retires
DOC.TEXT: The chief financial officer of Bank of New England Corp., one of the few senior executives who remained with the bank after it reported huge losses this winter, says he plans to take early retirement at age 54. David B. Payne will step down in July after 32 years with the bank. Named to the top financial post last year, Payne came from the bank's Connecticut subsidiary. He was named president at Connecticut Bank and Trust Co. in 1988. ``I'm going home,'' Payne said. ``I always considered this a short assignment and I let everybody know early on that I wanted to go back to Hartford.'' Late last year, the bank began to show huge losses primarily due to bad loans in the plunging New England real estate market. The $25 billion bank had more than $1 billion in losses last year. Federal regulators apparently sought the ouster of several top bank executives. But Payne distanced himself from the problems and escaped the purge. Lawrence K. Fish, the bank's new chairman, said Payne was helpful as the bank struggled to set itself aright. ``His steadiness was especially valuable during the most troubled times,'' Fish wrote in a letter to employees. Payne said he will stay on with the institution as outside director of Constitution Capital Management, the bank's subsidiary that oversees about $500 million in pensions and institutional funds. First, however, ``I'm going to put my feet up for a couple of months,'' Payne said Monday. ``The last year was 12 months but it seemed like it was many more than that.'' The bank had not named a successor to Payne, a spokesman said Monday.
Stock prices pushed ahead, touching new highs in a carryover of last week's strong advance. Shortly before the close, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was up 22.03 at 2,823.61.

DOC.HEAD: Greenspan Warns Against Banking Protectionism
DOC.TEXT: Closing the United States to competition from foreign banks would be ineffective and prompt retaliation against U.S. banks, Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan told a congressional panel Monday. U.S. banks need less regulation, not protection from overseas financial institutions, to compete in a rapidly changing international marketplace, Greenspan and other witnesses told a subcommittee of the House Banking, Finance and Urban Affairs Committee. ``It would clearly be counterproductive to close our markets to foreign competition merely because foreign markets are less open than we like,'' Greenspan testified. ``Such an action would invite retaliation and would not be very effective in any case.'' Greenspan said foreign companies simply would funnel their transactions through offshore banks that continue to do business in America. He also said removing the competition of foreign banks would reduce the pressure to update banking regulations, delaying needed changes and harming U.S. banks and consumers. The subcommittee was meeting in Chicago to assess the competitiveness of U.S. banks against their Far East counterparts. But witnesses also said the nation's banks soon could face stiff international competition from European banks. By Jan. 1, 1993, European countries plan to eliminate many internal trade barriers, forming a market the subcommittee's witnesses said would surpass the United States in size and wealth. Some witnesses criticized U.S. regulations that bar banks from certain lines of business. They said these regulations make it more expensive for banks to attract deposits. That, in turn, limits the ability of U.S. banks to compete against foreign banks that are faced with fewer restrictions, the witnesses said. ``We believe the system now hampers the ability of our financial institutions to effectively compete in the marketplace,'' said L. William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. ``It's hard to think of what more we can do to handicap our banks.'' But Greenspan said the nation's low saving rate also hampers the competitiveness of U.S. banks in foreign markets by lowering the amount of money available to banks to loan out. Committee members and speakers disagreed on what steps would strengthen U.S. banks' ability to compete overseas. Committee Chairman Frank Annunzio, D-Ill., hinted broadly for sanctions against countries with policies that lock out U.S. banks. ``In America, we say `Buy American,''' he said. ``In Japan, they say, `Buy Japanese or else.' To those who seek to keep our institutions out, I say, keep away.'' Annunzio said Japanese banking concerns now own 40 percent of the world's banking assets and foreign-owned banks hold 23 percent of U.S. bank assets. ``If this rate of Japanese expansion continues, you will not get dollars from an automatic teller machine, you will get yen,'' he said. But representatives of Asian-based banks said their countries' restrictions against U.S. banks were temporary and necessary to protect local banks, which were ``ill-prepared to cope with the competitive challenge of foreign banks.'' ``The long-term objective of the Korean government, in my opinion, is to provide a level playing field for both domestic and foreign banks as they face ... a more deregulated, competitive banking environment in Korea,'' said Chang Woo Lee, regional managing director for Korea Exchange Bank. Rep. Marcy Kaptur, D-Ohio, argued against further bank deregulation. She called the savings and loan industry crisis compelling evidence that the financial community could not handle it. ``We gave new powers to financial institutions, and now the American people have to pay up $500 billion,'' she said, referring to the federal bailout of the thrift industry.

DOC.HEAD: Court Rules Price-Cutting Schemes Do Not Necessarily Violate Laws
DOC.TEXT: Price-cutting schemes do not necessarily violate federal antitrust laws, even if they hurt a competitor's business, the Supreme Court ruled Monday. The justices voted 7-2 to end a lawsuit against Atlantic Richfield Co. brought by independent gas stations in California and Washington state. The court said that only when a company's price-cutting can be proved to be ``predatory'' and harmful does it violate the federal Sherman Act, a major antitrust law. Predatory pricing is defined as setting prices below the level necessary to sell a product at a profit or below an appropriate measure of the cost of producing the product. In other rulings Monday involving businesses, the justices: _Squelched a lawsuit charging the United Steelworkers of America with negligence in a 1972 Idaho silver mine disaster that killed 91 miners. The justices said the state court suit was pre-empted by federal labor law. Families of dead miners had sued the union in state court on grounds it appointed a member to the mine's safety committee. The union was accused of negligence for the alleged failure of its member to point out or correct such problems as corroded oxygen-breathing equipment and padlocked rescue equipment. _Refused without comment to allow 30 states to sue 26 manufacturers in the Supreme Court over removal of asbestos from public schools and other government buildings. The ruling action does not preclude the states from suing asbestos manufacturers in their respective state courts. In the antitrust case, USA Petroleum Co., an independent oil dealer, had accused Atlantic Richfield, or ARCO, of conspiring with ARCO gas station dealers to fix prices illegally to drive the independents out of business. ARCO contended that its plan _ which included lowering gasoline prices to attract more customers and discontinuing credit card sales to save money _ is legitimate. ARCO lawyers said the major company's share of the retail gas market in California and Washington was 10 to 12 percent in 1981 and increased to 14 to 16 percent in 1983 because of lower prices. A federal judge threw out the lawsuit but the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals reinstated it in 1988. The appeals court said that although there was no proof ARCO engaged in predatory pricing, it still may have injured USA Petroleum in violation of federal antitrust law. But Justice William J. Brennan, who wrote the court's opinion, said USA Petroleum had not suffered any antitrust injury. ``When a firm, or even a group of firms ... lowers prices but maintains them above predatory levels, the business lost by rivals cannot be viewed as an anticompetitive consequence,'' Brennan said.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Ends Mixed, Gold Lower
DOC.TEXT: The dollar ended mixed Monday against major foreign currencies in quiet, trendless dealings. Gold prices fell after rising overseas. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $368.40 a troy ounce, down 40 cents from late Friday. Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $368.10 an ounce, also 40 cents lower. Currency dealers said the market ignored a drop in interest rates in the U.S. bond market and continued strength in stock prices Monday. They said traders were marking time in anticipation of upcoming government data that could provide a clearer picture of the direction of the economy and interest rates. ``There were just no new fundamental factors today to drive the dollar in any serious direction,'' said James T. McGroarty, a senior vice president at Greenwich Capital Markets Inc. in Greenwich, Conn. The government is set to release its report on industrial production for April on Tuesday, April consumer prices and housing starts on Wednesday, and March trade figures on Thursday. McGroarty said market sentiment is that the data will point to a further weakening in the economy, which could result in lower interest rates, and, subsequently, depress the dollar. ``The dollar sentiment is still quite negative,'' he said. The feeling is that there's more of a chance that rates will decline.'' The dollar continued to lose ground against the Japanese yen following Friday's trouncing. Dealers say the yen is gaining support on renewed investor confidence in Japan's economy. In Tokyo, where the global trading day begins, the dollar fell to a closing 153.35 Japanese yen from 154.15 yen Friday. It traded at 152.75 yen in London, and 152.50 yen New York, down from 152.70 yen Friday. The dollar was unchanged to weaker against the British pound. Sterling cost $1.6817 in London, unchanged from Friday, and $1.6825 in New York, up from $1.6790. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's quotes, included: 1.64288 West German marks, up from 1.6380; 1.3915 Swiss francs, down from 1.3995; 5.5360 French francs, up from 5.5295; 1,208.00 Italian lire, up from 1,207.75; and 1.17715 Canadian dollars, up from 1.17575. Late dollar rates in Europe, vs. late Friday: 1.6442 West German marks, up from 1.6300; 1.3952 Swiss francs, down from 1.3955; 5.5430 French francs, up from 5.5096; 1.8472 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8330; 1,209.75 Italian lire, up from 1,200.40; and 1.1767 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1783. Gold rose in London to a late bid price of $369.75 an ounce from $369.05 bid late Friday. In Zurich, gold fell to $368.75 an ounce from $368.80 Friday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell 97 cents to close at a bid $369.10 an ounce. Silver prices gained ground. DOC.HEAD: Cocoa Futures Surge To 13-Month Highs On Ivory Coast Unrest
DOC.TEXT: Cocoa futures prices roared to their highest levels in more than year Monday in a rally ignited by reports of renewed unrest in the Ivory Coast, the world's largest cocoa producer. On other commodity markets, oil futures rose sharply; soybeans plunged while grains were mixed; livestock and meat futures were mixed; and precious metals were mixed. Cocoa futures settled $88 to $105 higher on New York's Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange with the contract for delivery in May at $1,389 per metric ton, the highest settlement of a near-month cocoa contract since April 3, 1989. The rally followed reports that solidiers had temporarily surrounded the presidential palace and some radio and television stations in the Ivory Coast capital of Abidjian, protesting wages and living conditions. Protests by various sectors of Ivory Coast society have occurred occasionally since early March after President Felix Houphouet-Boigny ordered austerity measures to combat economic distress caused by last year's collapse of cocoa prices. Houphouet-Boigny has since rescinded some of the measures and has said multiparty elections will be held later this year. Yet traders remain closely attuned to the Ivory Coast situation and tend to buy futures on signs of unrest, fearing cocoa shipping could be disrupted, analysts said. ``The market is convinced this is a boiling pot,'' said Arthur Stevenson of Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. He said traders fear a new government may not honor longstanding cocoa supply agreements forged during Houphouet-Boigny's 30-year reign. Analyst Stephen W. Platt of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. said buying interest also may have been piqued by bullish comments made over the weekend by Derek Chambers, a trader with Philipp Brothers Inc. who is believed to be holding a large cash position in cocoa. Energy futures prices rose on the New York Mercantile Exchange amid reports that Saudi Arabia had cut oil production and Western oil companies had agreed to reduce their purchase requests. Further buying was prompted by reports that loadings of cargo from Brent oil platforms in the North Sea would be reduced in June for maintenance. West Texas Intermediate crude oil futures settled 27 cents to 76 cents higher with June at $19.71 a barrel; heating oil was 1 cent to 1.57 cents higher with June at 52.43 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .80 cent to 1.23 cents higher with June at 62.97 cents a gallon. Soybean futures fell sharply on the Chicago Board of Trade, extending the previous session's steep losses amid concerns that rainy weather could force an expansion of soybean acreage. Grain futures ended mixed. Rainy weekend weather in the Midwest is believed to have slowed the pace of corn planting in the region, which also is the nation's soybean belt. The National Weather Service has predicted above-average rainfall in the Midwest through mid-June. Analysts said speculation is brewing that some farmers may be unable to plant as much corn as they had planned and will instead sow those acres with soybeans, which can be planted later than corn. Corn planting was 69 percent complete as of Sunday, according to an Agriculture Department report. Soybean planting was 12 percent done. Wheat futures staged a modest recovery Monday after the USDA announced the Soviet Union had bought nearly 300,000 metric tons of U.S. wheat at subsidized prices. The USDA also said the Soviets bought 150,000 metric tons of U.S. corn. Wheat futures settled 1 cent lower to 2} cents higher with May at $3.84\ a bushel; corn futures were { cent lower to 2\ cents higher with May at $2.89} a bushel; oats were 3{ cents to 4\ cents lower with May at $1.56{ a bushel; soybeans were 8 cents to 13 cents lower with May at $6.23{ a bushel. Pork bellies for May delivery plunged the permitted daily limit of 2 cents a pound on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange on signs of slack demand and lower wholesale pork prices. Hog futures also retreated while cattle futures were mixed. Live cattle settled .12 cent lower to .32 cent higher with June at 73.95 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .10 cent lower to .05 cent higher with May at 84.75 cents a pound; live hogs were unchanged to .18 cent lower with June at 63.50 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were unchanged to 2 cents lower with May at 62 cents a pound. On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold futures settled 60 cents lower across the board with June at $369.90 a troy ounce; silver was 1.9 cents to 2.3 cents higher with May at $5.066 a troy ounce.

It must be something which fulfills us to our heart. It must be somns deeper than oething more. More than an all-consuming drive to look out for number one,'' said Morita, who earlier was given an honorary doctor of law degree at graduation exercises for Penn's 4,900 undergraduates. Morita said the role today's graduates and future business people choose must be more than ``merely an unending, personal quest for the dollar, or yen, or D-mark.'' ``You should strive to create an atmosphere where management and employees can come together to develop and reach common goals. Mutual recognition and mutual respect must be instilled,'' he said. ``You must recognize the worth of the individual and respect his or her right to discover fulfillment for themselves. ``Work, therefore, becomes a rn and wheat _ 3,561,500 tons of wheat and 15,784,200 tons of corn. DOC.HEAD: Tax Benefits Help Reduce Southland Red Ink
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf to CORRECT pre-tax income to pre-tax losses. Picks up 5th graf pvs, `Southland was ...'.
DOC.TEXT: Southland Corp., the parent of the 7-Eleven convenience store chain, said Monday that tax benefits from past red ink helped reduce its first quarter loss by nearly 60 percent. The company _ which has turned to Japanese investors for help in avoiding junk-bond-induced bankruptcy _ said it lost $69.44 million, or 35 cents per share, in the quarter ended March 31, compared with $169.43 million, or 86 cents, in the same period last year. Revenue rose 2 percent to $1.94 billion from $1.90 billion. This year's quarter was helped by a $52 million tax benefit from past losses carried forward. Pre-tax losses from continuing operations increased to $161.98 million from $137.95 million. Southland was taken private in December 1987 by the founding Thompson family in a $4.9 billion leveraged buyout financed with high-yield ``junk'' bonds. The company has struggled under the debt load, and has sold off its gasoline refinery and other operations to help pay down the notes. The company said Monday it had paid $1.59 billion on senior bank term loan since the buyout, including $399.5 million this year, and still owes $900.4 million. In March, Southland announced a complicated restructuring involving the sale of $400 million of Southland stock to Ito-Yokado Ltd., which operates 7-Eleven stores in Japan. The sale would give Ito-Yokado 75 percent of the company's common stock, leaving 15 percent in Thompson hands. The deal is contingent on bondholders approving the restructuring of $1.8 billion in debt and preferred stock. Some analysts have expressed doubts the bondholders, who would forego about $1.4 billion, would go along with the plan. Southland operates the world's largest convenience store chain, with 6,900 company-owned stores and 5,900 run by licensees and affiliates.

DOC.HEAD: Inventories Down, Sales Up at U.S. Businesses
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, `The Commerce ...,' to CORRECT that February inventories declined 0.4 percent, sted increased.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Budget Talks, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Businesses held inventories steady while increasing sales in March, the government said Monday. Analysts said the report indicated little threat of production cutbacks or loss of jobs. The Commerce Department reported that shelf and backlot inventories were unchanged at a seasonally adjusted $794 billion. Backlogs had fallen 0.4 percent in February and risen 0.3 percent in January. Sales rose 0.6 percent to a seasonally adjusted $539.1 billion following gains of 1.4 percent in February and 0.4 percent in January. The February increase was first reported at 1.3 percent. ``What it (the report) means is that producers are looking very realistically at domestic demand and the possibility of a slowing overseas demand for U.S.-made goods and are bringing production in line with those expectations,'' said Gilbert Benz, an economist with the Swiss Bank Corp. in New York. ``Unlike a period of slow growth where businesses often get caught short with an excess buildup of stocks, in the current environment, we see they are anticipating a slowdown and adjusting production so they don't have to slash inventories and cut production radically,'' he added. March business activity produced a 1.47 ratio of inventories to sales, matching a January 1989 ratio that was the lowest since the current economic expansion began after the 1981-82 recession. The ratio means that it would take 1.47 months to exhaust inventories at the March pace. It peaked at 1.70 in October 1982. The decline in inventories was greatest in the manufacturing sector, dropping 0.3 percent for the second straight month. However, backlogs edged up 0.2 percent at the wholesale level after declining 0.3 percent in February. Retail inventories gained 0.3 percent after posting a 0.7 percent loss the previous month. Sales, on the other hand, dropped 0.2 percent at the retail level and the Commerce Department reported last week that retail sales fell another 0.6 percent in April, the biggest plunge in six months. But manufacturing sales rose 1.1 percent. Wholesale sales advanced 0.8 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Prudential Executive Named CEO of New England Investment Unit
DOC.TEXT: A top investment officer at Prudential Insurance Co. has been named president and chief executive officer of Loomis, Sayles & Co., a money-management subsidiary of the Boston-based New England insurance company. Robert Riley, who will join the company June 1, is executive vice president of the Prudential Investment Corp. and chairman of the Prudential Realty Group. He previously served as chief executive officer of Putnam Management Co. and of Marsh McLennan Asset Management Co., and as senior vice president of American Express Co. Loomis, Sayles manages assets of about $30 billion for institutional and individual clients. Its former chief executive, Robert Kemp, is now managing partner of Capital Growth Management, another affiliate of the New England.

DOC.HEAD: Playboy Dressing Up Its Stock
DOC.TEXT: Playboy Enterprises Inc. is hoping no nudes will be good news for its bottom line, at least as far as its stock certificates are concerned. Ever since Playboy went public in 1971, its stock certificates have been graced with the nude image of February 1971 Playmate Willy Rey. But Playboy said Monday it will replace the nude figure with a clothed one in conjunction with a recapitalization plan unveiled last week. The change is expected to save the Chicago-based company money. The unusual design gave the stock a certain measure of novelty appeal. Spokeswoman Terri Tomcisin said Playboy has about 14,000 single-share stockholders _ about six times as many as most other companies its size _ many of whom bought one share just to get the racy stock certificate. The problem, she said, is that it costs Playboy about $100,000 annually to service the accounts of those shareholders. Playboy hopes to reduce that expense through its recapitalization. The plan includes a reverse stock split _ one new share of Class A voting stock for two old shares, plus a dividend of three new shares of Class B non-voting stock for each new share of Class A stock. Stockholders with just one share of Playboy would get only a check _ $12.62{ at Monday's closing price _ and a facsimile of the old stock certificate. Ms. Tomcisin said the design of the new stock certificates will include someone's image. And although she said she didn't know who it will be, they will be clothed to discourage novelty purchases. Ms. Tomcisin laughed at a suggestion that Playboy founder Hugh Hefner may be pictured on the certificate. All she knows, she said, is that the new design ``will somehow reflect the fact that the company is a global company.''

DOC.HEAD: Report: Chrysler OKs Production of 2-Seat Sports Car
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. has approved limited production of the Dodge Viper, a two-seat sports car billed as a performance and price rival to the Chevrolet Corvette, AutoWeek magazine reported Monday. Two versions of the Viper will be built, probably as 1992 models and delivered in mid- to late 1991, AutoWeek said in a report in its May 21 issue. The rear-wheel-drive car will cost between $30,000 and $40,000. One version will be powered by a 318-cubic-inch V-8 engine, AutoWeek said. The other will offer a V-10 engine developed in part by Chrysler subsidiary Lamborghini and capable of reaching 100 mph in less than 10 seconds, the magazine said. Chrysler Chairman Lee Iacocca was expected to formally announce production of the Viper on Friday in Los Angeles, the magazine said. A concept version of the Viper was seen as long ago as January 1989 at the North American International Auto Show in Detroit. Chrysler Motors President Robert Lutz and Thomas Gale, vice president of product design, have supported production of the Viper while awaiting Iacocca's decision. Iacocca said in July 1989 that he was leaning toward approving the Viper. Such an exotic product might not be expected to emerge from a slumping auto market and Chrysler's $1-billion cost-cutting program. But the Viper was the first project to result from Chrysler's conceptual design and rendering system. The computer-driven system could cut by 25 percent the amount of time needed to bring a totally new car to market, Gale said last year.

DOC.HEAD: Pennsylvania Sues Seven Insurance Companies
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 6th graf pvs, `These companies ...' to UPDATE with Aetna reax; picks up 7th graf, `Since its ...'
DOC.TEXT: The state of Pennsylvania filed a lawsuit Monday against seven of the state's largest car insurers in an effort to force them to cut rates under the state's revamped auto insurance law. The complaint, filed in Commonwealth Court, also claims the companies have been acting in concert to undermine the new law, which calls for rate rollbacks of at least 10 percent beginning in July. Last week Gov. Robert P. Casey vowed to wage ``war'' against insurance companies that attempt to pull out of the Pennsylvania market to avoid rate cuts. The suit appeared to be an early shot aimed at those companies and others that failed to meet a May 1 deadline to file new rates with the state Insurance Department. Named in the suit were State Farm Mutual Automobile Insurance Co., State Farm Fire and Casualty Insurance Co., Allstate Insurance Co., Erie Insurance Exchange, Aetna Casualty and Surety Co., Harleysville Mutual Insurance Co. and Erie Insurance Co. The suit also names the state's assigned risk plan, an insurance pool run by companies for motorists with bad driving records. Together, the defendants write nearly half the car insurance in the state. ``These companies are not above the law,'' Casey said at a news conference, promising that the suit would be a first step toward ensuring the law takes effect and motorists realize savings. A spokesman for Aetna said the accusations were ``outrageous and simply untrue.'' ``This company never has and never will conspire in any of its business dealings,'' said spokesman John Hawkins. ``Today's action by the governor further deflects attention from the real issue, which is making auto insurance more affordable in Pennsylvania.'' Since its enactment in February, the law has been attacked by at least 29 separate lawsuits. The law requires companies to cut rates 10 percent for all drivers and 22 percent for motorists who give up their right to sue in most cases. The law also includes a one-year rate freeze, a cap on medical costs and provisions to fight fraud.

DOC.HEAD: Single-Use Packages Criticized by Wastemaker Awards
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS last 3 grafs to DELETE reference to trademarked item with substitute phrase ``plastic foam,'' UPDATE with B&O comment. Also moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Environmental activists took aim Monday at producers of single-use, throwaway packages for such products as juice and laundry detergent and cameras. Several private groups and Rep. Frank Pallone Jr., D-N.J., said they had designated ``Wastemaker Awards'' for Coca-Cola Corp. for packaging Minute Maid juice in nonrecyclable boxes wrapped in plastic, Eastman Kodak for its single-use Fling camera and Colgate-Palmolive for Fab One Shot laundry detergent. Pallone, Clean Water Action, Environmental Action Foundation and the U.S. Public Interest Group said the products were wasteful and cost more. They asked corporations to take the products off the market. Bob Murray, a spokesman for Colgate-Palmolive in New York City, said the company agreed the packaging for the Fab One Shot detergent was excessive and he said it was being redesigned. The new package will eliminate the plastic tray and plastic overwrap, incorporate recycled board and take up less shelf space, said Murray. Officials at Coca-Cola headquarters in Atlanta and Kodak in Rochester, N.Y. did not return phone calls Monday. The groups' ``awards'' also cited Worthington Industries Inc. of Columbus, Ohio, for the Celebrate Birthday Balloon Kit with a disposable helium tank; Oscar Mayer Foods Corp. of Madison, Wis., for Lunchables single-use portions of lunch meat, cheese and crackers, and SOS Juniors steel wool soap pads, sold by Miles Inc. of Chicago. Joe Stegmayer, vice president of Worthington, said the firm's helium tank is recyclable. ``It's made all of steel. If people do throw it away, there are systems in most communities that pull metal out. There's no way this should go into any landfill anywhere.'' Dionn Tron, a spokeswoman for Miles at its Elkhart, Ind., headquarters, said the half-size soap pad was designed ``for consumers who only use a soap pad once in a while,'' and don't want to throw out a full-size pad that rusts between uses. ``If they use a junior, they only throw away half as much,'' Ms. Tron said. Bang & Olufsen of America Inc. was criticized for its Moving Micro Cross Stylus. The record player stylus, which is less than an inch long, was wrapped in ``a blatant, almost comical example of excessive, wasteful packaging,'' the groups said. It consists of a 5{-inch plastic cylinder protected by two pieces of nonrecyclable plastic foam, inside a nearly foot-long cardboard box. ``The Madison Avenue ad agencies have taught us to that when we see these products, we should think `convenience,''' Pallone said. ``Our mission is to teach consumers that when they see these products, they should think `waste and destruction of the environment.''' ``We of course are not too happy to get such an award,'' said Bang & Olufsen president Leif Lundin from Mount Prospect, Ill. ``We will seriously look into how we can change the package.'' A telphone call to Oscar Mayer was not returned.

DOC.HEAD: New Soviet Purchase Announced
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Agriculture Department announced Monday that the Soviet Union is purchasing an additional 150,000 metric tons of corn and 100,000 more metric tons of soft red winter wheat. The department also announced that 30,000 tons of U.S. soybean oil are being sold to Pakistan. Sales to the Soviet Union this marketing year now total 19,345,700 tons of corn and wheat _ 3,561,500 tons of wheat and 15,784,200 tons of corn. The marketing year began Oct. 1, 1989. Under government agreement, the Soviet Union can buy up to 22 million tons of the two commodities until the year ends Sept. 30. A metric ton of wheat is about 36.7 bushels and a metric ton of corn is about 39.4 bushels
