DOC.TEXT: Stock prices climbed to a record high Monday, building on their rally of the last two weeks as interest rates continued to ease. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 19.95 to 2,821.53, extending its gain since April 27 to 176.48 points. In so doing the average surpassed its previous closing peak of 2,810.15, reached last Jan. 2. Most other, broader market measures remained below their former highs, however. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by about 2 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 1,062 up, 555 down and 440 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 225.41 million shares, against 234.04 million in the previous session. The rally has been attributed to a sudden favorable swing in economic statistics of late, which has reduced worries about inflation and the interest-rate outlook. ``You can almost hear the opinion change,'' said John Connolly, head of the investment policy committee at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. Open-market interest rates kept falling Monday after dropping sharply on Friday. Yields on long-term government bonds, which topped 9 percent a couple of weeks ago, stood in the 8.58 percent-8.62 percent range. Brokers say the drop in rates touched off a rush to buy stocks among money managers at investing institutions who had been sitting on large cash reserves. ``Nobody's in the market. Everybody's underinvested,'' said Michael Metz, managing director and investment strategist at Oppenheimer & Co. Even so, prices pulled back in afternoon trading from their best levels of the day, when the Dow Jones industrials sported a gain of about 50 points. Brokers said prices reached levels where a good many traders seized the chance to cash in their recent gains. Among actively traded blue chips, American Express gained { to 29\; Philip Morris { to 44}; DuPont 1} to 40]; General Electric ] to 68{, and International Business Machines \ to 114\. Two exceptions to the general uptrend were Federal Home Loan Mortgage, down 1 at 69[, and Federal National Mortgage, down ~ at 37~ as the most active NYSE issue. The stocks, up strongly in early trading, reversed course after the Treasury recommended that they and other government-sponsored enterprises be required to get top credit ratings from at least two rating agencies independent of their implicit backing from the government. Atlantic Richfield rose 2~ to 118}. The Supreme Court ruled in the company's favor in a dispute with independent gasoline stations in California and Washington. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 270.80 million shares. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market increased $23.42 billion, or 0.70 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks gained 1.41 to 193.65. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 3.17 to 412.62, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was up 2.75 at 354.75. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market added 3.51 to 441.61. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 354.34, up 1.84.

DOC.HEAD: SEC Files Civil Suit Against President of Pager Company
DOC.TEXT: The Securities and Exchange Commission filed a civil lawsuit Monday accusing the president of a radio paging services company of manipulating the price of his company's stock. The SEC early last month suspended trading in the stock of the company, Southland Communications Inc. of Santa Ana, Calif. Southland president Ahmad Bayaa was accused of engaging in the stock manipulation scheme with Shaw Terhrani, a broker with BC Financial Corp. of Atlanta. The SEC complaint said that beginning in January 1989, Bayaa and Terhrani began accumulating Southland securities in various broker accounts opened in the names of friends and family members. As of April 11, they controlled more than 1 million shares, in addition to the 898,800 owned by Bayaa and his wife, the SEC said in the lawsuit filed in Manhattan's federal court. When Bayaa and Terhrani became worried that Southland's financial condition would cause other investors to sell their stock, they allegedly attempted to keep Southland stock off the open market, the lawsuit said. The SEC said the men did this by arranging matched trades and by negotiating an agreement with at least one brokerage firm not to loan out Southland stock held in customer margin accounts. These practices caused the price of Southland stock to nearly double, from $8.75 to $16.75, between March 13 and April 3, according to the lawsuit. The SEC is seeking a court order compelling Bayaa and Tehrani to give up their alleged illegal profits, which were not specified, and freezing their assets.

DOC.HEAD: Preliminary Count Shows Armstrong Wins 3 Seats, Company Says
DOC.TEXT: Armstrong World Industries Inc. said a preliminary count shows its candidates won three of four board seats contested by the Belzberg family of Canada in a proxy fight. Armstrong also said Monday that shareholders had rejected five amendments to the company's bylaws proposed by the Belzbergs. The Belzberg's own 10.7 percent of Armstrong through their investment vehicle, First City Diversified Inc. Their efforts to exercise greater control over the company prompted Pennsylvania lawmakers to pass the nation's toughest anti-takeover law earlier this year. Armstrong said an independent group of judges, Corporation Trust Co., had found Armstrong nominees received about two-thirds of the votes cast while the Belzberg slate received about one-third. A spokesman for First City said Armstrong has yet to give the Belzbergs any meaningful breakdown of the vote. Shareholders voted at their annual meeting April 30 to elect four directors to the company's 13-member board. An Armstrong spokesman said the company has 47,150,000 shares outstanding, and 83 percent of them were voted in the election. Official results should be available within the next few days, Armstrong said. ``We're delighted that our shareholders have backed us so solidly,'' said William W. Adams, Armstrong chairman and president. ``The fact that such a large portion of shares was voted in support of our board's nominees and not voted in favor of the Belzbergs' proposals is highly gratifying,'' he said. The Belzbergs contend that the company improperly voted 5 million shares of stock in its employees stock ownership plan on its behalf in the proxy fight. Edward E. Scharff, spokesman for First City, said those shares technically aren't owned by anybody because they have not yet been distributed to the employees. ``They shouldn't have been voted for anybody,'' he said. Scharff also disputed the company's claim that the Belzbergs' proposed amendments had been defeated. He said that if the shares in the employee stock ownership plan were excluded, the Belzberg's position would have carried. ``It's possible, if not likely, that the five shareholders' rights proposals would have carried overwhelmingly,'' Scharff said. The proposed changes are being argued in federal court in Reading, Pa. One proposal would allow a shareholder or group owning 20 percent or more of the stock to call special shareholder meetings. The company's position is that shareholders have the right to ask the board, at its discretion, to call meetings. Adams said he could not yet confirm First City's claim to have elected one of its candidates, Harvard business professor Michael E. Jansen, to the board. ``But if so, we would hope that as he learns more about our company, he will make a substantial contribution to Armstrong and its continuing success,'' Adams said. Armstrong management has declined to meet with the Belzbergs. The family has publicly criticized the company for supporting Pennsylvania's new anti-takeover law and accused management of working against shareholder interests. Conversely, Armstrong has characterized the Belzbergs as inept managers who have driven companies virtually into the ground, compromising shareholder earnings.

DOC.HEAD: Varian to Cut 600 Jobs
DOC.TEXT: Varian Associates Inc., an electronics company, said it will cut 600 jobs, consolidate facilities and re-evaluate assets by the end of September. The company will take a one-time charge of $74 million during the fiscal third quarter ending June 29, resulting in a loss for the period. In the same period last year, Varian earned $9.2 million on sales of $334 million. Primarily support staff will lose their jobs, a spokesman said Monday. Varian plans to sell its divisions in Texas and England that make radio and television transmitters. It also will abandon its production of gallium arsenide computer chips, which are used primarily by the military but have not generated much of a commercial market. Varian also will sell its night-vision goggle division. ``A number of the activities we plan to exit should present interesting opportunities for others,'' said J. Tracy O'Rourke, who joined Varian as chairman and chief executive officer in March, promising to ``reposition'' the company. ``But in our particular situation, they proved to be a diversion that was no longer acceptable or affordable,'' he said. The divisions represent sales of $200 million and employ 1,600 people.

DOC.HEAD: Workers Go on Strike at Hyundai Motor Plant
DOC.TEXT: About 27,000 union workers went on strike Tuesday over pay and working conditions at Hyundai Motor Co., halting production at South Korea's largest auto plant. Union and company officials said more than 22,000 day-shift workers showed up at the plant in Ulsan, 200 miles southeast of Seoul, for a solidarity rally Tuesday morning. They refused to work following the union's decision the previous night to launch an indefinite general strike. The walkout came only a week after the plant, which produces 2,650 vehicles a day, reopened following a weeklong strike. That walkout was in sympathy with workers at the nearby Hyundai Heavy Industries Co. shipyard, where protests were crushed by a police raid April 28. Officials of Hyundai Motor Co. threatened to seek punitive legal action against union leaders charging that they launched the latest strike without going through required legal procedures. Howwever, the union leadership denied the charge and said the strike was called to press union demands after failing to reach agreement with management on a contract despite 22 rounds of negotiations since Feb. 13. Among other things, workers are demanding an 18.95 percent raise in their average monhtly pay of the equivalent of about $621, and a reduction in their work week to 42 hours from 44. The company says it can give only a 5.95 percent wage hike. Hyundai Motor Co. sold 589,000 vehicles, including cars and trucks, in 1989. It exported 200,000 vehicles, mostly subcompact cars. Hyudnai Motor's public relations section said a total of 29,000 workers are employed at the Ulsan plant, including 27,000 union members.
